headline: 13% Stake in Aloha
abstract: A group of investors said that it had bought about 13 percent of Aloha Inc. and ''may consider seeking control'' of the Honolulu-based regional airline. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investment group said that it might also seek to influence Aloha's management. The three investors are Michael L. Neary, president of Dallas-based Dimension Development Company; Norman Siegal, a Fort Worth-based investor, and James R. Cruce, president of Peoples Heritage Savings and Loan Association, based in Salina, Kan.

headline: DEMOCRATIZING LUNCHES, I.R.S. STYLE
abstract: FOR now, few workers are being affected by a new I.R.S. rule that taxes cheap company meals as a fringe benefit. Companies are finding loopholes in the law, and ways to exploit them.   The rule, issued last December, applies to employees of companies that operate dining rooms at a loss in order to offer free or cheap meals to their staff. The I.R.S. says that employees can be taxed on the difference between what, if anything, they pay for the meals and what they would have to pay in order for the dining room to break even. The only exceptions apply to dining rooms that are open to all employees, not just executives.

headline: Sri Lanka Landslides Kill 21
abstract: Landslides caused by heavy rains have killed at least 21 people in Sri Lanka's tea-growing central highlands, officials said today. The slides followed three days of torrential rain. The worst landslide occurred in a small village in the Nuwara Eliya district where 14 bodies were dug out by rescuers, officials said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Allegheny Beverage Corp., Washington, has named Edward A. Weisman president, succeeding Morton M. Lapides, who remains chairman and chief executive officer. David Barr was appointed executive vice president and William Avella was named president of the company's food and vending subsidiary, Service America Corp.    * Anchor Hocking Corp., Lancaster, Ohio, said Carl J. Dargene had resigned as senior vice president of its hardware and packaging products group, effective Feb. 25.

headline: Advertising;
abstract: DHL Worldwide Express, which pretty much had the international express business to itself before Federal joined the act, is now introducing a new product to help keep its market lead.   It is being called Express Document - 15 pages with a 5-ounce limit for $10 less than the regular minimum for a shipment, which currently is $36 to London and $39 to Tokyo.

headline: UNION SQUARE AREA GETTING A NEW LOOK
abstract: The Union Square area, when designed in 1831, served as a gathering place for New York's aristocracy. The Roosevelts lived in the neighborhood, and much of society's cream flocked to the Academy of Music, which stood nearby as the center of the city's theatrical district.   The square was also the midpoint of the Ladies' Mile, a stretch of fashionable stores and memorable buildings. In later years, it became a focal point of civil unrest when anarchists, Socialists and Communists used it for mass demonstrations. Still later, in the late 1970's, the square became an open-air drug market.

headline: WHITTAKER MAPS NEW COURSE
abstract: ''Nothing is as easy as it looks,'' reads a plaque in the office of Joseph F. Alibrandi, the chairman and chief executive of the Whittaker Corporation. ''And if it can go wrong, it will. And at the worst possible time.''   These are lessons Mr. Alibrandi understands well. For about 18 months, he has been trying to put Whittaker on a new course after the loss of its lucrative hospital management contract with Saudi Arabia. Its major thrust now is the creation of a $1 billion chain of health maintenance organizations by 1990. All it has to show so far, however, is a handful of such operations, a set of blueprints for more, the prospect of up to five years of losses, and a lot of skeptics.   Its goal is highly ambitious, at best, competitors and Wall Street analysts say. Whittaker has plenty of company as it jumps into the race to build the first nationwide chain of H.M.O.'s, and, as a newcomer, it will be struggling for market share against such giants as the Cigna Corporation, U.S. Health Care Systems and Maxicare Health Plans Inc.

headline: POPE PAYS TRIBUTE TO INDIA'S APOSTLE OF NONVIOLENCE
abstract: Pope John Paul II, opening a 10-day visit to India, proclaimed his respect today for all the country's religions and offered a stirring tribute to the memory of Mohandas K. Gandhi.   In a subdued afternoon ceremony, the Pope placed a wreath at the memorial to the independence leader and apostle of nonviolence and spoke of all humanity's debt to ''this man so marked by his noble devotion to God and his respect for every living being.''   ''It is entirely fitting that this pilgrimage should begin here,'' the Pope said of the Gandhi memorial on the bank of the Jumna River. ''Today we hear him still pleading with the world: 'Conquer hate by love, untruth by truth, violence by suffering.' ''   The crowds were sparse on a mild and sunny day as the Pope sped through the broad, green avenues of the capital for meetings with Indian leaders and the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''All I get from this is that the Japanese have learned to play the U.S. trading relationship like a violin.'' Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, on Japan's extension of auto quotas

headline: G.E. Credit Offers $500 Million Notes
abstract: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering two issues of extendible notes totaling $500 million through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: IRAQI SAYS ENEMY USES MUSTARD GAS
abstract: A top-ranking Iraqi general charged today that Iranian troops dug into the city of Fao were using chemical weapons against counterattacking Iraqi troops.   The officer, Maj. Gen. Maher Abdul Rashid, commander of the Third Army Corps, said the Iranians used ''mustard gas and a similar kind of gas'' on Friday night, firing the chemical weapons at the Iraqis in mortar rounds.   Iran has previously said that it had the capacity to manufacture such weapons and that it would use them if necessary. Iraq used a form of mustard gas, forbidden since World War I by the Geneva Convention, to stop an Iranian offensive through the marshes of southern Iraq.

headline: Women's Rights
abstract: To the Editor:   Without rejecting Marilyn Loden's call for a change in the ''paramilitary model'' of American corporate leadership style (''A Machismo that Drives Women Out,'' Forum, Feb. 9), it is important to understand, as she does not, where the problem lies.   She writes that female leadership style ''resembles the highly touted methods of the Japanese,'' than whom it would be difficult to find a more patriarchal, traditional male style in any advanced society today! Apparently, it is not male leadership that is at fault, but rather the American leadership style.

headline: 3-PART BOND ISSUE BY DESERET CO-OP
abstract: The Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative of Utah is offering $377.9 million of bonds in three parts through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The 8 percent bonds due in 1991, 8 3/8 percent bonds due in 1996 and 9 3/8 percent bonds due in 2011 were all offered at par. The bonds are guaranteed by the National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corporation, of which Deseret is a member, and are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ethyl Corp., Richmond, has named Ray Wilkins Jr. president of its Chemical Group.    * Goldome, the mutual savings bank with headquarters in Buffalo, has named Edward K. Duch Jr. executive vice president.

headline: PEKING FOCUSES ON EXECUTION OF 3 AIDES' SONS
abstract: The Chinese Government, responding to accusations that it has tolerated nepotism, has given major publicity to a case in which the sons of three prominent Shanghai officials were executed for rape.   Television reports showed scenes at a Shanghai basketball stadium last Wednesday at which a crowd of 3,000 people watched the death sentences confirmed. The three young men, their arms bound and their heads forced down by policemen, were shown being led from the stadium for the drive to the execution grounds in the city's outskirts. The three were shot there.

headline: BANKERS TRUST
abstract: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is offering $150 million (Australian currency) of five-year zero coupon notes that pay no interest, through undewriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes, rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P., are offered at a price of $551.50 per $1,000 face amount, to yield 12.26 percent if held to maturity.

headline: UGANDA REBELS TIGHTENING THEIR GRIP, SAID TO SEIZE NO.2 CITY
abstract: Ugandan rebel forces were reported today to have further consolidated their control of the country, seizing Uganda's second largest city.   Western diplomats here said the rebels, who on Sunday overthrew the military Government of Maj. Gen. Tito Okello, overran the city, Jinja, at midday after a major battle.   The city, where many of Mr. Okello's bedraggled troops fled after being forced from Kampala, Uganda's capital, is the site of the landlocked country's major hydroelectric power station at Owen Falls and the point where the major road and rail links to the Kenyan coast cross the Nile. City Called Key to Control    Diplomats had said earlier that the rebel movement, known as the National Resistance Army, needed to take control of Jinja, 50 miles east of Kampala, to restore essential services that were disrupted during the fighting in Kampala and by fleeing Government troops.  [ Some troops fled to the Murchison Falls game park, where they were reported to be slaughtering rare wild animals for food just as Idi Amin's men did seven years ago, according to reports reaching the capital quoted by Reuters.  [ The Murchison Falls park, named after the spectacular waterfall where the Nile is forced through a 22-foot-wide rock gap and falls more than 100 feet, was heavily populated with elephants, lions, buffalo, antelope and other species in the 1960's.

headline: WALDHEIM CHARGES 'CONSPIRACY' AGAINST HIM
abstract: Kurt Waldheim says in an interview published today by a Belgrade daily that the publication of documents asserting that he joined in Nazi war crimes in Yugoslavia was part of an ''almost incomprehensible conspiracy.''   The former United Nations Secretary General, who is a conservative-backed candidate for the Austrian presidency, told the Belgrade daily Vecernje Novosti that his political opponents were behind what he called a ''slander campaign.''   In a recent autobiography, Mr. Waldheim discussed only his early military service with the German forces on the Soviet front in 1941, passing over his subsequent World War II activities in the Balkans with a German Army group that conducted brutal campaigns against Yugoslav partisans and their civilian supporters.   Since information about the Balkan phase of his military service first became public earlier this month, Mr. Waldheim has said that his duties were those of a German-Italian interpreter on the staff of the commander of Army Group E, Gen. Alexander Lohr. The general was tried in Belgrade as a war criminal in 1947 and was executed.

headline: Dow Hits 1,626.38, Another Record
abstract: Interest rates and oil prices declined again yesterday, pushing share prices on Wall Street sharply higher and sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its third consecutive record close.   The Dow, which last week broke through the 1,600 level for the first time, gained another 12.96 points yesterday to finish at 1,626.38 despite a slow start.   Taking a leadership role during yesterday's session were airline, auto and technology issues. The airlines and car makers, of course, would benefit from reduced energy costs, while the high-technology industry would be favorably affected, though indirectly, by the improvement in the economy that might result.

headline: A.M.C. Recovery SEEN BY NEW HEAD
abstract: Joseph E. Cappy, who was elected president and chief executive officer of the American Motors Corporation on Friday, found it hard in an interview to contain his enthusiasm on the future of the small auto maker, despite its past heavy losses.   Mr. Cappy , who joined A.M.C. in 1982 as vice president of the marketing group after a 26-year career at the Ford Motor Company, outlined several reasons why he believes that the ailing company will soon recover.   Mr. Cappy said that the company's losses had narrowed as a result of a severe cost-cutting drive in the second quarter, when the fourth-ranking domestic auto maker cut back its operating costs by 25 percent, and an improvement in the contract with the United Automobile Workers union, which brought A.M.C.'s labor costs more in line with those of the General Motors Corporation, Ford and the Chrysler Corporation.

headline: REAGAN BACKS ENVOY DESPITE TRIP TO LIBYA
abstract: The White House, responding to a report that a senior American envoy had had unauthorized contacts with the Libyan Government, said today that President Reagan still had confidence in the official, William A. Wilson, the Ambassador to the Vatican.   But the White House said Mr. Reagan had not authorized any meetings between the diplomat and Libyan officials.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Reagan had been told after the fact of a contact between Mr. Wilson, a longtime friend of the President, and Libyan officials. Mr. Speakes refused to say when the President was told or whether it was immediately after the meeting or after reports about the session in the Sunday issue of The New York Times.

headline: PATENTS; Audible Sound Identifies $1 to $20 Bills for Blind
abstract: An audible security validator for use by the blind was patented this week. It identifies bills from $1 to $20 and reports the amount by recorded sound.

headline: Brazil Debt Deadline Set
abstract: Brazil and its leading commercial bank creditors have set a deadline of March 15 for completion of negotiaMarch 15 for completion of negotiations on a new program to restructure debt due in 1985 and 1986.   In a telex message sent to the outstanding to Brazil, a 14-bank advisory committee said final details still needed to be hammered out regarding the restructuring of $6 billion of public-sector debt that fell due in 1985 and the rollover of another $8 billion in principal due this year.

headline: TWO MISSILE TYPES USED BY U.S. NAVY
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that Navy warplanes used long-range air-to-surface missiles to strike a missile site in Libya and two Libyan naval patrol craft.   Mr. Weinberger told reporters at the Pentagon that A-7 attack planes from the aircraft carrier Saratoga hit the missile site with HARM missiles and that Harpoon missiles fired from an A-6 attack plane from the carrier America had hit one Libyan patrol vessel. He said no details of the attack on the second Libyan boat were available.

headline: MARCOS CALLS FRAUD PROTESTS 'A CHILDISH DISPLAY'
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said Tuesday that his opponents' protests over electoral fraud and violence were ''a childish display of petulance.''   At the same time, he said he would abide by the results of an official vote certification by the National Assembly. Two-thirds of the assembly members are Marcos supporters.   His opponent, Corazon C. Aquino, called the National Assembly procedure, which is mandated under the Philippine Constitution, a distortion of democracy. She urged the United States not to come to the support ''in the name of shortsighted self-interest'' of a man who she said ''continues to steal our precious votes.''

headline: BIGGER DEDUCTION FOR NON-ITEMIZERS IS PROPOSED
abstract: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, is proposing a sharply increased standard deduction for taxpayers who do not itemize deductions and tax brackets lower than those approved by the House of Representatives, according to a document presented to committee members tonight.   The document will be used as the committee's starting point when it begins drafting tax revision legislation Wednesday.   The other main elements of the Packwood plan, including limits on indivduals' deductions of state and local tax payments and disallowance of business deductions for excise tax payments, were disclosed last week.   According to the document, which lists the Packwood proposals side-by-side with the provisions of current law, President Reagan's proposal and the bill passed by the House in December, the standard deduction for couples would be raised to $5,100 from the present $3,670.

headline: U.S. Sues Dynamics on Overcharges
abstract: The Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit today against the General Dynamics Corporation, seeking to recover sums that the big military contractor is accused of fraudulently billing the Government.   The suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles, relates to the company's development of a prototype of the Divad antiaircraft gun between 1978 and 1980. In early December the Justice Department brought criminal charges against the company and four current or past executives, because of the reported overcharges on the weapon. One of the past executives was James M. Beggs, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, who resigned earlier this year.

headline: HAITI'S EXILES, RETURNING STEADILY, CARRY HOME FORMULAS FOR CHANGE
abstract: Jean Dominique was in from New York and walked into what used to be Haiti's most outspoken radio station, now a place covered with dust, unraveled tapes and smashed cabinets. The transmitters were carted off five years ago by the political police.   Today, as Haiti is testing life without the Duvalier family, Mr. Dominique is back from exile, ready to start all over, joining many Haitians eager to come home.   In recent days, the cautious trickle of exiles returning has become a steady flow, with men and women arriving from Africa, Europe, the United States. They are here, celebrating, asking questions, offering recipes for change. Undaunted by the shake-up in the ruling council last week, some have already declared themselves political candidates.

headline: U.S. SAYS MANILA WILL BE PROVIDED MARCOS'S PAPERS
abstract: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told the leaders of a Congressional subcommittee today that the Reagan Administration would turn over to the Philippine Government copies of about 1,500 financial documents brought to Hawaii by Ferdinand E. Marcos, the legislative leaders said.   According to the ranking Democrat and Republican on the House Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, Mr. Baker said copies of the documents would also be made available to the subcommittee within a few days.   Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the subcommittee, and Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican and ranking minority member of the subcommittee, praised Secretary Baker and the Administration for their cooperation. Interest From Manila    The decision, according to Congressional and Administration officials familiar with the documents, means that investigators will obtain vital clues to unraveling the Marcos family fortune, an issue of intense interest in Manila as well as in Congress.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Carolina Power and Light Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $175 million of first mortgage bonds.    * Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $200 million of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: LIBYA BAN UNCLEAR TO U.S. COMPANIES
abstract: Less than a week before the deadline for complying with President Reagan's sanctions against Libya, many American companies doing business there are still unsure of what they will do. But most of the companies operating through foreign subsidiaries say they believe they will be able to carry on business as usual.   But lawyers who specialize in international trade issues say that until there is further guidance from the Federal Government, it is impossible to know exactly which activities will be allowed to continue in Libya after the sanctions take effect Feb. 1.   ''The big question is how hard a line the U.S. will take in looking at the foreign subsidiaries,'' said John Ellicott of Covington & Burling, a law firm based in Washington, D.C. Mr. Ellicott is representing several clients concerned with the sanctions.

headline: McDonnell Wins Military Contract
abstract: The Defense Department said yesterday that it had awarded a $331.6 million contract to the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company for a ballistic missile that could intercept incoming nuclear warheads.

headline: Texas Air Backed On Eastern Stake
abstract: The Transportation Department gave the Texas Air Corporation permission today to buy more Eastern Airlines stock, but said most of the shares must go into a voting trust until the Government decides whether the airlines can merge.   The ruling said that Texas Air, the parent of Continental Airlines and New York Air, may purchase up to 51 percent of Eastern.

headline: Advertising; Numerous Changes at Thompson
abstract: AS the adworld and much of the business community expected, the board of the JWT Group late Tuesday named Joseph W. O'Donnell chairman and chief executive officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company, its largest subsidiary and the world's fourth-largest advertising agency.   He had been selected by Don Johnston, who is stepping out of the chief executive's slot immediately but will remain chairman until the end of the year. Mr. Johnston, however, will continue as chief executive of the JWT Group, the publicly held parent company. Mr. Johnston, 59 years old, allowed the new man, 43, to pick his own worldwide team. And the changes, announced yesterday, are extensive.   Perhaps the most surprising of them was his naming his replacement as executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson, U.S.A., the domestic company, and general manager of the Chicago office. Donald G. Sullivan, 45, is being brought in from the presidency of Ketchum Advertising/ USA to fill the post.

headline: DOW RISES 8.95 TO 1,511.24, HALTING SKID
abstract: After four straight losing sessions, the stock market rose moderately yesterday in continued heavy trading as investors searched for issues that have fallen to attractively low prices.   I.B.M. and other technology stocks, after suffering through a selling spree on Wednesday, were taken by bargain hunters. Bank and oil issues, meanwhile, settled down after two days of heavy selling pressure.

headline: Market Place; Assessing the Newsletters
abstract: MORE than half a million people subscribe to investment newsletters in the hope of making money in stocks, bonds, options or commodities.   But some evidence suggests that these advice-for-a-fee market letters tend to follow trends rather than set the pace. That is the view of Mark Hulbert, owner of the Hulbert Financial Digest in Washington. In this monthly publication that costs $135 for a year's subscription, he analyzes recommendations made by some 80 newsletters and tracks their investment performance.

headline: PEOPLE
abstract: * Kristin Norrgard has been promoted to publisher at Savvy magazine.

headline: Republic Bank Expands Profit
abstract: The Republic New York Corporation, which owns the Republic National Bank of New York, reported yesterday that it earned $32 million, or $1.59 a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $25.2 million, or $1.33 a share, a year earlier.

headline: Briefcases
abstract: Finance ministers from the West's leading industrial powers - the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Japan - will meet in London next weekend. It will be the first gathering of the ministers from the Group of Five since early October, when they met in Seoul, South Korea.    * Congress' Joint Economic Committee is scheduled to hold a symposium Thursday and Friday on ''The American Economy in Transition: From the Second World War to the 21st Century.''

headline: Dollar-Yen Statement
abstract: The yen-dollar exchange rate should stabilize at the current rate, about 200 yen to the dollar, Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, said in an interview published today.

headline: Cartier, Gump's
abstract: Cartier of New York said it was considering the purchase of the four Gump's home furnishings and gift stores owned by Macmillan Inc., the publishing company.

headline: AQUINO MIGHT BYPASS GOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she was studying the option of declaring what her aides called a ''revolutionary government'' that would allow her to bypass the institutions left behind by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   Aides said the move could be adopted as a way to circumvent the pro-Marcos forces that continue to control the National Assembly and the Supreme Court. They said it could also enable her to seize monopolies held by his friends.   It is assumed here that before she can begin to make major changes, Mrs. Aquino must gain control of the governing institutions, which under the 1973 Constitution had evolved into a personal machine for Mr. Marcos, who fled the country Tuesday.   ''We are studying it,'' she said of the proposal in an interview here. ''I think it's too soon to act.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 3, 1986
abstract: Companies    Union Carbide plans to sell its consumer products lines for $2 billion or more and to distribute the proceeds to shareholders. It also said it would offer to buy 55 percent of its shares, rather than the 35 percent it had already bid for. These are two parts of a tough defensive package that came after GAF said it would offer to raise its bid for Carbide by $4 a share, to $78 a share, under certain conditions. GAF shares fell $5.75, to $53.25. Arbitragers said the drop reflected the feeling that GAF would lose its battle unless it raised its offer again or made headway through some unforeseen move. Carbide shares, meanwhile, jumped $2.375, to $73.25.  [ Page D1. ]    Court documents show discrepancies in statements by Union Carbide about whether the Bhopal plant was controlled by corporate headquarters or by its Indian subsidiary. The issue is considered crucial as the court battle opens today before a Federal judge in New York over claims arising from the gas-leak disaster.  [ D1. ]

headline: SOME ALAMITO DIRECTORS VIEW A BID UNFAVORABLY
abstract: Osceola Energy Inc. sweetened its offer Saturday for the Alamito Company to $158 a share in cash, or $360.2 million, in the bidding war for the Tucson, Ariz., electricity wholesaler.   Osceola, formed by the Catalyst Energy Development Corporation; Bear, Stearns & Company; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, and William M. Pope Jr., a Donaldson, Lufkin senior vice president acting independently, raised its bid from $150 a share in cash and $5 in exchangeable preferred stock.   Mr. Pope said today that Alamito had not yet responded to the revised offer. A secretary at Alamito said its executives were unavailable for comment. The company's stock closed Thursday on the American Stock Exchange at $148.50, down 50 cents.

headline: HESS, EXPECTING LOSS WILL OMIT ITS DIVIDEND
abstract: The Amerada Hess Corporation, buffeted by the impact of sharply declining oil prices, yesterday said that it expected a substantial loss for the first quarter and would omit its quarterly dividend. Further, the company said it would undertake a sweeping retrenchment that included a sharp reduction of its capital budget and layoffs of some employees.   The actions by the New York-based company, made public in a statement released after the stock market had closed for the day, go much further than the reductions in capital and exploration budgets other oil companies have announced as a result of the sudden plunge in oil prices.

headline: AVONDALE DEAL
abstract: Avondale Mills, a textile manufacturer based in Sylacauga, Ala., said it had signed an amended agreement to be acquired by Walton Monroe Mills Inc., a producer of yarn and unfinished fabrics, and two other companies affiliated with it, for $28.20 a share, or $112.9 million. The agreement follows by nearly two months a definitive pact between the companies under which Avondale, the largest domestic producer of knitting yarn, agreed to be acquired for $23.41 a share. But higher offers were later received from two other suitors.

headline: REAGAN CONDEMNS NICARAGUA IN PLEA FOR AID TO REBELS
abstract: President Reagan, condemning Nicaragua as a ''cancer'' that poses a direct threat to the United States, said tonight that stopping Communism and international terrorism there would serve as a historic test of his Presidency.   In a bluntly worded television speech that lasted about 20 minutes, Mr. Reagan called on the American people to demand that Congress endorse the Administration's $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels. The alternative, he said, was to face a growing Soviet beachhead in Central and South America, increased terrorism in the region and a tide of ''desperate Latin peoples by the millions'' fleeing into the southern United States.   ''For our own security, the United States must deny the Soviet Union a beachhead in North America,'' he said.

headline: KOHLBERG SEEKS TO PAY LESS CASH FOR BEATRICE
abstract: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which has agreed to buy the Beatrice Companies for $6.2 billion, has proposed modifying the terms of the acquisition so that it would pay less cash, Beatrice announced today.   The price of Beatrice's stock plummeted in heavy trading in reaction to the proposed modification in which Kohlberg would pay $40 in cash and $10 in preferred stock. On Nov. 14, Beatrice announced that it had accepted an offer from Kohlberg, a New York-based investment firm, to acquire it for $43 in cash and $7 in preferred stock.

headline: EASTERN AIR HAS A LOSS IN QUARTER
abstract: Eastern Airlines yesterday reported a $67.4 million loss in the fourth quarter, in line with the expectations of management and analysts. The loss followed five profitable quarters.   Frank Borman, chairman and chief executive officer, said the loss was caused by fare wars and ''relentless expansion'' into key Eastern markets by airlines with low operating and payroll costs. New carriers such as Presidential Airways have expanded into Florida, Eastern's main market.

headline: THE ORDERLY WORLD OF MARTIN DAVIS
abstract: THE snow was falling heavily, obscuring the glorious view of Central Park from the 42d floor of the Gulf and Western building. The pristine vista did little to cheer Martin S. Davis, the company's 58-year-old chairman.   He and his wife were scheduled to leave for a week of skiing in St. Moritz, and a snowstorm could postpone what was to be his first real vacation in three years.   As it turned out, luck was with Mr. Davis - his plane took off despite the weather. It was another example of how, despite momentary uncertainty, things have tended to work out Mr. Davis's way.

headline: Bail Denied In Thrift Case
abstract: A circuit judge today denied bail for the former president of the Old Court Savings and Loan Association and his wife. But an appellate court did not rule on their case, allowing Jeffrey and Karol Levitt to remain free at least through the weekend.

headline: Boeing Gives Refund
abstract: The Boeing Company has voluntarily refunded $5.2 million to the Defense Department for what the company considered overcharges for spare parts, the Pentagon said. The Department said Boeing held an internal audit of contracts and decided that some prices charged by a subsidiary - Hydraulic Units Inc, of Duarte, Calif. - were excessive.

headline: NEEDHAM IS 2D AGENCY FOR HASBRO-BRADLEY
abstract: Needham Harper Worldwide has become the second agency for Hasbro-Bradley, the country's largest toy company, by winning a competition that came down to five finalists, each of whom prepared campaigns for three products.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Alaska Housing Finance Corp. is offering $50 million of triple-A 8 1/4 percent, 12-year mortgage bonds at 99.55 to yield 8.31 percent through Salomon Brothers.    * American Express Overseas Finance Co. is offering 20 billion yen of 5 7/8 percent, five-year Eurobonds at 101 to yield 6.08 percent through Nomura International Ltd.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ametex Inc., a manufacturer of industrial measurement equipment, elected Allan Kornfeld as chief financial officer.    * Columbia Pictures Inc. has promoted Nora B. Kavner to assistant general counsel.

headline: CANADA SUPPORTS U.S. ON SANCTIONS
abstract: Canada announced a series of steps tonight in support of the Reagan Administration's sanctions against Libya.   In a statement issued by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, the Government said it would halt all help to Canadian companies doing business with the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, ban new exports of technically advanced oil-drilling equipment to Libya and block any attempts by Libya to obtain technical assistance through Canada that was denied by the United States.   ''We do not want them to do by the back door what they could not do by the front door,'' the Foreign Minister, Joe Clark, said after Mr. Mulroney issued a statement condemning terrorism.

headline: A Biederman Toast
abstract: Biederman & Company, with glasses high, toasts the good judgment of the management of Freixenet, the Spanish-wine marketers, who have seen fit to assign the agency its Castellblanch Brut Zero and Brut Extra wines.

headline: Coca-Cola Plans Bottling Merger
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said it planned to merge its bottling interests with those of the JTL Corporation, which operates Coca-Cola bottling companies in the West, to form the world's largest independent soft-drink bottler. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: SWORN IN, NEW PRESIDENT HAS A QUIET LUNCH
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino went home for her inaugural luncheon today. It was a quiet affair.   After being sworn in this morning at a private and venerable establishment called Club Filipino, Mrs. Aquino left with her family in a station wagon with tinted windows. It was recently provided to her for security purposes in light of threats against her life.

headline: JAPAN UNDECIDED ABOUT 'STAR WARS'
abstract: Despite more than a year of Government study and internal debate, Japan has been unable to make up its mind about whether to take part in President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' missile-defense program.   The most that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has said in public is that he has an ''understanding'' of the project, known formally as the Strategic Defense Initiative. By using the deliberately vague expression, one he has used many times, Mr. Nakasone has hinted at his interest while withholding endorsement.   Nevertheless, some Government officials and defense experts say they believe pressure on Japan to make a clear decision has increased, especially now that Britain has agreed to take part in ''Star Wars'' research and West Germany has signaled its qualified approval.

headline: Pulitzer Action on Bid
abstract: The directors of the Pulitzer Publishing Company directors recommended today that shareholders reject a $500 million takeover offer from A. Alfred Taubman, the real estate developer. Three family members who control 54 percent of the stock had previously said they would not accept the offer.

headline: Bid for Carson Pirie Spotlights Investor
abstract: Gilbert K. Granet, a Chicago investment banker, has always prided himself on financing acquisitions and making deals without much fanfare.   But within the last year, Mr. Granet's name seems to keep popping up in Chicago retailing circles and the not-so-related trucking industry.   On Friday, he and his two-week-old private investment firm, Baytree Investors, offered to buy Carson Pirie Scott & Company, one of the city's largest retailers, for $350 million.

headline: Sheller Signs Pact On Its Acquisition
abstract: The Sheller-Globe Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired for about $482 million by an investor group led by General Felt Industries, Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the senior management of Sheller. Under terms of the agreement, Sheller-Globe shareholders would receive $39 a share in cash and junior subordinated notes having a face value of $17 a share.

headline: CUTS IN HOUSING AID OPPOSED
abstract: Several leaders of the nation's home construction and financing industries said this weekend that they would strongly oppose a range of cutbacks in housing-related programs that the Reagan Administration is expected to propose for the 1987 Federal budget.   ''They want to remove every vestige of Government support for housing whether it costs the taxpayer money or not,'' said David O. Maxwell, chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Assocation, an investor-owned company commonly known as Fannie Mae. ''I am worried.''   Anger over the Administration's reported aims to pare housing programs benefiting moderate- and low-income buyers overshadowed optimistic forecasts at the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders here of another year of steady demand for new houses.

headline: United Fares Cut to Hawaii
abstract: United Airlines said today that previously announced fares between major Unites States cities and Hawaii would be cut by as much as 18 percent for fall and summer travel.   The price reductions, beginning June 6, affect travel between Hawaii and New York, Chicago, Denver, Dallas-Fort Worth, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, San Diego and Portland, Ore., United said.

headline: AQUINO SAYS SHE WOULD PERMIT COMMUNISTS IN HER GOVERNMENT
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition candidate, campaigned today in a political stronghold of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and said she would allow Communists into a coalition government if they agreed to renounce violence.   Mrs. Aquino stood at the base of a three-story-high bust of Mr. Marcos that overlooks a Government-run golf course and resort named Marcos Park and said, ''I will leave it to the Filipino people to decide what they want to do with this.''   At a news conference in nearby Baguio, 125 miles north of Manila, Mrs. Aquino responded to charges by Mr. Marcos that the country would fall to Communism if she defeated him in the special election scheduled for Feb. 7. Rebuts Assertion on Communism   ''I would be the last person in the world to be a Communist,'' she said. ''I have never been a Communist, and I do not intend to be a Communist.

headline: U.S. STUDY IS READY ON TERROR POLICY
abstract: An Government task force on terrorism has recommended that potential injury to innocent civilians be considered in determining the need for American military intervention.   The recommendation is contained in a report to be released Thursday by a task force headed by Vice President Bush. A copy was obtained today.

headline: Estimating Taxes Due
abstract: FOR most Americans, settling with the Federal Government is a chore to be endured but once a year. But for the eight million or so taxpayers who file estimated taxes, the chore falls due four times a year.   The majority of those who pay estimated tax are either self-employed or derive their principal income from investments or other capital gains. ''People who pay estimated taxes are people who have fairly substantial amounts of income not covered by withholding,'' Roderic P. Young of the Internal Revenue Service said.

headline: Unilever's Earnings Grow
abstract: Unilever, the British-Dutch food and household goods company, reported today that its fourth-quarter pretax profit jumped 50.5 percent from a year earlier. The figure was $:322 million, or $467 million at the present exchange rate of $1.45 to the pound, compared with the previous $:214 million.

headline: MARCOS U.S. BANK DEALINGS MODEST
abstract: American banks and financial institutions played a modest role in the finances of Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family, according to documents brought to Hawaii by the Marcos party.   The documents, which were made public Thursday, also shed new light on New York City real estate purchases by the Marcoses and deals involving American corporations and Mr. Marcos and his associates.   Several prominent institutions, such as Chase Manhattan Bank and the Irving Trust Company, are named in the documents and some of the transactions involve tens of millions of dollars.   But the United States connection in the Marcos family holdings, based on the various documents and reports on the papers so far, appears to be small relative to the Marcos dealings with Swiss banks and Japanese companies.

headline: Australia Is Told I.R.A. May Try to Kill Queen
abstract: A warning that Irish Republican Army terrorists might try to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II of Britain as she visits Australia caused a nationwide alert by the authorities, newspapers said today.   Despite the report, the Queen and her husband, Prince Philip, rode in an open carriage to a ceremony after their arrival today in Adelaide.

headline: Kaiser Suit Names 2 Former Officers
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had filed suit against two former employees who have been retained as consultants by the investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., which is trying to take over the company.

headline: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Midway Collides With a Korean Boat
abstract: The aircraft carrier Midway collided with a South Korean fishing boat in the Yellow Sea on Friday, damaging the 45-foot fishing boat but leaving the 52,000-ton warship unscathed.

headline: Japan Reviews Euroyen Curbs
abstract: Japan wants to abolish restrictions on the issuance of Euroyen bonds by non-Japanese companies, Finance Ministry sources said today.

headline: Merrill's Stock Bucks the Tide
abstract: The stock of Merrill Lynch & Company jumped $2.75 a share yesterday, to $38, in heavy trading, amid rumors that any one of a number of major corporations was interested in taking it over. On Monday, the big Wall Street broker topped the list of most-active stocks, climbing $1.50, to $36.25, on a volume of 2.3 million shares.

headline: 2 WORRIES FOR BANGKOK: GROWING AND SINKING
abstract: This is a city with more than five and a half million people and no sewage system. It is a city sinking into its soft-clay base at a rate of almost four inches a year, officials say. Most of it will soon be below sea level. It is a city whose storied canals are now ecologically dead, polluted by organic and chemical waste.   But Bangkok is also struggling with an unseen problem that makes life hard for its Western-educated planners: how to put a brake on unbridled, environmentally damaging development in a society that instinctively shrinks from confrontation and rejects harsh measures.

headline: People
abstract: * Murray Gaylord, Stuart Epstein and William Tucker, management representatives, promoted to executive vice presidents at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.    * Deborah Yount has been named president of Yount-Moeller, subsidiary of Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa.

headline: Pressure Increases On Gemayel to Resign
abstract: Pressure mounted today on Lebanon's Christian President to resign, and firing again broke out across the demarcation line that divides Beirut into Christian and Moslem sectors.

headline: Beech Layoffs
abstract: About 300 workers of the Beech Aircraft Corporation in Wichita and Salina, Kan., or 9.4 percent, will be laid off during the next three months, a company spokesman said. The action reflects the impact of continuing softness in the general aviation market and the transition from development to production of the Starship I, Beech's new-generation composite turboprop, John Gedraitis, a spokesman, said.

headline: Transtechnology
abstract: The Transtechnology Corporation said that it had begun a cash tender offer to buy 1.3 million shares of Lundy Electronics and Systems Inc. common stock for $14 a share.

headline: AFTER THATCHER, KINNOCK DOESN'T SPRING TO MIND
abstract: If British politics were still being played in the traditional way as a two-party game, then the leader of Her Majesty's Opposition would be the obvious and automatic beneficiary of the waning of a Prime Minister's popularity and power such as Margaret Thatcher is now having to endure at the end of her seventh year in office.   Mrs. Thatcher's ability to dominate her Government and her prospects of leading the Conservative Party to a third consecutive victory at the polls late next year or early in 1988 have both been damaged by a dispute over the affairs of a small helicopter company called Westland.   The dispute provoked two resignations from her Cabinet and left large question marks next to her reputation for competence and forthrightness. Yet hardly anyone seems to regard Neil Kinnock, 43 years old, the opposition leader, as a sure bet to replace her.   Hardly anyone, that is, besides Mr. Kinnock himself. Interviewed the other day as he rode in his official car through the East Anglian countryside, on his way to the cathedral city of Norwich to make a speech, the leader of the Labor Party replied with an offhand ''Oh sure'' when asked whether he felt the Westland affair was helping to make his move to 10 Downing Street inevitable.

headline: Income Falls At Chemical
abstract: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that increases in loan-loss provisions, operating expenses and income taxes caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1985 to fall 7.5 percent.   Chemical said that net income in the three months ended Dec. 31, 1985, dropped to $97.6 million, or $1.82 a share, from $105.5 million, or $2.03 a share, a year earlier.

headline: 15.7% JUMP IN BUILDING OF HOUSING
abstract: Construction of new homes surged 15.7 percent in January, the biggest jump in almost two years, the Commerce Department said today.   New homes and apartments were started at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.09 million units, compared with a December rate of 1.8 million units. The January increase, following a 9 percent December gain, was the strongest since a 17 percent jump in February 1984.

headline: The U.N. Today: March 7, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Expert Group on Accounting and Reporting Standards - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Compaq Adds 3 Computers
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced a series of faster, lighter-weight portable computers today that analysts said were likely to help extend the company's rapid sales growth.   ''They are making solid, simple, incremental improvements in price and performance,'' said Harvey Allison, a technology analyst with Wertheim & Company.

headline: 2 SMALL SLUM VICTIMS NOW PAST MANILA'S AID
abstract: The political upheaval that occurred up north in Manila is falling at least two lifetimes short of having any effect on the hungry children of Purok No. 6 in the Magsungay slum.   Lycel Obligada died this morning at 8:30 from malnutrition after two years of life in the crammed fishing village where work and food are equally scarce and the infant mortality rates try the effectiveness of any Government, despotic or not.   Her neighbors donated the 5 pesos (a little more than 20 cents) in taxi fare to get her to the hospital for the final hours, and she stopped breathing with her grandmother keening by the crib. When her father, Godofredo, saw her finally left without animation after her long glassy-eyed struggle for life, he knelt and wept.

headline: STATE DEPT. STUDY ON TERROR GROUP CITES LIBYAN LINK
abstract: The State Department issued a report today asserting that the Abu Nidal group, which is suspected of organizing the attacks last week at airports in Vienna and Rome, was ''among the most dangerous of the Middle Eastern terrorist organizations.''   The report stressed what it said were the Palestinian group's links to Libya. Apparently in an effort to encourage European support for international moves against the sponsors of terrorist acts, it emphasized that the group had increasingly concentrated its attacks in Western Europe.   Today Libya denied involvement in the Rome and Vienna attacks and asserted that remarks by the United States and Israeli officials reflected plans for ''joint aggression against Libya by the American military machine and Israel.''  [ Page 5. ]  In Beirut, a caller purporting to speak for Islamic Holy War threatened further action against Americans and Israelis. The group has said it is holding four Americans hostage in Lebanon.  [ Page 5. ]  Group Linked to 60 Attacks The State Department report blamed the Abu Nidal group for more than 60 terrorist attacks in the last eight years, half of them in the last two years. The attacks have killed hundreds of people and have increasingly been aimed at innocent bystanders, the report said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Texas Air Raises Stake in Eastern
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation said today that it had moved closer to acquiring control of Eastern Airlines by raising its stake in the Miami-based airline to the equivalent of 47 percent, from 43.5 percent.

headline: Household Plans A Stock Buyback
abstract: Household International Inc. said its board had approved the purchase of up to 11.5 million, or 22 percent, of the company's shares outstanding with cash from the sale of its merchandising unit. Household said it would pay $42 to $46 a share, based on the number of shares tendered and the price each shareholder specifies.

headline: RED APPLE BUYING GRISTEDES
abstract: The Red Apple Company, a supermarket operator based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the 36 Gristedes Brothers supermarkets in the metropolitan area from the Southland Corporation.   The deal also includes 11 Charles & Company food emporiums in the New York metropolitan area. It will make Red Apple the largest supermarket chain in Manhattan and the city, with 75 stores, industry analysts said. The price was not disclosed.  When Southland acquired Gristedes in 1968, the stores led a vanguard of gourmet food purveyors. But Southland officials said that Gristedes, whose butchers claimed to know customers' tastes by heart, no longer fit into its long-range corporate plans.

headline: REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR CONTRA AID IS MEETING RESISTANCE IN CONGRESS
abstract: Congressional opponents of President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels began to mobilize today, indicating that the Administration faces an uphill fight to gain passage of the authorization.   Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, declared his opposition and predicted ''intense resistance'' in the Senate in view of projected cuts in domestic social programs. He said that the Administration's request would be referred to his committee as well as to the Foreign Relations Committee.   He and Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, initiated a letter to President Reagan, signed by 18 senators, urging a postponement of the request pending thorough diplomatic efforts at negotiations through the Contadora group of Latin American countries. ''This would be a particularly bad time for the United States to increase the level of conflict inside Central America,'' the letter said. The President has said that one purpose of the aid is to force Nicaragua into negotiations.

headline: People
abstract: Warren Fischer has been promoted to senior vice president at Grey Advertising.    * Robin Hall has joined Bamberger's as vice president-creative director of the sales promotion division.

headline: Coast Power Unit Sets Bond Sale
abstract: The Southern California Public Power Agency is offering $180 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 8.37 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The financing also includes bonds with yields ranging from 6 percent for an issue due in 1988 to 7 percent in 1992, 7.60 percent in 1996, 8 percent in 2001 and 8.10 percent in 2006.

headline: 2,000 SALVADORANS MARCH IN CAPITAL
abstract: An estimated 2,000 demonstrators marched through the capital of San Salvador ths morning to mark the anniversary of the slaying of the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop six years ago.   The Archbishop, Oscar Arnulfo Romero, was shot through the heart by a gunman while saying mass. Archbishop Romero was an outspoken opponent of the wave of Government repression that took thousands of lives in 1980 and his assassin is widely believed to have been a member of a right-wing death squad.

headline: 3 Arabs Drop Israeli Suit
abstract: Three West Bank Arabs suspected of being active in hard-line wings of the Palestine Liberation Organization today dropped their High Court appeal against an order expelling them from Israel. The three men said they were withdrawing the suits because they could not expect a reasonable decision. They are Dr. Azmi Shu'aibi, a dentist; Ali Abu Hilal, a leader of a building workers' union, and Hassan Abdul Jawad, a journalist.

headline: Sony America Doubles Its Billings at McCann
abstract: The Sony Corporation of America has consolidated almost all of its advertising in McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies and its agency since 1978. It doubles McCann's Sony billings, to about $40 million.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 6, 1986
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in Southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: PEOPLE AIR CUTS FARES IN WEST
abstract: People Express Inc., in a bold attempt to expand its low-cost system to the recently acquired Frontier Airlines and open the West to more East Coast travelers, said yesterday that it had cut the one-way fare between Newark and Denver from $99 to $69. It also cut fares to more than 100 other cities served by its new subsidiary.   In a move to lower Frontier's costs to compensate for the reduced fares. Stephen Schlachter, a People executive, said at a news conference that his company would try to apply its management approach to Frontier's 4,000 mostly unionized workers. People's employees, who are not unionized, perform a variety of jobs other than their specialties and are considered part of the company's management. They are also required to own stock in the company.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN LEADER IN AN OFFER ON NAMIBIA
abstract: South Africa proposed today that a United Nations plan for the independence of South-West Africa should begin on Aug. 1, but made clear the offer was conditional on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.   The announcement seemed designed, in part, to shift responsibility for South-West Africa's continued dependence on South Africa to others, notably the United States.   For most of the past five years, Washington has been seeking the withdrawal of the estimated 30,000 Cuban soldiers in Angola in return for a South African withdrawal from South-West Africa under the seven-year-old United Nations formula.

headline: Filing by Sun Microsystems
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc., a fast-growing vendor of computer work stations for engineers, has filed for an initial public stock offering and plans to offer four million shares at an expected price of $16 to $18 a share.   The filing, disclosed Friday, came only a few days after the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its own work station, which will compete with Sun's.

headline: INVESTING; SORTING GOOD JUNK BONDS FROM BAD
abstract: AT any one time, there are some securities that even junk bond managers - the investors who buy the market dogs - will not buy. Today, the market's real pariahs are the debt securities of oil companies.  ''It doesn't even cross my mind to own energy,'' said Robert M. Wallace, vice president of Fort Hill Investors in San Jose, Calif.  With oil prices sliding,the potential for making money there has turned sour, most pension and mutual fund managers agree. But managers also are scorning the issues of some airlines, whose revenues could be whittled by fare wars, and the bonds of companies involved in leveraged buyouts, which require heavy new debt loads. The troubles in steel have also prompted hesitation about that industry's debt securities.

headline: DISPUTE OVER A MOSLEM DIVORCE ENSNARLS GANDHI
abstract: She was cast aside by her husband after 43 years of marriage, a not uncommon occurrence in much of the world. But Shah Bano reacted differently for an Indian woman, especially for a Moslem woman. She went to court to demand money from the man who divorced her.   It took 10 years for the case to reach the Indian Supreme Court, which last year awarded Shah Bano a $40 monthly maintenance fee to be paid by her former husband, a well-to-do lawyer in the city of Indore.

headline: HOUSEHOLD TO BUY DYSON'S HOLDINGS
abstract: The Household International Corporation said it would buy almost all of its common and preferred stock owned by the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation for about $190 million. The purchase of Household's 500,000 common and 1.8 million preferred shares completes the previously announced share repurchase program that began in January.

headline: Sebring, Fla., Utility Is Raising $119 Million
abstract: The Sebring, Fla., Utilities Commission is raising about $119 million through the sale of interest-bearing and non-interest-bearing bonds with a face amount of about $280 million through underwriters led by Wertheim & Company.   The bond financing will provide the commission with financial relief by reducing its interest expenses for the next several years.

headline: PRESIDENT AGREES TO ALTER HIS PLAN ON AID TO REBELS
abstract: President Reagan, faced with likely defeat in the House of Representatives, agreed today to compromise on his proposal on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.   Under the plan, most military aid to the insurgents would be suspended for 90 days while renewed efforts are made to seek a negotiated settlement in Central America.   The House is scheduled to vote Thursday on Mr. Reagan's proposal to give the rebels $100 million in aid to continue their efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, $70 million of it in military assistance. Missiles for the Rebels   Larry Speakes, the President's spokesman, said that under the compromise, $25 million of the $100 million would be released immediately. Most of this would go for nonmilitary purposes, such as food, he said, but some would be used to provide portable antiaircraft missiles and intensified military training for the rebels.

headline: Israel Retains Chief of Staff
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet agreed today to extend by a year the term of the Chief of Staff, Gen. Moshe Levy, a Cabinet statement said. General Levy, a 49-year-old former paratroop commander, took on the three-year post in 1983.

headline: COMPAQ'S EXPLOSIVE GROWTH
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation has secured its place in the annals of corporate America by becoming the first company to eclipse sales of $500 million in its third year of business.   That was cause enough for the laser-lit festivities, accompanied by the 113-piece Houston Symphony Orchestra in its ultramodern music hall here, that Compaq threw Thursday for its employees, dealers and dozens of Wall Street analysts.   What many of the analysts said they found more telling for Compaq, as it continues to jockey with the giant International Business Machines Corporation for buyers of personal computers, is the firm grip on costs the company has maintained during its explosive growth. Inventories Pared    In a year in which Compaq's sales jumped 53 percent, to $503 million, the company actually pared inventories of circuit boards, microprocessor chips and other parts by $9 million, to $76 million, from the 1984 year-end total. This translates into greater earnings because it frees money that otherwise would be tied up in parts sitting in warehouses.

headline: Advertising; Contest Stiffens for Merrill Job
abstract: THE recently formed Bozell Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, a subsidiary of Lorimar, has resigned the Prudential-Bache business in order to compete for the far larger account of Merrill Lynch & Company.   The difference is approximately $10 million compared with about $40 million in billings.

headline: Penn Central Plan To Spin Off Unit
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said its board had authorized management to develop a plan to spin off to shareholders a new company that would consist principally of the Marathon Manufacturing Company.

headline: WINNIPEG: CANADA'S COLDEST BIG CITY HAS DIVERSITY
abstract: As some Canadians tell it, the coldest spot in Canada lies at the corner of Portage and Main Streets in downtown Winnipeg.   The numbing cold swept on the prairie wind through canyons of high-rise offices and stores has become less formidable now that Winnipegers can cross Portage and Main through an underground shopping mall sprawling beneath Canada's most notorious street corner.   But the hyperbole is not undeserved, for Winnipeg sometimes has been ranked behind Fairbanks, Alaska, as the coldest city in North America, with only 116 frost-free days each year.   ''There is no city in the world larger and colder than Winnipeg,'' said James G. Carr, director of community relations at the University of Winnipeg, with the perverse pride that Winnipegers exhibit toward their climate. People here felt smug when a warm spell sent Winnipeg's temperature briefly soaring above New York City's in January.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: Dennis Schmidt is joining Campbell-Ewald, New York, as a group senior vice president and associate creative director.    * John J. O'Connor, New York bureau chief of Advertising Age, is joining Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as senior vice president, director of public relations.

headline: PATENTS; Method for Tracing Origin of Blood in Urine
abstract: Cleve W. Laird, a biochemist, received patent 4,575,486 this week for International Remote Imaging Systems Inc., in Chatsworth, Calif., on a method of tracing the origin of blood calls in urine and assisting in the diagnosis of disorders. Blood cells from the kidney, coded with a special protein, are identified by applying antibodies.  According to a spokesman, the company may incorporate the invention in a machine it manufactures for urinalysis.

headline: Walesa Urges Poland To Overhaul Prisons
abstract: Lech Walesa, the founder of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, urged the Government today to improve the nation's penal system and free its remaining political prisoners.

headline: REAGAN APPOINTS HABIB AS ENVOY TO CENTRAL AMERICA
abstract: President Reagan, saying the United States was seeking a ''diplomatic solution for Central America,'' announced today that he was appointing Philip C. Habib to serve as special United States envoy to the region.   Hours after Mr. Habib returned from what Mr. Reagan termed his ''successful mission'' to the Philippines, the President told reporters that he was sending the 66-year-old diplomat to El Salvador in the start of an effort to step up negotiations in the region, especially with Nicaragua.   Administration oficials made it clear that Mr. Habib's mission was designed in large part to sway skeptical members of Congress in favor of Mr. Reagan's $100 million aid package for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. The proposal, which includes $70 million for military assistance, is scheduled to be taken up by the House and the Senate in less than two weeks.   ''Let there be no misunderstanding,'' Mr. Reagan said, standing near Mr. Habib in the White House press room. ''Ambassador Habib's efforts to achieve a diplomatic solution must be accompanied by an increasing level of pressure on the Nicaraguan Communists. What we're asking Congress for is the tools so that Ambassador Habib can do the job.''

headline: Harvester's New Name
abstract: Hitching its wagons to a star, of sorts, the International Harvester Company is about to become Navistar International.   That is the name the company, descended from Cyrus McCormick, inventor of the reaper, has chosen to signal its rebirth.   The public was not supposed to know about Navistar just yet. The struggling company, which gave up the rights to its original name when it sold its farm equipment operations to Tenneco Inc., has been keeping the new one under wraps for months.

headline: WHITE HOUSE LIABILITY PLAN
abstract: The Reagan Administration today disclosed its proposals for dealing with what it described as a severe crisis in liability insurance.   The proposals, presented to President Reagan at the White House this week, included limiting punitive damages to ''fair and reasonable'' amounts, preventing ''windfall'' double recoveries and limiting attorneys' fees.

headline: Y.&R./Detroit Wins Auto Club Account
abstract: The Detroit office of Young & Rubicam beat out 14 other agencies to win the Automobile Club of Michigan account billing about $4 million.

headline: SLIGHT PROGRESS IS REPORTED IN EGYPT-ISRAEL BORDER TALKS
abstract: A team of Egyptian officials left Israel today after the latest round of talks to define arbitration terms in the border dispute over Taba, a tiny enclave at the northern tip of the Red Sea that is now controlled by Israel.

headline: PURCHASERS CITE UPTURN IN ACTIVITY LAST MONTH
abstract: The economy began the new year on a strong note, helped by expanded production and a surge in new orders, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.   In its latest survey, which is based on responses from 250 purchasing managers who buy equipment and supplies for industrial companies, the trade association said inventory levels increased and employment rose in January. Vendor deliveries slowed, an indication that demand is picking up, and lead times for production materials expanded, another reflection of increased activity.

headline: Brazil Economic Plan
abstract: President Jose Sarney of Brazil will announce an economic package on Friday aimed at cutting the country's 255 percent annual inflation rate, a presidential spokesman said today.   The measures will include a gradual de-indexation of the economy, the spokesman said.

headline: 9 7/8% Bond Issue By Florida Power
abstract: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $150 million of 9 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due 2016 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The bonds, rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P., are offered at a price yielding 59 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds with a similar maturity.   Proceeds from the sale will be used to redeem 15 7/8 percent bonds that the utility sold in 1981.

headline: Tide Floods Venice On Eve of Carnival
abstract: The third-worst flood tide of the century swamped Venice today on the eve of the opening of its carnival.

headline: Arbitragers Cited in Decline
abstract: The stock market did not fall off of a cliff yesterday, it was pushed.   A principal factor behind the stock market's plunge was an arbitrage strategy used by institutional investors.

headline: Gemayel Meets With Pontiff But No Statement Is Issued
abstract: Pope John Paul II interrupted his Lenten retreat today to meet with Lebanon's beleaguered President, Amin Gemayel.   The meeting was announced suddenly after the Vatican had said on Tuesday that the Pope would not meet with the Maronite Christian leader.

headline: An Indictment in Thrift Case
abstract: The owner of a savings and loan association that figured prominently in Maryland's thrift institution crisis last spring was indicted today on a charge of stealing millions of dollars from it and another savings and loan.   The indictment of Jeffrey A. Levitt, owner of Old Court Savings and Loan, was the first in the investigation of the Maryland thrift situation.

headline: U.S. OIL COMPANIES MAY BE EXEMPTED FROM LIBYA CURBS
abstract: The Administration is considering granting licenses to American oil companies to let them continue to receive some income from Libya after President Reagan's economic sanctions go into effect Saturday, a senior Administration official said today.   He said a high-level State Department and Treasury group was acting on requests from oil companies operating in Libya to exempt them, in effect, from the ban on further business with Libya. The official said the licenses would prevent the Libyans from reaping a ''windfall'' from the assets and income of the companies. Americans Leaving Libya    Under the original sanctions announced by Mr. Reagan on Jan. 7, all Americans and American companies were to cease commercial dealings with Libya by Feb. 1. All Americans, except journalists and those with special humanitarian permission to remain, such as spouses of Libyans, were ordered to leave Libya.

headline: TEXACO AND PENNZOIL SET RESUMPTION OF TALKS
abstract: Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company are scheduled to begin a new round of talks on Monday that could make or break their attempt to negotiate a settlement, sources close to both companies said yesterday.   Monday's meeting, the fourth face-to-face session between the companies, will be held at an undisclosed location amid signs that Pennzoil wants significant progress toward an agreement or else might return the bitter struggle to the courts as early as Thursday.   Texaco said yesterday that the companies had scheduled time to appear before Judge Charles L. Brieant in Federal District Court in White Plains Thursday. Texaco has asked Judge Brieant for protection from a Texas court's award of $10.53 billion plus interest to Pennzoil.

headline: VIABILITY IS SEEN FOR A SLIM CARBIDE
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation will pay a high price for its tough antitakeover defense against the GAF Corporation, analysts said yesterday.   Under the plan, which includes the sale of its consumer businesses and the payout to investors of a substantial portion of the proceeds, Carbide would be transformed into a smaller, debt-laden operation without benefit of the consumer businesses, around which it had built its growth strategy.   But while some analysts viewed the plan as a ''scorched earth'' tactic, many agreed with Union Carbide that it would nonetheless remain viable.   ''They will do all right,'' said William R. Young, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., ''It can survive,'' said another analyst, Leonard Bogner of the First Manhattan Corporation. But he added that it would be primarily a commodity chemicals, plastics and industrial gas company and that it would be ''dramatically leveraged.''

headline: SOME IN COMGRESS FAVOR MORE AID FOR PHILIPPINES
abstract: Congressional leaders said today that American aid to the Philippines was likely to be increased because of the departure of Ferdinand E. Marcos.   But they warned that pressure to reduce the Federal deficit could limit the increase in aid. In addition, some suggested that they might still want restrictions on the distribution of the aid.   Many in Congress applauded the departure of Mr. Marcos and praised President Reagan's role.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 29, 1986
abstract: Companies    Exxon's income rose nearly 27 percent in the fourth quarter, to $1.81 billion, but fell almost 12 percent for the year because of special provisions. Earnings before these items rose 3.5 percent for the year. Chevron's fourth-quarter net rose 38.5 percent.  [ Page D1. ]    U.S. Steel's earnings nearly doubled in the fourth quarter, but sales were flat and the company's basic steel business showed an operating loss. Analysts said U.S. Steel got a big earnings boost from its Marathon Oil subsidiary.  [ D4. ]

headline: Shamrock Layoffs
abstract: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it would lay off 600 employees, or about 5 percent of its 11,500 workers, by May 1, in a ''streamlining of the corporation.'' The Dallas-based company said its board had decided to ''focus the corporation's resources on the oil and gas business,'' and would consider selling the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company in Irving, Tex., and the Diamond Shamrock Coal Company in Lexington, Ky.

headline: Swedes Elect Carlsson To Succeed Palme
abstract: Parliament elected Ingvar Carlsson, a Social Democrat, to succeed Olof Palme as Prime Minister today without any opposing votes.   Mr. Palme was shot dead on a Stockholm street on Feb. 28.

headline: Mack Reiterates 'Outsourcing' Plan
abstract: Mack Trucks Inc. is not likely to reconsider its decision to use outside companies to produce some parts now manufactured at its plant here, a company official said. But it is still too soon to say how many jobs will be lost at the Hagerstown plant once ''outsourcing'' begins, said William McCullough, Mack's vice president of corporate affairs. Mack said last Saturday that it would move its outdated Allentown, Pa., manufacturing operation to Winnsboro, S.C., and outsource some parts made at Hagerstown as a means of cutting costs.

headline: LOS ANGELES: MONEY CENTER
abstract: Itinerant New Yorkers ambling through downtown Los Angeles these days are likely to encounter gleaming new buildings bearing familiar corporate names. Workers recently put the finishing touches, for instance, on a 41-story building for Citicorp. And a few blocks away a 22-story office tower is going up for another New York-based banking giant, the Chase Manhattan Corporation.   The buildings testify to two fundamental changes under way here:   First, Los Angeles is becoming a world-class financial center, eclipsing San Francisco to dominate the West Coast and be a gateway to Asia.   Second, as Los Angeles becomes a scene of more financial activity, New York-based companies are becoming key players.

headline: DO METAL SALES SUBSIDIZE APARTHEID?
abstract: THE political controversy surrounding platinum mirrors the arguments critics raise in protesting American investments in South Africa and domestic sales of the krugerrand.   ''We are opposed unequivocably to increased imports of platinum; the conditions under which black miners mine platinum are just as horrible as those under which they mine gold or diamonds,'' said Ibrahim J. Gassama, a spokesman for the TransAfrica Forum, a Washington organization that demonstrated against krugerrand sales until President Reagan banned them last summer as part of his economic sanctions against South Africa.   ''We would be concerned if any trend leads to increased financial benefits to the South African Government,'' Mr. Gassama said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 20, 1986
abstract: International    The five major industrial nations may try to lower interest rates, U.S. officials said after the meeting in London of the Group of Five. But the countries stopped short of committing themselves, even secretly, to an orchestrated drive of the sort that they began against the dollar last fall, the officials indicated.  [ Page A1. ]

headline: The U.N. Today; March 31, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Two Big Tax Exempts Are Quickly Sold Out
abstract: The first two sizable tax-exempt offerings of the year were well received this week, as a light supply of new issues compensated for the lack of buying by commercial bank investment portfolios.   Underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank submitted the winning bids Tuesday for general obligation bonds totaling $39.7 million for Maine and $29.7 million for Middlesex County, N.J., and said that the bonds were all sold by yesterday afternoon.   The Maine issue, rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, was initially offered with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.35 percent in 1991 and 7.1 percent in 1996. Yields for the Middlesex bonds, rated Aaa/ AA+, were about the same, with a maximum yield of 7.2 percent for bonds due in 1998.

headline: New Top Officer Named by Carbide
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, announcing its plans for management succession, said yesterday that Robert D. Kennedy would be named president and chief executive.   The announcement came as Warren M. Anderson, chairman and chief executive, confirmed his intention to retire when he reaches age 65 in November. Mr. Anderson said he would recommend to the board April 23 that Mr. Kennedy, 53 years old, be named to the posts. Mr. Kennedy will become chairman as well when Mr. Anderson retires.   Mr. Kennedy, who has worked for Carbide for 30 years since he left Cornell as a mechanical engineer, said he felt ''great'' about being chosen as Carbide's top man. He is now president and chief operating officer for chemicals and plastics.

headline: REPUBLIC HEALTH
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the large aerospace and information systems concern, said it had joined a group that last month proposed a $288 million leveraged buyout of the Republic Health Corporation. McDonnell Douglas, with 13 percent, and LeRoy A. Pesch, a Republic director who heads the buyout group, are the largest stockholders in Republic Health, one of the nation's largest health-care services companies. It currently operates 84 facilities in 24 states.

headline: OFFERING BY ROTHSCHILD
abstract: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc. yesterday consummated its plans to convert from a partnership to a publicly held company, as it offered 7.7 million common shares at a price of $20.50 a share.   The offering, which had been expected since last summer, when Rothschild rejected a takeover bid by General Felt Industries, is larger than orginally anticipated.

headline: FLUOR PROFIT OF $6.6 MILLION
abstract: The Fluor Corporation, an engineering, construction and natural resources company, announced net earnings of $6.6 million, or 8 cents a share, for the first quarter ended Jan. 31, compared with a net loss of $32.6 million for the quarter last year.   If not for a gain of $24.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of a 10 percent interest in its holdings in the St. Joe Gold Corporation, Fluor would have reported a loss for the quarter.

headline: Callers Besiege Kodak on Trade-Ins
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company was flooded yesterday with calls from owners of its suddenly obsolete instant camera seeking information about a company exchange offer.   Kodak, charged by Polaroid with infringing on patents, was barred beginning yesterday by a court injunction from making any more instant cameras or film. Since film will not be available, the instant cameras already sold become useless.

headline: WHITE MOVES TO BLOCK OFFER
abstract: White Consolidated Industries moved yesterday to block a tender offer by Electrolux A.B. of Sweden.   White, based in Cleveland and the nation's third-largest appliance maker, has had no official reaction to the $711 million, or $45 a share, offer from Electrolux, Europe's biggest appliance manufacturer.

headline: A HIGH-YIELD OPTION FOR I.R.A.'S
