abstract: FALLING interest rates may be welcome in some quarters, but they bring scant pleasure to people with Individual Retirement Accounts. Most I.R.A. money has gone into certificates of deposit, but the present one-year C.D. yield of about 8 percent has sent many investors in search of higher-yield options. For a growing number, the search is ending with publicly registered limited partnerships, which are riskier than C.D.'s but could produce double-digit compound yields.   ''Many investors equate limited partnerships with tax shelters,'' said Charles Lefkowitz, president of Financial Blueprints Inc., a financial planning firm based in Florham Park, N.J. ''But some limited partnerships are suitable for I.R.A. investors, because they're structured to generate current income.'' William Turchyn Jr., senior vice president and national director of direct investments for E.F. Hutton & Company, said, ''About 25 percent of the money we raise for limited partnerships now winds up in I.R.A.'s.'' In fact, partnerships with a minimum investment of $2,000 or less probably are aimed at I.R.A. investors.

headline: VIOLENCE IN KOREA FOLLOWS BIG RALLEY BY THE OPPOSITION
abstract: A huge anti-Government rally went off peacefully here today, but late tonight violence erupted as a small band of students burned placards and threw stones at riot policemen.   Earlier, tens of thousands of people gathered on the city's main thoroughfare as opposition leaders staged their third rally in recent weeks.   The rally appeared to be the largest anti-Government gathering in Kwangju since troops killed several hundred protesters here in May 1980. Rally organizers said more than 100,000 people took part today, but Government officials put the figure at 20,000 to 30,000. Independent observers gave estimates of 50,000 to 60,000.

headline: IN CREDIT CARDS, ALL THAT GLITTERS...
abstract: WHEN Robert J. Shalhoub set up his New York City accounting practice, he decided to pay a $250 premium for an American Express platinum card, thinking it would give his fledgling business instant prestige. Instead, he found the reaction was mixed. ''Some clients were in awe,'' he recalls, ''but others would say, 'You sucker, you're paying $250 for what?' ''   The so-called ''premium cards'' offer a variety of services that may justify the fee for big spenders or frequent travelers. Mr. Shalhoub, for one, got a personalized, 24-hour toll-free travel service, customized billing privileges, check-cashing services, $500,000 of travel accident insurance and a complimentary membership in the Centurion Club, an international network of 25 private clubs. Beyond that, the platinum card confers on the holder ''unparalleled prestige worldwide,'' as the American Express Company puts it in promotional literature.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 6, 1986
abstract: Markets    The bond rally faltered as prices of long-term Treasury issues fell as much as 3 points before ending the day with losses of more than 2 points. Some analysts saw the downturn as a normal correction that still leaves the market in a strong position. One widely mentioned reason for the setback was a buildup of unsold corporate bonds.  [ Page D1. ]  Treasury-bond futures fell by the daily limit on profit taking at the Chicago Board of Trade.  [ D22. ]    The dollar rose sharply on the rise in interest rates. By one broad measure, it made its biggest one-day advance since 1978. Gold slid 10 cents an ounce, to $342.50, in New York.  [ D22. ]

headline: New Chief Named At Computervision
abstract: James R. Berrett, who resigned last week as president and chief executive of the beleaguered Computervision Corporation, has been succeeded by Robert L. Gable, the vice chairman and chief operating officer.   Last August, Mr. Gable assumed control of daily operations of the maker of computerized design and manufacturing systems, which is based in Bedford, Mass., while Mr. Berrett, who had overseen operations since 1982, was placed in charge of strategic planning.   Mr. Gable, who is 55 years old, had been a director of the company since 1974 and had also been a group vice president of Kidde Inc. from 1966 until last August.

headline: TWO CHARGED IN U.S. FRAUD
abstract: A former engineer at the Northrop Corporation and the head of a California company have been charged with fraud in connection with subcontracts for the Air Force's Stealth program.   The former engineer, William Albert Reinke, was charged today, in a criminal information filed by the United States Attorney, with defrauding Northrop and the Federal Government by causing more than $600,000 in subcontracts to be awarded to RF Engineering, of which he was also president and principal owner.

headline: WALDHEIM SAYS REPORTS ON PAST ARE 'UNFOUNDED'
abstract: Kurt Waldheim told the World Jewish Congress yesterday that published reports linking him to Nazi wartime misconduct were part of a ''unsubstantiated and unfounded'' campaign against him.   In response, the congress issued a statement accusing Mr. Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, of continuing ''a 40-year pattern of falsification and deception.''   In a telex from Vienna to Edgar M. Bronfman, the president of the congress, Mr. Waldheim reiterated his argument that documents that led to the charges had been ''deliberately misinterpreted.''

headline: Bond Prices Continue to Rise
abstract: Bond prices continued to improve yesterday, and ended the day with prices of long-term Treasury issues within about a point of the highest levels reached in early January.   Since the Treasury auctioned $23 billion of notes and bonds last week, investor demand has been good, and absorbed enough of the heavy supply so that securities dealers are not holding larger inventories than they desire. A constant barrage of news reports about lower oil prices continues to attract investors to long-term notes and bonds, government securities dealers said.   ''Lower oil prices are seen as some kind of nirvana for the bond market,'' one trader said. ''You get lower inflation plus the prospect of deficit reduction from the combination of faster economic growth or some kind oil import tax.''

headline: OCCIDENTAL SLASHES CAPITAL SPENDING
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation became the latest oil company to slash its exploration and development budget in the face of plummeting prices, reducing its 1986 expenditures by 25 percent from the 1985 level.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WEST GERMAN OUTPUT
abstract: Industrial production in West Germany rose about 2.5 percent in January from December, despite a lull in the construction sector, the Economics Ministry said today.

headline: Sri Lanka Restores Bandaranaike's Rights
abstract: President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka announced today that he was restoring the political rights of his chief rival, who was barred from political activity more than five years ago.

headline: Manila Hotel Manager Finds The Future Is Suddenly Clear
abstract: The art of surviviving a feared government transition was being practiced all about Manila today At the Manila Hotel, Roman A. Cruz Jr. resigned as chief executive in a pair of letters. The first was addressed to his political patron, President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who appointed him to the job.   The other letter was addressed to Corazon C. Aquino, a brief notice that Mr. Cruz had resigned the job initially granted by ''your predecessor.''

headline: Salvadoran Troops Raid Rebel Forces on Volcano
abstract: Some 2,000 Government troops began an offensive against leftist guerrillas today on the flanks of a volcano in eastern San Vicente Province, military officials and civilians said.   Local residents reached by phone said air force planes began to bomb the volcano, 26 miles southeast of San Salvador, at dawn, with explosions rocking houses in surrounding towns.

headline: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Realigning Top Levels
abstract: LOUIS T. HAGOPIAN, chairman and chief executive officer of N. W. Ayer, has restructured some of his top management to free himself to do a bit of acquiring not only of general agencies but also, more important, of specialty communications companies.   Although the agency has gone to $826 million in billings from $200 million in the decade of Mr. Hagopian's chairmanship, the chief indicated that its domestic growth, particularly in the specialty companies, would have been far better if acquisitions had augmented internal growth.   Probably the biggest single responsibility the chairman has had has been for the headquarters New York office, which billed $560 million last year. That responsibility is going to Jerry J. Siano, 51 years old and the former worldwide creative director. He will fill the new position of president of Ayer New York.

headline: A Vintner's Fall Puzzles Industry
abstract: The dismissal of the president of the Sebastiani Winery has puzzled the industry, and provoked doubts about the direction of one of California's largest and best-known wineries.   Sam Sebastiani, who in his five years at the head of the winery had moved dramatically from low-priced wines toward more delicate and expensive varieties, was forced out by his mother, Sylvia Sebastiani. Mrs. Sebastiani, who is 69 years old, owns the vast majority of the shares of the privately held company.   Mr. Sebastiani, who is 45 years old, spent his last day at the company on Jan. 3, but because the company made no announcement, news was slow in filtering through the industry.   ''We thought he was the winery,'' said Ed Everett, an industry consultant in San Francisco. ''How could he be fired?''

headline: U.S.-Japan War Games
abstract: Japan and the United States will begin the first joint war games involving all branches of their armed forces next week. The chairman of Japan's Joint Staff Council, Gen. Shigehiro Mori, said today that about 150 officers from the United States Navy, Army, Air Force and Marine Corps and 250 officers from the Japanese Maritime, Air and Ground Self-Defense Forces would join the five-day exercise. It will prepare for real joint maneuvers in September, the announcement said.

headline: Options Expansion
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it had decided to expand its successful energy futures business by offering options contracts later this year. The exchange said it would offer an option on its crude oil future contract. If approved by regulators, the option is expected to begin trading by the fall.

headline: JAPAN PLANS TO EXTEND AUTO CURBS
abstract: In a move to ease trade frictions with the United States, Japan announced this morning that it would continue its export restraints on automobiles for a sixth year, beginning in April.   The quota for Japanese automobile exports to the United States will be 2.3 million cars, the same as this year. The quota will expire at the end of March 1987.   Many Japanese officials in the Government and automobile industry hoped the restraints would end this year. But a senior official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said that Japan's $50 billion trade surplus, the United States Congressional elections later this year and fears of surging exports made the continuance necessary.

headline: MANILA SAYS $5.5 MILLION MAY BE IN MARCOS CARGO
abstract: The head of the Central Bank of the Philippines said today that officials here still did not know for certain how much currency might have been on the transport plane that followed Ferdinand E. Marcos into exile in Hawaii.   But the bank governor, Jose B. Fernandez, said that if the 22 crates flown to Hawaii on a United States Air Force plane were identical to the kind of crates confiscated here by authorities last week from a vehicle belonging to a brother of Mr. Marcos's wife, Imelda, they could contain 110 million Philippine pesos, or about $5.5 million.   Mr. Fernandez made the comment in announcing that the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino had begun legal proceedings in the United States to recover assets that may have been illegally exported last week by Mr. Marcos and his party.   ''The Government feels that if there are a lot of pesos in Hawaii, why should they be there?'' Mr. Fernandez said. ''I am under instructions from the Government to recover what can be recovered.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Champion Spark Plug Co., Toledo, Ohio, said the board had postponed action on its first-quarter dividend and would consider possible adjustments at a special meeting Feb. 11.    * Computer Automation Inc., Irvine, Calif., said it was approached by Everett-Charles Test Equipment Inc. in mid-December about a possible merger of the companies and has been engaged in exploratory discussions.

headline: Economic Scene; Lost Standing Of Economists
abstract: IN his presidential address to the American Economic Association this week, Charles F. Kindleberger, Ford International Professor of Economics emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the United States had lost the appetite for providing the world with what he called ''international economic public goods.''   Public goods are goods and services that the entire community benefits from but which no single consumer or consuming country will necessarily pay for. By international economic public goods, Mr. Kindleberger meant open markets in times of glut, supplies in times of acute shortage, steady flows of capital to developing countries, international money, coordination of economic policy and last-resort lending in times of financial crisis.   The implication is that without a nation strong enough and responsible enough to play the role of leader, the international system is in peril, despite the exhilaration of the moment.

headline: TYLENOL MAKER FINDING NEW CRISIS LESS SEVERE
abstract: The announcement that a 23-year-old Peekskill, N.Y., woman died last weekend after taking a cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule has rekindled a crisis for Johnson & Johnson that the company hoped had ended more than three years ago.   Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., is the pharmaceutical giant with a subsidiary, McNeil Consumer Products, that manufactures Tylenol. Johnson & Johnson has often been praised for its response to the 1982 cyanide poisonings of seven Chicago-area Tylenol users and its subsequent rehabilitation of the Tylenol brand.   This time, most industry analysts say, Johnson & Johnson probably will not need to take drastic action to avoid a corporate disaster.

headline: Delay on Plan For Seven-Up
abstract: Pepsico Inc., which had been expected to announce yesterday that it planned to buy the Seven-Up Company, is now likely to announce the purchase today, sources close to the company said yesterday.

headline: C.I.A. IS REPORTED SET TO CHANNEL AID TO CONTRAS
abstract: If Congress approves the military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that President Reagan has requested, the Central Intelligence Agency is ready with a basic plan for providing them with arms and training, according to Administration and Congressional officials.   The officials said Stinger antiaircraft missiles would be high on the C.I.A.'s list of weapons for the insurgents. The weapons would be shipped to Honduras and turned over to the rebels as soon as possible, the officials said.

headline: DOW TOPS 1,600, THEN FALLS BACK
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average moved above the 1,600 level for a brief period yesterday before profit taking and highly sophisticated arbitrage activity pulled it back and gave Wall Street its first loss in three sessions.   Activity in the stock market remained brisk, but Jack Baker, the head trader at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said automatic buying and selling programs coming out of the big brokerage firms again dominated the action and caused wild price swings.   The Dow had been up as much as 9 points in the morning, when it topped the 1,603 mark, but finished at 1,593.23, down 1.04 points.   The blue-chip average, however, was down more than 13 points at one point in the afternoon when the bond market suddenly weakened and when investors apparently became jittery over President Reagan's State of the Union Message last night.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $3.4 billion, to $211.39 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Ex-F.D.I.C. Chairman Said to Form New Firm
abstract: After handling banking crises for the Government as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, William M. Isaac, will now be working on them for the industry.   Though he would not confirm it, Washington lawyers said yesterday that Mr. Isaac plans to announce next week the formation of a consulting firm affiliated with one of Washington's largest law firms, Arnold & Porter, that will help banks deal with their ever more ornery regulators. Mr. Isaac has already joined the firm as a partner.

headline: BISHOP TUTU RETURNS HOME TO BARRAGE OF CRITICISM
abstract: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, returned home today after a visit to the United States to face a barrage of editorial and other criticism from whites angered by his reported comments about his country.   At a news conference, Bishop Tutu said he had no regrets about what he said in the United States.   ''I have said hardly anything in the U.S. that I have not said here,'' the Bishop said at an Anglican priory in a segregated white suburb. ''I am ashamed of absolutely nothing I said on our trip.''

headline: Diamond Crystal
abstract: The Diamond Crystal Salt Company said its chairman, Frederick S. Moore, had received an unsolicited offer from Gabelli & Company to buy all the company's stock outstanding for $32 a share, or a total of about $82 million. Diamond Crystal had no comment on the offer, whichGabelli made on behalf of Gabelli-Rosenthal & Partners.

headline: WALDHEIM FIGURES IN 1948 ARMY LIST
abstract: Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, was identified as a suspected war criminal on lists kept by the United Nations and the United States Army, according to a document in the National Archives.   A 1948 Army document said Mr. Waldheim was wanted by Yugoslavia on murder charges. It does not indicate what evidence, if any, was provided.   Allan Ryan, former director of the Office of Special Investigations at the Department of Justice, a unit that hunts war criminals, said today that the names on the list were often based on unverified accusations.

headline: Tenneco Reduces Capital Spending
abstract: Citing the recent sharp decline in oil prices, Tenneco Inc., the Houston-based oil and gas company, said yesterday that it had reduced its 1986 capital spending budget by 25 percent, to $1.3 billion, from $1.7 billion in 1985. On Wednesday the Atlantic Richfield Company said it had reduced its 1986 capital budget to $2 billion, from $3 billion, because of the monthlong price slide that has shaken the oil industry.   Tenneco's chairman and chief executive, James L. Ketelsen, said the company's exploration and production would be most sharply affected.

headline: U.S. ARMY UNITS TO BUILD 6TH AIRFIELD IN HONDURAS
abstract: In a continuing expansion of military centers in Honduras, United States Army units will begin on Monday to build an airfield, according to an American Army spokesman. It will be the sixth airfield to be built by such units here in the last three years.   The new airfield is one of several indications that the Reagan Administration may be planning a more extensive and lengthy American military presence in Honduras than Administration officials have yet to acknowledge.

headline: U.S. REGULATORS WANT BANKS TO COVER RISKY LOANS BETTER
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board and two other Federal agencies today proposed requiring banks to maintain more financial reserves for risky loans than for safer loans.   The plan to establish a variable standard for bank capital - profits plus money from shareholders - reflects the central bank's concern about mounting third world, energy, agriculture and real estate loans.   It also reflects a concern about the accumulation of more than $100 billion of bank liabilities that do not show up on bank balance sheets, primarily letters of credit, which provide security for large corporate transactions. Under the proposal, these commitments will have to be accounted for the same way loans are.

headline: MINERALS CONCERN
abstract: The International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, the world's largest private producer of phosphate rock and potash, said it had approved an anti-takeover plan involving a rights distribution.

headline: THE LONE STAR STATEKEEPS ITS ALLURE
abstract: Texas banks may be having their troubles, but big banks outside the state still see the Lone Star State as a lush market they would like to enter.   ''It's got some major problems in terribly important sectors, but it's still a very attractive state,'' said Robert R. Douglass, vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation. ''We're not seeking to enter Texas to take advantage of its problems, but if we had the opportunity to be there, we'd take it,'' he said.

headline: Saudis Ready to Come To Kuwait's Defense
abstract: Saudi Arabia declared today that it would come to the defense of Kuwait if the Kuwaitis were attacked by Iran.

headline: BIG BANKS UPGRADE ARGENTINA
abstract: It was only one year ago that American bankers were girding themselves to write off billions of dollars in Argentine loans. But now, one major bank after another is reporting sharply higher profits, thanks in part to the interest earned from those same loans.   In year-end earnings reports released in the last week, four of the nation's largest banks - Chemical, Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty, and Irving Trust - said that in the fourth quarter they placed more than $500 million in Argentine loans back on ''accrual'' status. That meant that the banks resumed reporting interest on the loans. In the next few days, moreover, other multinational banks are expected to announce that they, too, resumed booking profits on their Argentine loans.

headline: OTHERS FOLLOW AS LORENZO CUTS COSTS
abstract: Eastern Airlines' acceptance early today of a $600 million takeover bid from the Texas Air Corporation emphasizes once again how the aggressive, low-cost operating strategy of Texas Air's chairman, Frank Lorenzo, is contributing to the transformation of the airline industry.   Even the fear of that strategy has had its impact. Unions were successful in opposing his bids last year for Trans World Airlines and Frontier, citing his wage cuts at Continental Airlines, a unit of Texas Air. But they nonetheless had to agree to some pay cuts with other acquirers.

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; SELLING YOUR HOME WITHOUT AN AGENT
abstract: ON Manhattan's upper East Side, Brad Holbrook is offering to sell a ''very brite 1-BR'' apartment with ''rvr vu.'' Real estate agents need not apply. Like many sellers, Mr. Holbrook has eschewed the services of a broker in favor of the Sunday classifieds and his telephone-answering machine.  In New York, the standard broker's commission is 6 percent of a property's selling price. Some agents, if pressed, may shave a point or more off this percentage; many will not. For their part, real estate brokers provide a pool of potential buyers, while screening out browsers and those who cannot afford the price.

headline: REAGAN PRAISES 2-PARTY-SYSTEM OF PHILIPPINES
abstract: President Reagan reserved judgment today on reports of fraud by supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippine election, and called on both sides to ''work together to form a viable government.''   Speaking with regional editors, Mr. Reagan said: ''In spite of all these charges, there is at the same time the evidence of a strong two-party system now in the islands.''   He expressed hope that President Marcos and his opponent, Corazon C. Aquino ''can come together to make sure the government works.''   White House officials said Mr. Reagan would comment on the situation in a news conference Tuesday after conferring with Senator Richard G. Lugar, the head of a group of American election observers. The Senator returned from Manila today.

headline: Indians Assail Union Carbide
abstract: More than 1,000 protesters shouted slogans today near Parliament, demanding seizure of the Union Carbide Corporation's property in India and additional help for victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.   ''Killer Carbide quit India!'' yelled the demonstrators, who included more than 50 Bhopal survivors.

headline: PATENTS; RECTANGULAR CONTAINERS
abstract: Juris M. Mednis received a patent this week for a package of rectangular containers that are offered as substitutes for bottles.

headline: RECORD U.S. TRADE DEFICIT
abstract: The deficit in the nation's broadest measure of foreign trade hit a record $117.7 billion last year, the Government reported today.   The Commerce Department said the deficit in the country's current account, which includes trade in merchandise and American investments overseas, surged 9.6 percent above the previous record deficit of $107.4 billion in 1984.   A surplus in investment earnings, $21.4 billion, was wiped out by a record $124.3 billion merchandise trade deficit and $14.8 billion in transfer payments such as foreign aid, producing the $117.7 billion current account deficit.

headline: COFFEE PRICE BOOM STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
abstract: Jose Francisco Jacinto chose to buy a house and add 90 acres to his property, while Motomu Shimota finished building his home and then bought three new cars, a color television, a personal computer and a radio telephone.   The recent rise in world coffee prices - from around $1.45 per pound for the spot price of Brazilian coffee last October to $2.30 in January - has also meant a windfall for tens of thousands of small coffee planters across four Brazilian states, enabling some to make long-postponed trips abroad and others simply to pay off their debts.   The story is even told that the coffee farmers of Sao Gabriel da Palha in Espirito Santo State, who in the past would hire an old bus for their annual 400-mile pilgrimage to the shrine of Our Lady of Aparecida, this year chartered a plane to take them to Rome.   Yet beyond the cheerful spending spree that has swelled commerce as well as inflation in provincial towns such as Franca, 180 miles north of Sao Paulo, the brief boom has so far provoked as much nervousness as celebration in Brazil's coffee industry.

headline: Eastern's Fares Cut Up to 75%
abstract: Eastern Airlines cut fares by up to 75 percent today, including some $89 flights to Florida, fighting back against low-cost competitors. At the same time, USAir and People Express Airlines cut prices, intensifying a nationwide fare war.

headline: U.S. SEEKS TO CUT ROLE IN INSURING PENSION BENEFITS
abstract: The Reagan Administration is developing proposals to reduce the role of the Federal Government in insuring private pension benefits paid to millions of Americans.   At present, there is no private insurance of pensions. Under Federal law, most pension plans must carry Federal insurance. Administration officials said the switch to private insurance would not harm workers or retirees.

headline: GENSTAR UP ABOVE BID BY IMASCO
abstract: Responding to a takeover bid over the weekend, shares of the Genstar Corporation reached a high of $41 in heavy trading yesterday before ending the day at $39.75 - well above the offering price of $38.66.   Traders said rumors circulated throughout the day that Imasco Ltd., the big Canadian cigarette producer, might soon increase its takeover bid for Genstar, already close to $1.8 billion in cash.   Rumors were also strong, traders said, that a new bidder for Genstar might soon emerge, although others said the likelihood of a sweetener from Imasco seemed more realistic.

headline: Greengage-Sun Line
abstract: Greengage Associates, which served as agency to Sun Line Cruises from 1978 to 1981 and then lost the client to AC&R Advertising, has just won it back. Billings should be $1.5 million.

headline: Guinness Rebid
abstract: Guinness P.L.C., the brewing giant, raised its bid for the Distillers Company to the equivalent of $3.5 billion, coupling the offer with a revision aimed at meeting antitrust objections to the deal. Its previous $3.2 billion offer was to be the subject of an antitrust investigation by the British Government. The new bid tops the Argyll Group P.L.C.'s offer of $3.3 billion.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM BOTHA TALK TO M.P.'S IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Following are excerpts from President P. W. Botha's speech to Parliament today:   CAPE TOWN, Jan. 31 (Reuters) - Following are excerpts from President P. W. Botha's speech to Parliament today:   In a world where freedom is becoming increasingly rare, our country today is a symbol of the expansion of freedom, of the upholding of freedom of religion and free enterprise, sustained by equal rights before an independent judiciary. The Republic of South Africa is therefore a powerful bastion against Communist domination and enslavement.   Yet the campaign against the Republic of South Africa from abroad has greatly intensified. Attempts are continually being made to belittle each step forward and to brand all Government initiatives as merely cosmetic, while conditions more appalling than those ostensibly prevailing in South Africa are sanctimoniously tolerated elsewhere.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied-Signal Inc.'s Signal Energy Systems Inc., Hampton, N.H., will develop, own and operate a $30 million cogeneration plant for Metropolitan State Hospital in Norwalk, Calif.    * American Honda Motor Co., a unit of Honda Motor Co. Ltd.,, said it had raised prices 3.59 percent on its 1986 Honda division automobiles that are sold in the U.S.    * Becton, Dickinson & Co., Paramus, N.J., said it intends to divest itself of its Endevco division and had retained First Boston Corp. to assist.

headline: Gulf Bid Opposed
abstract: The board of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. unanimously recommended today that shareholders reject the Gulf Canada Corporation's $1.2 billion (Canadian) bid for control of the Toronto-based company. In a statement, Hiram Walker, which controls a vast array of liquor, resource and utility companies, criticized the Gulf offer as ''a coercive attempt to pressure shareholders into a hasty decision to sell their Hiram Walker shares.''

headline: POLES DISCOVER IT'S NOT 1948 ANYMORE
abstract: The idea was simple: an international convention of artists and scientists who would come to Poland this week to talk about world peace, and in so doing echo a conference of intellectuals held 37 years ago in Wroclaw. At the Wroclaw gathering Pablo Picasso presented his dove of peace and Albert Einstein sent a letter of greetings.   ''Early last year a few of us realized that 1986 would be the U.N. Year of Peace,'' said Marian Podkowinski, a foreign affairs specialist for Polish newspapers. ''We recalled the Wroclaw meeting and the impact it made in the world, and from our discussions came the concept of the Congress of Intellectuals for the Peaceful Future of the World.''

headline: SOVIET ASSERTS RECOGNITION OF AQUINO RULE IS AUTOMATIC
abstract: The Soviet Union, which recently indicated support for President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, said today that its recognition of President Corazon C. Aquino was automatic.   Deputy Foreign Minister Georgi M. Korniyenko told a news conference that Moscow maintained relations with the Philippines regardless of who was in power and did not need to take any steps to show it accepted Mrs. Aquino.

headline: Hanson-Imperial
abstract: Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson Trust P.L.C., said he would write to the chairman of Imperial Group P.L.C., Geoffrey Kent, suggesting an immediate meeting that he hoped would result in Imperial's recommending acceptance of Hanson's bid of $:1.8 billion - about $2.5 billion.Lord Hanson made his remarks at Hanson Trust's meeting where the bid was approved.

headline: Texaco Unit's Stock Accepted
abstract: A Federal judge yesterday accepted more than $1 billion worth of common stock in Texaco Inc.'s Canadian subsidiary as adequate security for the company to appeal a multibillion-dollar judgment in favor of the Pennzoil Company in a Texas state court.   Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant, sitting in White Plains, approved Texaco's proposal to use 65 million shares of Texaco Canada, whose stock is publicly traded, to meet his requirement that Texaco provide $1 billion in security to appeal its legal battle with Pennzoil.

headline: Ralston Purina
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company said its board had adopted a new program to repurchase up to five million shares of the company's common stock.

headline: South African Debt Revision
abstract: South Africa's lead bankers will propose to the rest of the country's creditors certain changes in a debt-rescheduling agreement reached last month, industry sources in London said.

headline: Copytele Gains Display Patent
abstract: Copytele Inc., a three-year-old high-technology company based on Long Island, said in a statement Friday that it had been awarded a patent for a flat-screen display device that could reduce the size of computers and other equipment using cathode-ray tubes.

headline: THE BEARS BET AGAINST COMMODORE
abstract: DESPITE the popularity of its inexpensive home computers, Commodore International Ltd. has been badly wounded in the industry's marketing wars - and some professional traders are betting that the wounds may prove fatal if the company's vaunted Amiga does not pan out.   ''My gut is that they're going to hit the wall,'' said one analyst, who asked not to be identified.   Other Commodore watchers - some of whom had sold Commodore short and want the stock to sink - offered similar comments. ''I have serious doubts that they'll make it to Christmas '86,'' said a money manager with a short position in Commodore stock.

headline: CONSUMER FUND URGED
abstract: The California Supreme Court, in a ruling today, suggested that unclaimed refunds from a class action suit filed in 1978 against Levi Strauss & Company might be used to set up a consumer trust fund, which would engage in lobbying and education on consumer issues. Attorneys said establishment of a consumer fund was a rarely used but growing means of distributing the awards in class action suits, which have a large number of claimants but relatively small individual awards.

headline: MARKETS FALL ON GROUP OF 5'S INACTION
abstract: The financial markets yesterday registered their disappointment that the weekend meeting of the so-called Group of Five in London had yielded no commitment to cut interest rates.   Prices for stocks and bonds were down from Friday. And with no sign that the five leading industrialized nations that make up the group were planning to push the dollar down much further, currencies and financial futures traded in narrow ranges, except for the British pound, which dropped sharply against other currencies as the price for North Sea oil fell to less than $20 a barrel.   Market participants described the meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the United States, Japan, West Germany, France and Britain as a ''non-event'' endorsing a status quo position on exchange rates and interest rates. Although it had been, in the words of one futures dealer, ''transparently improbable'' that the meeting would lead to a coordinated attack on interest rates, securities prices rose at the end of last week in the hope that Japanese and French calls for such a step would be heeded.

headline: PERES SAYS HE'LL FOSTER PALESTINIAN SELF-RULE
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that he was considering measures to promote self-rule among Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories.   ''We shall keep the door to peace open and enable Palestinians to assume responsibilities as they wish to,'' he said in an interview at his home.   The Israeli leader's comments came a week after King Hussein of Jordan ended efforts to work out a joint strategy with the Palestine Liberation Organization for Middle East peace talks.   In the interview, Mr. Peres outlined steps that Israel would take, or was considering, to enhance the ability of the 1.3 million Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip to more easily express their political views and to play a more active role in administering their affairs. The Peres Government has previously advanced such an approach, with relatively few specifics, under the name of ''devolution.''

headline: BATTLE RAGES FOR 10TH DAY NEAR OIL PORT IN SOUTH IRAQ
abstract: Heavy fighting raged for a 10th day in the strategic Fao peninsula south of here today as Iraq tried to repulse what appears to be Iran's most serious offensive in the five-and-a-half-year-old war.   Iran's success last week in seizing a swath of southern Iraq has sent a wave of consternation and fear through the Persian Gulf emirates and other Arab governments that are backing Iraq.   As has been the case throughout the war, the two sides issued conflicting claims of sweeping victories and of thousands of enemy casualties.

headline: Bonner Goes to Hospital; To Get Bypass Today
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident, entered a hospital today for open heart surgery, and her family said she was worried because she had not heard from her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, in more than two weeks.   Miss Bonner, 62 years old, waved to reporters but made no comment as she entered Massachusetts General Hospital with her mother, Ruth Bonner, and her son, Alexei I. Semyonov.

headline: HUSSEIN-ARAFAT RIFT SAID TO AID P.L.O. UNITY
abstract: The breakdown of the peace effort between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat has improved the chances of healing the rift inside the Palestine Liberation Organization and improving the P.L.O.'s relations with Syria, according to Palestinian officials and reports by Arab press organizations.   ''The farther Arafat moves away from Amman, the closer he becomes to his opponents in the Palestinian guerrilla movement,'' a Palestinian source said here today.   The source said feelers had already been sent out in an effort to start a dialogue within the P.L.O. about closing Palestinian ranks. The Marxist Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, apparently with backing from the Soviet Union, is trying to act as a go-between in contacts between Mr. Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and rival guerrilla factions.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS KNEW MARCOS WAS LEAVING WITH MONEY
abstract: American officials in the Philippines were aware that Ferdinand E. Marcos was taking currency with him when he left Clark Air Base for Hawaii, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The presence of the money was revealed in preliminary inventories and became a source of consternation to the United States even before Mr. Marcos arrived in Hawaii, an official said.   Officials also said weapons had been collected from the Marcoses and their party before their departure. An official said the weapons included small arms, such as pistols and rifles.

headline: PAINE WEBBER CITES 20 STOCKS
abstract: WITH the start of the second quarter near, Paine Webber Inc. has compiled a list of 20 stocks it finds attractive for potential price gains over the next six to 12 months.   ''We picked stocks where we believe the value is good and the fundamentals are reasonably strong,'' Edward M. Kerschner, chairman of the investment policy committee, said yesterday.   He added that, thanks to the recent sharp drop in interest rates, he was more bullish about prospects for equities than at any time since the beginning of the bull market in August 1982.   ''We now believe the odds are 4 to 1 in favor of stocks outperforming bonds in the months ahead,'' Mr. Kerschner said. ''That represents a big reversal from our thinking back in June 1984, when the odds heavily favored bonds.''

headline: British Aerospace
abstract: Four American airlines have ordered 24 aircraft worth $135 million from British Aerospace Inc., the British company said. The company's executive vice president, Dewi Rowlands, said that Pacific Southwest Airlines had exercised a $65 million option to buy four 146-200 jetliners. Pacific Southwest currently operates 20 of the British aircraft.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV SPEECH ON ARMS
abstract: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address tonight, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:   Several days ago the United States staged yet another nuclear explosion. It is clear to all of us that its timing was by no means accidental. The blast was staged on the eve of the ending of the Soviet Union's unilaterally declared moratorium. It was learned yesterday that in the next few days, in the near future, the United States intends to set off yet another nuclear device.   Soviet people, just as people of good will in all countries, are incensed by these actions of the United States. They write about this in their letters to the party's Central Committee and request that an assessment be made of the situation. They ask how all this should be understood. What conclusions should be drawn from this? Why did the United States take such a step? How does our country's leadership intend to act in these conditions?

headline: MARXIST'S GREAT LEAP: CAPTIVITIY TO CELEBRITY
abstract: They call him Joma, and women bring handkerchiefs or scraps of paper to him for his autograph.   Jose Maria Sison, the founder and former chairman of the Communist Party of the Philippines - titles he acknowledged this week after being released by President Corazon C. Aquino from more than eight years in detention - has become a celebrity in two days of freedom.   ''Wherever I go I am overwhelmed by the warm reception given to me,'' he said at a party Friday night before dashing off to appear on a 90-minute television talk show. One of the program's sponsors was McDonald's. Another was Spam.

headline: USING COMPUTERS TO PLAY THE MARKET
abstract: WHILE most investors continue to rely on brokers - and intuition - for their stock picks, many larger investors are turning to personal computers to tap electronic libraries for stock market information. In most cases, all that is needed is a modem, the device that allows computers to communicate over telephone lines.   ''The main benefit of these computer services is their timeliness, the ability to obtain current news,'' said Thomas A. Meyers, president of the American Association of Microcomputer Investors and the author of a new book on using the data bases. ''Now when someone gives you a tip, you can actually turn somewhere and find out right away what's happened to that company recently.''

headline: MANILA OPENS INQUIRY ON GRAVES
abstract: The Aquino Government announced today that it is investigating reports of mass graves containing the bodies of foes of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos or his allies.   Jose Diokno, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Human Rights, said his committee had evidence of such mass graves.

headline: GATX Gets Another Offer
abstract: The GATX Corporation said today that it had received an unsolicited bid of $40 a share, or a total of $514.4 million, from a group led by Adler & Shaykin, a New York-based investment house. GATX, the Chicago-based company that leases rail cars and aircraft, declined to comment in detail.

headline: BRAZILIAN LEADER IN DARING GAMBLE
abstract: A year after becoming Brazil's first civilian ruler in two decades, President Jose Sarney has for the first time seized the political initiative by introducing ing a daring package of economic measures aimed at ending the country's inflation.   Coming at a time of growing dissatisfaction with the Government's performance, the so-called zero inflation plan decreed Friday is expected to be decisive in determining how long Mr. Sarney will serve in office.   Chosen originally to be Vice President, Mr. Sarney took over last March when the President-elect, Tancredo Neves, fell ill and died without being sworn in. Since he and Mr. Neves were picked by an Electoral College, a constituent assembly to be elected this November will fix the date of the next presidential elections.

headline: BAKER'S DEBT PLAN STARTS TO TAKE HOLD
abstract: Progress on the debt crisis came on several fronts, and although he was not a participant, the presence of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was keenly felt. The World Bank approved $1.5 billion in new loans to Latin debtors by the end of April, its largest single commitment in so short a time. The United States also dangled a multibillion-dollar carrot in front of the Inter-American Development Bank, saying it would increase its support if the lending agency adopted the proper lending policies. The new loans appear to be right in line with Mr. Baker's plan to solve the problem of heavily indebted developing countries by spurring their economies. Separately, the I.M.F. said it would set up a $3 billion loan pool for the poorest nations.   Mexico downgraded its loan needs to $4 billion, the level it was requesting before oil prices plunged. The estimate, coming after warnings that Mexico would need as much as $10 billion, was a pleasant surprise. Mexico says its trade position has improved.

headline: WHAT'S NEW WITH BREAKFAST
abstract: ON a typical day, 89 percent of Americans eat breakfast. At least, that is the figure that keeps turning up in surveys run by M.R.C.A. Information Services, which regularly measures consumer trends for manufacturers and marketers of grocery products.   The percentage of eaters has not changed much in the last few decades, but where -and what - they eat is changing radically. ''We're seeing breakfast become a more important meal in America,'' said Ted Balestreri, president of the National Restaurant Association. ''Americans have become more health conscious and there is a greater emphasis on lighter meals. A nutritious breakfast fits in perfectly with these trends.''

headline: Tighter Rules In Repo Deals
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a regulation requiring disclosure of details of repurchase agreements.   In certain cases, the commission said, it will require disclosure of the firms with which the agreements are arranged as well as information about the maturity of the agreements, the kind of securities involved and their market value.

headline: U.S. Delegates Attend Morocco Celebrations
abstract: An American delegation led by William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, attended the 25th anniversary celebration of the rule of King Hassan II today, American officials said.   American-Moroccan relations cooled after the king signed a treaty of union with Libya in 1984.

headline: Dow Jones Net Up
abstract: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that it had earned $40.9 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985, up 18.9 percent from $34.4 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Cambodia Rebel Dispute Reported Near an End
abstract: An attempt by a dissident faction to overthrow the leaders of a major Cambodian rebel organization is faltering, apparently for lack of support from Cambodian exiles and their international backers, according to Cambodian guerrillas and Thai officials.   A spokesman for the group, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, the larger of two non-Communist organizations battling to oust the Vietnamese from Cambodia, said today that a monthlong public power struggle between the dissidents and the front's leader and founder, Son Sann, was likely to be resolved ''very soon.''   Sangwar de Lopez, who represents the National Liberation Front in Washington, but who has been in Thailand for the last two months to try to mediate the dispute, said in an interview today that Mr. Son Sann had met this week with Gen. Sak Supsakhan, a leader of the front's guerrilla army, and that the talks had gone well.

headline: SCHISMS AND LANDMARK BATTLES
abstract: Not since the Battle of Britain has control over air space generated so much conflict. The prospect of developers buying air rights to pile them into ever taller buildings has divided church congregations, most notably St. Bartholomew's, and caused neighborhoods, including the Upper East Side, to seek landmark status.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Poland Will Permit American Wife to Stay
abstract: The Polish authorities who threatened to expel Donna Sue Kersey, an American, relented today and granted her a residence permit, allowing her to remain with her Polish husband.   Miss Kersey, 32 years old, from Ashland, Ky., had been due to leave today with her year-old daughter, Daniela, leaving her husband behind.

headline: TAX PLAN ON MUNICIPAL BONDS SAID TO SNARL MANY PROJECTS
abstract: Plans for large construction projects by state and local governments around the country are being disrupted by provisions in the Federal tax bill, approved by the House last month, which severely restrict sales of municipal bonds, government officials and securities dealers say.   Financing for some major capital projects for sewers, roads and school buildings has been postponed since the start of the year. And local government officials report that restrictions on cooperative ventures with private businesses are complicating efforts to attract new businesses and stimulate local economies.   Although the House bill to overhaul the nation's tax system is not law, it has already forced changes because provisions covering sales of bonds whose interest is not subject to Federal income tax would be applied retroactively to Jan. 1, 1986.   Lobbying has already begun in the Senate Finance Committee to change that date and other aspects of the House bill. But if the Senate accepts the House version, local governments that disregard the House's restrictions -and the investors who buy their tax-exempt bonds - could find that interest on the bonds is taxable beginning from the date of issuance.

headline: DENATIONALIZATION FOR FRANCE
abstract: Some of the best-known companies in French industry and banking will shortly be coming onto the auction block if, as the polls predict will happen, France's right-wing opposition alliance wins next Sunday's parliamentary election.   That alliance has pledged to sell back to private investors the major industrial groups and banks nationalized by President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists in 1981, when they came to power committed to ''a rupture with capitalism.''   The conservative alliance also plans to sell off other banks and enterprises nationalized by earlier governments. Historic New Commitment   In fact, the denationalization pledge represents a historic new commitment by the French right to economic deregulation that reverses a centuries' old tradition of state involvement in industry and finance.   ''Our aim is to change the course of French economic history,'' says Alain Juppe, the economic spokesman for the opposition alliance, which consists of Jacques Chirac's Rally for the Republic and the Union for French Democracy, led by former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

headline: Boesky Holds 4.3% Of Carbide's Stock
abstract: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said he had retained 1,233,776 common shares of the Union Carbide Corporation, or 4.3 percent of its shares outstanding after the completion of Carbide's self-tender offer. On Jan. 9, the Connecticut-based chemical concern completed a partial exchange offer of $85 in bonds and cash per share for 55 percent of its stock, which blocked a hostile bid by the GAF Corporation.

headline: THE MAN WHO KNOWS WHAT EVERYONE'S DRINKING
abstract: SUCCESSFUL men often enjoy rehashing their youthful shortcomings - it puts their later achievements in an even more impressive light. Take Marvin Shanken. He loves to recall that he finished last in his class at the University of Miami back in the 1960's. It is a dubious distinction that is easy for him to admit - he has not been last at much of anything since.   Marvin R. Shanken is president of M. Shanken Communications Inc., a rambunctious little publishing company that seemed to come out of nowhere a decade ago to become one of the hottest phenomena in the liquor business since bathtub gin.   Like most privately held companies, M. Shanken Communications does not disclose overall figures, but Mr. Shanken says that it had its first seven-figure month last May and that ''we've never had a year when we haven't grown 50 percent. Some years it's been 100 percent.''

headline: CHICAGO MAGAZINE
abstract: WTTW-TV, the public television station in Chicago, said it was offering for sale Chicago magazine, which began as a program guide and grew into a profitable monthly publication.

headline: SPLITTING THE ASSETS FAIRLY IN DIVORCE
abstract: THE advent of no-fault laws has transformed the American way of divorce. In the old days, couples who wished to part had to prove that one of them had ''sinned,'' and usually the sinner paid.   But no-fault divorce, which was designed to eliminate much of the acrimony and sham testimony that once took place in court, changed the rules. The divorce process no longer focuses on ''who did what'' so much as ''who gets what.'' Virtually every state, including New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, has adopted some form of equitable distribution law. These statutes are based on the premise that marriage is an economic partnership, and that property acquired during a marriage should be divided in a way that recognizes the contributions of both parties - homemaking services, for example, as well as monetary support.

headline: PATENTS; New Thermometer
abstract: An optical fiber thermometer, made of a single crystal aluminum oxide, was patented this week by Ray R. Dils of Vancouver, Wash. He assigned patent 4,576,486 to the Commerce Department, the parent agency of the National Bureau of Standards. Mr. Dils is a former staff member of the bureau. Tests show the invention should prove useful for measurement and control of high temperatures in gas turbines and internal combustion engines, as well as in chemical processes.

headline: Glut Economy
abstract: To the Editor:   I was sorry to read that the economy is suffering from a glut (''Waking Up to the Glut Economy,'' Dec. 8). However, I have a solution.

headline: G.M. Allison Unit In Pratt Venture
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that its Allison Gas Turbine division had formed a joint venture with the Pratt & Whitney unit of the United Technologies Corporation to develop propane engine and propulsion systems. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Allison Gas said a demonstration propulsion system would be produced for commercial and military transport markets in the 1990's.

headline: BILL TO SHUT WEAKENED BANKS SEEN
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee will vote out a bill this year with a provision giving Federal agencies the power to close weak banks and savings and loan associations before they fail, the committee's chief of staff predicted today.   The agencies are now required to close a bank or thrift institution when it becomes insolvent. They then can liquidate it or find a merger partner. Under the new proposal, regulators would receive broad powers giving them the right to liquidate the assets of hundreds of weakened institutions.

headline: U.S. and Greece Fail To Reach Base Accord
abstract: The United States and Greece failed today to agree on the future of American military bases in Greece after the current agreement expires in 1988.   But Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and Secretary of State George P. Shultz described their talks in glowing terms, holding out prospects for major improvement. Mr. Shultz said there had been ''a real turn'' in relations.

headline: AFGHAN WAR, AFTER 6 YEARS, BECOMES A SOVIET FACT OF LIFE
abstract: After six years, the Afghan war has begun coming home.   The outlines may be hazy - the size of the Soviet force, the scale of the fighting, the casualties and the Western reports of Soviet atrocities are not widely known here, or are dismissed as Western propaganda. Yet in conversations with Russians the war has become more familiar and tangible.   Although the Soviet Union has made no statistics public, hundreds of thousands of Soviet youths, most of them draftees, are known to have gone and returned from the dusty and dangerous mountains to the south. Thousands have been wounded and killed. Some have returned crippled, some troubled.

headline: Investing Advice
abstract: To the Editor:   So-called incentive- or performance-based fees for investment advisers are long overdue (''Another 'May Day' Worries the Market,'' Investing, Dec. 22). In this age of index funds, there is absolutely no reason for plan sponsors to pay high fees for sub-par performance.

headline: Burlington To Sell Unit
abstract: Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textile company, will sell its Domestics division to J. P. Stevens & Company for an undisclosed amount.   The division manufactures sheets, towels, pillowcases and accessories.

headline: SHULTZ, IN ATHENS, CONDEMNS TERROR
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz publicly and privately urged the Greek Government today to take a sterner line against what he called ''the insidious threat of terrorism.''   Warning that the overall state of relations would have a direct impact on tourist travel and other economic ties, Mr. Shultz sought backing from the Greeks for the American military action against Libya earlier this week.   The Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou avoided taking sides in a statement issued just before Mr. Shultz's arrival here on Tuesday night, but today, Mr. Papandreou's Socialist Party, known as Pasok, sharply condemned the United States for its military moves.

headline: NEW ILLINOIS ISSUE TOTALS $200 MILLION
abstract: Despite the uneasiness of issuers and investors, market conditions remained firm enough for a $200 million issue of Illinois general obligation refunding bonds to be offered through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.   Yields range from 4.50 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.50 percent in 1991, 6.40 percent in 1996, 6.90 percent in 2001, 7.15 percent in 2006 and 7.20 percent in 2009. The tax-exempt bonds, backed by the state's full faith and credit, are rated triple-A by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.   Proceeds from the sale will be used to refund bonds sold from 1981 to 1984 with coupons as high as 12 percent.

headline: LONDON'S TAXI ELITE PROTESTS, WITH STYLE
abstract: Stanley Roth hardly sounds like a disgruntled worker. ''This trade has given me everything I want in life,'' the 49-year-old Londoner said. ''I'm a free man. There's no boss looking over my shoulder. I earn a comfortable living, and I travel and talk to interesting people.''   Yet Mr. Roth was one of more than 2,000 taxicab drivers who on Jan. 2 took part in a four-mile-long protest caravan that wound through the streets of the city, highlighting the first job action by London cab drivers in 80 years.

headline: SHCHARANSKY TO BE RELEASED IN A BERLIN EXCHANGE TODAY
abstract: Swans and ducks paddled among chunks of ice in the Havel River under the green metal spans of the Glienicke Bridge today. Occasionally, an American or French military vehicle would rumble across the bridge from Potsdam, making a seemingly effortless transit from a Soviet command post behind the Berlin wall to the American sector of West Berlin.   On Tuesday at about noon, if there are no last-minute hitches, Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident, and three Germans accused of spying for the West will arrive at the Potsdam side of the snow-dusted Glienicke Bridge and be inspected by Francis J. Meehan, the United States Ambassador to East Germany.   On the American side of the divided bridge, Wolfgang Vogel, a dapper East Berlin lawyer, will check the identities of five Warsaw Pact intelligence agents, who will be driven to the wintry site in United States Mission vehicles.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 9, 1986
abstract: Markets    Stock prices plunged. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped a record 39.10 points, to 1,526.61, shedding nearly 2.5 percent of its value. Trading totaled 180.3 million shares in the fifth-busiest day in history, and stocks were down an average of 90 cents. Analysts decided that the economy was too strong for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates further.  [ Page A1. ]    Treasury bond yields rose sharply after the December employment data came out showing the economy entering the new year on a firm footing without the need for extra stimulus from an easier Federal Reserve monetary policy.  [ D1. ]  Average yields for bank investors fell in the latest week.  [ D17. ]

headline: TAX AMNESTY STIRS DOUBTS
abstract: Tax amnesty probably would not produce the windfall predicted by some of its advocates, according to Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. Supporters of such a program have estimated it would prompt the payment of as much as $20 billion in back taxes owed to the Government.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 8, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law -Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: WOODSIDE PLANT TURNED INTO CONDOMINIUMS UNITS
abstract: Alex Blau does not own property in Manhattan but the higher that prices rise for co-ops and condominiums in Manhattan, the happier he is. Mr. Blau builds for people priced out of the Manhattan market.   ''Hopefully the young people will discover us,'' Mr. Blau said.   He is one of the developers of Queens Landmark, a 63-unit building at 62-10 Woodside Avenue, which he believes is the only industrial-to-condominium renovation in Woodside.   The condominium units sell for an average of $180 a square foot - ranging from $360,000 for a 1,795-square-foot penthouse with terrace to $117,000 for an angular, 647-square-foot one-bedroom unit on the first floor. To some Woodsiders, the prices sound alarmingly high, but in Manhattan, the price of most new condominiums begins at $300 a square foot.

headline: FUEL SAVING NOW ENTRENCHED
abstract: The twin oil shocks of 1973 and 1979 have caused American business and consumers to make such great strides in conserving energy that falling oil prices are not likely to lure the nation into reverting to its wastrel ways.   In fact, conservation has become so built into the country's infrastructure that the economy could become even more energy-efficient in the years ahead, according to economists, corporate officials and energy experts. And this progress, they say, could position the economy to reap an extra bonus from tumbling oil prices.   ''Since 1973, the economy has become significantly more energy-efficient,'' said Michael D. Smolinski, director of world oil service at Data Resources Inc., an economics consulting firm. The Department of Energy calculates that the amount of energy consumed to produce each dollar of gross national product has fallen by about 26 percent since 1973. Measured the same way, oil consumption has shrunk by about 33 percent.

headline: U.S. QUIETLY ASKS MIDDLE EAST AND EUROPE FOR MORE SECURITY FOR DIPLOMATS
abstract: The United States, concerned about the possibility of Libyan acts of revenge against Americans abroad, has privately asked Western European and Middle East nations to increase their security for American diplomats, Administration officials said today.   The statement came a day after several Western European governments, including Italy, Britain, West Germany and Austria, said they had already begun stepping up security around American Embassies and installations as well as airports.   Meanwhile, the State Department asked legislators to ''reassess'' planned trips to the Middle East over Easter in view of the possible dangers there. United States military installations also increased security because of potential terrorist attacks.

headline: QUOTRON EXPECTS BOARD TO REJECT CITICORP BID
abstract: Quotron Systems Inc. said last night that its directors would probably reject the $19-a-share cash offer made by Citicorp.   Quotron apparently saw a number of obstacles to a successful merger, quite apart from the question of price. These included unfavorable reactions from some of its largest customers.

headline: Malawi Dissolves Cabinet
abstract: President Kamuzu Banda has dissolved his 13-member Cabinet and personally taken charge of the Government, the semiofficial Malawi press agency reported today.

headline: Haiti Asks Extradition Of Police Chief in Brazil
abstract: Haiti has requested the extradition from Brazil of the former police chief of Port-au-Prince, Col. Albert Pierre, who has been accused of murder, torture and other human rights abuses.   Colonel Pierre, who took asylum in the Brazilian Embassy in Port-au-Prince days after President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled Haiti on Feb. 7, was given a safe-conduct out of the country and was sent by Brazilian authorities to the island of Fernando de Noronha, off Brazil's northeast coast.

headline: PHILIPPINES MOVES TO RECOVER MONEY MARCOS TOOK OUT
abstract: The new Government of the Philippines moved in Federal District Court in Hawaii today to recover millions of dollars in currency taken by Ferdinand E. Marcos and his party when they left the country last week.   In an agreement worked out in Honolulu before the start of a court hearing today, lawyers representing the United States Customs Service agreed that on Friday, they would provide the Philippine Central Bank with an accounting of the currency contained in 22 crates that were flown to Hawaii last week.   Reagan Administration officials said Customs officials were completing a full inventory on the currency and other valuables, which were impounded after they arrived on an Air Force transport plane. Plane Delayed by a Day    The plane arrived a day after the Marcos party came to Hawaii on another C-141 provided by the United States.   In New York, a State Supreme Court judge said he had issued a temporary restraining order in a case involving four pieces of real estate in Manhattan and one on Long Island that the Philippine Government contends were acquired with funds improperly amassed by Mr. Marcos while he was President.  [ Page A12. ]  The Administration officials said the material impounded in Hawaii included millions of dollars' worth of freshly printed pesos, negotiable securities and many ''documents.''

headline: Advertising; New Home For Burson Employees
abstract: BY next Monday, after a frantic weekend, the 700 employees of the New York office of Burson-Marsteller, the world's largest public relations firm, should be comfortably ensconced in their new home at 230 Park Avenue South on the southwest corner of 19th Street.   It will mark the end of the biggest move south by a Manhattan communications company since the Geer DuBois ad agency began the rent-revolt exodus in 1981 by moving to 114 Fifth Avenue at 16th Street.   Burson-Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, will be consolidating an operation in 235,000 square feet that had spread from its 866 Third Avenue headquarters to three other Third Avenue locations, 919, 757 and 880. Half of the move was made over the Jan. 24-26 weekend, and the remainder will be done this weekend. And yesterday as workmen and word merchants mingled in the tastefully reconditioned 90-year-old quarters, Harold Burson, chairman and chief executive, with an entourage that included Maureen Flynn, director of office services, did the guided tour bit through their state-of-the-art facility.

headline: MALAYSIA HOLDS 706 IN SECURITY CRACKDOWN
abstract: The police said today that they had rounded up 706 foreigners for deportation in the eastern state of Sabah as part of a stiffer security program after bombings there.

headline: West German Soldier Reported Missing
abstract: A noncommissioned officer with access to classified information has been missing from his West German Army unit in Munich for three weeks, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: 2 Top 3M Posts Go To Domestic Head
abstract: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that Allen F. Jacobson, president of the concern's domestic operations, had been named chairman and chief executive, effective March 1.   Mr. Jacobson, who is 59 years old, succeeds Lewis W. Lehr, who is retiring. Mr. Lehr, 64, who is credited with advancing 3M innovations in health-care products, remains a director of the highly diversified manufacturer that makes 45,000 products ranging from adhesive tapes to artificial hip joints.   The company did not name a successor to Mr. Jacobson.

headline: BATTLING BRAZIL'S INFLATIONARY FIRES
abstract: IN private, the elegant, soft-spoken Dilson Funaro hardly matches his public image of an empire builder who in six months has become Brazil's most powerful minister. Yet, since taking over the Finance Ministry last August, the 52-year-old industrialist has become the undisputed boss of the country's $250 billion economy.   His first key decision in office was to end the International Monetary Fund's watchdog role here. He then demanded easier repayment terms for Brazil's $104 billion foreign debt. The new minister also revamped economic policy, giving emphasis to growth after four years of recession.   Now, however, Mr. Funaro's political future depends on his ability to defeat inflation in a country where it has become a way of life. Last Friday, President Jose Sarney announced sweeping economic changes, including a price freeze and an end to the automatic cost-of-living adjustments known as indexing. With a 16 percent jump in January, and 14 percent in February, the annual rate of inflation has hit 255 percent, the worst in Brazilian history, and has threatened to destroy the country's recent economic growth.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The number of foreclosure proceedings on homes fell during the final three months of 1985, but the number of late payments rose slightly, the National Association of Mortgage Bankers reported today.   The association said that foreclosures were started on 0.21 percent of all mortgages in the final three months of the year, down from 0.24 percent in the previous quarter.

headline: British Trade Surplus
abstract: Britain's trade balance improved sharply in January, helped by a record oil surplus and a huge budget rebate from the European Common Market, the Department of Trade and Industry said today. Britain had a current account surplus of $1.6 billion in January, the best performance since March 1983 and up $829 million from December, a statement said. Imports fell by $405 million, to $8.56 billion, and exports fell $185 million, to $8.72 billion.

headline: PACIFIC TELEPHONE
abstract: The Pacific Telephone and Telegragh Company is offering $350 million of 9 1/4 percent debentures due 2026 at a price of 98.45, to yield 9.399 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures, rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P., are offered at a price to yield about seven-tenths of a percentage point more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

headline: M.T.A. Bond Offering May Yield Up to 8.568%
abstract: A $299.6 million issue of Metropolitan Transportation Authority revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a top yield of 8.568 percent for bonds due in 2016. Dillon, Read & Company heads the underwriters.

headline: BAXTER UNIT SALE
abstract: Baxter Travenol Laboratories, based in Deerfield, Ill., announced an agreement in principle to sell its American Medical Optics subsidiary to the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. The unit, based in Irvine, Calif., had sales of more than $60 million last year of intraocular lenses and other eye-care surgical products. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: NEW COKE PRODUCTS
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company introduced new products yesterday in the suddenly burgeoning non-cola segment of the soft-drink industry.   Coke showed regular and diet versions of Minute Maid lemon-lime soda, which contains 10 percent fruit juices and is fortified with vitamins. The Atlanta-based soft-drink company also said it would bring out nationally its regular and diet Minute Maid orange sodas, which have been in test markets since last summer.

headline: Hanoi Condemns Plan By Cambodian Rebels
abstract: Vietnam today condemned a peace proposal from a rebel coalition fighting Hanoi-backed forces in Cambodia as ''unjust'' and ''hostile,'' but stopped short of rejecting it.   The official Hanoi radio said the eight-point plan announced Monday in Peking ''contains a lot of unjust demands and reflects the hostility of China in the face of the constant growth of the People's Republic of Vietnam.''

headline: A SHOCK THAT OPEC WON'T OVERCOME
abstract: IN THE 1970's, economists debated whether the oil market was fundamentally different from other commodities markets. Last week's impressive plunge in oil prices provided an emphatic answer to the questions of the 70's. Oil has become a commodity like any other, and the price changes of recent weeks are part of a pattern of volatility that will characterize the market in the future.   With the advantage of hindsight, we can see rather clearly how the seeds of OPEC's destruction were planted years ago. OPEC managers (and most of the rest of us) seriously underestimated the speed with which the industrial economies could adapt through investment in more energy-efficient dwellings, cars and industrial machinery. And few predicted the increased flow of non-OPEC oil from a price-induced drilling boom. As a result, the cartel overshot badly in setting crude prices, particularly in the months following the Iranian revolution, in late 1978 and 1979.   It was downhill from there, with a reduction in the total market and a drastic cut in OPEC's share. OPEC's production is now around 18 million barrels a day, and it needs to be cut another 2 million or so to match weakening demand. A decade ago, capacity totaled more than 30 million barrels a day. Today, even with the ravages of the Iran-Iraq war and the rundown of capacity in places like Kuwait, OPEC countries still could produce 40 percent to 50 percent more than they do now.

headline: CHRYSLER AND FORD OFFERING INCENTIVES
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, responding to buying incentives introduced last week by the General Motors Corporation, today announced their own plans intended to attract new-car buyers.   Ford, like G.M., is offering 9.9 percent financing on a wide range of cars and trucks. Chrysler, however, has shifted from offering either low-rate financing or a rebate, to only a rebate of $500 or $1,000 per car.

headline: Strauss Retires At Internorth
abstract: HNG/Internorth Inc. said yesterday that Willis A. Strauss, 63 years old, had retired as chairman and board member, effective immediately. As expected, Kenneth L. Lay, 43, the president and chief executive, was named to succeed Mr. Strauss.

headline: A.T.& T. FALLS OUT OF FAVOR
abstract: BEFORE the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at the start of 1984, Ma Bell was a stock that many brokerage firms kept recommending, rain or shine. It was viewed as a safe harbor in periods of general market weakness and a growth opportunity when investment skies brightened. But times have changed.   Yesterday, A.T.&T.'s shares rose 1/4, to 23 1/4. It stood at 25 at the end of 1985.

headline: U.S. PLAN FOR CONTRA MILITARY AID CONDEMNED BY HOUSE DEMOCRATS
abstract: Democratic leaders in the House today sharply criticized President Reagan's proposal to send military aid to the rebels in Nicaragua and expressed confidence that they could defeat his plan in a showdown vote.   The Democrats also said they opposed the President's plan to give $15 million in covert military aid to insurgents in Angola, but they acknowledged that they faced a tougher fight on that issue that they might lose.   The Administration's determination to aid the forces that President Reagan calls ''freedom fighters'' in the two countries and in other places around the world has created a critical point of contention between the President and many Democrats.

headline: AUDIO OPPORTUNITIES, NEW AND TOUGHER
abstract: NOT SO LONG AGO, an aspiring recording engineer might knock on the doors of a few recording studios, start out with a job sweeping floors, and gradually learn the business. Recent technological developments in sound reproduction have changed all that, and while today's budding audio specialist may still start work with broom in hand, he or she will probably need a degree just to get in the door.   While digital recording, the compact disk and now stereo television are widely credited with reviving sales of both recordings and equipment, industry sources say the new mediums also require greater sophistication from engineers and bigger capital outlays by manufacturers. Audio hobbyists can still turn their interest in sound into a career, but they will need more training than in the past, or more cash in start-up costs.

headline: 30 COMPUTER AIDES SAY VOTE IS RIGGED
abstract: Weeping and fearful, the 30 Government computer workers arose from their terminals and, data disks in hand, darted from the Commission on Elections to make the charge that the Marcos Government was rigging the presidential vote tally.   They headed to a church where they detailed their accusation that printout numbers favoring the opposition candidate, Corazon C. Aquino, were being ignored.   Instead, the workers said, President Ferdinand E. Marcos was inaccurately being depicted as the front-runner on the large hand-printed tally boards used to inform the nation of the count.   ''There's something fishy going on,'' one of the workers said outside the computer center. ''The numbers being printed on the tally board are different from the ones coming from the computer.''

headline: Cuba's Attorney General Reported Replaced
abstract: Attorney General Idalberto Ladron de Guevara, who headed the state prosecution office, has been replaced.

headline: Chicago ECU Trading
abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange opened trading today in the European Currency Unit, a composite of currencies in 10 member countries of the European Monetary System. The contract is 125,000 ECU's, quoted in United States dollars per ECU. The 10 currencies are the West German mark, French franc, British pound, Italian lira, Dutch guilder, Belgian franc, Danish krone, Greek drachma, Irish punt and Luxembourg franc.

headline: ROSE OF ISLAM AND A THORN FOR INDONESIA'S RULERS
abstract: As Indonesia prepares for an election next year, the Special Territory of Aceh, conservatively Moslem and historically rebellious, is a place to watch.   The voting is expected to be a test of both the level of opposition to President Suharto and his Government's willingness to tolerate dissent, There was once a powerful kingdom here at the tip of Sumatra. In the 17th century its Sultan boasted a cavalry of Persian horses, an elephant corps and a navy strong enough to hold off the Portuguese.
