The people of Aceh, living on the rocky western edge of Indonesia - its gateway to the Indian Ocean and the civilizations of South Asia, the Middle East and Europe - have not forgotten that golden age.

headline: A BIG PAYDAY FOR WALL STREET
abstract: As the markets surge, Wall Street is reaping the biggest payday in memory.   With the stock and bond markets breaking records daily, and trading volume soaring, earnings are expected to reach new highs both for firms and for the thousands of well-paid investment bankers, brokers and traders who work for them. And while the good times, of course, will not last forever, the rally has caused the already frenzied pace of Wall Street to be turned up another notch.   ''It's like watching a tidal wave sweep you along, and in its course it is affecting every part of our business,'' said Peter J. Solomon, vice chairman of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''Personally, I'm working 18 hours or more a day. With all the deals being done, the time pressures on our people are extraordinary. But it's a lot nicer working in an up market than a down market.''

headline: COMMON MARKET ADMITS 2 NATIONS
abstract: After eight years of arduous, often frustrating, negotiations, Spain and Portugal became members of the European Economic Community today.   Their inclusion as the 11th and 12th members was automatic after the signing of a treaty last June and its ratification since then by their Parliaments and those of the other Community members.   The expanded European Common Market encompasses 320 million people, one-third more than the population of the United States. Spain and Portugal will also take up places in the European Parliament and other Community institutions.

headline: INDUSTRY'S OPERATING RATE RISES
abstract: Industry operated at 80.8 percent of capacity in January, the third consecutive increase, but an improvement of only one-tenth of a percentage point over December's revised figure, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The increase in the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities followed more substantial gains of five-tenths of a percentage point in November and four-tenths of a percentage point in December.   The operating rate, which fell in September and October, was generally weak during 1985 as American manufacturers were hobbled by strong foreign competition.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Burlington Northern Railroad Co., Fort Worth, said John H. Hertog and Donald E. Engle would retire as senior vice presidents on Feb. 1.    * Colgate-Palmolive Co., a maker of consumer and health care products, has named Roderick L. Turner senior executive vice president.

headline: OFFICIAL TO COME TO U.S. WITH PAPERS ON MARCOS
abstract: The head of a commission seeking the return of Ferdinand E. Marcos's secret wealth plans to travel to the United States with documents he says ties the former President to real estate holdings in New York.   A member of the commission said today that Jovito R. Salonga, the chairman of the group, would fly to New York early next week to join the legal battle in New York State Supreme Court over five properties the new Philippine Government believes Mr. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, owned in New York City.   The commission member said Mr. Salonga had obtained a power of attorney signed by Mr. Marcos authorizing two brothers, Joseph and Ralph Bernstein, to act as his lawyers in managing the disputed buildings. The Bernsteins have repeatedly denied they have acted on behalf of the Marcoses.

headline: Thatcher Rebuffs Gorbachev on Arms
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has told Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that Britain cannot accept a freeze on British and French nuclear arsenals as a condition for a Soviet-American agreement on the withdrawal of all medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.   Mr. Gorbachev proposed the freeze in January when he offered a version of the ''zero option'' for medium-range missiles. Mrs. Thatcher's response was delivered Monday night in Moscow.

headline: New U.S. Envoy to Austria
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating Ronald Lauder, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Europe, to be Ambassador to Austria, succeeding Helene von Damm. Miss von Damm, Mr. Reagan's personal secretary when he was Governor of California, announced her resignation in June amid controversy over her marriage to a Vienna hotelier.

headline: DEAL FOR FRENCH CAPTIVES FAILS
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria was quoted today as saying that he and President Francois Mitterrand had reached an agreement earlier this year to free six French hostages in Lebanon, but that it fell through when the Moslem kidnappers backed out on the deal.   ''After a lot of effort, we reached an agreement with the people concerned,'' President Assad said in an interview published today by the daily Liberation. ''The hostages should have been released but the kidnappers went back on their word.''

headline: PHONE GROUP PLANS PACIFIC CABLE LINK
abstract: In one of the largest fiber-optic cable projects ever undertaken, the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and a host of international telecommunications companies said yesterday that they would build an underwater lightwave communications system across the Pacific Ocean by 1989.   The cable system, which will cost more than $700 million, will be the first ever in the Pacific.

headline: United Airlines
abstract: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, said it would add 10 flights a week from the United States across the Pacific this spring. United, the nation's largest carrier in terms of passengers flown, acquired Pan American's Pacific routes last month for $750 million.

headline: WORK WEAR DEAL
abstract: The Work Wear Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by an investor group led by Paine Webber Inc. for $86.8 million, or $28 a share, in cash for its 3.1 million shares outstanding.

headline: Avondale Mills In Merger Pact
abstract: Avondale Mills, a textile manufacturer based in Sylacauga, Ala., said that it had approved a definitive agreement to merge into Walton Monroe Mills Inc. for $23.41 a share, or a total of about $93 million.

headline: Commodore Credit Accord
abstract: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle for $135 million in credit through March 15, 1987.   Commodore, the troubled computer company based in West Chester, Pa., had announced last September that it was in technical default of some of its bank loans, attributing the problems to the devaluation a month earlier of its inventory of Commodore 64 home computers and other machines.

headline: AQUINO ASKS WEST TO BOYCOTT INAUGURAL
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino asked 13 Western European countries and Japan today to boycott President Ferdinand E. Marcos's inaugural and withhold recognition.   In a meeting with the 14 ambassadors, she asserted that she had won the disputed election. A spokesman for the European envoys said a decision would be made by their governments. But he said it was becoming ''more and more clear'' that ambassadors of the 12 countries of the European Economic Community would not attend the inaugural.

headline: Market Place; Revamping Penn Central
abstract: RESTRUCTURINGS have become a way of life at the Penn Central Corporation these past few years, and analysts do not expect it to stop now. This is especially true after this week's announcement that the former railroad holding company had settled its differences with the Internal Revenue Service over a disputed portion of the company's enormous tax loss carry-forwards.   Penn Central's stock has been inching its way higher recently - it is in the $55 range now -mainly because the small group of analysts who follow the Greenwich, Conn., concern expected the company's board to announce further realignments after their regularly scheduled meeting last Friday. The expectations were well founded, and earlier this week Penn Central announced that it would spin off to shareholders its Marathon Manufacturing subsidiary.

headline: POPE PREACHES AT SACRED HINDU BEACH IN INDIA
abstract: Pope John Paul II, winding up his tour of India's Roman Catholic heartland, delivered a seaside sermon today at a sacred Hindu beach and urged the church to fight for social justice.   Earlier, the Pope performed the first beatification ceremony in India, elevating a nun and a priest toward possible sainthood.   ''Brothers and sisters of the Catholic Church, you have the right and duty to contribute to the progress of the civic society to which you belong,'' the Pope told up to 200,000 people on the Indian Ocean beach in Trivandrum.

headline: General Felt Raises Its Offer for Sheller
abstract: An investor group led by General Felt Industries, a furniture, carpeting and floor products company, said it had sweetened its bid for the Sheller-Globe Corporation to $46.50 a share, from $43 a share.

headline: REAGAN, IN GRENADA, IS HAILED AS 'OUR OWN HERO'
abstract: President Reagan flew to this Caribbean nation today and told a crowd of thousands of cheering Grenadians that ''I will never be sorry'' that he ordered an invasion in October 1983.   Mr. Reagan, who was praised in a song by a calyso singer as he sat on a podium with other Caribbean leaders as ''Uncle Reagan,'' was introduced by Prime Minister Herbert A. Blaize as ''our own national hero'' and ''our rescuer after God.''   About 7,000 United States troops invaded this 133-square-mile island after the leftist Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop was toppled by hard-line Marxists in his regime. At the time, the United States said it was invading to protect the safety of about 1,000 Americans in Grenada.

headline: U.S. AND HANOI HOPEFUL AFTER TALKS ON THE MISSING
abstract: While American and Vietnamese officials expressed satisfaction last week with the atmosphere of good will surrounding two days of high-level talks in Hanoi on Americans missing in action since the Vietnam War, both sides agreed that they had reached a time when building confidence and increasing cooperation would be critical.   Material progress will have to be made, they said, if the issue of the missing is no longer to prevent better relations between the two countries.   There are potential problems on both sides, officials said, and the wide attention paid to the negotiations, which produced no breakthroughs, could sharpen divisions. Wants U.S. to 'Leave Us Alone'    Not all Vietnamese leaders favor cooperation with the United States.

headline: Market Place; Rises in Profits Seen for I.B.M.
abstract: WHEN the International Business Machines Corporation reports its 1985 fourth-quarter earnings - expected on Friday - the overwhelming expectation on Wall Street is that rising profits are back on track for Big Blue. The consensus calls for earnings to show a sizable advance over the $3.55 a share reported in the final quarter of 1984.   This would mark a significant step not only for the long-reigning favorite stock of institutional investors but also for prospects for the overall equity market in 1986. Most experts agree that rising corporate earnings, in contrast to the generally disappointing profits of 1985, hold the ultimate key to the market's action as this year progresses.

headline: SCM DEAL REJECTED BY U.S. COURT
abstract: Ending a judicial split over an important takeover defense, a Federal court in New York ruled yesterday that directors of the SCM Corporation breached their duty to shareholders when, to fend off one acquirer, they agreed to sell the company's most prized assets at bargain prices to another.   The essence of the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in a 2-to-1 decision, was that such ''lockup'' arrangements are illegal if they produce asset sales at prices so low as to be unfair to shareholders.   ''The Court of Appeals has said that lockup arrangements will now be carefully reviewed,'' said Arthur Fleischer, an attorney at the New York firm of Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, specializing in merger law. ''That favors bidders over targets.''

headline: GOODRICH-UNIROYAL TIRE LINK IS SEEN
abstract: The B. F. Goodrich Company and Uniroyal Inc., two major tire manufacturers, are planning to combine their tire operations in a partnership, industry sources said yesterday.   In addition, the sources said, Uniroyal will sell its specialty chemical business, estimated to be worth $500 million to $600 million, to Goodrich.   Neither Goodrich, the nation's third-largest tire maker, nor Uniroyal, the fifth-largest, would confirm the industry reports. But Goodrich scheduled a news conference in New York this morning for what it called ''a significant announcement.'' The company said it planned to meet with security analysts in the afternoon.

headline: Gramm, Rudman Won On Balanced-Budget Bill
abstract: Republican Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire teamed up to produce one of 1985's most controversial pieces of legislation. But the principal authors of the bill that requires the Government to balance its budget in five years could hardly be more different representatives of their party.   Mr. Gramm is a former Democrat who avidly supports President Reagan, while Mr. Rudman is a moderate who has had his differences with the Administration. But together they engineered passage of the bill that requires annual reductions in the deficit to achieve a balanced budget by 1991. The President hailed the bill as necessary for his economic and political goals, although when he signed it Dec. 12 he expressed some reservations about its constitutionality.

headline: COSTS IN NEW YORK AREA FALL 0.2%
abstract: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the first decrease since October 1984, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.  The regional commissioner of the bureau, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, attributed the drop in inflation to lower costs for residential fuel oil and natural gas.

headline: NAVY SAYS IN A NONNUCLEAR WAR IT MIGHT ATTACK SOVIET A-ARMS
abstract: The Navy has officially acknowledged that if a major nonnuclear conflict broke out between the United States and the Soviet Union, it might seek to attack Soviet submarines that carry long-range nuclear missiles.   The contemplated action, using conventional weapons, would be intended to tip the nuclear balance in favor of the United States and induce the Soviet Union to end the conflict on terms favorable to American forces, according to the Navy.   In the past, some senior Navy officials have declined to commit themselves publicly to such a strategy. In an interview in November, the Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., said it was ''not necessarily'' United States strategy to attack Soviet strategic submarines in a nonnuclear war.& Policy Has Critics Some critics have said that Navy attacks using conventional weapons against Soviet submarines carrying long-range nuclear missiles would put pressure on the Soviet Union to use nuclear weapons in response and would increase the risk that a conventional conflict would turn into a nuclear war.

headline: Market Place; Capital Goods Issues Favored
abstract: CONSUMER stocks have provided the leadership ever since the bull market began in the summer of 1982. But there are signs now that the long-depressed production sector of the economy is about to stage a recovery and, in the process, brighten the outlook for this stock group.   ''We believe that 1986 will be a transition year from the old leadership of consumer stocks to new leadership by issues oriented to capital goods,'' said A. Marshall Acuff Jr., strategist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.   He cautioned, however, that, ''since major changes in theme leadership take about a year to unfold,'' many capital-goods and cyclical stocks might perform better in the second half of 1986 than in the first six months. This sector of the market, he noted, first began to improve in the late spring and early summer of 1985.

headline: PATENTS; Reagents Aid Output Of Drugs and Vaccines
abstract: Chemical reagents that are expected to improve the production of many drugs and vaccines are the subject of patent 4,575,541, issued this week.

headline: Students Riot in Karachi
abstract: Policemen fired tear gas at rioting right-wing students who set six buses ablaze and damaged 16 others in Karachi today, witnesses said. They said the students were protesting what they called inaction by the Pakistani Government in curbing lawlessness in colleges after the death of a colleague who was shot last month.

headline: REAGAN REPORTED TO LACK 10 VOTES ON AID TO REBELS
abstract: Congressional leaders of both parties agreed today that President Reagan must persuade at least 10 more House members to vote for his $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels or face defeat.   Mr. Reagan, meanwhile, continued to lobby legislators for the aid, one of the major foreign policy initiatives of his Presidency. The House is scheduled to vote on the measure Thursday.   Vote counters on Capitol Hill say the President has apparently won over a handful of wavering legislators in recent days. Supporters of Mr. Reagan contend that, given the political leverage of the White House, he is within reach of the votes he needs.

headline: U.S. WON'T CONSULT SOVIET ON U.N. MISSIONS
abstract: The United States said today that it would not consult with Moscow on the size of the three Soviet missions to the United Nations and that it stood by its order reducing the mission size.   Herbert S. Okun, the American deputy chief delegate, said in a meeting of the Host Country Committee that the order for a cutback over a two-year period from 275 to 170 staff members was ''reasonable.''   Richard C. Hottelet, American spokesman, said in an interview: ''There is not going to be any negotiation on the substance of this decision. It is U.S. policy and it is legal.''

headline: WASTE MAKES HASTE IN HIRING TO CONTROL IT
abstract: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency estimates that American industry, which works with more than 400 highly toxic chemicals, annually produces more than a ton of liquid and solid hazardous waste per citizen. A growing public awareness of environmental concerns and a series of chilling experiences in the last two decades has hardened public attitudes toward such substances and how to dispose of them.   The bad experiences have ranged from the 1978 discovery of chemical seepage from the Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y.,that made 227 families homeless to sudden leaks at Union Carbide chemical plants that killed more than 2,000 people in Bhopal, India, in 1984 and injured 141 at Institute, W. Va., last Aug. 11. They include the still unfolding tragedy of cancers and lung diseases caused by exposure to asbestos as much as 50 years ago.

headline: Cetus Planning Stock Offering
abstract: The Cetus Corporation, a leading biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said Friday that it intends to file a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offering of 3 million common shares.

headline: AN AUDIT UNDER FIRE
abstract: THE fight over the remains of the bankrupt DeLorean Motor Company is still pitting an array of investors and creditors against the company's flamboyant founder, John Z. DeLorean. But now the spotlight also is falling on the normally shrouded work of the auditors that assessed the company's books.   In at least three lawsuits, Arthur Andersen & Company, the nation's largest accounting firm, is charged by investors and creditors with having given Mr. DeLorean's company unqualified audit approval despite clues that something was amiss. The plaintiffs claim that Andersen knew, or should have known, about what they contend was fraud at DeLorean Motors. And, they say, the Chicago-based firm should have disclosed the information to them.   The plaintiffs allege that some of their money was diverted through a Swiss bank account maintained in the name of GPD Services Inc., a Panamanian company with a Geneva address, to Mr. DeLorean's personal account in the United States. Andersen, they say, had ample reason to suspect financial irregularities in Delorean Motor's transactions with GPD, and should have further pursued the circumstances of GPD's contract with the car company - even, perhaps, auditing the books of GPD, which was not Andersen's client. Andersen counters that the investors gripes come from their losses in a risky area and that it was under no obligation to delve into GPD's records.

headline: A.T.&T. Cutback
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would phase out production of data terminals at its Skokie, Ill., plant, eliminating about 800 of the 2,000 jobs there. Research, development and administrative functions would continue in Skokie.

headline: U.S. WARNS IRANIANS ON THREATS TO OTHER NATIONS IN PERSIAN GULF
abstract: The United States warned Iran today that if it carried the war against Iraq into other Persian Gulf nations, such a move would be regarded as ''a major threat to U.S. interests.''   The warning came as State Department officials said that Iran, perhaps encouraged by its ability to maintain its recently gained foothold in Iraq despite Iraqi counterattacks, had been privately and publicly threatening other Gulf countries with attacks unless they stopped aiding Iraq.   Bernard Kalb, the State Department spokesman, said, ''The Iranians have made no secret of their campaign to intimidate moderate Gulf Arab states.''

headline: Nigeria Replaces Oil and Finance Aides
abstract: Nigeria, hurt by plunging oil prices and a $20 billion foreign debt, replaced its Oil and Finance Ministers today in a Cabinet shuffle.   Oil Minister Tamunoemi David-West changed jobs with Mines and Power Minister Rilwanu Lukman, and Finance Minister Kalu I. Kalu changed posts with National Planning Minister Chu S. P. Okongwu.

headline: CORRECTING THE TRADE GAP WITH TAIWAN
abstract: Last summer, when Taiwan was heading for a $13 billion trade surplus with the United States, the Boeing Aircraft Company was lobbying hard for China Airlines, the nation's flag carrier, to fill its need for a new wide-bodied airliner by buying a third twin-jet 767.   It was an uphill struggle. The plane Boeing wanted to sell cost $55 million. The competition was a $35 million A-300 built by Airbus Industrie, the European consortium.   The cut-rate European plane was awaiting a buyer at the plant in Toulon, France, after a deal for it with Iberia Air Lines, the Spanish flag carrier, fell through. It also had a capacity for 30 to 40 more seats than the 767, an important factor on China Airlines's busy regional routes to Tokyo and Hong Kong.

headline: 3 Convicted in Palau Killing
abstract: Three men were found guilty today of murder and conspiracy and face life sentences in the assassination last year of the first elected president of Palau.

headline: SHUTTLE'S BUILDERS HAVE VARYING STAKES IN PROGRAM'S FUTURE
abstract: Many of the leading names in the United States aerospace industry are key contractors in the space shuttle program. As in other major aerospace projects, however, their dependence on the program is not as great as their huge National Aeronautics and Space Administration contracts might suggest because a great deal of the work is passed to hundreds of subcontractors.   Nevertheless, all the industry giants involved in the project were shaken, financially as well as emotionally, by the explosion of the Challenger.   A day after the disaster, they declined to comment on their theories about the accident's possible causes. But they said they all expect to participate in NASA's investigation.

headline: A.H. Robins Posts Profits
abstract: The A.H. Robins Company said today that it posted a 1985 fourth-quarter profit of $13.5 million, or 55 cents a share, after losing more than $481.8 million in the 1984 period.   For all of 1985, the company earned $75.8 million, or $3.12 a share, in contrast to a loss of more than $461 million in 1984.

headline: IN SOVIET, A SHIFT TO INCREASING SUPPORT FOR MARCOS
abstract: The Soviet Union, apparently sensing an opportunity to gain from the turmoil in the Philippines and disrupt American policy, has stepped up its support of President Ferdinand E. Marcos since his disputed election victory.   The Soviet Foreign Ministry, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda and the Government press agency Tass have all defended Mr. Marcos in recent days, saying his victory and his Government are legitimate.   Moscow issued no official reaction today to a declaration by the Minister of Defense and the deputy chief of staff of the armed forces that they would not recognize Mr. Marcos as the victor in the election Feb. 7.   Pravda accused Washington on Friday of trying to manipulate the internal affairs of the Philippines.

headline: THRUWAY YIELD VARIES TO 6.05%
abstract: A $161.3 million issue of New York State Thruway Authority bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 percent for maturities in 1988 to 5.50 percent in 1991 and 6.05 percent in 1996.

headline: THE FOLLY OF INFLATING QUARTERLY PROFITS
abstract: To meet quarterly revenue targets, the Daisy Systems Corporation, a Silicon Valley computer maker, often rushed to ship as many computers as possible at the end of each quarter. Sometimes that meant shipping new products that had not yet been perfected. Other times it meant forgetting to include floppy disks, or other vital parts.   Last year the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a machine tool company based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., recognized that delays in orders might push down its profits in the quarter ending Dec. 31. It took part of its well-funded reserve for bad credit and added it to earnings. Presto, the quarter's income was up from a year earlier.

headline: CAR MAGAZINES' BIG 3 ARE HOT
abstract: ''We were starting to wonder if America would ever get up the gumption to build cars like the Taurus and the Sable: Friendly to look at, functional to use, and full of the world's best technology.''   So begins a typically breezy, opinionated review of the new line of midsize cars from the Ford Motor Company in Car and Driver, one of the influential auto enthusiast magazines that help shape the public's taste in cars.   Known in the auto industry as ''buff books,'' the major magazines in the field have grown fat and prosperous on a monthly formula of detailed auto testing, news about future models, a big dollop of fantasy and a resolute conviction that cars are among the most interesting and enjoyable things in life. The Big 3 Magazines    Although there are more than 100 magazines covering one aspect or another of the automobile business, the general interest segment of the market has been dominated in the past, like the domestic auto industry, by a Big Three - Car and Driver, Road & Track and Motor Trend.

headline: BLOOM AGENCY CHOSEN IN U.S. BY ALFA ROMEO
abstract: The New York office of Dallas's Bloom agency has been named to do United States advertising for Alfa Romeo, the Italian-made automobile. Billings could be between $8 million and $10 million.

headline: Seoul Dissident Released From House Arrest
abstract: Kim Dae Jung, a key opposition leader, was released from house arrest early this morning, ending 12 consecutive days in which he had been confined to his home with telephone lines cut.   The police gave no reason for Mr. Kim's release.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1986
abstract: International    Mexico cut its oil prices by $4 a barrel on average, catching up with other declines. Oil prices in the spot and futures markets sagged, too, as traders looked ahead with trepidation to an OPEC committee meeting on Monday. Mexico, meanwhile, agreed to cooperate with Venezuela on pricing and production decisions. They did not say how that would be done, and Venezuela did not immediately announce any price cuts.  [ Page 33. ] Companies    Searle will stop selling two intrauterine contraceptive devices in the U.S. It cited the cost of ''unwarranted'' product litigation and the difficulty in getting liability insurance. Searle's IUD's have been the subject of 775 lawsuits. About a million women in this country use Searle's Copper-7, the most frequently prescribed IUD in the nation, or its Tatum-T. Searle was the last major producer of the device in the U.S.  [ 1. ]

headline: 4 Killed, 15 Wounded In Attacks in Punjab
abstract: Four people were killed and 15 wounded today in attacks in the Sikh stronghold of Punjab State.   The press agency Press Trust of India said gunmen killed two people and injured two other people at a gasoline station in the Jullundur district.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1986
abstract: Companies    Eastern Airlines agreed to be taken over by Texas Air, in a $600 million deal that could vastly change Eastern and the industry as a whole. The move by Eastern's board was precipitated by the stand taken by Charles E. Bryan, who heads the machinist union at Eastern. Mr. Bryan, also an Eastern board member, refused to make the concessions that Eastern's management wanted.  [ Page A1. ]    Eastern's capitulation to Frank Lorenzo of Texas Air will put more pressure on an already consolidating industry to reduce overall operating costs, experts say.  [ D1. ]  Texas Air may have to sell either its Eastern or New York Air shuttle routes in the Boston-New York-Washington corridor, antitrust experts said.  [ D26. ]  Frank Borman, Eastern's chairman, will probably not remain at the company after the takeover, insiders said.  [ D26. ]  The proposed takeover of Eastern will create the country's most debt-ridden carrier, but analysts believe Texas Air will be able to carry the debt.  [ D27. ]

headline: MULRONEY PRAISES U.S.-CANADA TIES
abstract: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney says he thinks most Americans, though not President Reagan, take Canada for granted.   Good neighbors do not make good news, the Prime Minister said. ''But a good little revolutionary who has particularly venomous remarks to make about the United States can usually do a lot better in terms of publicity,'' he said.   Mr. Mulroney's view has not stopped him from being the most visibly pro-American Prime Minister in Canada's history. On Monday, he will fly to Washington to meet President Reagan and press his message that good neighbors should be cherished.

headline: Russian, 17, Reunited With Mother in Vienna
abstract: A 17-year-old Soviet youth allowed to immigrate to the United States was reunited with his mother today after more than six years of separation, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

headline: Hewlett-Packard
abstract: The president of the Hewlett-Packard Company, John Young, told analysts today that some Wall Street estimates that his company would earn $2.40 a share in the fiscal year 1986 were ''very optimistic.''

headline: GENETIC COUNSELORS MULTIPLY
abstract: OVER the last 10 years thousands of families have been helped by genetic counseling, a service that is growing along with the sweeping advances in the genetic sciences. And the task of educating the layman or family about the implications of birth defects and the genetic mechanisms that cause disorders is shifting from physicians and geneticists to a new class of health professionals, genetic counselors. They are becoming the trusted experts who also give emotional and psychological support to families confronted by genetic disorders.   Among those it has helped is Ann Adams of Des Moines, 41 years old, who is expecting her fifth child in May. When she was 16 weeks pregnant she attended a genetic-counseling session at the University of Iowa's Hospitals and Clinics in Iowa City in preparation for an amniocentesis test. The chromosomes in the cells from the amniotic fluid surrounding her unborn baby would be studied for Down's Syndrome.   ''This is a surprise pregnancy, and when you're over 40, you've got to be concerned about the chance of having a Down's Syndrome baby,'' she said. ''Genetic counseling was extremely helpful. I learned that Down's Syndrome children are born with an extra chromosome. I also learned that at 41, my risk factor for having such a child is 1 in 80 and for having a child with any chromosome problem is 1 in 40.''

headline: NEW VOTING SYSTEM AIDS MITTERRAND
abstract: The new voting system of proportional representation instituted by President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government has accomplished almost exactly what the Socialists intended, political analysts said today.   They said the new system had limited Socialist Party losses, weakened the parliamentary strength of a fragile conservative majority and placed Mr. Mitterrand in a far stronger position than he would have been under the previous voting system, French analysts and polling experts also agreed that the new system had enlarged the presence in the French Parliament of the extreme right-wing National Front, headed by Jean-Marie Le Pen. The National Front secured 33 seats Sunday in the National Assembly, the first time it had ever won seats.   ''The proportional system opened the door to the National Front in many constituencies,'' said Helene Riffault, a voting expert at Faits et Opinions, one of the few polling organizations that accurately predicted the national strength of Mr. Le Pen's party.

headline: Bristol-Myers In Syntex Deal
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Syntex Corporation to clear the way for Bristol-Myers to complete its proposed $294 million acquisition of the Genetic Systems Corporation, a Seattle biotechnology company.   In the agreement, Syntex is to drop a plan to increase its stake in Genetic Systems to 18 percent, from 2 percent.

headline: DENIES HIS OUSTER
abstract: President Jean-Claude Duvalier declared a state of siege today and went on national radio to refute widespread rumors, and an erroneous White House report, that his 15-year-old Government had fallen and that he had fled the country.   ''The President is here,'' Mr. Duvalier said in the colorful Creole language of Haiti, ''strong, firm as a monkey's tail.'' The phrase is a common Creole expression.   The erroneous information that the President, 34 years old, had fled came after a week of tumultuous anti-Government demonstrations in half a dozen cities and towns in this country, the poorest in the Western Hemisphere. On Thursday, State Department officials said they had decided to take steps to block about $7 million in direct aid to Haiti because of human rights abuses.

headline: Market Place; How 2 Funds Outdid Index
abstract: TOP-PERFORMING equity managers at banks used vastly different investment strategies last year in handily beating the 31.7 percent total return - market appreciation plus dividends reinvested - shown by Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.   The Citibank Special Situation Fund, with a total return of 47.9 percent, took top honors among 80 aggressive growth funds managed by banks, according to a survey by CDA Technologies Inc., a financial information concern in Silver Spring, Md. ''We tend to be event-oriented in our approach to the market,'' Ronald C. Wiener, the portfolio manager, said yesterday. ''We look for specific events that will impact in a positive way the internal dynamics of a company.''

headline: SHCHARANSKY, IN PHONE CALL, TELLS MOSCOW KIN OF RELEASE
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky's family here heard his exhilarated and exhausted voice from Jerusalem by telephone today.   Ida P. Milgrom, Mr. Shcharansky's 77-year-old mother, and his older brother, Leonid, said that the call came at 2:30 A.M. and that Anatoly talked for an hour about his last days in captivity and his abrupt release.   ''He spoke quickly, without stopping, like he was afraid it would end,'' Leonid Shcharansky said.

headline: Measuring Bonds Over Time
abstract: The past three weeks, as the yield for the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond fell to 8.27 percent, from 9.30 percent, have been exhilarating for bondholders. But that rally has not reduced the anxiety of traders and investors, who must decide whether the rally will continue.   Now that bond yields have plunged decisively into single-digit territory, analysts are brushing the dust off financial records of the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's to remind themselves of ''normal'' market conditions. What they find is that long-term bond yields are at their lowest levels since April 1978, but remain high compared with earlier years.

headline: MOST WORLD STOCK MARKETS SOARED IN FIRST QUARTER OF YEAR
abstract: Investors and securities brokers have had little time to gloat about the excellent performance of stock markets around the world last year, as 1986 already threatens to outpace the generally robust 1985. The powerful combination of falling interest rates and declining oil prices gave a big lift to equities in most major stock markets in the last three months.   To be sure, market performance was uneven because of varying domestic economic circumstances. The weaker dollar, in particular, was a mixed blessing, lowering inflation for some countries, but hurting their exporters. Thus, the Western European bourses, which led last year's charge, are starting to wane to some degree, while the United States market is moving ahead at a faster rate.   But over all the first quarter of this year topped the strong performance of the last quarter of 1985. The Morgan Stanley Capital International World Index rose 17.5 percent during the three months, compared with a 13 percent increase in the preceding three-month period.

headline: Western Union Loss Widens
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said today that it lost $335.7 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $62.2 million a year ago. Revenues slipped 10.8 percent, to $257.8 million, from $289.1 million a year ago.

headline: MORE RATE DROPS SEEN LIKELY
abstract: Hopes for continued declines in interest rates will be kept alive by some weak economic statistics expected in the next few weeks, but many analysts are now looking ahead to the second half of the year when they foresee a stronger economy possibly accompanied by upward pressure on rates.   ''Readings on economic growth in the weeks ahead will continue lackluster,'' said Donald H. Straszheim, cheif economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, adding that short-term rates may decline as the Federal Reserve ''leans toward easing.'' This week, many analysts expect Government reports to show a decline in February's housing starts from the high January level and a small increase in personal income.   In the latest issue of Weekly Economic and Financial Commentary, the Merrill Lynch official said that ''plunging oil prices will eventually help the U.S. economy a great deal but the decline's bad effects are showing up first.'' Once oil companies digest the bad effects and consumers begin to benefit from lower energy prices and increased financial wealth, the economy will rebound, inflationary pressures will rise and bond yields will increase modestly, said Mr. Straszheim.

headline: FROM CHICKEN CHIPS TO INSTANT BEER
abstract: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.   But the feisty stock market and plunging interest rates have changed all that. Economists all over are expecting another respectable - albeit not sizzling -performance this year. (See graphics display on Page 4.) Exploding stock values have added more than $1 trillion to the nation's wealth over the last 18 months, experts say, giving consumers added confidence and new buying power. But business leaders fear that increased competition at home and abroad could make this a tough year. To flesh out the details, industry by industry, The New York Times asked its own specialists to look ahead for 1986. Here are their reports.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $335.5 million, to $208.05 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds fell significantly, dropping $739.4 million, to $93.26 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds and 80 institutional investment funds, however, rose $248.6 million, to $60.59 billion, and $157.3 milion, to $54.21 billion, respectively.

headline: IRAQ SAYS IT DOWNED 2 JETS
abstract: Iraq said today that it had shot down two Iranian warplanes as they headed for targets in southern Iraq.

headline: NEW INCIDENT ON TEMPLE MOUNT
abstract: A new confrontation erupted today in Jersualem between Israeli legislators and Moslems on the Temple Mount, which is sacred to Jews and Moslems. It was the second incident in a week.   More than 600 policemen wielding riot sticks, tear gas and shields were needed to protect a 16-member parliamentary inspection party from Moslem protesters shouting ''The Jews desecrate this place!'' and ''We are the sword of Mohammed!''

headline: 10 MORE KILLED IN PHILIPPINES, OPPOSITION SAYS
abstract: The bodies of 10 opposition party supporters have been found mutilated and decapitated in Quirino Province in recent days in continuing election-related violence, opposition party officials said today.   The opposition called for help from Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, commander of the national constabulary, who has a reputation as a professional military man who does not always go along with the wishes of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   On Thursday, General Ramos ordered the arrest of the commander of a military constabulary in Antique Province on Panay Island in connection with the killing of Evelio Javier, a leader of the presidential campaign of Corazon C. Aquino. Marcos Blames Clergy   There was no immediate response to the plea to General Ramos, although President Marcos charged in an interview that it was his opponents, particularly the Roman Catholic clergy and Communist guerrillas, who were killing and terrorizing his supporters.

headline: PLAINTIFFS PRESS INQUIRY ON U.S. SUPPORT FOR NICARAGUA REBELS
abstract: Attorneys for the plaintiffs in a civil lawsuit asked an appeals court here this week to lift an order that has delayed an investigation of the Reagan Administration's support for Nicaraguan rebels.   The request before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit came more than two years after a Federal District Court Judge ordered the United States Attorney General to investigate charges that American support for the rebels violated the longstanding United States Neutrality Act.   The neutrality law makes it a criminal offense punishable by three years in jail and $3,000 in fines to furnish money or prepare for a military enterprise against a country with which the United States is at peace.

headline: 14 UNIONISTS WIN ULSTER ELECTIONS
abstract: All but one of 15 Northern Irish Protestants have been re-elected to seats in Parliament, results from by-elections Thursday showed today.   Protestant unionist leaders said the vote showed an overwhelming rejection of the British-Irish agreement giving the Irish Republic a say in the province's affairs.   The 15 members of Parliament had resigned to force by-elections that they said they would be regarded as a referendum on the British-Irish agreement signed in November.

headline: EUROPE'S EUREKA PROJECT AIMS TO NARROW U.S. LEAD
abstract: EUROPEAN GOVERNMENTS have borrowed Archimedes's triumphant shout of discovery - ''Eureka'' - as the name of their latest combined attempt to close the technological gap with the United States and Japan. But it remains unclear what if anything the Eureka Project will find. Nearly a year after President Francois Mitterrand of France launched it with great fanfare last April, vagueness and uncertainty still dog this plan for collaborative high-technology research.   All 18 Western European countries, including Turkey, have now signed up as participants in the project. When they hold their next ministerial-level meeting in London this June, they hope to give further shape to the project by setting up a clearinghouse for research either in Strasbourg, France, or Brussels, as well as by approving 16 or so more projects to add to the 10 they accepted at their meeting in Hanover, West Germany, last November.

headline: G.M. VERIFIES CANADA PLANS
abstract: The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it would spend $1.4 billion to renovate its Oshawa, Ontario, assembly plants for production of new lines of midsize cars and pickup trucks.

headline: U.N. Halts Broadcasts On Shortwave Band
abstract: The United Nations radio service has halted its shortwave broadcasts because it cannot afford a 600 percent increase in transmitting fees charged by the Voice of America.   The news and feature broadcasts, amounting to 4,200 hours of air time last year, had been transmitted by Voice of America since the United Nations founded its radio station in 1946.

headline: MUSCOVITES VOICE POSITIVE REACTION
abstract: President Reagan's New Year's greeting to the Soviet people was broadcast at the beginning of the evening television news today, and the initial reaction among Soviet citizens seemed positive.   His remarks, translated in a voice-over, were not edited by the Soviet authorities and no commentary or analysis about his five-minute statement was immediately broadcast.   When Mr. Reagan was interviewed by four Soviet journalists last year, his remarks were published in Izvestia, the principal Government daily, alongside a commentary of equal length that criticized much of what he said. Other Soviet newspapers published only the commentary.

headline: Advertising; Alberto-Culver Shifts Some Duties to Grey
abstract: The Alberto-Culver Company in Melrose Park, Ill., has switched the creative responsibility for most of its hair-care and food brands to Grey Advertising's Chicago office from Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt of Chicago.   The billings are around $20 million but the assignment does not include media planning or buying, which will continue to be done by company-owned Draper Daniels Media Services in Chicago.

headline: Dow, Up 4.24, Edges Toward 1,700
abstract: On the strength of just two stocks, Union Carbide and Kodak, the Dow Jones industrial average moved closer to the 1,700 level yesterday while the rest of the market turned in an unremarkable performance.   The Dow surpassed the stubborn 1,700 level twice during the session -once in late morning and again in the afternoon - before profit taking caused the index to close at 1,696.90, for a gain of 4.24 points.   Kodak was the second-busiest issue of the day, rising 4, to 58 3/4, on consolidated volume of more than 5.2 million shares. Carbide, which is in the process of selling its consumer products business, rose 4 3/8, to 97 3/4, while its when-issued stock was the third most heavily traded issue, up 1, to 19 1/2. The when-issued shares represent Carbide after a 3-for-1 stock split and after the sale of the consumer products division, according to a Carbide spokesman.

headline: SAKHAROV LETTER PRINTED IN LONDON
abstract: Details of methods used by the Soviet authorities to break a 1984 hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov emerged here today in a letter said to have been written by the dissident Soviet physicist from Gorky, the industrial city to which he has been confined for six years.   In the letter, printed in The Observer, a Sunday newspaper, Dr. Sakharov describes how he was taken into custody while accompanying his wife to an interrogation at the prosecutor's office in Gorky on May 7, 1984. He says his abductors said they were doctors but were actually agents of the K.G.B., the Soviet internal-security agency.   At the time of his abduction, the Nobel Peace Prize winner was in the fifth day of a hunger strike designed to press the authorities into granting a visa to his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, so she could go abroad for medical treatment. The trip was finally permitted last October, just before President Reagan's meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in Geneva.

headline: U.S. Forces Reported Ready For Philippine Rescue Move
abstract: The United States has canceled Marine Corps exercises off Japan and placed the forces on standby to help evacuate Americans from the Philippines in the event of election-related violence, the Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported today.   A Japan Defense Agency official, Yuichi Tazawa, told the paper that the exercises had been scheduled for Feb. 1 to 7 off Iwo Jima, 660 miles south of Tokyo.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: Joseph P. Flanagan has been promoted to president of Impact, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

headline: IS IT TOO LATE FOR THE LITTLE GUY?
abstract: LINES formed 10 deep in front of the stock quotation machines at the Merrill Lynch kiosk in Grand Central Station last week. Brokers all around the country heard from long-forgotten customers and mutual fund managers were button-holed in restaurants for stock tips. From cocktail parties and subway platforms to suburban golf courses and country stores, conversations kept erupting about the most powerful rally to hit Wall Street in years. Now even the little guy, who has lingered on the sidelines during the last few years, is wondering whether he should jump in.  Overwhelmingly, the professionals say 'Yes.' Mutual fund managers, Wall Street strategists and large institutional money managers contend that there are still years left in the rally of the 80's. They say that people who missed the surge that catapulted the Dow up 500 points since September should take a deep breath - then pick their stocks carefully, brace for some turbulence and jump in.  Despite Friday's big 35.68-point drop - much of it due to the expiration of options and futures - professionals say that the market's fundamentals have not changed. And trying to predict further price declines before investing is an exercise in futility. ''Every time I think of doing that, I take two aspirin and lie down,'' said Harvey P. Eisen, president of Integrated Asset Management, the top-performing independent investment firm in 1985.

headline: STOCKS HIT HIGHS AS RATES DIP
abstract: Aided again by declining interest rates, the stock market yesterday scored its best single-day gain in nearly a month as indicators on all the major exchanges surged to record levels.   While the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record 1,565.71, an 18.12-point gain on the day, the price rises in stocks that trade on the American Stock Exchange and over-the-counter were a better indication of the depth of the market's recent rally.   Indicators that measure stock prices on those exchanges rose sharply, shattering records that have lasted for two and a half years. The Amex index gained 2.52 points, to 249.89, and the Nasdaq index was up 3.75, to 329.74.

headline: ANTI-SANDINISTA ADVISER LISTS AID NEEDS OF REBELS
abstract: A key adviser to the Nicaraguan rebels said today that they would use American military aid, if it is approved, to create secure supply lines inside Nicaragua and to acquire anti-aircraft weapons, long-range mortars and artillery.   John K. Singlaub, the retired United States major general who has assisted the anti-Sandinista rebels in making arms purchases and obtaining private financing, said the military strategy of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force and smaller rebel groups had been limited by ''the fact that they don't have a secure line of supply.'' He said they had been able to mount only hit-and-run attacks.   Until the rebels are assured of aid to establish better supply lines, he said, they cannot move into urban areas of Nicaragua or take and hold territory.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS PRODUE NO GAINS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz returned to Washington early this morning after a meeting with the Soviet Prime Minister that apparently failed to advance prospects for the next Soviet-American summit meeting or produce progress on other major issues.   Reporters accompanying Mr. Shultz on his flight home from Stockholm after his meeting with the Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, said he seemed very tired after his grueling 31-hour round trip for the funeral of Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden.   One reporter said Mr. Shultz's comments on the plane also indicated disappointment with the continued Soviet unwillingness to set a date either for the next meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, or between himself and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to make preliminary plans for the summit meeting. Mr. Shultz has said that until a date for the meeting is set, it is difficult to focus high-level and bureaucratic attention on important Soviet-American issues. A Link to Nuclear Test Ban    Mr. Gorbachev and some other Soviet officials have publicly linked the timing of the summit meeting to agreements on some arms control issues, such as a ban on all nuclear testing, a proposal that Mr. Gorbachev has been vigorously promoting but that Mr. Reagan has rejected.

headline: MARCO'S OPPONENTS CHARGE AIM IS THEIR 'EXTERMINATION'
abstract: A few rows of desks away from the drone of the National Assembly's presidential ballot count, the lawmakers talked quietly of political homicide.   The opposition leader said he did not fear it; the deputy majority leader said he did not commit it.   ''I am fatalisitic,'' said Aquilano Pimental, the opposition strategist. ''Even if I have 100 bodyguards, when my time comes I will get it, for how do you expect to match the firepower of Marcos?''

headline: BRAZIL SURVEYS CARNIVAL VISITORS ABOUT AIDS
abstract: Brazilian health authorities, alarmed by the growing number of AIDS cases, have distributed questionnaires asking visitors arriving here for Carnival this week to answer questions about their sexual preferences and possible contacts with the disease.   But while Scandinavian, Portuguese and Dutch airlines have handed the forms to their passengers in recent days, the authorities said other airlines, including Pan American World Airways as well as Brazil's Varig, had refused to do so for fear of offending their customers.   ''Some airlines are putting their commercial interests above public health concern,'' said Jose Padilla de Castro, Director of Sanitary Control regarding foreigners.   The Federal health authorities said they had printed 50,000 questionnaires and asked all airlines flying to Brazil from the United States, Canada and Europe to distribute them on board to passengers of both sexes over the age of 18. They said the forms would not be used to deny anyone entry to Brazil.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES EASE IN PRICE
abstract: Prices of Government securities eased further yesterday in light trading. Dealers again cited concern over the credit market's lack of liquidity, which has been reflected in the strong demand for the Federal funds that financial institutions lend each other for brief periods.   One factor that did not concern the market was the Federal Reserve's announcement of a $5.3 billion rise in the M-1 money supply, to $627.9 billion, in the week ended Dec. 23. The surge in M-1, which consists of currency, checks and related liquid deposits, was in line with expectations.

headline: G.M. Job Cuts
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 4,100 workers temporarily in Wilmington, Del., and 30 jobs would be eliminated at a Detroit toolmaking shop. The Wilmington assembly plant, which had been making large Chevrolet and Oldsmobile cars, will be retooled for $300 million for a smaller front-wheel drive Chevrolet line currently code-named the L-car. G.M.'s Linden, N.J., plant was closed in August for retooling to produce the car.

headline: Eastern Strike Date Delayed
abstract: The union representing 7,200 Eastern Airlines flight attendants has revised its mid-January strike deadline to coincide with a Feb. 28 default deadline set by the airline's creditors, a spokesman said today.   The move gives six weeks of breathing room to negotiators, who were facing a Jan. 20 strike deadline, and focuses labor and financial pressure on the February date.

headline: MOSCOW'S STRATEGY IS FOILED
abstract: The Soviet Union, which unexpectedly came to the defense of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines after his contested election victory this month, noted his flight from the presidential palace without comment today.   The Government press agency, after earlier accusing Washington of issuing ''bawled orders and threats'' in suggesting that Mr. Marcos should resign, reported without elaboration later that he had fled Manila.   The developments in Manila in recent weeks seemed to catch the Kremlin by surprise and its recent support of Mr. Marcos, whatever the motivation, appeared to be a miscalculation, according to Western diplomats.

headline: OIL COMPANIES' OUTLOOK NOW
abstract: IN the last week the Exxon Corporation, the Chevron Corporation and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation all substantially reduced their planned capital and exploration budgets.   These moves, although expected, struck a more ominous note than earlier spending cuts by other integrated oil companies: Both Exxon and Chevron also said they were considering employee layoffs, and Occidental said it had already cut its work force by 700 with layoffs and early retirement.   Adding to the gloom was the major oil companies' revision, to $15 a barrel, of the floor for posted prices for the benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil. This move, led by the Mobil Corporation, occurred amid signs of production curtailment.

headline: INDIA REJECTS ACCORD IN BHOPAL CASE
abstract: India today rejected a tentative agreement by the Union Carbide Corporation to pay $350 million to victims of the gas leak at Bhopal and indicated that it would challenge the settlement in Federal court in New York City.   In a toughly worded statement, the Indian Government declared that the victims' lawyers who negotiated the tentative settlement with Carbide had no right to reach such an agreement.   ''It has to be pointed out that there cannot be any settlement without agreement by Government of India,'' the statement saidd. ''The reported amount of settlement is inadequate and has alway been so and is, therefore, totally unacceptable.''

headline: CAR BOMB IN EAST BEIRUT KILLS 5 AND WOUNDS 30
abstract: In a fresh surge of violence, 5 people were killed and 30 wounded in a car bomb explosion in Christian East Beirut today, while in the Moslem part of the capital, two political activists were slain after all-night street gun battles between Iranian-backed Shiite fundamentalists and Soviet-oriented Communists.   A car packed with what the police said were explosives, mortar shells and a mine was detonated outside a supermaket in a residential district of East Beirut. The blast occurred at midmorning when the area was crowded with people shopping.   Witnesses said the casualties could have been higher if a 15-year-old boy had not seen smoke coming from a car. The boy shouted to people nearby only moments before the bomb went off.

headline: FORMER DETAINEE, TORTURED UNDER MARCOS, SAYS HE ISN'T SOLD ON AQUINO
abstract: When Romeo Castillo walks at night, he worries that he may see someone open the trunk of a car.   ''I am frightened and I panic,'' he said today, clutching his chest, his eyes wide. ''That is how they took me in the dark, stuffed in that back compartment of a car.''   Mr. Castillo, a labor organizer who until last week was one of those jailed by decree of Ferdinand E. Marcos, says that a loud transistor radiomakes him lose control of his senses and regress into total, uncontrollable terror.

headline: SOVIET-BLOC PRESS LINKS U.S. TO PHILIPPINE REVOLT
abstract: Pravda, the daily newspaper of the Soviet Communist Party, quoted unidentified observers in the Philippines today as saying a coup had been planned against President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   It said the observers ''do not exclude that it was prepared with participation of United States special services.''   Pravda said the Marcos Government ''suffered intense pressure from Washington, which used the most evident and open political interference'' before, during and after the presidential election on Feb. 7.   The Philippine Government ''also suffered from military pressure,'' Pravda said, asserting that ''during these days the Philippines is literally under the barrel of the guns of the United States Seventh Fleet.''

headline: THE BUDGET CUTS AIMED AT DEFENSE
abstract: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.   But the feisty stock market and plunging interest rates have changed all that. Economists all over are expecting another respectable - albeit not sizzling -performance this year. (See graphics display on Page 4.) Exploding stock values have added more than $1 trillion to the nation's wealth over the last 18 months, experts say, giving consumers added confidence and new buying power. But business leaders fear that increased competition at home and abroad could make this a tough year. To flesh out the details, industry by industry, The New York Times asked its own specialists to look ahead for 1986. Here are their reports.

headline: Pepsi Termed No. 1 Seller
abstract: Pepsi-Cola, moving into the gap between old Coke and new Coke, has become the nation's best-selling single soft drink, an industry publication says.   Coca-Cola, as the Atlanta-based company's new formula, fell to No. 2 and Coke Classic, which uses the decades-old formula, came in third, according to the latest issue of Beverage Digest.

headline: Chairman Rebuilding Former Daon Corp.
abstract: Four years ago the Daon Development Corporation teetered on the edge of bankruptcy. Today the Vancouver-based real estate developer has a financial sugar daddy, a new corporate name and a renewed claim as one of Canada's hottest property developers.   Daon, which changed its name last month to BCE Development Corporation, agreed on Tuesday to acquire $1 billion (United States currency) of commercial real estate from the American subsidiary of the Oxford Development Group Ltd. BCE Development will pay Oxford $125 million and assume financing obligations for the properties. The deal is subject to formal approval.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 10, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Expert Group on Accounting and Reporting Standards, 3 P.M.

headline: COLOMBIA ACCUSED OF RIGHTS ABUSES
abstract: A human rights organization based in the United States has accused Colombia's armed forces of being responsible for summary executions, torture and ''disappearances'' in its campaign against leftist guerrillas.   In a report made public today, the organization, Americas Watch, also accused the armed forces of trying to ''derail'' President Belisario Betancur's efforts to negotiate a peace agreement with an array of rebel groups after almost four decades of political violence in Colombia.   Americas Watch said some kidnappings and killings of civilian noncombatants had been carried out by leftist guerrillas, but it blamed the armed forces for ''the great majority of violent abuses of human rights.''   ''Despite Betancur's good intentions, the army and police continue to violate human rights with impunity,'' the report said. It also said that, with large areas of Colombia under military control, paramilitary death squads operated freely and were responsible for 1,455 assassinations between early 1982 and August 1985. Some 540 people are listed as ''disappeared.''

headline: Home Ownership
abstract: If you bought a house last year, chances were you were older than those who bought houses in the last nine years and earned more money than they did.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO OFFER PROTECTION TO AQUINO
abstract: A United States Senator said today that the United States Navy had made available a ship for Corazon C. Aquino should she be forced to flee or need protection in the current Philippine situation.   Senator John Melcher, a Montana Democrat, said he was told by a senior admiral in the Office of the Chief of Naval Operations today that Mrs. Aquino got in touch with American military officials and said ''she might need some protection.'' Mr. Melcher said she was told a ship would be available for her if necessary.

headline: Spain to Establish Relations With Israel 'Early This Year'
abstract: Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said today that Spain would establish diplomatic relations with Israel early this year.

headline: PROSECUTOR STARTS HIS FINAL PLEA IN POPE PLOT TRIAL
abstract: The prosecutor in the trial of seven Bulgarians and Turks accused of conspiring to murder Pope John Paul II began his final plea this week, contending that there was enough evidence to prove there was a plot but that the state's key witness had sought to torpedo the case by feigning madness.   The prosecutor, Antonio Marini, had been expected to request the acquittal of the three Bulgarians, on the ground that there was not enough evidence to convict them. But Mr. Marini's vigor in pursuing the case led defense lawyers to concede Thursday that it was premature to predict what he would seek when he finishes his plea next week.   Indeed, on Tuesday Mr. Marini cited hearsay evidence, which is acceptable in an Italian court, that further implicated Bulgaria in a plot.

headline: British Hold Farrakhan For Questioning
abstract: Louis Farrakhan, the American Black Muslim minister barred from entering Britain, was detained for questioning by British immigration officers today when he landed at Heathrow Airport on his way to Nigeria.   Mr. Farrakhan, who has called Judaism a ''gutter religion,'' has been invited to Britain by a black group, but was barred from entering the country last month because the Home Office felt his presence would ''not be conducive to the public good.''

headline: BONN URGES NEW MISSILE DEFENSE
abstract: The Defense Minister of West Germany, Manfred Worner, has urged that Europe build a new defense against what he sees as an increasing threat from Soviet medium-range missiles.   Mr. Worner, in an article to be published this week, proposes a nonnuclear system that would be a more modest version of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, which is intended to knock out long-range Soviet missiles.   In the magazine Strategic Review, Mr. Worner asserts that a defense consisting of antiballistic missiles, radar, other sensors and the communications to link them could be built with technologies that ''are either available or within reach.''

headline: Wickes Units Sold
abstract: The Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell Red Owl Stores, a grocery chain; Snyder Drug Stores, and its Western Diversified Services insurance unit.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Fairmont Financial Inc. is offering in the Eurobond market $25 million of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2001, through Kidder, Peabody International. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at 120 percent of the closing price per share on Feb. 14, when the stock closed at $20.50.

headline: EASTERN PILOTS SAID TO BE SEEKING ANOTHER BUYER
abstract: Eastern Airlines' pilots are casting about for a carrier other than Texas Air to buy their troubled company, and in recent days their representatives have negotiated with Pan Am and Braniff, various sources close to the situation said yesterday.   Eastern's pilots, as well as its flight attendants and machinists, from the start have opposed the takeover agreement announced last week that would make Eastern a subsidiary of Texas Air, the low-fare carrier that operates Continental Airlines. Lazard Freres Hired    The Air Line Pilots Association opposed the deal so much that it directed Lazard Freres & Company, a Wall Street investment banking house, to fight the acquisition.   Sources say Lazard has been in touch with other airlines in hopes of locating a buyer that the pilots might find more suitable than Texas Air, whose head, Frank Lorenzo, has been in a running feud with labor.

headline: SPAIN'S DECISION: LET'S BE PRACTICAL
abstract: Behind Spain's vote Wednesday to stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was a sense of pragmatism that reflects how far this once fratricidal country has come in a decade.   By a margin of 53 percent to 40 percent, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez prevailed by stressing domestic political continuity and economic development. His pragmatic arguments overcame such emotional principles as anti-Americanism and opposition to military blocs that just two years ago were upheld by even his Socialists.   Spain joined NATO under a conservative Government four years ago, and Mr. Gonzalez hammered home the point that continued membership would foster international confidence and investment in Spain and give it access to modern technology.

headline: MORE INSURERS EXPECTED TO STRENGTHEN RESERVES
abstract: A number of insurance companies with large property and casualty portfolios are likely to follow the Cigna Corporation's lead in taking big charges to bolster their property and casualty reserves, executives and analysts said yesterday.   Cigna, the nation's second-largest publicly held insurance company, jolted the industry when it announced that in order to shore up its reserves it would take a $1.2 billion charge against fourth-quarter earnings, believed to be the biggest charge ever taken in the insurance industry.   Cigna's action, taken to cover larger-than-expected awards on policies written before 1985, came two weeks after the Chubb Corporation, another major property and casualty insurer, said it had bought $173.5 million worth of medical malpractice reinsurance from a British insurer as a way of bolstering its reserves. Charges Unlikely to Top Cigna's   ''With only half of the companies reporting'' fourth-quarter results ''so far, it would be foolhardy to say that Cigna and Chubb are the only ones who will increase reserves,'' said Allerton J. Cushman, an insurance industry analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: ANTITRUST LAWS
abstract: To the Editor:   Under the current Administration the Federal agencies assigned by law to police mergers refuse to do so (''Inviting Mergers That Are Sure to Fail,'' Forum, Feb. 16). However, our antitrust laws provide that private parties may themselves sue for relief, and can ask the court to prohibit the anti-competitive merger before it occurs.

headline: APARTHEID'S 'REFERENCE BOOK' IS FULL OF SAD STORIES
abstract: Beulah Rollnick looked across her desk at the man with his head cocooned in a bandage and pondered, out loud, whether there was any hope left at all ''in this bloody country.''   The man and three colleagues said they were striking workers from a factory near Pretoria. They said they had been beaten when the police arrived to end the brief stoppage. The officers had given them three minutes to hand back their coveralls and go.   And so, the man said, they had come to the office of the civil rights movement Black Sash in central Johannesburg where Mrs. Rollnick and other white women work across the color line with black people confronted with a tangle of laws that seem often to work against them and protect others.

headline: AQUINO PROCLAIMS INTERIM GOVERNMENT
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino abolished the National Assembly and claimed all legislative powers for herself today.   She promised a ''swift and safe'' return to democratic representative government within a year.   Mrs. Aquino announced the imposition of a temporary ''freedom Constitution,'' including a bill of rights and, aides said, the possibility of judicial review through this uncertain interim period.   This is to be the law of the land until a new constitution can be composed and submitted to ''genuine and honest'' plebiscite and a new legislature elected, Mrs. Aquino declared.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IN SEOUL, CRITICS TOE A LINE
abstract: The other day, a curious crowd gathered on the avenue near the headquarters of Korea's main opposition party. They gazed at the scene: rows of riot policemen in black helmets that make them so uncannily resemble the ''Star Wars'' character Darth Vader, big black armored cars with sirens and tear gas dispensers and hundreds of plainclothesmen, their youthful faces blank as they stood in the cold with parkas zipped tight.   ''What is it,'' one onlooker said, ''a traffic accident?''   The sight of riot policemen and plainsclothesmen does not faze most people in Seoul. They see them every day, standing guard at the entrances to the city's ubiquitous underground passageways or taking tea breaks at their semipermanent posts outside university campuses.

headline: TANK BATTLE PUTS LEBANESE NEARER TO FULL CIVIL WAR
abstract: A tank battle raged today between rival Lebanese at the approaches to the hometown of President Amin Gemayel as Lebanon slipped closer toward full-scale civil war.   A Lebanese Army spokesman said Christian troops loyal to Mr. Gemayel used United States-supplied tanks and armored personnel carriers to drive back Syrian-backed Moslem and leftist militiamen using Soviet-built tanks.   The spokesman said the Moslem and leftist forces had tried to advance on Bikfeiya, Mr. Gemayel's hometown in the mountains 12 miles northeast of central Beirut. Artillery Duels in Villages   The spokesman said 21 attackers had been killed and more than 50 wounded. The army lost 11 dead, he said, and 26 soldiers were wounded.

headline: 2 RIVERDALE PROJECTS OFFER RIVER VIEWS
abstract: Where there is a cliff rising from a riverbank in New York City there is usually a striking view. And where there is a view there is the potential for development.   Just such a situation led two builders to acquire residentially zoned sites in the Riverdale section of the Bronx a year ago and start high-rise condominiums. Both are well into construction, but have quite different histories.

headline: ROCKEFELLER BROADCAST UNIT IS SOLD
abstract: The Rockefeller Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Outlet Company broadcasting unit to an investment group made up of Outlet executives and the Wesray Capital Corporation.   The deal would be in the form of a leveraged buyout and would bring the Rockefeller Group, which has been selling off assets, more than $625 million in cash and warrants.   Wesray, an investment concern headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, specializes in leveraged buyouts. In recent years, it has acquired Atlas Van Lines Inc., Gibson Greetings Inc. and Proctor-Silex Inc. Last year, it indicated an interest in the media business when it reportedly bid for Group W Cable.

headline: NORTHWEST TO BUY REPUBLIC
abstract: Northwest Airlines, the nation's 10th-largest airline and the biggest carrier to the Pacific, announced yesterday that it would buy Republic Airlines, the nation's seventh-largest airline, for $884 million.   The acquisition, which would be the largest under deregulation, would form the nation's fifth-largest airline in terms of passengers carried, ranking behind United, Eastern, Delta and American.   The move by Northwest, which along with Republic has its headquarters and main hub in Minneapolis, was not a surprise.   Steven G. Rothmeier, Northwest's president and chief executive officer, has said in several interviews that his airline would be forced to seek to acquire a major domestic airline if United Airlines was allowed to acquire the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways.

headline: Debt
abstract: * Associates Corp. of North America is offering $100 million of 7 3/4 percent notes, rated A-1/AA- and due in 1989, at par through Salomon Brothers.    * Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone filed with the S.E.C. an offering of up to $100 million of debt securities.

headline: PALESTINIANS BATTLE SHIITES FOR THIRD DAY
abstract: For the third day, Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen battled today around two Palestinian centers in southern Beirut.   The police said eight people had been killed and 35 wounded in the fighting at the outskirts of the Sabra and Shatila districts.

headline: BID FOR EASTERN JOLTS THE MIAMI AREA
abstract: The planned sale of Eastern Airlines jangled nerves all over Miami today.   Eastern, which moved its executive headquarters here from Rockefeller Center in New York 14 years ago, is the area's largest private-sector employer. It has 14,000 workers in south Florida - 13,000 of them in Greater Miami - and an annual payroll of $400 million.   Its total economic impact on the area is $2 billion a year, according to Raymond Fishe, an economist with the University of Miami.

headline: NEWCOMER IS CHOICE FOR BLACK & DECKER JOB
abstract: Nolan D. Archibald, who joined the Black & Decker Corporation just five months ago, was recommended yesterday to be the company's chief executive officer. Laurence J. Farley, now chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest power tool maker, said he would relinquish the c.e.o. title in March and recommended that the company's directors replace him with Mr. Archibald.   Mr. Farley, who is 49, will continue as chairman of Black & Decker, based in Towson, Md.

headline: INVESTING; STARTING THE YEAR IN SECONDARY STOCKS
abstract: IT'S probably not in the same league with the theory of relativity or the discovery of electricity, but the stock market's ''January Effect'' has spurred dozens of studies. According to the research, the stocks of companies with lower-than-average market capitalizations should outperform the stocks of larger companies this month.  ''Certainly, all the academic research says that it's true, and our experience says that it's true,'' said Preston G. Athey, a vice president and portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price Associates New Horizons Mutual Fund, which invests $1.5 billion in the stocks of small companies.  Donald B. Keim, an assistant professor of finance at the Wharton School of Business, analyzed the returns of small and large stocks for every year back to 1930. And in only two of those years did the stocks of small companies fail to beat the large ones in the first month of the year.

headline: Request on Sanctions
abstract: The Reagan Administration confirmed today that it was considering requests by American oil companies to sell or transfer their assets and their equity in Libya's oil production rather than have the assets and oil be given to the Libyan Government and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi after sanctions start on Saturday. Bernard Kalb, the State Department spokesman, said, ''The Administration is presently considering what exceptions, if any, to make to permit service and oil concession contracts to be fulfilled after Feb. 1.''

headline: 2 DOMESTIC CARRIERS IN TIE TO JAPAN AIR
