abstract: In a bid to counter stiff competition from United Airlines, Japan Air Lines has agreed with Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines to offer additional services and connecting flights.   By allowing passengers to check their baggage through to connecting Western and Delta flights, and by cutting the time between connecting flights, Japan Air hopes to entice customers who might otherwise choose United because of its extensive domestic flights to cities throughout the United States. United vastly expanded its flights to Japan through its recent purchase of Pan American World Airways' Pacific routes.  [ In Chicago, Reuters reported Wednesday that United had reached an agreement with British Airways to coordinate flight schedules. The arrangement will make it easier for United's domestic passengers to transfer to British Airways' international flights at the 15 American cities British Airways serves, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Boston, New York, Washington and Miami. ]  The president of Japan Air Lines, Susumu Yamaji, recently told a Japanese reporter that he felt like a novice wrestler fighting a champion.

headline: CONTROL DATA HAS BIG LOSS
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, which has long faced turmoil in several of its divisions, said yesterday that it lost $297.9 million in the fourth quarter, compared with earnings of $4.5 million in the 1984 quarter. Revenues for the quarter were $981.4 million, compared with $1.01 billion.   The Minneapolis-based computer maker has been battered by a weak market for computers and peripherals. To shore up its finances, Control Data last year sold several operations but still went into technical default on some of its loan agreements.

headline: TRADING AIR TO BUILD TOWERS
abstract: At a site on West 56th Street, Bruce Eichner has assembled enough air to build New York's tallest residential building.   The 72-story project, called Cityspire, came about because Mr. Eichner, a former prosecutor turned real estate developer, could acquire the vacant space over the building behind his site and move that air to his own lot.   Lawyers call it ''a transfer of air rights.'' Real estate brokers, builders and city planners describe it as ''assembling developable space'' or ''buildable square footage.''   But they all mean air. And it is the creative packaging of such parcels of air that is the driving force in the Manhattan real estate market these days.

headline: SOVIET SPOKESMAN IS EXPECTED TO BECOME ENVOY TO BRITAIN
abstract: Leonid M. Zamyatin, the Soviet Union's chief press spokesman, is soon to be named Ambassador to Britain, diplomats say.   Mr. Zamyatin, who is 64 years old, has been the chief of the International Information Department in the Central Committee's Secretariat. Although he is a career diplomat - he joined the foreign service in 1946 - Western diplomats view the move from the center of power in Moscow to the London post as a demotion.

headline: FOR AMERICANS IN HAITI, DAYS OF FEAR AND FASCINATION
abstract: Margaret Vanka sat ensconced in her peacock wicker chair and declared the veranda of the Grand Hotel Oloffson ''a wonderful place to watch this revolution.''   ''There are nine inches of snow at home - why go home?'' asked Mrs. Vanka, 78 years old, a visitor from Rushland, Pa. ''At least I'm here in the middle of something interesting.''   Suzanne Seitz, the American owner of the Oloffson, also saw a silver lining in Haiti's political upheaval. A general slump in the tourism here had recently touched her hotel, a gingerbread masterpiece at which Graham Greene set his novel, ''The Comedians.''

headline: WEARY OPEC OFFICALS FAIL TO DEVISE OUTPUT PLAN
abstract: OPEC ministers emerged from an eighth weary day of talks here today unable to come up with any specific agreement to stop the plunge of oil prices.   In what one delegate described as ''acrimonious discussions,'' ministers from numerous countries apparently rejected out of hand a complicated system of individual national quotas under an overall production ceiling of 14 million barrels of crude oil a day. A spokesman, James Audu, said the ministers would set forth their discussions Monday.   Reflecting the gloom and exhaustion gradually surrounding the talks, ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries avoided reporters or said little as they emerged from discussions.

headline: EAST BLOC LANDS, IN REPLY TO U.S., LIMIT TRAVEL
abstract: Three East European Governments have informed the United States that they are taking travel measures against American diplomats and other officials in retaliation for steps taken by Washington last month against them, diplomats said today.   The latest moves will produce tighter surveillance on American official representatives trying to move around in some Soviet bloc countries, the diplomats said. They are almost tit for tat for restrictions imposed by the Administration to help the Federal Bureau of Investigation keep closer track of Communist officials.   The Aministration was responding to concerns in Congress and security agencies that the East Europeans were working for the Soviet Union, particularly in trying to gain access to high technology in parts of the United States, such as the Silicon Valley region in California, that are closed to Soviet representatives.

headline: Chris-Craft Extends Credit
abstract: Chris-Craft Industries said yesterday that it had extended the $250 million credit line that its subsidiary, BHC Inc., has been using to buy stock in Warner Communications Inc. That credit line had been scheduled to drop by $50 million on Dec. 31.   Analysts said that it was not immediately clear whether Chris-Craft would buy additional stock in the company.

headline: TEXAS AMERICAN SELECTS AN ECONOMIST AS CHIEF
abstract: Texas American Bancshares Inc., the state's seventh-largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that Lewis H. Bond will step down as chairman and chief executive after the company's annual meeting on April 24.   Mr. Bond will retire from the bank at the end of July, when he will reach age 65, Texas American said.   Mr. Bond joined the Fort Worth National Bank, a predecessor of Texas American's principal subsidiary, Texas American Bank/Fort Worth, in 1952. He has held his current posts since 1976.

headline: Ecuadorean General Is Told to Surrender
abstract: Gen. Frank Vargas Pazos, Ecuador's ousted armed forces chief, was warned today to leave the Manta air base where he took refuge Friday or face a military showdown.   The rebellious general responded by asking to be judged ''within military law'' by a commission of fellow officers.

headline: U.S. ANNOYED, PRESSES SOVIET ON A DATE FOR NEXT SUMMIT MEETING
abstract: The Reagan Administration expressed impatience today with the failure of the Soviet Union so far to agree on a date for the planned visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the United States this year.   The Government has been saying that preparations for the next summit meeting have been proceeding without trouble. But today, as a result of comments from Moscow, some annoyance was evident.

headline: AD INDUSTRY HEIGHTENS ITS WATCHDOG FUNCTION
abstract: What the advertising industry regards as a desire to tamper with the freedom to advertise is apparently still strong at the state level because the Washington-based American Advertising Federation, which has long used its grass-roots organization to monitor such activity, has now joined with the two other major forces in the industry to give the watchdog operation still greater observation power.   Howard Bell, president of the federation, says it has joined with the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers to create the State Legislative Alert and Action Coalition. William F. Sutherland, formerly with the Food Marketing Institute, will run the show as director of state government relations.

headline: U.S.-Italian Offer For Westland Rises
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation and Fiat S.p.A. improved the terms of their rescue plan today for Britain's financially troubled helicopter maker, Westland P.L.C.   The Westland board, in turn, said that it ''unanimously and strongly'' recommended the American-led bid, despite a competing offer by a European consortium, which has the backing of Britain's Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine.   Westland's chairman, Sir John Cuckley, said that if his company accepted the European bid, it would reduce Westland to being a ''manufacturer of parts only.''

headline: GANDHI'S POLITICAL TALENTS ARE TESTED
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who has enjoyed nearly universal praise for his political skills, has run into an unusual storm of criticism over several recent steps and missteps.   Mr. Gandhi's aides are now saying that the Prime Minister's ''honeymoon'' with the press and his political opposition, which has continued since he took office on Oct. 31, 1984, has at last come to an end.   ''The euphoria has to stop,'' Mr. Gandhi, 41 years old, acknowledged to the magazine India Today in a recent interview, sounding somewhat philosophical over the turn of events. Fuel Price Increases Protested    Opposition leaders refused to meet with Mr. Gandhi on the eve or the opening of Parliament this week and then boycotted the Prime Minister's speech on the opening day. Instead, they and several thousand supporters took to the streets to protest Mr. Gandhi's policies.

headline: A Stock Split By Chrysler
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would split the stock of the corporation, issuing three shares for every two held by stockholders of record Feb. 20, 1986. In addition, the company said it would maintain a 25-cents-a-share quarterly dividend after the split, thus effectively raising the annual dividend from $1, to $1.50 a share.

headline: OPEC SET TO DISCUSS STRATEGIES
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, after holding two preliminary sessions today, is expected to start Monday to try to devise a strategy to deal with plunging oil prices and a diminishing share of the world oil market, in what may be a weeklong emergency session.   Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, the conference president and Venezuelan oil minister, said that ministers from OPEC's 13 member nations would begin closed-door discussions on Monday on ''the fair share of the market that OPEC is willing to defend'' and ''the level of prices.''   He added, ''All the ministers are concerned about avoiding a price war and maintaining a reasonable level of prices.'' Mr. Hernandez briefed reporters after the meetings, which were held in a conference room on the 18th floor of the Inter-Continental Hotel here, overlooking Lake Geneva. Policy Changed in December   OPEC decided in principle in December to abandon its official policy of trying to defend a $28-a-barrel oil price through cuts in output, which all its members were flouting. Instead, OPEC decided to try to protect a fixed share of the world oil market by cutting the prices its members charged to secure more sales.

headline: Telenova Official Fills 2 Top Posts at Ericsson
abstract: Ericsson Inc., the American subsidiary of L.M. Ericsson of Sweden, yesterday named a new president and chief executive. He is M. Peter Thomas, president and chief operating officer of Telenova, a small Silicon Valley manufacturer of voice/ data office controllers.   Ericsson began in 1980 as a venture between L.M. Ericsson and the Atlantic Richfield Company, based in Richardson, Tex., Last November, the Swedish parent announced it had purchased Arco's interest for $42 million, and said it would be looking for an American executive to head the unit, which makes telecommunications equipment.

headline: People
abstract: * David Cathers was named executive vice president, director of client services, at Franklin Spier Inc., a subsidiary of BBDO International.    * Michael Markowitz and Mitchell Siegel were named senior vice presidents at Altschiller Reitzfeld Inc.    * Paul Gold, Henry Lewczyk and Hugh O'Brien have been elected executive vice presidents at Dallas-based Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

headline: KEY SENATOR OFFERS A COMPROMISE ON CONTRA AID
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the Administration should provide money to the Nicaraguan insurgents, but withhold military aid if the Sandinistas agree to a series of internal changes.   Offering the Administration what amounted to a compromise in its uphill battle in Congress for a $100 million aid request, the chairman, Senator Richard G. Lugar, said alternatives that would delay the financing in the hope of achieving negotiations would be counterproductive.   ''Adding all kinds of strings and certifications will only hinder the effectiveness of the United States to act,'' the Indiana Republican said.   The support of Mr. Lugar was viewed by White House officials as critical in the Congressional vote scheduled for next week on Mr. Reagan's request for $70 million in military aid and $30 million in so-called humanitarian help.

headline: Doubleday Sale Of Radio Units
abstract: Doubleday & Company said today that its broadcasting subsidiary is putting its remaining three radio stations up for sale as part of its restructuring program. The stations include WHN-AM and WAPP-FM in New York, as well as WAVA-FM in Washington.

headline: May Stores Announces Executive Reshuffling
abstract: The May Department Stores Company, the nation's third-largest department store retailing chain, announced a reshuffling of veteran executives at three of its department store divisions.   The moves were precipitated by the sudden resignation last week of H. Gene Nau, president and chief executive of the company's Famous-Barr St. Louis division. Mr. Nau, who had held those posts since 1984, gave no reason for his decision to step down.   Judith K. Hofor, president and chief executive of the May Company of California, was named to succeed Mr. Nau at Famous-Barr.

headline: Swan Seeks to Buy Pittsburgh Brewer
abstract: The Swan Acquisition Company today offered $27 million in cash, or $21.50 per share, for the 1.25 million shares outstanding of the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, the ninth-largest American brewer. A Pittsburgh Brewing spokesman, William Eiler, declined comment but said the company might respond to the offer on Tuesday.

headline: New Name Sought At R.J. Reynolds
abstract: R. J. Reynolds Industries said its board had voted to seek shareholder approval to change the company's name to RJR Nabisco Inc. It said shareholders also would be asked to approve an increase in the number of authorized Reynolds common and preferred shares, limits on the ability of shareholders to take action by written consent and adoption of a ''fair price'' provision.   Reynolds proposed that the numberof its authorized shares would increase to 600 million from 300 million and preferred shares to 40 million from 20 million.

headline: IRISH RUGBY: THE ATTENTION IS UNDIVIDED
abstract: To the sports fan, Ireland's rugby team has just ended an unremarkable season. It lost to Scotland, leaving Ireland winless in four matches in international competition this year.   Yet from a social and political perspective, every game the Irish team plays is remarkable indeed. As it has for decades, the Irish Rugby Football Union selects for the national team the 15 best players it can find on the whole island - some from the Republic of Ireland, a predominantly Roman Catholic nation, and others from Northern Ireland, a mainly Protestant region that remains a British province.

headline: ECONOMY UP AS FRENCH VOTE
abstract: After five years of Socialist rule, France is approaching Sunday's parliamentary elections with a stronger economy and a firmer attachment to capitalist values than at any time since the left came to power, and perhaps before.   If the polls are to be believed, however, the recent sharp improvement in France's economy has come too late to save the Socialists from defeat. On the other hand, the progress would encourage a new right-wing government to press ahead with its electoral commitment to roll back France's centuries-old tradition of state control over the economy.   Until now, many economists feared that the opposition party's pledge to ease price and exchange controls, reduce restrictions on worker dismissals, cut taxes and denationalize state-owned companies would result in a wider trade deficit, more inflation and higher unemployment.   But the sharp drop in oil prices lessens many of these risks by slowing inflation, improving France's trade accounts and giving a welcome fillip to economic growth.

headline: Eastern Air Labor Crises
abstract: The Federal Government's top labor negotiator warned today that Eastern Airlines must resolve the labor crises with its 40,000 employees by the end of next month, calling the carrier's financial situation ''perilous.''   Walter Wallace, chairman of the National Mediation Board, refused to say outright that the company faces bankruptcy if the deadline set by its major creditors is not met.

headline: CAR BOMB KILLS 5 AND WOUNDS 30 IN EAST BEIRUT
abstract: A car bomb exploded today in East Beirut, the predominantly Christian sector, and 5 people were reported killed and 30 wounded. It was the seventh bombing in the area in seven weeks.   The police said a French-made car loaded with 250 pounds of explosives was detonated near offices of President Amin Gemayel's Phalange Party. There was no immediate assertion of responsibility for the bombing.

headline: Boeing Gets Order
abstract: British Airways has ordered two 747 jumbo jetliners and one twin-engine 757 jet aircraft at a cost of more than $245 million, the Boeing Company said.

headline: IN SPANISH VOTE, THE ISOLATIONIST URGE
abstract: A referendum Wednesday on whether Spain should quit the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has split the nation over the fundamental question of its national identity.   Spain joined the European Economic Community in January. According to intellectuals and political figures, with the vote on Wednesday Spaniards will decide whether to complete their integration into the West or remain slightly apart.   For almost four centuries, up through the dictatorship of Generalissimo Francisco Franco that ended 11 years ago, Spaniards have mainly been an isolationist people, avoiding developments such as the Reformation and two world wars.

headline: It's Now Navistar
abstract: As expected, the shareholders of International Harvester voted overwhelmingly today to approve changing the company's name to the Navistar International Corporation. The vote, at the company's annual meeting, was 46.7 million shares in favor to 474,000 against, with 498,000 abstentions. The Chicago-based truck manufacturer, had proposed changing its name following the completion of the sale of its agricultural equipment business to J. I. Case, a subsidiary of Tenneco, in January.

headline: SHAKE-UP IN HAITI: OUSTING OLD GUARD
abstract: The shake-up in the Haitian Government, just six weeks after it took over, appears to politicians and diplomats to be the result of continuing popular pressure to eliminate remnants of the ousted Duvalier regime from the structure of power.   The crisis was brought to a head by the resignation last Thursday of Gerard Gourgue, the only one of five original full members of the ruling junta who was widely recognized as a longtime opponent of the Duvalier dictatorship.   The shake-up took place in the context of almost continuous work stoppages, strikes and protests. Over the last few weeks, ordinary Haitians, for the first time in years, have gained an awareness of their power to affect events. They have pressed demands both for higher wages and for a thorough purge of officials associated with the dictatorship who continued to occupy many positions of influence.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WALL ST. FIRMS USE 'GOLDEN HANDCUFFS'
abstract: All over Wall Street, investment banking houses are slapping their employees in handcuffs - ''golden handcuffs'' to be precise.   Even the most prominent firms appear to be tortured by the same fear these days: that their stars will get a better offer from a competitor and jump ship.   So to make sure they stay on board, such firms as Morgan Stanley; Bear, Stearns and L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin are trying to bind them with lucrative arrangements that often promise them tens of thousands, if not millions, of dollars with only one condition: they must stay around awhile to collect.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Anderson Clayton & Co., Houston, announced completion of the sale of American Founders Life Insurance Co. to Continental Fidelity Life Insurance Co. for $58 million.    * Celanese Corp. said it would purchase up to 600,000 shares of its common stock from time to time in the open market.    * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said it had raised the prices of imported passenger cars made for Chrysler by its Japanese partner, the Mitsubishi Motors Corp., an average of 1.8 percent.

headline: Polish Debt Agreement
abstract: Poland has reached an agreement to reschedule slightly more than $1.6 billion of its debt to Western governments, an official close to the talks said today. Before the pact, Poland's annual debt service to both governments and foreign commercial banks was estimated at almost $6 billion.

headline: Advertising; Addendum
abstract: * PC World Communications, San Francisco, is expecting to acquire Desktop Publishing magazine from Bove & Rhodes Associates, Woodside, Calif.

headline: Greyhound Closing 35 Terminals
abstract: Greyhound Lines Inc. will close 35 of its 125 bus terminals nationwide by Oct. 1, company officials announced today.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: The New York Public Library's 1986-87 institutional campaign to Jameson Advertising.

headline: NICARAGUA ASSEMBLY TO FORM CHARTER
abstract: When Nicaragua's elected National Assembly ended its first year of work recently, its President, Carlos Nunez Tellez, said in his closing speech that the Assembly's principal role was to be ''the maximum expression of national unity.''   After the speech, several opposition members of the Assembly complained that Mr. Nunez's statement reflected its weakness and its failure to become an effective forum for political debate.   In 1986 the Assembly's principal task will be to draw up a new constitution, and opposition members are planning to use the constitutional debate to demand greater power for the Assembly.   ''It will be hard for anyone outside the Sandinista Front to support a constitution in which the Assembly is not given the power to approve treaties or vote on the national budget,'' said Luis Humberto Guzman, an Assembly member from the Popular Social Christian Party. ''Can you imagine that in a country at war, the parliamentary Committee for Defense has never met?''

headline: Bid for Minstar Bowling Unit
abstract: The Minstar Corporation, the Minneapolis holding company headed by Irwin L. Jacobs, said yesterday it had received an unsolicited bid of $200 million for the bowling operations of its AMF Inc. unit. Minstar did not identify the bidder, but insiders said it was an investment group led by a retired AMF executive.

headline: Kodak Refunding
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company's refund program for owners of soon-to-be-worthless Kodak instant cameras will be delayed about a month because of delays in the printing of special forms and brochures, a company spokesman said. Kodak began its special refund program, in which consumers call a special toll-free number to get a packet of information about the refunds, on Jan. 9, the day a court order went into effect forcing the company from the instant photography business.

headline: Japan Makers' Reaction
abstract: Japanese auto makers appeared resigned today to the Government's decision to continue automobile export quotas. Their comments reflected a widespread recognition here that the continuance was a political necessity.

headline: Allied-Signal Executive Shifting to Henley Post
abstract: Last fall, Allied-Signal Inc. stunned Wall Street by announcing that it would spin off more than 30 companies with combined assets of more than $3 billion and send its president, Michael D. Dingman, off to run them. Ever since, Paul M. Montrone, Allied-Signal's executive vice president for finance and administration, has tried to be a good soldier.   As part of the spinoff, it was agreed that a number of Mr. Dingman's longtime business associates, including Marc I. Stern, Harold S. Eastman and David L. Summers, would move with him over to the new company, the Henley Group. But Edward I. Hennessy, Allied-Signal's chairman and chief executive, made it clear that he wanted Mr. Montrone, who has worked with Mr. Dingman for the last 16 years, to remain with ''Mother,'' as Mr. Dingman calls Allied-Signal.

headline: A DAIRY SOARS BY STAYING PUT
abstract: While most food companies are shifting as fast as they can away from commodities and toward highly profitable packaged foods, the Dean Foods Company has stayed put, sticking largely to that most basic of commodities - milk.   The strategy has paid off handsomely. It has become the leading dairy not only in Chicago, but also in other major markets around the United States, supplying milk sold under private labels at such grocery chains as Super Valu, Jewel and Kroger. It also is a major supplier of ice cream sold though about 425 Baskin-Robbins outlets. And, though not a household name, Dean Foods has become one of the most profitable companies in the food industry.   ''You can't point to just one thing,'' said Richard G. Elam, an analyst with Blunt Ellis & Loewi. ''They consistently make good acquisitions in important markets. They have conscientious management, plus the expertise. Put that all together, that spells success.''

headline: U.S. REPORTED CLOSE TO ARMS SALE TO CHINA TO MODERNIZE AIR FORCE
abstract: The United States is close to concluding a sale to China of radar and other equipment to modernize China's fighter planes, Reagan Administration officials said today.   If this deal, being negotiated in Peking by Chinese and American officials, goes ahead, it will be the largest sale of American military equipment to China since it was authorized to buy such hardware in 1984. Officials said it could run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Times Mirror Net Off 30.5%
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said today that its net income dropped 30.5 percent in the fourth quarter, to $58.2 million, or 90 cents a share, from $83.7 million, or $1.21 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 7.3 percent, to $803.6 million, from $748.7 million a year ago.

headline: Operating Net Up at Cargill
abstract: CHICAGO, March 14 -    Cargill Inc., the grain trading and processing giant that is one of the nation's largest privately held companies, disclosed today in a rare public document that its operating earnings have improved recently even though its grain trading operations remain depressed.   In a prospectus for a $100 million Eurodollar offering, Cargill said its operating profits jumped to $201.1 million for the six months ending Nov. 30, up 39.1 percent, from $144.6 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: PRICES OF OIL EASE ON THATCHER TALK
abstract: Prices of crude oil and refined products eased in moderate trading on world markets yesterday.   The price drop, which came on the heels of a Monday rally, occurred shortly after remarks by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain to Parliament were released.   In those remarks, Mrs. Thatcher reiterated her Government's long-standing position of noninterference in the production decisions of British North Sea oil companies.

headline: Angola Rebels Report Damaging Oil Complex
abstract: Angolan rebels asserted today that they had attacked and seriously damaged American-operated oil installations in the northern part of the country.   But a spokesman for the Chevron oil subsidiary Gulf Oil, which operates the complex, said today that it was unaffected by the rebel attacks.

headline: Bishops in Philippines Challenged by Marcos
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos demanded today that the nation's Roman Catholic bishops prove their allegations that the Philippine presidential election was fraudulent, and he threatened to prosecute some members of the clergy.   Mr. Marcos's challenge came in a letter to Ricardo Cardinal Vidal, president of the Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines, a day after the conference denounced the election as ''unparalleled in fraudulence'' and urged Filipinos to wage a ''nonviolent struggle for justice.''

headline: OUTLOOK MODEST FOR GENEVA TALKS
abstract: The talks on intermediate-range nuclear weapons represent the most promising area for progress at the next round of the Geneva arms negotiations, which begin on Thursday, according to some Reagan Administration officials.   But the officials also caution that there are several major stumbling blocks in the way of an agreement on reducing such weapons, including Soviet insistence that British and French nuclear arsenals are counted.   The coming talks, which will also deal with intercontinental weapons and space weapons, are the first since the Geneva summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in November.   Administration officials said the United States negotiators would introduce only minor adjustments to their position, because the Soviet Union had not yet responded in detail to a American proposal made at the end of the last session in early November.

headline: FED'S FUTURE AFTER MARTIN
abstract: THE events surrounding the departure of Preston Martin as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board have been disturbing for everybody concerned. Nominally, the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, often called ''the second-most powerful man in the country,'' comes out the winner. But, as one veteran Fed-watcher, Lawrence A. Krause of the Brookings Institution, puts it, ''Paul has been hurt, even though Martin is leaving.''   Like a flash of lightning over a darkling plain, the fight at the Fed revealed for one brilliant moment the power struggle at the central bank and the Administration's dominance over monetary policy.

headline: RUMMAGING THROUGH MARCOS'S DESK
abstract: Documents found in the desk of the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, portray the final days of a desperate and harried man struggling to cling to office while still enmeshed in the minutiae of the power he had accumulated.   Along with intelligence reports, orders to his generals and telegrams urging him to take strong action, Mr. Marcos's desk was stuffed with requests for favors, promotions and loans, a prayer and a prediction by a member of a religious cult that Mr. Marcos would be the vehicle for the second coming of Christ.   The documents offer a glimpse of events from within Malacanang Palace as the world outside crumbled around it during the crucial days in mid-February leading to a military revolt that drove Mr. Marcos from office.   The contents of his desk include strategy suggestions for influencing President Reagan, a draft proclamation of a state of emergency that was not put into effect, and election tally sheets with notations that appear to indicate Mr. Marcos's involvement in vote manipulation.

headline: LET PEOPLE KNOW WHAT THEY'RE EATING
abstract: IMAGINE a $50 billion-a-year campaign to sabotage Americans' health. Though it would never admit it, that is essentially what the fast-food industry is doing with its slick merchandising of products dunked in fat and laced with salt. While it may be unrealistic to expect fast-food restaurants to adopt a completely healthful menu, is it too much to ask that they label product ingredients so that consumers can at least make informed choices about what they eat?   Actually, current Federal regulations call for ingredient labeling of packaged foods, but there is some question whether this applies to fast-food restaurants. Last month, the Agriculture Department rejected a petition filed by several consumer health groups to extend labeling requirements to meat and poultry products served in fast-food restaurants, contending that the practice would be expensive, cumbersome and unnecessary. A similar petition is now pending before the Food and Drug Administration, which is responsible for most fast-food products besides meat and poultry.

headline: EUROPEANS EXPECT DELAYED PROJECTS
abstract: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger is expected to have far-reaching effects on the pace and perhaps the future of European space projects, government and industry officials in several European countries said today.   The French-led Ariane satellite launcher has emerged in recent years as a serious competitor to the shuttle in the lucrative business of putting commercial satellites into space. France is also spearheading efforts to develop a European space shuttle.

headline: TURNAROUND AT ITALY'S E.N.I.
abstract: For years the largest corporation in Italy was known as ''the hospital,'' and the nickname reflected a reputation for illness rather than healing. The company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, regularly used to run up losses proportionate to its size as the world's third-largest, non-American multinational company.   But now, E.N.I. seems to be curing itself. In one of the sharpest turnarounds in business history, E.N.I. reported a profit of about $474 million for 1985, based on year-end exchange rates, compared with losses of about $871 million in 1983 and about $34 million in 1984. The transformation of E.N.I.'s balance sheet is the result of a program, begun in 1983, under which Italy's Socialist Government decided to run E.N.I. like a private company, but without relinquishing its ownership.   Like all of Italy's state holding companies, E.N.I. is a political creature. While its good health is crucial to the Italian economy because it provides more than half of the nation's oil and gas supplies, the company's recent success also demonstrates the extent to which management techniques copied from the private sector can improve the performance of a state enterprise that must pursue goals set in political forums rather than the marketplace.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: The drawings with an article on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s ''dishonor roll'' appeared without a credit line. The artist was John S. Dykes.

headline: Denial on Bids By Bingham
abstract: Barry Bingham Sr. says that no companies have been invited to become potential bidders on the three communications companies he has placed on the market.   That conflicts with remarks earlier this week by Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Company, who said in a news conference in Detroit on Monday that ''Gannett is one of the companies that has been invited to take a look'' at the Courier-Journal and Louisville Times Company, WHAS Inc. and the Standard Gravure Corporation.   But Mr. Bingham, chairman of the three companies that have been controlled by his family for three generations, said Tuesday that ''nobody has been invited to make a bid for the companies.''

headline: Frates Stake in Kaiser
abstract: An investment group led by J. A. Frates, the Oklahoma investor, said on Friday that it had raised its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to almost 20 percent from 18.6 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

headline: FALLING PESO DRAWS NEW CONCERNS
abstract: Bankers, economists and business executives will be watching the currency exchange markets closely Monday to learn whether the Mexican peso will stabilize or continue its precipitous slide against the dollar that began at the end of last week.   Mexico's currency fell 62 pesos against the dollar last Thursday and Friday, closing at 475 pesos to the dollar in bank-owned exchange houses. At some private exchange houses, the rate exceeded 500 pesos to the dollar by the end of business Friday.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: American Century Corp., San Antonio, said its board had approved the previously announced offer by Gerald H. Stool to acquire the 67 percent of the company he does not already own for about $6.30 a share.    * American Standard Inc. said it intended to buy up to another two million shares of its common in open market or other transactions.    * Bethlehem Steel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., said it was raising transaction prices for rails and accessories $35 per short ton and 5 percent for track work, effective immediately for new orders placed for shipment starting April 1.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The trade deficit surged to $13.68 billion in November, the third-biggest monthly imbalance ever recorded between the value of goods the United States imports and the goods it exports. For the first 11 months of 1985, the deficit exceeded the $123.31 billion record for all of 1984. Analysts warned that protectionist sentiment could revive if the gap does not start to narrow by spring.  [ Page 1. ]    Sales of new homes rose by 7.7 percent in November, the biggest advance in more than a year. The increase followed declines of 7.8 percent in October, 4.5 percent in September and 5.3 percent in August. Those declines had surprised economists, since mortgage rates have been falling.  [ 35. ]

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: REVERE REPORTS ACQUISITION OFFER
abstract: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. said it had received an offer from an investment group to be acquired for $16 a share, or about $127 million. The investment group included the Oxford Financial Group, the Jamie Securities Company and Prudential Equities Inc. The investor group said the proposal was friendly and added that it wanted Revere's management to continue to operate the company.

headline: LEBANON CAR BOMB KILLS DRIVER, HURTS 7 AT PALESTINIAN SITE
abstract: A car bomb exploded today at the entrance of the largest Palestinian refugee district in southern Lebanon, killing the driver and wounding seven people.   The police said the explosion occurred outside the Ain Khilwe camp, near the port of Sidon 25 south of here, half an hour before Palestinian students were to join a Moslem march in the city marking the 11th anniversary of the slaying of a Sidon mayor.   ''It would have been a blood bath if the blast took place at the time of the march,'' a police spokesman was quoted by the Beirut Moslem radio station Voice of the Nation as saying.

headline: Technologies Net Up 10.7%
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 10.7 percent on a 5.8 percent increase in revenues.   Net income advanced to $165.9 million, or $1.25 a share, from $149.8 million, or $1.21 a share, in the 1984 quarter, which included a loss from discontinued operations of $10.3 million.

headline: World Bank Aid Delayed
abstract: The Reagan Administration is withholding a $75 million contribution to the World Bank's special fund for Africa to see if it will be cut under the new deficit-reduction law, a Treasury official said Tuesday.   The contribution, approved by Congress on Dec. 19, was to have been paid to the World Bank by Tuesday.

headline: Advertising; ABC-TV'S 4th OF JULY PROMOTION
abstract: Tickets for the rededication of the Statue of Liberty will be available in many forms and at many prices. But one source that has not been mentioned yet is the ABC television network. It will provide tickets to TV sponsors of ABC News coverage of the four-day event on the Fourth of July weekend.   ABC-TV is using the tickets as pot sweeteners, an extra added attraction for advertisers. Then the advertisers themselves can turn around and use them as an incentive for their customers, sales people, dealers, bottlers, franchisees or anybody else in need of a carrot on a stick.

headline: ARAFAT ACCUSES SYRIA AND LIBYA IN RAIDS
abstract: Syria and Libya are behind the recent rash of terrorist attacks in the Mediterranean and Europe and are trying to discredit the Palestine Liberation Organization and hinder negotiations with Israel, Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said in an interview published in today's issue of the Washington Post.   Mr. Arafat also said the United States, by refusing to negotiate with the P.L.O., had stalled Middle East peace efforts and helped create an environment in which young Palestinians are recruited for terrorist operations by Arab intelligence agencies.

headline: WORKING WEEKENDS AT THE AGE OF 89
abstract: 'I HAVE a theory,'' said Philip L. Carret. ''The top brass should have at least a year's salary invested in their company.''   In fact, the 89-year-old founder and chairman of Carret & Company, the New York broker-dealer and investment advisory firm, believes so strongly in that theory that it is one of the deciding factors he uses in picking stocks.

headline: SHULTZ DENOUNCES PHILIPPINE FRAUD
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today assailed what he called ''fraud and violence on a systematic and widespread scale'' carried out by the supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the election in the Philippines.   Speaking out for the first time, Mr. Shultz, in testimony before the Senate, issued the Administration's strongest condemnation so far of the Feb. 7 election.   ''One can't say that we got out of the election what one wants to get out of the election, namely a legitimized and credible government,'' he said of the re-election of Mr. Marcos over his opponent, Corazon C. Aquino. Questioning Legitimacy    Before the election, the United States had repeatedly urged the Marcos Government to permit a vote that would be honest and credible to the Filipino people. This was the first time a senior Administration official had publicly questioned the ''legitimacy'' of the Marcos victory, although President Reagan on Saturday had criticized fraud and violence by the Marcos camp.

headline: Kaiser Golden Parachutes
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, responding to an unsolicited takeover proposal by an investor group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., issued a proxy statement today disclosing certain ''golden parachute'' provisions for the company's executives. The statement accompanied a letter urging Kaiser shareholders not to sign consent statements allowing Mr. Frates's group to replace the Kaiser board with its own nominees.   According to the proxy statement, Kaiser, beginning in the summer of 1985, entered into severance agreements with 17 current employees, including 5 executive officers, granting them lump sum severance payments of 2.5 times their basic salary in the event they are terminated after a change in the control of the company.

headline: OCCIDENTAL VOTE
abstract: Shareholders of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation approved the acquisition of the Midcon Corporation and the transaction is expected to be concluded Tuesday. Midcon held a separate shareholders meeting in Lombard, Ill., to approve the deal, but because Occidental already held 53 percent of Midcon, there was no doubt about the outcome.

headline: COURT CURBS TOXIC WASTE TAX
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that some of the special taxes New Jersey has collected from oil and chemical companies for toxic waste cleanups were pre-empted by the Federal Superfund law and must be refunded.   The decision could also block use of such taxes to create special funds for toxic waste cleanups not only in New Jersey but in New York, California and other states, environmentalists concerned about its potential impact said today.   But while the decision spread concern among environmentalists and state officials, its import is unclear even for New Jersey, the state most directly affected. This is because the Court did not specify whether the pre-emptive effect of the Federal Superfund law continued after key provisions of that measure expired in September and because of disputes about how much money today's decision requires New Jersey to refund.

headline: Thrift Unit Reopens
abstract: Sierra Federal Savings and Loan Association of Denver will reopen today as a branch of Commercial Federal Savings and Loan Association of Omaha following the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's closing of Sierra Friday.

headline: STANDARD OIL'S 2 TOP OFFICERS OUSTED
abstract: In a move that stunned Wall Street, the Standard Oil Company, which is controlled by the British Petroleum Company, announced yesterday that its two top officers would be replaced April 1. They are Alton W. Whitehouse, chairman and chief executive officer, and John Miller, president and chief operating officer.   The Standard Oil board of directors named a British Petroleum executive to lead Standard and also placed two other senior B.P. executives in key management positions. The London-based company also is seeking to double, to six, its seats on Standard's 14-member board.

headline: EXXON'S TIME OF OPPORTUNITY
abstract: When John D. Rockefeller, a young partner in a produce business in Cleveland, ventured into the oil business in 1863, the industry was in the midst of a disastrous glut, with wildly fluctuating prices and wholesale bankruptcies. Mr. Rockefeller saw opportunity in the chaos, and by 1882 he had established the Standard Oil Trust, the leviathan that eventually gave birth to the modern Exxon Corporation.   The environment of collapsing oil prices is certainly more complicated now than it was in the industry's infancy. But when oil analysts look at Exxon's future, they invariably look backward as well as forward. What they see is an almost impregnable giant that has been able to take advantage of opportunities offered by bad markets as well as good ones.   So while Exxon is facing many of the same short-term problems as the rest of the industry, analysts say that its enormous cash flow and light debt load could provide a historic opportunity for the world's largest oil company to become that much larger.

headline: U.S. Holds Up Sri Lanka Tea After Rebels Warn of Cyanide
abstract: Black tea arriving in the United States from Sri Lanka is being held up and tested because of threats by terrorists in that country to contaminate exports with cyanide, the Food and Drug Administration said today.   In an internal advisory to its regional offices, the F.D.A. said it had moved to intercept tea imports from Sri Lanka after the State Department warned that terrorists had made the threats.

headline: THE EXECUTIVE AS ARTIST
abstract: Venture capitalist Walter Channing likes to follow a day of deal-making with an evening of sculpting. Robert S. Whyte, a financial services executive, spends weekdays orchestrating corporate strategy and weekends as a banjo-playing bandleader. Attorney Joseph W. Bartlett, a former Under Secretary of Commerce, writes frequently about business and law, then pens plays about dilemmas in those two worlds.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Adventure Inc., Kirkland, Wash., a private recreational vehicle campground, said it named John M. Nye president and director.    * Bank of America, San Francisco, has appointed Richard D. Morrison president and chief executive officer of BA Cheque Corp., a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corp.    * Bowne & Co., a financial information printer, has elected Franz von Ziegesar chairman, succeeding Edmund A. Stanley Jr. Richard H. Koontz was elected president.

headline: KEY APPEAL BY PENNZOIL SET TO OPEN
abstract: Armed with some of the country's top lawyers, Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company plan to take a key portion of their dispute to a Federal appeals court today.   At issue is what Texaco considers its right to an orderly appeal of a Texas state court's multibillion-dollar verdict against it and what Pennzoil feels is an unwarranted intrusion by a Federal court in a state proceeding.   The appeals court's decision will have a major impact on the ultimate outcome of the feud over Texaco's acquisition of the Getty Oil Company in 1984, according to analysts and lawyers following the litigation. Texaco Position    If Texaco prevails, it could pursue its case with minimum financial disruption and enter any settlement negotiations with Pennzoil from a position of strength.

headline: BUYERS SEE MORE SIGNS OF GROWTH IN ECONOMY
abstract: The nation's economy continued to show strength in February, with higher production and rising new orders, according to a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management.   The report, based on a survey of 250 purchasing managers who work for industrial companies, said net inventories rose for the third month in a row as purchases increased in response to expanding business.   New orders in February were the highest since June 1984, the survey said, while employment fell after an increase in January and the speed of vendor deliveries was unchanged.

headline: Chase Will Buy Bank in Florida
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank said last night that it had submitted the winning bid to take over an insolvent commercial bank in Florida from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Chase said it paid $62.6 million.

headline: NEW FRENCH CABINET HOLDS FIRST MEETING
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand held his first Cabinet meeting today with the leaders of a new conservative Government made up of his political opponents.   The meeting, which was described as ''cool'' by commentators here, was the first visible act of the power-sharing arrangement, known as cohabitation, between Mr. Mitterrand, a Socialist, and members of the rightist parties that won a narrow victory in parliamentary elections a week ago.   The meeting was held as usual in a Baroque room in the presidential palace, where Mr. Mitterrand sat at the large oval ministerial table this morning. He was opposite Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the leader of the largest conservative political party, and surrounded by the 37 ministers and secretaries of state who make up the Government named by Mr. Chirac on Thursday.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. HURTS RELATIONS BY ITS U.N. ORDER
abstract: The Soviet Government said today that ''direct damage'' to relations with the United States could result from the American order that the size of Soviet missions to the United Nations be reduced.   A protest read at the Foreign Ministry to the United States charge d'affaires, Richard Combs Jr., said:   ''Of course, the Soviet side cannot pass such unlawful United States actions over and will have to draw approriate conclusions.''   The protest, which was made public by Tass, the Government press agency, did not specify what actions the Soviet Union contemplated. But it mentioned plans for the next summit meeting and the new agreement to set up consulates in Kiev and in New York.

headline: Low Inflation in E.E.C.
abstract: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January for an annual inflation rate of 4.7 percent, the lowest since 1970, the community's statistics office said Friday.

headline: MARCOS WEIGHS HIS CHOICE OF EXILE
abstract: Ferdinand E. Marcos spent today in seclusion, discussing with members of his family where they will settle permanently as exiles.   According to a knowledgeable source in the Hawaiian Government, one option being considered by Mr. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, is a plan under which they would make their principal home here but eventually divide their time between Hawaii and New York City. Mrs. Marcos is said to favor living in New York.   Mr. and Mrs. Marcos, their two daughters and a son and more than 80 other relatives, servants and associates arrived here Wednesday from Guam in American military transport planes. They had fled Manila on Tuesday as Mr. Marcos's rule began to collapse under pressure from military forces loyal to Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: EASTERN'S LABOR TALKS FACE GROWING PRESSURE
abstract: Eastern Airlines will have to reach agreements with its three major unions by the end of February on large permanent cuts in wages and changes in work rules in order to meet requirements set by lenders to keep the carrier out of default.   Eastern has had similar requirements placed on it by its lenders before, in 1983 and in 1984, and managed to gain the concessions from most of its unions. This time, however, Eastern faces a much tougher task. The carrier is asking for permanent changes, rather than the temporary measures it sought in the past, and many of the union rank and file are taking a tough stance against further concessions.

headline: Two Presidents of Units Of HNG/Internorth Quit
abstract: Aftershocks from last year's merger of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Internorth Inc. reverberated through the executive suite yesterday, when the presidents of two of HNG/Internorth's largest subsidiaries announced they were stepping down.   In separate announcements, William V. Morgan, who was named president of the Northern Natural Gas Company in September, and Melvin R. Sweatman, president of the Houston Pipe Line Company since September 1984, both said they would leave their respective jobs at the end of the month to pursue other business interests.

headline: Seabrook Project Issues May Finish Financing
abstract: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday announced two bond issues totaling $288 million that are expected to complete the financing needed for the Seabrook nuclear power plant.   Since early 1984, when the utility was on the brink of bankruptcy, it has raised more than $500 million in a three-stage financing plan devised and managed by Robert G. Hildreth Jr., a managing director at Merrill Lynch Cpaital Markets. ''This latest financing means that borrowing for Seabrook is done and in the bank,'' Mr. Hildreth said.  The latest offering consists of highly speculative issues of taxable and tax-exempt bonds, both rated B-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and CCC by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; Avoiding the Minimum Tax
abstract: RECENTLY, a corporate executive was looking forward to exercising an incentive stock option that would enable him to pick up some shares for less than their market value. But his accountant cautioned him that what seemed like a bargain could increase his taxes -because the difference between fair market value and incentive option prices is one of the tax preference items of the alternative minimum tax.   After discussion with the accountant, the executive decided instead to exercise some nonqualified stock options that he held. That way, he would be creating ordinary income, which would raise his adjusted gross income and not trigger the A.M.T., as it is known.

headline: OGLIVY & MATHER WINS ITS 3d TOP KELLY AWARD
abstract: At the fifth annual Stephen E. Kelly Award luncheon Wednesday Ogilvy & Mather, the house built by David Ogilvy, a star of print advertising, won its third top prize for ''execellence in magazine advertising.''   The entry was the American Express/Retail campaign and the agency people honored for it were Thomas Rost, creative director; Nancy O'Neal, art director, and Jeffrey Atlas and Martha Fenton, both copywriters.   The only agency among the 10 runners-up to have two selected campaigns was, of course, Fallon, McElligott Rice of Minneapolis.

headline: Positions Shift At Monsanto
abstract: The Monsanto Company has announced that Richard J. Mahoney, president and chief executive officer, has been named chairman. Mr. Mahoney, 51 years old, replaces Dr. Louis Fernandez, 62, who is taking early retirement.   The St. Louis-based chemical company also said on Friday that Mr. Mahoney would be relinquishing the president's post, which will be taken by Francis J. Fitzgerald, 58, an executive vice president and president of the Monsanto Chemical Company. Mr. Fitzgerald was also named chief operating officer.

headline: Pump Leaks Plutonium Mist At a Nuclear Plant in Britain
abstract: Plutonium mist leaked from Britain's only nuclear reprocessing plant today, prompting a major alert and tests on 70 workers, the plant owners said.

headline: SHOULD CONGRESS RAISE THE MINIMUM WAGE?; THE WORKING POOR DESERVE A RAISE
abstract: ECONOMISTS are predicting continued economic growth and prosperity for the foreseeable future, and that is good news. Unfortunately, the millions of Americans who work for the minimum wage are not sharing this prosperity. The real value of the minimum - which was designed to protect the working poor by placing a floor under their meager earnings - is now at its lowest level since 1955.  At $3.35 an hour, the minimum wage is still at the same level it was in January 1981. In that same time, the cost of living has risen by 26 percent, so that a full-time, year-round minimum wage worker currently earns income equivalent to only 76 percent of the poverty level for a family of three.

headline: Land Mine Kills 19 Near Afghan Border
abstract: A land mine Saturday destroyed two pickup trucks filled with Afghan refugees on their way to a wedding, killing 18 women and a man, guerrillas and newspaper reports said today.   Eight people were wounded in the explosion in the remote Gamo area near the town of Parachinar, close to the Afghan frontier, Afghan guerrilla officials said.   Guerrilla officials said the trucks set off an antitank mine on the road near an Afghan refugee camp.

headline: Carbide Vice Chairman Is Retiring Tomorrow
abstract: Alec Flamm, who until last summer served as president and chief operating officer at the Union Carbide Corporation, announced yesterday that he will retire tomorrow as vice chairman and a board member.   Mr. Flamm's decision to leave Carbide followed a conversation he had recently with Warren M. Anderson, the company's chairman and chief executive. According to Mr. Flamm, 59, the conversation centered on who would succeed Mr. Anderson next November, when Mr. Anderson, 64, reaches retirement age.

headline: U.S. Denies It Barred Nicaragua First Lady
abstract: The Nicaraguan Embassy said today that the wife of the Nicaraguan President had canceled plans to visit the United States for health reasons and because the United States had denied her a visa, but an American official disputed the account.   A State Department press officer, Greg Lagana, said the visa requested by Rosario Murillo de Ortega, the wife of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, had been approved and was available at the United States Embassy in Managua earlier this week.

headline: MANAGUA PRELATE IS PRESSED ON WAR
abstract: More than two dozen disfigured war veterans, some in wheelchairs and others missing limbs, arrived Friday morning at the office of Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo.   The veterans said they wanted to meet the Cardinal and appeal to him to denounce United States support for the guerrillas. He was not available, but his spokesman, the Rev. Bismarck Carballo, met with the protesters.

headline: American Delegation Is en Route to Vietnam
abstract: A high-level American delegation arrived in Thailand today on its way to Hanoi for talks on Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.   The team, led by Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard L. Armitage and including Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, is the highest-level group to visit Vietnam since the war ended in 1975.

headline: GAIN PUT AT $81 MILLION
abstract: The battle for the Union Carbide Corporation is over, and so too, it appears, is the war.   In a move that took few people by surprise, Samuel J. Heyman, head of the GAF Corporation, yesterday backed out of an exceptionally complex fight to take over the giant chemicals company. In withdrawing GAF's offer for Carbide's shares, Mr. Heyman walked away with handsome profits for GAF and for thousands of other Carbide shareholders who sold their stock back under Carbide's counteroffer.   At the same time, the feisty Mr. Heyman hinted vaguely that he might still resume the fight. The one-time real estate developer broke off an earlier proxy battle for GAF before ultimately winning control of the roofing and chemicals company two years ago.

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: Stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. The weekly Treasury bill auction will take place tomorrow instead of today.

headline: The Rising Regional Agencies
abstract: SITTING in his red brick headquarters building facing a statue of Robert E. Lee, David N. Martin, chairman of the Martin Agency of Richmond, ponders, on occasion, what he considers a developing trend in the advertising agency business.   It is a trend that involves regional agencies that are becoming national ones thanks to their own managements' drive, the willingness of some highly creative agency people to desert the big cities, and the desire of some clients to be served by such creative talent.   Mr. Martin certainly considers the Martin Agency as part of that trend. Why else would he spend time thinking about it?

headline: SWEDISH PREMIER SHOT DEAD AS HE STROLLS WITH HIS WIFE ON MAIN STOCKHOLM STREET
abstract: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden was assassinated Friday night on a Stockholm street minutes after he left a movie theater with his wife.   Mr. Palme, the leader of the country's Social Democratic Party, was 59 years old. #10 Questioned by Police There were no immediate arrests. The police said they had questioned about 10 people at the site of the shooting but had learned little, although at least one person, a taxi driver, said he had seen the shooting.

headline: LEAPING INTO SECURITIES WITHOUT LOOKING
abstract: THE rise of ''blind pool'' offerings has begun to disturb some analysts, who view such deals as symptoms of speculative fever.   In a blind pool, an investor does not know precisely how his money will be put to work. The offerings are designed to raise a bankroll. How that bankroll may be used by the deal's manager is often described only in the broadest terms. For example, while some blind-pool prospectuses will outline an area of investment, such as stocks, real estate or television stations - even the acquisition of companies - other prospectuses promise only that the manager will seek profitable opportunities.

headline: U.S. Promotes China Expert
abstract: Richard H. Solomon, a China expert, was appointed today to direct the policy planning staff of the State Department. Mr. Solomon has served on the National Security Council, taught at the University of Michigan and written three books about China. He succeeds Peter W. Rodman, who is moving to the National Security Council to oversee foreign policy there.

headline: THE THIRD WORLD CHALLENGES DETROIT
abstract: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.   But the feisty stock market and plunging interest rates have changed all that. Economists all over are expecting another respectable - albeit not sizzling -performance this year. (See graphics display on Page 4.) Exploding stock values have added more than $1 trillion to the nation's wealth over the last 18 months, experts say, giving consumers added confidence and new buying power. But business leaders fear that increased competition at home and abroad could make this a tough year. To flesh out the details, industry by industry, The New York Times asked its own specialists to look ahead for 1986. Here are their reports.

headline: Schroder Picks Officers And Sets Japanese Sale
abstract: The J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, the American banking, trust and leasing businesses of Schroders P.L.C., the big British merchant bank, has announced a number of changes in its top management.   Peter Rona, an executive vice president at the bank, was named president and chief executive officer. Alva O. Way, a former president of American Express, was named chairman.

headline: PIONEER ACCEPTS MESA'S BID
abstract: The Pioneer Corporation, a diversified energy company with sizable natural gas reserves but several struggling operations, said today that it had approved a merger offer from Mesa Limited Partnership, an energy concern headed by T. Boone Pickens.   Under the offer, Pioneer shareholders will receive a new form of Mesa securities called preference units. The merger was valued at between $763 million and $830 million.   Analysts said the purchase was consistent with Mr. Pickens's strategy of acquiring proven energy reserves rather than investing in exploration for new reserves. They added that the pact would increase Mesa's total natural gas reserves by more than two-thirds, to 2.1 trillion cubic feet. Natural gas accounts for nearly 90 percent of Mesa's energy reserves.

headline: BIAS IN NICARAGUA REPORTED BY JEWS
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted yesterday that President Reagan was correct when he accused the Nicaraguan Government of persecuting Jews in Nicaragua.  The group issued a four-page white paper in which it said the Government conducted a campaign of death threats and harassment against Nicaraguan Jews. The persecution led to the flight of almost all the Jews in Nicaragua, the league said.

headline: CURFEW RESUMED AS NEW DISTURBANCES ERUPT IN HAITI
abstract: New disturbances racked the country today, only hours after Gen. Henri Namphy, president of the five-man interim Government, lifted a monthlong curfew and appealed, in an address to the nation, for unity.   By nightfall, the Government declared that curfew had been reinstated, with an earlier starting time of 7 P.M. instead of the previous 11 P.M. It ends, as before, at 5 in the morning.   The Government also forbade the departure of former officials accused of human-rights abuses and arrested two reputed torturers. The actions were were seen as a response to the street unrest and as reflecting disagreement within the junta that was formed after President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled the country Feb. 7.

headline: PROTESTERS INCREASE PRESSURE ON HAITI'S NEW RULERS
abstract: Protesters chanting ''Down with the Government!'' set up roadblocks north of the capital today as pressure intensified on the military and civilian officials who came to power when the Duvalier regime fell six weeks ago.   Responding to demands that officials close to the former ruler be removed from the six-member ruling council, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy of the army announced Friday that three members with especially close ties to the Duvaliers had resigned. That left the council with three members.   In the last four days this military-civilian council, which General Namphy heads, has been shaken by a series of fresh street confrontations, in which at least seven people have been killed. The taxi and minibus drivers have gone on strike. Commercial flights by Eastern Air Lines, American Airlines and Air France have been suspended and the daily curfew has been extended, going into effect at 8 P.M.

headline: General's Resignation Accepted by Honduras
abstract: The Honduras Armed Forces Superior Council today accepted the resignation of the armed forces commander, Gen. Walter Lopez Reyes, even though he said he had changed his mind and wanted to stay.   The announcement, made on national television, said General Lopez would be replaced temporarily by Col. Efrain Gonzales of the Honduran Army.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SIGNALS ITS SUPPORT FOR 2 MILITARY MEN IN PHILIPPINES
abstract: The White House signaled today that it supported two Philippine military leaders who resigned from the Government and who called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign because of fraud in the elections Feb. 7.   In an unusual statement, issued with President Reagan's approval, the White House moved closer to calling for Mr. Marcos to give up office.   It said statements by the two former high Marcos aides reinforced Administration concern that the fraud in the elections, carried out mostly by the Marcos party, was ''so extreme as to undermine the credibility and legitimacy of the election and impair the capacity of the Government of the Philippines to cope with a growing insurgency and a troubled economy.''   The White House, in effect, endorsed the remarks made by the former Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, and the former Deputy Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, by summarizing them without qualifications in its statement and by pointedly not referring to Mr. Marcos's rebuttal.

headline: UGANDA TO SET UP PANEL TO INVESTIGATE ATROCITIES
abstract: The Ugandan Government will set up an international commission to investigate atrocities committed by past administrations since independence in 1962, the official Ugandan radio said today.   It did not indicate when the commission would be established, but quoted Prime Minister Samson Kisekka as saying Friday that the Administration would pursue former officials responsible for past atrocities against civilians in the same relentless manner as Israel pursues Nazi war criminals.   President Yoweri Museveni has vowed to seek the extradition of two former Ugandan leaders, Idi Amin, who is in Saudi Arabia, and Milton Obote, who is in Zambia.

headline: Airliner Crash Kills 21 People in Mexico
abstract: An AeroCalifornia DC-3 slammed into a hill and burst into flames today when it tried to land at a small, foggy airstrip on the Pacific coast. All 21 people aboard were killed, officials said.

headline: Carter, in Nicaragua, Meets With Officials and Opposition
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter met separately today with leaders of Nicaragua's Government and with opposition figures here, after having talked in Costa Rica with rebels trying to overthrow the Government.

headline: Pope to Visit Colombia
abstract: Pope John Paul said today that he would visit Colombia in July, and he expressed hope that he could tour other Latin American countries ''in the not too distant future.''

headline: U.S. NICHE IN COMPACT DISKS
abstract: When the compact disk arrived on the audio scene three years ago to general fanfare, many of the most demanding hi-fi enthusiasts and many American stereo manufacturers dismissed it. The new medium, they said, fell short of the sonic perfection claimed by its developers, offering a sound that was harsh, strident, ''mid-fi,'' at best.   But with annual sales of compact disk players approaching $500 million, many former nay-sayers have changed their tune. Several American manufacturers have introduced compact disk players for the high end of the audio market, where sonic excellence, assembly by hand and technical innovation are prized above convenience or economy.

headline: BRITISH OWNER IS PLANNING TO SELL GIMBEL CHAIN AND OTHERS IN U.S.
abstract: The 36 Gimbel stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee will be sold by B.A.T Industries, the British company that bought them from the Gimbel family in 1973.   In its announcement yesterday, the diversified London-based company, whose American subsidiary, Batus Inc., has its headquarters in Louisville, Ky., said that the chain's performance had proved disappointing.   For the same reason, it said it would also sell the Kohl's department stores in Minneapolis, the Frederick & Nelson stores in Seattle and the Crescent department stores in Spokane, Wash. Five Others to Be Kept    It will retain its five other American retail companies: Saks Fifth Avenue, based in New York; Marshall Field, Chicago; the Ivey's department stores in Charlotte, N.C.; Breuner's, a furniture chain in California, and Thimbles, a chain of popular-price apparel stores.

headline: Union Pacific Deal
abstract: The Union Pacific Corporation and the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad announced that they had terminated a merger agreement for a Union Pacific subsidiary, the Missouri Pacific Railroad, to acquire M.K.T. for about $110 million in cash and securities.

headline: Advertising; Campaign for Wine Coolers
abstract: THE Canandaigua Wine Company of Canandaigua, N.Y., has so far managed to succeed where a lot of other small- and medium-sized beverage companies have failed: in establishing itself as a major player in the booming wine cooler business.   The phenomenal growth of that category - from nothing five years ago to an estimated $935 million in retail sales last year - has been one of the few pieces of good news for the wine business and for the beleaguered alcoholic beverage industry in general. In the first six months of last year, shipments increased by 216 percent on a unit basis, according to Impact, an industry newsletter, while the overall wine market, excluding coolers, fell 7 percent.   Grabbing and holding on to a piece of that market for Canandaigua has been the job of Towne, Silverstein, Rotter Inc., which yesterday introduced a new $20 million campaign -double last year's spending - for the company's Sun Country wine coolers. Sun Country has become the top-selling product for Canandaigua, which last year had sales of $133 million and is the nation's eighth-largest winery.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Market Place; Stock-Buyback Strategies
abstract: THE stock market took a drubbing early last week when falling prices of crude oil caused particular weakness in oil issues and shares of money-center banks perceived as having possible energy loan problems. But Richard S. Strong, a money manager in Milwaukee, said the market had misread the implications of lower energy prices and overreacted in its initial behavior.   ''Lower oil prices will mean lower inflation rates and that will lead to lower interest rates,'' he said. ''In the process, this builds a very stable platform for financial instruments such as stocks and bonds.''

headline: MORE PHILIPPINE DIPLOMATS QUIT MARCOS SIDE
abstract: Additional numbers of Philippine diplomats in key foreign and United States posts broke with the Marcos Government yesterday, declaring their support for opposition leaders and Corazon C. Aquino.   At the Philippine Mission to the United Nations, the press officer, Narciso M. Reyes Jr., and a Third Secretary, Virgilio A. Reyes, called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign.   The two men, in a joint statement issued at an upper East Side apartment, said, ''We implore President Marcos to step down immediately in order to avert needless bloodshed.''

headline: Latin Debtors Meeting
abstract: The monitoring committee of the Cartagena debtors group is planning to meet Feb. 27 and 28 in Punta del Este, Uruguay. Foreign ministers of five nations forming the Cartagena monitoring committee - Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela - met in Washington earlier this week in response to a call for an emergency meeting by the latter two countries.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * DeLong Sportswear of Grinnell, Iowa, to Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zirbel, Des Moines.

headline: Market Place; Analysts View Railway Group
abstract: SEVERAL major railroad stocks, after lagging behind a surging equity market in the final quarter of 1985, have been selling recently at or near record prices.   ''It's essentially a case of the rails playing catch-up to the rest of the stock market,'' Stephen R. Klein, an industry analyst for Standard & Poor's, said yesterday. ''But the rails are still selling at a discount to earnings for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.''   His favorite in the group is Norfolk Southern, a leading Eastern coal-hauling railroad. His ''runner-up choice'' is the CSX Corporation, the territorial archrival of Norfolk Southern.

headline: SANDINISTA BAN ON CHURCH RADIO SEEMS TO BE STEP IN DRIVE ON PRESS
abstract: A decision by the Government this week to close the Roman Catholic radio station here appears to be the latest step in a three-month campaign against non-Sandinista press and broadcasting outlets.   Since October, two periodicals have been shut down, and editors of two others have been warned to stop publishing. In one case, a labor union magazine was closed because the Government said it did not have enough censors to read and check its contents.   The two editors who have been warned to stop circulating material are trying to continue doing so through various subterfuges.

headline: AT THE DAWN OF AN ERA OF LOW INTEREST RATES
abstract: A FEW years ago, with their children grown, Liz and Nelson Casmer bought a piece of land not far from their home in suburban Pittsburgh, planning to build a smaller house on it. But it was not until November, when interest rates made houses more affordable, that they found a buyer for the four-bedroom house they had owned for 22 years.   The Casmers then approached J. Roger Glunt, a Pittsburgh-area builder who specializes in single-family homes selling for $100,000 to $150,000 and whose business, he said, is now the best it has been in five years. Besides customers, he says he has banks pouring in the door. ''They're flooding us with rate sheets saying, 'Hey! We've got money!' ''   Next, the Casmers went to one of these lenders, Mellon Bank, which had knocked its rates for 15-year and 30-year conventional mortgages below 10 percent at the start of the year, sooner than most other lenders. ''We are probably doing in the vicinity of $20 million a month in western Pennsylvania,'' said Gary Frauenhotz, executive vice president in charge of mortgage banking. ''That compares with $3 million to $4 million a month a year ago.'' The bank granted the Casmers a 9 1/2 percent, 30-year loan. As Pittsburgh goes, so goes the nation.

headline: Advertising; Foote, Cone President Is Appointed Chairman
abstract: Norman W. Brown, president and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has also picked up the chairman's title left behind by John E. O'Toole when he retired at the end of the year.   Mr. Brown, 54, has been chief executive for three years, during which the agency's billings grew 50 percent worldwide while its full-service offices went to 61, from 38. Today it operates in 37 countries and is the country's ninth-largest agency worldwide.

headline: Metromedia Ad Business Sale
abstract: Metromedia Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its outdoor advertising business, the nation's largest, for $710 million.   The proposed sale, coming eight months after Metromedia agreed to sell its seven television stations for more than $2 billion, continues a radical streamlining and restructuring of the Secaucus, N.J., company by its chairman, John W. Kluge.   Metromedia said that it and Outdoor Advertising Associates, a limited partnership that owns the 45,000 billboards managed by Metromedia's Foster & Kleiser unit, had agreed to sell the business to Gerard P. Joyce, the founder and president of Patrick Media Group Inc. of Scranton, Pa.

headline: No Israeli Reaction
abstract: Israeli officials said they would have no direct comment today on Colonel Qaddafi's announcement.   ''We don't take him seriously,'' a Foreign Ministry official said. ''Why should we react to everything he says?''

headline: ALLIES GENERALLY BACK REAGAN'S RESPONSE ON ARMS
