abstract: President Reagan's proposed response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev plan to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000 has been given a generally positive reaction from the United States' allies, according to Administration officials.   But they said that reservations had been expressed, particularly by Japan. As a result, suggestions to modify the response were said to be under consideration, although it is not likely to be fundamentally changed.

headline: Utah Electric Project In $359 Million Issue
abstract: The National Cooperative Services Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell nearly $359 million of bonds as part of a sale and leaseback transaction involving a new electric generating plant leased by the Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative.   According to an official at Salomon Brothers Inc., which is handling the bond sale, the financing for the new Bonanza power plant in Vernal, Utah, is the largest leasing transaction ever arranged for a single facility.

headline: GAF Holdings
abstract: The GAF Corporation said it had retained a 10.6 percent stake the Union Carbide Corporation after its tender of 3.49 million shares to Union Carbide. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, it confirmed plans to remain the largest shareholder of Union Carbide and said it might try again to seek control of the chemical concern.

headline: DOW UP 11.02 TO CLOSE AT HIGH OF 1,821.72
abstract: The stock market improved again yesterday, despite some afternoon profit taking, as investors continued to react favorably to declining interest rates.   ''Bond prices were strong and the feeling is that interest rates are definitely coming down,'' said Chester Pado, a market analyst with Jefferies & Company in Los Angeles.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 32 points on Wednesday, gained an additional 11.02 points yesterday to finish the week at a record 1,821.72. The stock market is closed today for Good Friday.

headline: U.S. SAYS IT MAY LIMIT MANEUVERS IF LIBYA STOPS ARMED RESISTANCE
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that United States flight and naval operations in disputed waters near Libya may end before the scheduled conclusion next Tuesday provided that Libya did not resume armed opposition to the American maneuvers.   A ranking White House official said late today that the withdrawal of the Navy's 30-ship armada was tentatively scheduled to start on Thursday, but hinged on whether Libya restrained or resumed missile fire at Navy aircraft.   Since American retaliation began Monday for what the United States has said were Libyan SAM-5 missile attacks, there has been no reported military response from the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi except for sorties by small naval craft.   ''We were over there to make a point and we've made our point,'' said the official. ''Regardless of what Qaddafi says, by international law we are allowed to go into international waters and we've stayed in those waters.''

headline: SLOW SALES PORTEND A SHIFT BY RETAILERS
abstract: Many of the nation's retailers, facing only modest growth in the first half and a drying up of available suburban sites for long-term expansion, are turning their attention inward. Their goal is to wrest greater results from their existing stores. But to do this some stores are expected to undergo drastic changes.   The shift in planning was disclosed by store executives in interviews during last week's 75th annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association in New York.

headline: ELECTROLUX OF SWEDEN MAKES BID FOR WHITE
abstract: Electrolux A.B., a Swedish company that is one of the world's largest appliance makers, said it would begin a tender offer today to purchase the 15.8 million outstanding shares of common stock of White Consolidated Industries at $45 a share in cash.   The total price would be about $725 million, including offers for options and preferred stock, the company said yesterday.   The offer will be made through a newly organized Electrolux subsidiary, DMT Holdings Inc.

headline: Israelis Shoot Man in Gaza
abstract: Israeli soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip shot and killed a Gaza resident today when he fled after being detained for questioning, a military spokesman said. The spokesman said that the dead man was one of two men stopped by a patrol this morning in the center of the city of Gaza, and that the second escaped unhurt.

headline: IN BEDFORD-STUYVESANT, A KEY RESTORATION IS ON
abstract: Residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn see Gates Avenue as a moat that separates the largely decayed areas to the north from the often beautiful renovated brownstones to the south.   City housing officials, developers and community activists in the neighborhood also see Gates Avenue as a residential corridor, because it is lined for many blocks with large red-brick apartment buildings.   The financial and physical well-being of the low-income developments that line the street are considered vital for the community.   If any of the buildings started to decline ''you would have a domino effect on Gates,'' said Oliver A. Ramsay, a community activist. ''Gates Avenue is the corridor into Bed-Stuy; it is the borderline between what remains intact and the deterioration.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Borden Inc. said its board had approved a 3-for-2 stock split and a 10.5 percent increase in its annual dividend.

headline: COMMODITIES IN TRANSITION
abstract: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.   But the feisty stock market and plunging interest rates have changed all that. Economists all over are expecting another respectable - albeit not sizzling -performance this year. (See graphics display on Page 4.) Exploding stock values have added more than $1 trillion to the nation's wealth over the last 18 months, experts say, giving consumers added confidence and new buying power. But business leaders fear that increased competition at home and abroad could make this a tough year. To flesh out the details, industry by industry, The New York Times asked its own specialists to look ahead for 1986. Here are their reports.

headline: THE OSCARS TONIGHT: ARGENTINA WAITS WISHFULLY
abstract: Despite the thousands of miles that separate this country from Hollywood, the attention of Argentines is fixed on the distant land of stardom, and the nation seems to have become obsessed with its Oscar prospects.   For the second time in two years, an Argentine movie has been nominated for the best foreign film. This year the movie is ''Historia Oficial,'' or ''The Official Story,'' which is about events surrounding Argentina's so-called dirty war when more than 9,000 people disappeared in a military counterinsurgency campaign. The film was also nominated in the category of best original screenplay.

headline: Advertising; Polaroid Shuffles 2 of Its Assignments
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation has shifted a couple of accounts among its three agencies.

headline: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF U.S. ON LIBYA
abstract: The Soviet Union today condemned United States military actions against Libya, but stopped well short of threatening to intervene.   The Government press agency, Tass, called the use of force against Libyan naval ships and against a missile site an act of piracy that violated international law.

headline: EYE ON MARCOS BILLIONS: JOVITO REYES SALONGA
abstract: Almost 20 years ago, just as Ferdinand E. Marcos began amassing his enormous wealth, one of the most popular politicians in the Philippines publicly accused the President of manipulating the nation's Securities and Exchange Commission for his own end.   The politician, Senator Jovito R. Salonga, kept watching the accretion of the Marcos billions.   And so, as a new Manila Government formed last month, it came as no surprise that the self-effacing lawyer and politician, described by his colleagues as possessing impeccable integrity, was appointed to head the commission investigating Mr. Marcos's billions.   ''It was almost inevitable that he would be chosen,'' said a close colleague, Rafael Fernando, a Filipino businessman in Los Angeles. ''People were looking for leadership by moral principles.''

headline: KIDDER, PEABODY CENSURED BY S.E.C.
abstract: Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street securities firm, and its director of operations have been censured and ordered to tighten procedures for managing customer-owned securities because of charges that they mishandled $145 million in customers' securities in late 1983 and 1984, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.   In the consent decree, Kidder, Peabody and its operations head, Gerard A. Miller, neither admitted nor denied the administrative charges, which were first filed by the S.E.C. last October. But they agreed to ''findings that Kidder willfully violated and Miller willfully aided and abetted the violations,'' Ira Lee Sorkin, the S.E.C.'s New York regional administrator, said in the statement.

headline: ACCOUNTS
abstract: Accounts    * Mercury Marine to Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis, for Mercury brand outboard motors.    * Group Health Inc. of Minneapolis to BBDO/Minneapolis.    * Chrysler Credit Corporation to Ross Roy Inc., Detroit.

headline: IDEOLOGY
abstract: To the Editor:   Professors Buchanan and Tullock ought not hide behind ideology unless they admit that much of economics is little more than a set of professed religious beliefs (''A Bias Toward Bad Government?'' Jan. 19). Robert D. Hershey Jr. writes that ''they call themselves proponents of powerful ideas whose time has come.''

headline: A SURPRISING CHOICE FOR THE WORLD BANK
abstract: The choice of Barber B. Conable Jr. to head the World Bank was a surprise to many, although most concede it was a pleasant one. Others that had been mentioned for the job included Paul A. Volcker, Bill Brock and William E. Simon, all of whom have far more experience with developing nations than Mr. Conable, a former Congressman from upstate New York. But analysts say that Mr. Conable may be a more effective leader than A. W. Clausen, the incumbent. A conservative Republican, Mr. Conable gets along well with the Reagan Administration and is likely to be of greater help with the Baker plan to increase the lending role of the multinational development agency.   Producer prices plunged 1.6 percent in February, the biggest drop ever, mainly because lower oil prices are trickling through the economy. Gasoline prices, for example, dropped 11 percent, and home heating oil dropped 26 percent. Combined with continuing low interest rates and the stock and credit market booms, that bodes well for the future. But the oil drop has a downside too: Industrial production fell a steep six-tenths of 1 percent because drilling for oil and gas have been cut back. . . . Business inventories jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in January and sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent. . . . Consumers went $6.9 billion deeper in debt in January, but retail sales dropped one-tenth of 1 percent in February.

headline: Ex-Guatemala Aide Slain
abstract: Gunmen have assassinated a former head of Guatemala's secret police, Carlos Ignacio Gonzalez Palacios, the authorities said today. Mr. Palacios, a retired army colonel, was attacked on Tuesday on a street corner in Amatitlan, 15 miles south of the capital. He headed the secret police in the 1960's.

headline: Euromarket Sale Of Currency Units
abstract: Salomon Brothers International is offering in the Euromarket ''put'' and ''call'' warrants for European Currency Units, a basket of 10 European currencies.

headline: U.S. LINKS SOME FOREIGN AID TO PRIVATIZATION
abstract: Reagan Administration officials have declared that the extent of United States assistance for some developing countries will depend on their efforts to transfer public assets and programs to private industry.   The remarks were made Tuesday by several officials of the Agency for International Development during an International Conference on Privatization sponsored by the agency and attended by 250 participants from 40 nations.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the conference that ''Privatization is not just a device to cut back the size of government; rather, it is a policy to improve the delivery of services people are now getting - energy, housing, transportation, whatever.''

headline: DEERE PLANS CUTS
abstract: Deere & Company said it planned to reduce its work force by 6 percent, or 750 people, this spring. A spokesman for Deere, based in Moline, Ill., said the action, which would result in an after-tax charge of $30 to $35 million in the second quarter, was necessary because of reduced agricultural equipment schedules.

headline: G.M. AIDE CHALLENGES APARTHEID
abstract: An American company operating in South Africa directly challenged apartheid today, saying it would offer financial and legal support to its employees who defy a law that calls for racial segregation of beaches.   Bob White, managing director of the General Motors Corporation's subsidiary at Port Elizabeth, said in a letter to the editor of a newspaper there that his company found the city's beach segregation ordinance ''odious.''   Mr. White said he wrote the letter without consulting the corporate parent's headquarters in Detroit. He said G.M. would provide lawyers and money to defend in court any of its employees accused of violating the ordinance. In many parts of South Africa beaches are segregated by race, as are buses and restrooms.

headline: MANILA REGION WITH 2 MAYORS: A SYMBOL OF BATTLE TO CONTROL LOCAL OFFICES
abstract: In what some of them regarded as an act of political obligation and others a mere attention-grabbing gimmick, several hundred men and women blockaded the entrance to the cream-colored City Hall of the San Juan district of Manila today.   They had formed human barricades there for days. But they held forth on this sun-blistered afternoon with a flourish and listened to a marching band, loudspeakers and a speech from a movie actor who stirred them with praise. The man the demonstration was for was Joseph Estrada.

headline: JOINT HELP FOR MEXICO SUGGESTED
abstract: Bankers said yesterday that Mexico's debt burden, aggravated by the slump in oil prices, would probably require a joint rescue by lenders, with most of the assistance coming from public entities such as the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank and governments around the world.   These bankers, who participated in a debt conference with Mexican officials this week, said it was unlikely that private lenders would provide anything near the $8.7 billion in new loans that Mexico now says it will need this year.   ''We just couldn't raise that kind of money, at least not from the private banking sector alone,'' said a senior officer of an international bank who attended the meeting, which was held in New York Tuesday. Viewpoint of the Bankers    For bankers, however, withholding large amounts of new loans from Mexico may be more easily said than done. United States bankers who work in Mexico City said in January that their institutions were already so heavily lent out to Mexico that they would have no choice but to extend billions of dollars in fresh credits.

headline: KN Energy Sets Mesa Bid Review
abstract: KN Energy Inc., a Colorado-based natural gas distribution company, said it would review an unsolicited takeover from Mesa Limited Partnership when KN Energy's directors meet on Feb. 20.

headline: Cabinet Maker Accepts Offer
abstract: The Triangle Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest maker of kitchen and bathroom cabinets, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Beta Partners, a San Francisco investment group headed by Edward L. Scarff, for about $201.7 million, or $53.50 a share.   The offer would be subject to a minimum of at least two-thirds of the Triangle shares being tendered.

headline: SAKHAROV'S STATUS: CAN HE BE NEXT?
abstract: The release of the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky has moved supporters of another dissident, the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, to speculate on whether he might also be freed.   But in view of his reported role in producing the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, the Nobel Peace Prize winner's prospects for being freed from internal exile in the Russian city of Gorky appear, at best, uncertain.   The Soviet position, restated by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in an interview Feb. 4 with the French Communist newspaper L'Humanite, is that Dr. Sakharov - convicted in 1980 of engaging in illegal activities after years of publicly criticizing Soviet policy - would not be given permission to travel because ''he remains the bearer of particularly important state secrets,'' an apparent allusion to Dr. Sakharov's work on the hydrogen bomb after World War II.   Interviews with several people who played similar roles in the United States nuclear weapons program indicated that Dr. Sakharov could cast light on projects talked of, planned or under way when he was cut off from the Soviet nuclear weapons program.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Jerry Sherman has been promoted to president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves's sales promotion and collateral division.    * David Park has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Milici Valenti Smith Park Advertising, Honolulu, part of Doyle Dane Bernbach/West.    * John Lee Oliver has been named to the board of Lowe Marschalk.

headline: U.S. VOWS TO RESIST DESPOTS OF RIGHT AS WELL AS OF LEFT
abstract: In a major policy statement to be made public on Friday, President Reagan says explicitly for the first time that his Administration will oppose dictatorships of the anti-Communist right as well as the pro-Soviet left.   The core of a message that key Administration officials said would be sent to Congress says, ''The American people believe in human rights and oppose tyranny in whatever form, whether of the left or the right.''   This new approach differs in emphasis from the one enunciated by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former delegate to the United Nations. That policy held that ''traditional authoritarian'' regimes were ''less repressive,'' more susceptible to change and better for American interests than Marxist rulers. Left Called Greater Threat    Mr. Reagan's statement still calls leftist dictatorships the greater and ''unique'' threat to world peace. But his intention is take advantage of his recent role in helping to remove right-wing dictators in the Philippines and Haiti and to blunt charges that he has a double standard on human rights.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Central Louisiana Electric Co. is offering $25 million of 9 1/4 percent, A-2/ A- rated first-mortgage bonds due 1996 at 99.77, to yield 9.285 percent, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Centrust Savings Bank is issuing $35 million of 7 percent convertible Eurobonds due 2001 at 100 through Banque Paribas Capital Markets. The bonds are convertible into Midland Ross Corporation common stock.

headline: Lewis Is Resigning Warner Amex Jobs
abstract: Drew Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., said yesterday that he plans to resign from the television company on April 1.   According to industry sources who asked not to be identified, Mr. Lewis will join the Union Pacific Corporation, where they said he would succeed William S. Cook as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Cook retires next year.   In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Lewis, who was Secretary of Transportation from 1981 until Warner Amex recruited him in 1983, neither confirmed nor denied the Union Pacific reports.

headline: TED TURNER'S SCREEN TEST
abstract: FOR many Americans, Ted Turner is a buccaneer entrepreneur, an imaginative egocentric who takes on improbable ventures - and somehow makes them work.   It was tall, square-jawed Ted Turner who invented Cable News Network, the nation's pioneer 24-hour cable newscast. And earlier, it was Ted Turner who converted a foundering Atlanta TV station into the nation's first ''superstation'' by beaming its programs via satellite to cable networks around the country.   Now the 47-year-old Georgian has plunged into the most daring venture of all: the purchase of the MGM/ UA Entertainment Company for $1.5 billion. It is Mr. Turner's first foray into Hollywood, his first purchase of a piece of the show business establishment. And though Mr. Turner defends the acquisition staunchly - and he may yet prove to be right - many on Wall Street are deeply skeptical about the price he paid and the prospect for profits.

headline: POLISH POLICE ARREST SOLIDARITY FIGITIVE
abstract: The Polish authorities announced the arrest today of the leader of the Solidarity underground in the Gdansk region, who went into hiding when martial law was declared four years ago.   The Solidarity figure, Bogdan Borusewicz, was a member of the clandestine provisional committee that administers Solidarity's underground, collecting dues from supporters at factories and organizing an extensive network of illegal publications.   No details were given of the circumstances of Mr. Borusewicz's arrest, but the official Polish press agency announced his arrest on the eve of a scheduled mass for political prisoners at St. Brigida's Church in Gdansk, the Baltic port.

headline: Warner-Lambert To Sell Reichert
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company said it had agreed to sell its Reichert Scientific Instruments subsidiary to the Cambridge Instrument Company, a British manufacturer of scientific equipment.

headline: Swedish Stocks Plunge
abstract: Stock prices plunged today after Sweden's Government said it would double the tax on stock trading, to 2 percent. The Veckans-Affarer index fell to 618.9 points from 653.4.

headline: BETHLEHEM REPORTS LOSS OF $77.5 MILLION IN PERIOD
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a $77.5 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1985, compared with a loss of $64.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1984.   The company said it expected that the current quarter would also produce a loss.   Bethlehem, the No. 3 producer, after the United States Steel Corporation and the LTV Steel Company, has reported losses for 14 of the last 16 quarters. Its loss for 1985 totaled $196 million, compared with a loss of $112.5 million in 1984.

headline: EUROPE AGREES TO BAN ARMS TO COUNTRIES BACKING TERROR
abstract: The European Common Market agreed today to ban arms sales to countries that were ''clearly implicated in supporting terrorism.''   A declaration by the 12 member nations did not mention Libya, which President Reagan has accused of being behind the recent airport attacks.   However, one of the participants in the meeting, Linda Chalker, who is British Minister of State at the Foreign Office, said, ''There is absolutely no doubt at all that it is Libya the text refers to.''

headline: DOYLE DANE PROFIT OFF
abstract: Citing the economy and budget cuts by clients, the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group said its fourth-quarter revenues fell 1 percent and net income fell 59 percent. Revenues came to $61.24 million, down from $62.1 million a year earlier. Net income was $1.65 million, or 29 cents a share, down from $4 million, or 70 cents a share.

headline: Futures/Options; Deficit Cutting And Spreads
abstract: TREASURY bond futures make up an elastic world, a fact that has rarely been more evident than in the last several months.   Under the influence of the debate over the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, with its potential for substantially reducing future Federal budget deficits and thus Treasury bond supplies, the spreads between the near-term and longer-term Treasury bond futures contracts have stretched wider or narrower like a rubber band.   In the hands of a savvy trader, those changing relationships can be used to play some money-making melodies. More important, these shifts have a major impact on the hedging strategies of corporations that use Treasury bond futures.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Leslie H. Green and Karl Maier have been promoted to senior vice president at Lowe Marschalk.    * Andrew Fogelson is joining the United Artists Corporation as president of worldwide marketing.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Caldor Inc., Norwalk, Conn., a discount department store chain and a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corp., has appointed Arthur M. Heller senior vice president and general merchandise manager of hard lines.    * General Development Corp., Miami, which develops planned communities, has elected to its board Peter R. Brinkerhoff, a managing director of Paine Webber Inc.    * Hooker Enterprises Inc., Nashville, a fast-food company, has appointed Bernard Johnson president and chief operating officer.

headline: Market Place; Funds' Goal: Buying Cheap
abstract: ''I DIDN'T plan to be better than everybody else,'' Max L. Heine once told a reporter.   ''I'm much more interested in not getting hurt on the downside of the market.'' That philosophy has paid off handsomely for the mutual funds co-managed by the 75-year-old Mr. Heine, president of Heine Securities Corporation, and Michael F. Price, 34, vice president, who joined him 10 years ago.   In fact, two large funds under their stewardship have done so well that they will cease offering shares to new investors on Feb. 1. The Mutual Shares Corporation, with net assets totaling slightly more than $1 billion, has been open to the public. The companion fund, Mutual Qualified Income Fund, is tailored for institutional investors. Its assets amount to $440 million.  Suspending sales to stem the inflow of new cash typically is a hallmark of success in the mutual fund business. ''At some point in time, you can't invest that well in such a big spectrum,'' Mr. Price explained.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''It was either fix it, sell it or merge it. Since we couldn't fix it, we merged it, and we're very pleased with it.'' Frank Borman   Chairman, Eastern Airlines, on decision to sell to Texas Air

headline: CHEVRON ARRANGES BIG CREDIT FACILITY
abstract: The Chevron Corporation has arranged a $2.975 billion, three-year revolving credit facility, through a group led by BankAmerica Capital Markets, banking sources said.

headline: SHCHARANSKY GETS WELCOME IN ISRAEL
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky arrived in Israel today to a joyful welcome from Government leaders, friends and tumultuous crowds of supporters.   Mr. Shcharansky, who was freed from a Soviet labor camp on Monday, pledged to continue the struggle for human rights.   His wife, Avital, who had campaigned for nine years for his freedom, stood by his side, blinking back tears as well-wishers on the tarmac sang Hebrew wedding songs.   Mr. Shcharansky looked stunned at first, but soon displayed the wit and poise for which he was known in the Soviet Union. When he spotted familiar faces of Moscow friends in the crowd, he rushed over and hugged them.

headline: LIBYA CONTINUES TO DENY IT FIGHTS FOR THE REBELS IN CHAD
abstract: With a civil war in Chad intensifying, Libya continues to maintain that it is not directly involved in the hostilities.   In statements issued throughout the week, the official Libyan press agency and state-controlled radio and television have blamed the United States and France, which they call America's ''pawn,'' for the renewed fighting.   The Tripoli radio issued a statement Tuesday on behalf of the Libyan-backed rebel forces in Chad, led by Goukouni Oueddei, claiming responsibility for the bombing on Monday of the airport at Njdamena, Chad's capital.   The radio, quoting a spokesman for the Transitional Government of National Unity, the rebel coalition, said the airport was bombed in reprisal for France's ''criminal attack'' on the rebel air strip near the village of Wadi Doum on Sunday.

headline: CARBIDE'S OFFER INSPIRES HEAVY WALL ST. SELLING
abstract: Wall Street professionals were big sellers as stockholders of the Union Carbide Corporation tendered shares last night to the big chemical company for an $85 package of cash and securities.   Carbide shares, meanwhile, continued to climb in very busy trading yesterday, while shares of the GAF Corporation, which is trying to take over Carbide, continued to slump. Carbide rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $70.875, with 4.7 million shares changing hands. The day before, Carbide slid $1.125, to $70.50, on a volume of 3.5 million shares. Carbide topped the most-active list on both days.

headline: Paying Directors
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Directors Feel the Legal Heat'' (Dec. 15) provided a concise snapshot of the issues facing outside directors and the problems encountered by corporations in attracting and retaining board members.

headline: WESTERN GOVERNMENTS GIVE POLAND RELIEF ON DEBT
abstract: Western governments have agreed to give Poland more favorable repayment terms on $1.7 billion in debt, according to diplomats here.   The rescheduling agreement was reached Friday night by Poland and 17 Western governments at a meeting of the so-called Paris club, the forum in which Western creditor nations negotiate with debtor countries that cannot meet their obligations.   Officials said Western governments had given Poland an additional 10 years to repay $1.9 billion it should have paid them this year, including $550 million in arrears from 1985.

headline: EMPLOYEE GROUP BUYS VICKERS SHIP
abstract: Workers and managers at Britain's only nuclear submarine maker pulled off the country's biggest worker buyout today. The Government sale of Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering to a management consortium -despite a higher bid from an outsider - was announced to Parliament by Industry Secretary Paul Channon.   The new private owners will carry on with construction of four submarines to carry the American Trident missiles, which will be Britain's new nuclear deterrent in the 1990's, he said. Mr. Channon said the consortium would pay $87 million now to Vickers's parent company, state-owned British Shipbuilders, and was expected to deliver another $56 million in 1993.

headline: HANSON CLAIMS 66% OF SCM
abstract: Hanson Trust P.L.C. claimed victory yesterday in its fight to gain control of the SCM Corporation. One day after a Federal court struck down a ''lockup'' agreement that SCM was using to defend itself, Hanson said it had acquired two-thirds of SCM's shares and would soon call a stockholders' meeting to take control of SCM's board.   SCM, a chemical and typewriter company based in New York, began the day by announcing it would ask the entire United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to reconsider the decision against it. In that decision, a three-judge panel of the court ruled that SCM directors had violated their duty to shareholders when they agreed to sell two of SCM's most valuable businesses to Merrill Lynch & Company in return for Merrill's pledge to take SCM private in a leveraged buyout. The lockup arrangement was illegal, the panel said, because the directors had hastily agreed to sell the businesses at bargain prices.

headline: TEXACO'S LEGAL STRATEGIST
abstract: On the evening of Dec. 9, Texaco Inc.'s top executives, in a crisis meeting at the oil company's branch office in Houston, made a risky decision: to attempt to bring a portion of their legal battle with the Pennzoil Company before a Federal court.   Last Friday that gamble paid off. While waiting in a conference room at the United States District Courthouse in White Plains, Texaco's lead counsel, David Boies, received word at a few minutes past 4 P.M. from Judge Charles L. Brieant that Texaco had won a major legal victory that changes the complexion of the bitter feud.   The story of how the Federal action came about and how it was won by Texaco is the latest chapter in one of the most extraordinary corporate battles ever. And it has provided Texaco with its first hero of the case in Mr. Boies, the 44-year-old lawyer who crafted and executed with his law firm colleagues the strategy that may prove to have saved the nation's fifth-largest corporation from bankruptcy.

headline: AQUINO AIDES, AT PALACE, AWED BY 'MADNESS OF IT'
abstract: An advance party from the office of President Corazon C. Aquino toured the back rooms of Malacanang Palace today and found, as one of the visitors said, that ''behind the facade of stately offices is madness.''   Military police officers held back crowds of gawkers at the palace gates as Col. Adelberto Yap, Mrs. Aquino's aide-de-camp, and Ching Escaler, her appointments secretary, walked up the red-carpeted stairs where a case that once displayed the disputed war medals of President Ferdinand E. Marcos stood looted and empty.   The high-ceilinged reception hall, with plastic shrubs and flowers because of his allergies, and the book-lined study, where he received visiting potentates, were quiet and empty.   But back doors that led from those rooms to private quarters opened into a world of compulsive opulence seldom seen by outsiders. And the Aquino aides who visited the palace today expressed the same disbelief as other Filipinos and foreigners who have gone there in the days since Mr. Marcos fled.

headline: SO LONG, SMOKESTACKS
abstract: THE Ogden Corporation washes the windows at the World Trade Center, burns municipal garbage and serves food on the Concorde. The former industrial conglomerate also performs a thousand other daily chores in maintaining Yankee Stadium, the United Nations and hundreds of office buildings and industrial plants.   Ogden, with more than $2 billion in annual revenues, has practically created a new company, transforming itself into a major purveyor of services. Until last fall it built ships and freight cars, turned out machine tools, processed ferrous scrap. But in September, Ogden cut loose seven smokestack operations and sold them to the employees in a $280 million transaction.   The changes at Ogden have made it one of the most vivid examples of a company adapting to a changing business environment. Many economists see the United States moving toward a service economy as basic industry shrinks. Ogden's transformation has more or less mirrored the trend. m ''This company has done some very dramatic things in the last four years,'' said Larry Baker, an analyst at E. F. Hutton. ''Other companies shift businesses, but this has been more radical than most.''

headline: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT ON HABIB
abstract: Following is the text of President Reagan's written statement today on his decision to send Philip C. Habib to the Philippines as a special envoy:   The Philippine elections have captured the attention of the American public. At times we need to remind ourselves that this is a Philippine election, not an American election. Yet our interests are deeply affected by these elections - by the results, by the deficiencies of the process, and by what all this means for the future.

headline: REAGAN WELCOMES CHANGE IN MANILA
abstract: President Reagan sent a congratulatory message to President Corazon C. Aquino today, saying the United States ''welcomed the democratic outcome'' of the Philippine elections, according to White House officials.   The officials said Mr. Reagan had also noted that the United States and the Philippines ''would be working closely'' to promote the Manila Government's efforts to revamp the economy and the armed forces.   At the same time Mr. Reagan sent a message to Ferdinand E. Marcos in Hawaii, praising his ''difficult and courageous decision'' to step down after 20 years as Philippine President, according to the officials.   Meanwhile, representatives of the new Philippine Government and some members of Congress said they would take steps to try to strip Mr. Marcos of millions of dollars of assets in this country that might have been gained illegally.  [ Page A15. ]  The White House said Mr. Marcos might remain in Hawaii for a long stay. The 68-year-old former President and about two dozen associates, including his personal physician, landed at Hickam Air Force Base today aboard a United States military plane from Guam.

headline: FOR ISRAEL, POLITICS ON SUNDAY, N.F.L. ON MONDAY
abstract: Only in Israel could you find Jews watching ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' on a pirate evangelical Christian television station broadcasting from predominantly Shiite Moslem southern Lebanon.   Each week in the regular football season, Middle East Television broadcasts the ''Monday Night Football'' game from the week before. Middle East Television is financed by an American evangelical Christian group and has its studios just across the Israeli border in southern Lebanon.   Israeli diplomats and journalists who have served in the United States long enough to become football fans go to great lengths to pick up the transmissions in Jerusalem.

headline: Sea-Land Investor
abstract: Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, said he had bought an additional one million Sea-Land Corporation common shares, raising his stake in the shipping concern to 39.5 percent of its shares outstanding. Mr. Simmons, who is seeking control of the company, disclosed the purchases, made for $24.75 a share Tuesday in two private deals, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Belgium Said to Demote Officers Over Soccer Riot
abstract: The three police officers in charge of security at the European Cup Championship here last year have been reassigned, and there are reports that they have been demoted because of security lapses at the match, at which 38 people were killed in rioting.   A spokesman for the gendarmerie, a paramilitary police force, confirmed a newspaper report that the major, colonel and captain in charge of security at Heysel Stadium have been reassigned to administrative posts.   The spokesman denied the newspaper's assertion that the changes resulted from the rioting last May, but a source indicated that the report was accurate.

headline: Top Energy Regulator Resigns Federal Post
abstract: Raymond J. O'Connor, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the natural gas, electric utility and oil pipeline industries, said yesterday that he intended to resign at the end of the month, citing personal and family reasons.   The White House, which has been dealing with a spate of resignations recently, was informed of Mr. O'Conner's decision only hours before it was announced.   Mr. O'Connor, who was named to the chairmanship in late 1983, had said in interviews last year that he intended to stay on the job until his term expired in October 1987.

headline: BRAZILIANS BACK WAGE-PRICE FREEZE
abstract: Buoyed by strongly favorable public reactions to the wage and price freeze decreed on Friday, Brazil today began the complex task of readjusting its economy.   One early sign of confidence was that the difference between the official and the black market dollar exchange rate fell sharply today. Furthermore, the decision to lop three zeroes off the old currency, the cruzeiro, and rename it the cruzado was quickly accepted by banks, shops and consumers.

headline: FED LOSES 'NON-BANK' BANK CASE
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 0, that the Federal Reserve Board has no authority to regulate or restrict so-called limited-service banks.   Upholding a September 1984 Federal appellate decision that invalidated amendments to the Fed's Regulation Y, the Court said the Fed would need new legislation - which it suggested might be desirable - to regulate limited-service banks.   Sometimes known as ''non-bank banks,'' limited-service banks function much like full-service banks but limit their activities in order to skirt the statutory definition of banks and thereby avoid restrictions on interstate banking and other regulations. Aid to Interstate Banking   The decision is likely to speed the movement toward interstate banking and the expansion of insurance, retail, securities and other companies into financial services traditionally performed by banks. ''Every merchandiser in the country will have a bank,'' said J. Charles Partee, a member of the Fed.

headline: General Re Stock
abstract: The General Re Corporation, an insurance holding company, is offering 2.5 million common shares at $114.50 a share through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Most of the proceeds will go to General Re's property-casualty reinsurance subsidiaries to support anticipated growth, the company said.

headline: QUOTRON CHAIRMAN CAUGHT OFF GUARD
abstract: Six months ago, a takeover bid from Citicorp would not have surprised Milton E. Mohr, the chairman and chief executive of Quotron Systems Inc.   But Tuesday's offer by the nation's banking giant to buy Quotron for $19 a share in cash, or a total of $680 million, caught him off guard.   ''I haven't talked to Citicorp since October, so I thought the deal was off,'' Mr. Mohr said in an interview yesterday.

headline: REPORTERS' POOL KEPT FROM ACTION
abstract: No American journalists have been allowed to observe the clashes between the American fleet and Libyan forces in the Mediterranean.   Before the hostilities began on Monday, a pool of reporters and photographers was flown to the aircraft carrier Saratoga to observe the maneuvers in which that carrier and two others were involved. The fighting began later in the day.   The journalists were kept far away from the area off the Libyan coast where the hostilities took place, and were returned to Italy later in the day. They were not not flown across the boundary claimed by Libya as the limit of its territorial waters. Libya calls the boundary ''the line of death.''

headline: South African Black Killed in Police Raid
abstract: Policemen armed with riot sticks broke into a meeting in the black township of Kagiso on Monday night and one black student was killed and 30 people were hurt, residents said today.   Meanwhile, 12,000 black miners struck the Vaal Reefs gold mine, South Africa's second largest.

headline: Bond Prices Continue Surge
abstract: Bond prices, bolstered by lower oil prices and hopes that inflation will move to even lower levels, surged for the third day in row.   Analysts said the surge in bond prices in late afternoon was fueled by a prediction by the First Boston Corporation's economist, Albert M. Wojnilower, of even lower interest rates that would keep inflation in check until late this year or early next.   The long Treasury bond - the 9 1/4 percent 30-year issue due in 2016 -fell to 7.77 percent. 'Inflation Is Dead'    ''For the bond market's money, inflation is dead and decomposing,'' said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ''The continued weakness in oil prices has been a tonic for government bonds - there were eight-year highs today in the Treasury market - but poison for speculative-grade oil issues.'' For instance, Mr. Grant said, a Petro-Lewis Corporation issue yesterday dropped 2 points.

headline: CHAIRMAN OF AMAX JOINS PAINE WEBBER
abstract: Pierre L. Gousseland, whose long and successful career at Amax Inc. faltered as the company's fortunes declined, is joining the Paine Webber Group as a senior consultant to Paine Webber's Capital Markets.   Mr. Gousseland, who retired from Amax earlier, will resign from the position of chairman, which the company said he had occupied in a nonexecutive capacity, effective March 31. He will remain a member of the Amax board, however.

headline: Man Gets 12 Medals 40 Years After War
abstract: The ceremony was 40 years late, but Houston Lowe has finally received 12 medals that he earned in the Army Air Corps, including the Bronze Star and Purple Heart.   Mr. Lowe was wounded in combat and held prisoner in the Philippines from 1942 until the end of World War II.

headline: U.S.-TURKISH TALKS REACH AN IMPASSE
abstract: Senior United States and Turkish officials said today that their differences were too great to permit agreement on a new defense and economic pact during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's current visit.   In separate news conferences, both sides said they were still interested in maintaining good relations, including the interim use by the United States of more than 15 military installations affected by that accord. But each spokesman held the other side responsible for the present deadlock.

headline: MORE OIL-RIG DEBT PROBLEMS SEEN
abstract: The offshore drilling industry has been so battered by cuts in exploration budgets at major oil companies that other drilling companies are expected to take the same route as Global Marine Inc., which announced Monday that it would seek court protection from its creditors.   ''We've been telling investors to stay away from drillers'' with high debt loads, said Paul C. Shiverick, an oilfield-services analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. They include the Zapata Corporation, the Reading & Bates Corporation and the Western Company of North America, he said. In today's stock trading, Zapata closed at 6 5/8, down 1/8; Reading & Bates 4 1/8, up 1/8, and Western 1 3/8, down 1/8.

headline: China Aircraft Trade
abstract: China will increase exports of civilian and military aircraft over the next five years, but will have to import increasing numbers of long-haul passenger aircraft, the aviation minister, Mo Wenxiang, said. The China Daily quoted Mr. Mo as saying China is already exporting aircraft and can manufacture more than 20 types, including fighters, bombers, helicopters, transport and reconnaissance planes.

headline: Filing the Return: Advice From Experts; Take Care In Matching Your Records
abstract: WITH proposals flying about Washington to overhaul the nation's income tax system, 1985 may have been the calm before the storm - forms for 1985 taxes remain much the same as in the previous year.   ''It's pretty much business as usual,'' said Stanley H. Breitbard, Price Waterhouse's national director of executive financial services. ''The tax forms are relatively similar to forms in the previous year with some minor tinkering that's done every year. In some ways it's a relief. But expect to see major changes next year.''

headline: POPE EMPHASIZES RELIGIOUS LIBERTY
abstract: Pope John Paul II, paying homage to St. Thomas the Apostle at a hilltop shrine and greeting a multitude at a seaside mass, called on the Indian Government today to live up to its Constitution's guarantees of religious freedom.   Moving into southern India, where the country's Roman Catholic minority has its strongest hold, the Pope drew the largest crowds of his five-day-old trip.   A crowd put at more than half a million people stretched nearly two miles down a beach on the Bay of Bengal as John Paul said mass just 50 yards from the gently breaking waves. Earlier, the Pope used diplomatic but pointed language to raise the bitterly contested issue of religious discrimination, including the church's right to preach and seek converts.

headline: Market Place; High Yields And Bond Calls
abstract: IN the fixed-income market, falling interest rates have been a bonanza for speculators who chose to cash in their profits on bonds purchased last year. Similarly, the sharp drop in bond yields and the rise in bond prices have delighted many local governments and corporations that are now able to refinance outstanding bonds sold when interest rates were much higher. This allows the issuers to reduce interest expenses.   But most individuals who buy bonds tend to be long-term investors, and for them the redemption of high-coupon issues presents the problem of re-investing their money in new, lower-yielding bonds. Their situation is similar to that faced by holders of money market funds and certificates of deposit who no longer can enjoy the lofty returns once offered by these instruments.

headline: Store Consolidation Seen at Federated
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest operator of department stores, is planning to merge its two Middle West department store divisions, Wall Street and retailing sources said yesterday. It will also merge two discount chains, the sources said.   The moves, which would involve a change in name for two of the companies, are intended to help hold down costs through smaller staffs and centralization of operation for the chains involved.

headline: ECONOMISTS MORE HOPEFUL
abstract: The United States will enjoy stronger growth this year, with little danger of a recession, as falling oil prices help keep inflation low, the nation's business economists predicted today.   The National Association of Business Economists said its latest survey of 300 members found them decidely more optimistic about growth.

headline: Bonuses at Volkswagen
abstract: Volkswagenwerk A.G. said today that it paid a record $5 million in bonuses last year to employees who suggested ways to increase the car maker's productivity.

headline: FRANKFURT STOCK RISE IGNORED
abstract: This city's stock exchange, amid rising corporate profits and overall economic growth in West Germany, was one of the biggest movers among the world's stock markets last year. But such a performance has done little to enhance the status of stock trading among German financiers or the investing public.   Though Germans on average save 14 percent of their wages, they tend to shy away from the stock market and invest instead in interest-bearing bonds or savings accounts. In 1984, individual shareholders held barely 17 percent of outstanding equity in Germany, compared with 25 percent in Britain and more than 70 percent in the United States, and bankers say the relationship has changed little since.

headline: Jordache Inquiry
abstract: Federal agents searched the offices of Jordache, the jeans maker, earlier this week, but the authorities have not yet publicly disclosed the reason for the search or the results. The agents, who told employees they were from the Internal Revenue Service and the Customs Service, took photographs of the Jordache office on the fifth floor of 498 Seventh Avenue, and the offices of Gasoline, an affiliate.

headline: NEW SPLIT ON WORLD BANK POST
abstract: Labor Secretary Bill Brock has taken himself out of the running for the presidency of the World Bank, creating new divisions between the Treasury Department and the White House.   Insiders say that Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, is backing William E. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary, for the job, while Treasury Secretary Baker wants John M. Hennessy, the London-based president of Credit Suisse First Boston. The current bank president, A. W. Clausen, is leaving in June, when his term ends.

headline: Estonians' Pensive Refrain: We Are Not Russians
abstract: While the rest of the Soviet Union watches state-controlled television programs these wintry evenings, residents of this Estonian capital have been following the latest episodes of ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty.''   The sagas of the Ewings and the Carringtons come courtesy of Finnish television. Helsinki broadcasts can be picked up in Tallinn from across the Gulf of Finland, and most antennas are pointed in that direction.   ''Everyone watches 'Dallas' on Thursdays,'' a schoolteacher said.

headline: Chrysler Truck Engine
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation has begun making a 3.9-liter V-6 truck engine, to be optional on the Dodge Dakota pickup. It was developed for $70 million, the company said, by cutting the front two cylinders off a 5.2-liter V-8 engine and using an existing engine block.

headline: TOP PRETORIA OFFICIAL GETS REPRIMAND
abstract: South Africa's Foreign Minister has been rebuked by President P. W. Botha for suggesting that this racially divided nation might one day be led by a black President.   The unusual public reprimand of Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha came in response to a comment he made to foreign reporters Thursday that ''it would possibly become unavoidable that in future you might have black presidents in this country.''   Appearing before the dominant white house of South Africa's three-chamber, racially segregated Parliament, President Botha declared that ''any speculation about future presidents is purely hypothetical'' and that ''no member of the Cabinet has any right to compromise the party in such a way.''   The development came amid renewed rumors about the destiny of Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned black nationalist leader. The South African Press Association reported that an unidentified official at the Zambian headquarters of the African National Congress, the leading black South African opposition group, said the organization's leaders there were expecting Mr. Mandela to be released to them this weekend. There was, however, no other indication that Mr. Mandela was about to be set free.

headline: Deficit Pared By Renault
abstract: Despite a diminishing share of the car market, Renault narrowed its 1985 losses to $1.56 billion, from $1.79 billion a year earlier, Renault said Friday.

headline: WHY MANY WOMEN OPT TO GO IT ALONE
abstract: CRITICS argue that women, despite strong gains in the business world, have been kept out of the board rooms by continuing male prejudice. They usually point out that of the 500 largest industrial companies, only one has a woman as the top executive (Katharine Graham of the Washington Post Company).   That picture may be accurate, but it hardly tells the whole story. It takes a generation for a man who starts at the bottom of the corporate hierarchy to reach the top. It has been only 10 years since women began entering the business world in large numbers. Clearly it is too early to say how far -or high - they can go.

headline: U.S. EASES LIBYAN OIL CURB RULES
abstract: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was modifying its economic sanctions against Libya to allow American oil companies to continue to make profits from the sale of Libyan oil. The intent is to prevent the funds from going to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government.   But a company's profits, under regulations made public this afternoon, will have to be placed in a United States Government escrow account until the company ''completely terminates its remaining activities in Libya.'' While no specific time limit was set, the Government indicated that the companies were expected to wind up their affairs as rapidly as possible and that the exemption should not be regarded as long-term.

headline: U.S. ARMY COPTERS CARRY HONDURANS TO BORDER REGION
abstract: Fourteen United States Army helicopters today transported a battalion of Honduran troops close to an area where Nicaraguan Government forces were reported to be fighting anti-Government rebels.   A United States Embassy spokesman here said the helicopter crews consisted of 50 American soldiers. He said the helicopters - 4 twin-rotor Chinooks and 10 UH-1's - were not armed and would land at a secure airstrip well away from the fighting.   The airlift, to a United States air base near the border, appeared to represent a major increase in American involvement in efforts to protect Nicaraguan guerrilla bases in Honduras.

headline: SHCHARANSKY, INDISPOSED, SKIPS APPEARANCES
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky is suffering from a ''small heart problem'' and from nightmares about his Soviet imprisonment, his wife said today.   Mr. Shcharansky, who has canceled a series of appearances, has been in seclusion with his wife, Avital.   He arrived in Israel on Feb. 11 after serving nearly nine years in Soviet prisons on charges of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency. Both Mr. Shcharansky and the United States have denied the accusation.

headline: Advertising; Ogilvy Group's Income Rises 22.2% in Quarter
abstract: The Ogilvy Group yesterday released its fourth-quarter earnings, which its chief executive, William E. Phillips, characterized as ''satisfactory'' while noting that they included a number of one-time gains and special provisions.

headline: DOW RISES 7.11 TO ANOTHER RECORD
abstract: Snapping back from a one-day slump, the Dow Jones industrial average rose again to a record level yesterday. The broader market advanced moderately on technical factors and a continued weakness in oil prices.   The Dow, which on Tuesday was unable to extend its string of records, rose 7.11 points yesterday, to 1,629.93.

headline: Youth Seized on Berlin Wall
abstract: East German border guards seized a teen-age boy on Wednesday as he was trying to scale the Berlin wall in a sector facing West Berlin's French sector, the West Berlin police said today.

headline: MARTIN BOWING OUT OF THE FED SPOTLIGHT
abstract: Preston Martin will quit as vice chairman of the Fed when his term expires at the end of April. The resignation was something of a surprise, since the grip of the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, is apparently loosening, and Mr. Martin appeared amenable to taking over that job. Mr. Martin and the other three Reagan appointees overruled Mr. Volcker's objections to the recent discount rate cut, and the Fed chairman was sharply criticized by one of the new members, Martha R. Seger, who said he was moving too slowly on lowering interest rates. Mr. Volcker is used to being at odds with the Administration, but dissension from the Fed board is another matter and was seen by some as a signal that he should resign. Instead, it is Mr. Martin who is leaving, indicating that the chairman is digging in his heels.   Died. Homer Jones, a longtime official of the St. Louis Fed and a popular monetarist, at 79. An appreciation by Milton Friedman is on page 13.

headline: YUGOSLAV NEWSPAPER SAYS ARCHIVES SHOW WALDHEIM WAR ROLE
abstract: One of Yugoslavia's leading newspapers today charged former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations with taking part in Nazi military operations against Yugoslav partisans, but the Foreign Ministry withheld comment.   The paper, Vjesnik, said documents found in war archives in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia on Wednesday proved that Mr. Waldheim, as an officer in the German armed forces, had taken part in military operations against partisans.   The partisans were Communist forces who, under Tito, fought the Nazi occupiers during World War II and took power in Yugoslavia after the war.

headline: Somali President Declares an Amnesty
abstract: President Mohammed Siad Barre declared a general amnesty today for thousands of Somali who have been living in exile for nearly a decade.   The official Somali radio quoted the President as saying during a visit to Hargeisa, a northwestern regional capital, that exiles wanting to return home should register at the nearest Somali Embassy or Consulate.   The exiles, who include former Cabinet ministers, politicians and military officers, fled the country during and after the 1977-78 war with Ethiopia over the disputed Ogaden region.

headline: HOW BALLOTS ARE COUNTED BY ASSEMBLY
abstract: The Philippine National Assembly, the focus of the unsettled election, is a legislative body that is under the control of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   He can dissolve it and, under the present party line-up, he is considered to control two-thirds of its members.   Under the Constitution, which Mr. Marcos crafted after he imposed eight years of martial law in 1973, the assembly has the task of canvassing, or certifying, the vote count. This would normally be a routine clerical task except that this election has been rife with charges of fraud, and rival unofficial counts ended in discord.

headline: Student Loan Unit In Australian Issue
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday offered a $100 million Australian issue of 13 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: PATENTS; Cyclic Air-Conditioning With Ice Cogeneration
abstract: Calvin D. MacCracken, president of the Calmac Manufacturing Corporation, Englewood, N.J., was granted patent 4,565,069 this week for what is entitled a method of cyclic air-conditioning with cogeneration of ice. He predicts that the method will save money for commercial buildings.

headline: OIL PRICES IN MODERATE RALLY
abstract: Reversing a sharp three-day slide, prices for crude oil and petroleum products rose moderately in light trading yesterday on world markets. Prices for refined products moved close to or above the 50-cents-a-gallon level, and crude oil prices moved above the $16-a-barrel mark.   Analysts said the market had responded positively to an oil industry report showing the first substantial decline of the winter in distillate stocks, and to President Reagan's comment yesterday morning that he was willing to consider imposing taxes on imported oil.   Analysts said that the market, battered by the recent acceleration of the three-month downturn in prices, used the positive news to gain ground after the huge losses it has sustained recently.

headline: Allies Plan to Consult On Soviet Arms Offer
abstract: President Reagan will send two officials to consult with allies in an effort to form a response to the Soviet proposal to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000.   A senior Administration official, briefing reporters before Mr. Reagan's State of the Union Message, said one of the envoys, Paul H. Nitze, would leave Wednesday to consult with allies in Western Europe, and the other, Edward L. Rowny, would leave the same day to confer with allies in Asia.

headline: AMERICANS BARRED FROM SEEING MANDELA
abstract: The South African authorities refused permission today for a visiting United States Congressional delegation to visit Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned black nationalist who is viewed by many blacks as their leader.   ''The visit will not take place,'' a Prisons Service spokesman said, but offered no further explanation.   In other developments, the white authorities today turned down a black demand for a delay in reopening the nation's black schools, the targets of months of classroom boycotts.

headline: U.S. MAY FREE PRAGUE SPY SUSPECT
abstract: The United States plans to release a man accused of spying for Czechoslovakia, among other prisoners, in an exchange that is expected to include the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, Administration sources said today.   The suspect, Karl F. Koecher, 52 years old, is accused of having spied for Czechoslovakia for 19 years before his arrest in 1984.

headline: EASED LABOR CAMP CONDITIONS REPORTED IN LETTER BY SHCHARANSKY
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish activist, reported in a letter from labor camp last month that he was being treated better, his brother said here today.   The brother, Leonid B. Shcharansky, said the family did not know whether the improved conditions, including better medical care and more time for reading, walking and resting, were related to a possible release.   He said the family was hopeful although it had received no word from the Soviet authorities or from the United States Embassy regarding a reported plan to release Leonid Shcharansky as part of an East-West exchange of intelligence agents.   ''There have been rumors before and I hoped for Anatoly's release, but I did not really believe it would happen,'' the brother said. ''This time I believe it will.''

headline: A BELGIAN WOMAN IS CHARGED BY SOUTH AFRICA WITH TREASON
abstract: A Belgian woman was charged here today with treason or terrorism in helping the main black guerrilla group fighting white rule.   The woman, Helene Pastoors, 44 years old, was served with an indictment at Johannesburg magistrates court charging treason, which can carry the death penalty, or alternatively terrorism.

headline: Finding a Pro To Prepare Your Return
abstract: FOR many taxpayers the questions of whether to seek professional advice and whom to consult can be as daunting as filling out the tax returns.   There are probably more similarities than differences among the different categories of tax professionals and no hard-and-fast rules about who is best equipped to do what. The best approach is to be referred by someone you trust - a friend, a banker, a lawyer, a professional colleague -who is satisfied with the job done for him in previous years. But the specialist right for one person may not have the expertise needed by another, so it is useful to understand the distinctions among the different categories of tax advisers.

headline: UAL's Income Declines
abstract: UAL Inc. yesterday reported sharply lower net income in the fourth quarter of 1985 and an operating loss at its United Airlines subsidiary.   The holding company's net income fell 65.8 percent, to $20.8 million, or 43 cents a share, from $67 million, or $1.76 a share, in the 1984 quarter.

headline: JUSTICES UPHOLD CURB ON YARMULKE
abstract: Broadly asserting the primacy of military discipline over constitutional rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that the military can bar an Orthodox Jewish officer from wearing a yarmulke indoors while in uniform.   The Court ruled 5 to 4 that the military's power to ban all wearing of headgear indoors as part of a uniform dress code prevailed over the religious duty of an Orthodox Jewish rabbi to keep his head covered.   The decision upheld a reprimand and other disciplinary action in 1981 against S. Simcha Goldman, who was an Air Force captain working as a psychologist, for insisting on wearing his yarmulke while on duty.   In another religion case, the Court left unresolved one of the most contentious constitutional issues before it this term: whether student religious groups may hold prayer meetings in school.

headline: TREASURY BOND PRICES GAIN
abstract: The Treasury bond market yesterday shrugged off the lethargy of the past week as signs of good investor demand led to price gains of nearly 1 1/2 points for long-term issues.   Although securities dealers and economists are still debating whether and when the Federal Reserve will make an overt move to an easier monetary policy, there was widespread agreement that strong demand from Japanese investors would absorb a large portion of today's $4.75 billion auction of 20-year Treasury bonds.   Good buying of Treasury issues overseas last night, plus a long-awaited drop in the overnight rate for Federal funds to around 7 3/4 percent and a report by Knight Ridder Financial News that oil prices might drop to $20 a barrel, helped raise prices of Treasury issues when trading opened in New York. Seven-Year Notes    After the 1 P.M. auction of seven-year Treasury notes confirmed that domestic investor demand was good to fair, prices rose further, and the 9 7/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2015 closed at its highest offered price of about 107 7/32, to yield 9.17 percent.

headline: BL DISCUSSING SALE OF UNITS TO G.M.
abstract: BL P.L.C., the state-owned vehicle maker, is holding talks that have reached an advanced stage with the General Motors Corporation about the sale of the financially ailing company's truck and four-wheel-drive vehicle divisions, the Government said today.   Speaking in the House of Commons, Paul Channon, Trade and Industry Secretary, said, ''Discussions are at an advanced stage, but a number of important issues remain to be settled.''   The announcement brought attacks from opposition politicians and union officials. John Smith, a Labor Party leader, called the pending selloff plans a ''dreadful and shameful British retreat.'' Then, he asked rhetorically, ''Is nothing not for sale?''

headline: INDIA MEALS' PIZZA JOINS MENU
abstract: As Lakshmi Chand Nirula, the white-haired patriarch of the family running India's best-known pizza and fast-food chain, tells it, he and his brother went into the restaurant business here more than 50 years ago because their cook had run away.   ''We got tired of eating at different restaurants and so we decided to start a place of our own - accommodation was cheap and easily available,'' said Mr. Nirula, the 77-year-old chairman of Nirula's, the restaurant network.   But while Mr. Nirula and his 72-year-old brother, Madan, are still on the chain's board of directors, it is the younger Nirulas who are credited with changing the family's places in 1977 from traditional, sit-down restaurants to slick and shiny fast-food outlets.   The elder Nirula brothers bought their first hotel and restaurant in 1934. Lakshmi Chand Nirula was then running the family drugstore, and his younger brother was a professional photographer who made a living by taking pictures of the country's elite with the British Viceroy.

headline: ECONOMIC POLICY
abstract: To the Editor:   Mr. Culbertson would use ''powerful new tools'' to model and manage entire economies with ''computers, cybernetics, systems theory, organization theory, computer-based expert systems, and artificial intelligence.''

headline: OIL AND GASOLINE PRICES CONTINUE SLIDE
abstract: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday. The contract price of the major American crude oil closed under $15 a barrel, and contract prices for gasoline also declined.   Several analysts attributed the continuing drop more to market psychology than to any particular events. Trading was light.  The slide came as leading American and European oil companies met in London to devise a rescue plan for the London spot market, which has been disrupted in the last week by the threatened default of several large trading companies.

headline: Advertising; Marketer of Liqueurs Picks Isidore & Paulson
abstract: Isidore & Paulson took over the advertising account of Suntory beer a year ago.

headline: Liechtenstein Women Vote for First Time
abstract: Women voted today for the first time in this tiny Alpine principality and helped return a conservative coalition to power in the 15-member Parliament, election officials said.   Women were given the right to vote in 1984 when the Crown Prince, Hans Adam, assumed executive power from his father, Prince Franz Josef II.   The Fatherland Unity Party retained its eight seats, and its coalition partners, the Progressive Citizens, won the other seven seats, including one held by a woman, Emma Eigenmann.

headline: INDIA AWAITING VERDICT TOMORROW IN TRIAL OF 3 IN '84 GANDHI SLAYING
abstract: The trial of three men accused of conspiring to assassinate Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ended last week with the chief defense lawyer saying that the ''real assassin'' had been allowed to escape.   The defense lawyer also accused the Government of concealing and tampering with evidence to cover up a conspiracy in Mrs. Gandhi's own family to kill her. He said the conspiracy even involved her son and successor, Rajiv.   Judge Mahesh Chandra said he would issue a verdict Wednesday. If convicted, the defendants, all of whom are Sikhs, could be hanged or sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Technology; Detecting Food Contaminants
abstract: FOR the nation's farmers, the use of pesticides, animal drugs and other toxic substances is a way to increase production and limit damage from pests and disease.   But for the nation's consumers, a growing body of scientific evidence suggests that even tiny amounts of these chemicals may contribute to a number of human illnesses. And in recent years, new techniques for identifying traces of these substances in food has alarmed consumers and increased the movement to control the use of such chemicals.   Now a young California company using a slab of electronic wizardry - a device with the fiercesome name of triple-stage quadruple mass spectrometer, which quickly identifies chemical contaminants in food - is seeking to turn concern over food safety into a business.

headline: MALTESE PREMIER IN TRIPOLE TALKS
abstract: The Prime Minister of Malta met tonight with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, in an effort to defuse the confrontation with the United States over the Gulf of Sidra.   The Maltese leader, Karmenu Mifsud Bonnici, also said that he had sent a representative to Washington, his second in 10 weeks, to try to calm the situation.   ''We are directly involved in this region, and armed conflict is a question of life and death for us in the center of the Mediterranean,'' Mr. Bonnici told reporters. ''It is not a question of rights for us, it's a question of life and death.''

headline: Videotex Unit Shut By Times Mirror
abstract: The Times Mirror Company closed its Gateway videotex service, ending service for 3,000 subscribers, most of whom were personal computer users in Los Angeles and Orange counties.

headline: Grumman Offers Debt and Equity
abstract: The Grumman Corporation is offering debt and equity worth about $208.4 million, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

headline: Glut Economy
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Waking Up to the Glut Economy'' (Dec. 8) is in some respects a curiously parochial view, with a production/supply focus reminiscent of the earlier part of the century. Mr. Williams writes of ''a world awash in goods,'' ignoring the fact that hundreds of millions of people in Africa and Asia desperately need food, textiles, energy fuels, machinery - but cannot pay for them. On a worldwide potential-demand basis, there is no glut.

headline: 25,000 AT FUNERAL IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: At least 25,000 people, including diplomats from the United States and six other Western countries, crammed a crude and dusty sports stadium in this bleak township today for the funeral of 17 people killed in four days of rioting here and elsewhere around the country last month.   The police say 22 people died in the violence, most of them shot by the security forces. But anti-apartheid activists here say that in addition to those buried today, 13 more are awaiting identification in a local morgue.   Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed nationalist Nelson Mandela, who attended the funeral, said of the dead: ''Even this price is not too great to pay for freedom. No bullets or armies can stop an idea whose time has come.'' Her statement was read by a fellow activist, Frank Chikane.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Arthur Young, the accounting and consulting firm, has named Sandra K. Johnigan chairman of its National Real Estate Group.

headline: 4 Nimeiry Comrades Put on Trial in Sudan
abstract: Four associates of the former Sudanese President, Gaafar al-Nimeiry, went on trial today on charges of rebellion.

headline: Crocker's Employees Dismayed at Sale of Bank
abstract: The officers and employees of the Crocker National Corporation had struggled through two years of losses and thought they finally had their bank on the mend.   Thus, Crocker executives expressed shock and some anger at the surprise announcement Friday that the bank was being sold to Wells Fargo & Company, an action that will not let them reap the rewards for turning the bank around - and will cost many of them their jobs.   Many Crocker executives have been recruited only in the last two years. Now, many of them, along with thousands of lower-level employees, could be let go.

headline: House Committee Approves $250 Million Aid for Ulster
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to approve a $250 million aid program for Northern Ireland to help support the agreement between Britain and Ireland that gives Ireland a voice in governing the province.   The five-year program was approved by voice vote and sent to the House floor, where approval is expected.

headline: Salvadorans Call a Strike To Protest Carter Visit
abstract: Right-wing businesses called a two-hour strike today to protest a visit by former President Jimmy Carter, who is on a tour of Central America.

headline: BROOKLYN UNION
abstract: The New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation is offering $62.5 million of 7 percent tax-exempt bonds, due in 2020, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds, issued on behalf of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, are a conversion of variable-rate demand obligations sold by the development corporation last December.

headline: Market Place; How to Choose A Mutual Fund
abstract: ''READ prospectus carefully before investing.'' That familiar advice is carried in advertisements of equity mutual funds, and any potential buyer should pay it heed. A prospectus can provide valuable information ranging from the fund's financial history and performance to exchange privileges and how to redeem shares.   Sales for all types of equity, or stock-oriented, mutual funds swelled to a record $27.2 billion last year, nearly four times the volume in 1981. Attracted by the stock market's recent big gains, many people are considering an investment in equity funds, rather than relying on their own stock-picking ability.

headline: I.R.A. INVESTMENTS
abstract: To the Editor:   The article does not mention the difficulties or costs of having an account transferred or funds released. My experiences for the last two years, since depositing my account with a broker, have convinced me that even single-digit interest from a bank is preferable to whatever gain one may have from a broker-managed account. ANNE C. DAVID New York, Jan. 19

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Apricot Computer Group P.L.C., London, said it had agreed to restructure its AT Computerworld joint venture with Tandy Corp. because of the slowdown in the microcomputer market. The 13 company-owned stores will be transferred to Tandy and the 16 franchised stores will be put under Apricot's control.

headline: NOVEMBER BORROWING RISE SMALL
abstract: Americans took on $4.88 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in November, the smallest monthly increase in more than two years, the Government reported today.   The Federal Reserve Board said the November rise in installment debt was down sharply from increases of $8.12 billion in October and $11.53 billion in September.

headline: MARTIN RESIGNING FROM FED
abstract: Preston Martin, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and President Reagan's first appointee to the board, announced today that he was resigning.   Mr. Martin, in an unusual news conference in the board room at the Federal Reserve's marble headquarters on Constitution Avenue, cited personal reasons for his decision to leave at the end of April.   During the last month, Mr. Martin has been at the center of what appeared to many to be a ''palace revolt'' at the nation's central bank. However, he insisted at the news conference that he had ''agonized'' over his decision for more than three months and that it had no relation to a highly publicized policy disagreement on the board that has found him in the opposite camp from Paul A. Volcker, the Fed's chairman.

headline: Daffy Dan's Plans Store
abstract: Daffy Dan's, an apparel retailer based in New Jersey, plans to take over the vacant Harry Rothman store site in Manhattan, becoming the first major discounter of women's clothing to open on lower Fifth Avenue. The new 36,000-square-foot store on 19th Street and Fifth Avenue is expected to open late this summer or early fall.

headline: TRADING HEAVY
abstract: Wall Street yesterday recorded one of its biggest gains as the public, driven by shrinking yields on investments that are sensitive to interest rates, plowed funds into stocks in a frenzy of buying.   The Dow Jones industrial average, the 30-stock indicator that measures the pulse of the market, rose 43.10 points, its second-largest one-day gain, closing at a record 1,746.05. Other market gauges were equally buoyant as the average share climbed 82 cents and trading volume soared to its fifth-heaviest level ever.
