''It's fabulous,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''A lot of individuals realize that short-term rates are now 7 percent or less and could move even lower.'' This, Mr. Yardeni said, makes stocks a much more attractive investment.

headline: Oil Decline Spurs Rate Drop
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday as credit market participants were encouraged by the continued decline in oil prices.   As prices for crude oil for immediate delivery have fallen from slightly over $30 a barrel in the third week of November to more than $25 a week ago and $20.59 yesterday, it has helped to reduce yields on Treasury securities. A drop in oil prices increases the chances of lower rates in the future, traders and investors assume, because it points toward lower inflation and could make the Federal Reserve more inclined to follow a generous monetary policy.   Although lower oil prices have been a catalyst for lower interest rates in recent months, many economists have warned that the bond market might overestimate the deflationary effect of lower prices.

headline: Economic Scene; Shultz Takes Broad View
abstract: SECRETARY OF STATE George P. Shultz brings an economist's perspective to foreign policy. Unlike many ideologues, the conservative Mr. Shultz, once dean of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, does not regard the name John Maynard Keynes as a dirty word or his work as irrelevant to solving current problems.   During a recent interview in Washington, Mr. Shultz said he considered that the huge American trade deficit with Japan was a result of a combination of factors - the high dollar, the United States rate of expansion relative to the rest of the world, and ''only partly'' to Japanese restrictions on the inflow of goods, but ''more basically to an imbalance between gross savings and gross investment'' in Japan. ''When you have a big imbalance between excess of savings over investment,'' Mr. Shultz said, ''then, as Lord Keynes taught us, you're not going to have full employment unless something is done.''

headline: BINGHAM FAMILY TO SELL LOUISVILLE MEDIA HOLDINGS
abstract: Barry Bingham Sr., chairman and patriarch of a Kentucky media empire that includes The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times newspapers, announced yesterday that the family's communications holdings were for sale.   In a poignant memorandum posted on The Courier-Journal's bulletin board, Mr. Bingham called the decision to sell an ''unwelcome duty.''   He also mentioned the ''divergent interests'' of his children, apparently in reference to a struggle over the company that has pitted Mr. Bingham's three children against each other.   The announcement prompted the resignation of Barry Bingham Jr., the newspapers' editor and publisher, who was vice chairman and operating head of the combined companies.   In a statement, Barry Jr., who had opposed the sale, described his father's decision as ''irrational and ill-advised'' and added, ''It is difficult not to view this action as a betrayal of the traditions and principles which I have sought to perpetuate.''

headline: CORPORATE BORROWING INCREASING
abstract: The dramatic decline in interest rates in the first quarter - in some cases to levels not seen since the mid-1970's - has spurred a growing number of companies to raise cash for projects that had been long deferred because of the high cost of money.   Even before the Federal Reserve Board cut the interest rate it charges financial institutions on March 7 by half a percentage point, to 7 percent, and banks cut their prime rate half a point, to 9 percent, yields in the bond market had been moving down in anticipation of the Fed's action. On Thursday, the yield for the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue fell to 7.59 percent, the lowest level in about nine years.   One result, according to IDD Information Services Inc., a financial services concern, is that by the close of the quarter today, companies will have raised about $63 billion -three times the amount raised in the domestic capital markets during the same period last year. And, of course, more money was raised overseas.

headline: Cuban Communist Party Reshuffles Its Politburo
abstract: Cuba's Communist Party reshuffled its Politburo, promoting a women to full membership for the first time and ousting four of President Fidel Castro's revolutionary comrades.   ''We know the party has problems,'' Mr. Castro said in his closing speech Friday to the 1,790 delegates to the party's third congress.

headline: Advertising; The Insurance Industry Takes Its Case to TV
abstract: The television phase of the Insurance Information Institute's new advertising campaign aimed at combating the growing litigious bent will begin to run Monday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 25, 1986
abstract: Companies    Pepsico will acquire most of Seven-Up in the soft-drink industry's largest consolidation. Pepsi, which ranks No. 2, will pay Philip Morris $380 million for Seven-Up, which is No. 3. Lawyers see some potential antitrust problems; the Justice Department would not comment. The addition of Seven-Up's market share would put the total Pepsi product line only about 3 points behind Coke.  [ Page 33. ]    Texas Instruments lost $41.2 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $64.6 million in the period a year earlier. The company also announced that it filed patent infringement suits against nine Asian semiconductor makers.  [ 33. ]

headline: Advertising; Senior Officer Named For Waring & LaRosa
abstract: Allan Baum is coming aboard at Waring & LaRosa, the BBDO International subsidiary, as senior vice president, management supervisor.

headline: U.S. Embassy in India Denies Report on Spying
abstract: The United States Embassy denied today that any of its diplomats had ''engaged in espionage'' with an Indian businessman who was accused Tuesday of passing secrets to several American officials.

headline: ANOTHER BATTERING FOR TEXAS BANKS
abstract: LAST year, to replenish its coffers and lock in some core deposits, First City Bancorporation of Texas conducted a five-month compaign for new accounts that was extravagant even by Texas standards.   The Houston-based bank offered a Cessna 172 aircraft or a Porsche 928S sports car to anyone depositing at least $1 million into a new account for a minimum of five years. For the more modest sum of $500,000, customers could choose a Steinway grand piano or a scuba-diving vacation for two. And for a mere $100,000, the bank gave away purebred Arabian colts, weekend trips to New York City (plus a mink coat), and journeys to China or South America. The campaign, which cost the bank at least 1 Cessna, 7 Porsches and 15 Arabian colts, brought in $280 million in new deposits, a First City spokesman said.   First City needed the infusion because it was struggling to emerge from the trauma of about three years of mounting, bad energy loans.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The Fededal budget deficits have stopped expanding, and as far as experts can see, they are now going down. Government and private analysts say they are declining even without the contribution of cuts required under the new balanced-budget law, except for the small ones taking effect this year.  [ Page A1. ]    The dollar has ''fallen enough,'' Paul A. Volcker told the House Banking Committee. The Fed chairman's comment was seen as indicating that he would not cooperate in any Administration effort to drive the dollar down further.  [ D1. ]

headline: HAITI SAYS IT WILL SEEK EXTRADITION OF DUVALIER
abstract: The interim Government of Haiti announced tonight that it will ask for the extradition of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier who surrendered power and fled to France on Feb. 7.   The announcement was read on television by Justice Minister Gerard Gourgue, who said, ''The former President will shortly be the object of an extradition demand presented in the name of the Haitian state.''   The seven-point communique also called for the extradition of Col. Albert Pierre, the former head of Mr. Duvalier's notorious political police, who left last Sunday for asylum in Brazil.   The communique also said that the Government would bar Duvalier officials ''who are authors or co-authors of crime committed during the Duvalier regime'' from leaving the country.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday   None Tuesday Leading IndicatorsFebruary New-Car SalesFebruary Wednesday New-Home SalesFebruary Inventory Sales RationFebruary Thursday None Friday UnemploymentFebruary

headline: WHY IT PAYS TO PRIVATIZE PUBLIC SERVICES
abstract: FEDERAL budget-making in the era of the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget amendment has catapulted a new word into the nation's vocabulary - ''privatization,'' or the transfer of Federal assets and functions to the private sector. As a commendable first step, the Reagan Administration has proposed the sale of a portion of the $245 billion portfolio of outstanding Government loans, such as those to students and small-business men.   The political attractiveness of privatization is not hard to fathom. Traditional deficit cutting forces lawmakers to antagonize powerful blocks of voters or to raise taxes - both unpleasant political choices. Privatization, on the other hand, provides a way to reduce the deficit by giving voters a private source of supply for some of the goods and services now provided by the Government.

headline: DOES MARCOS DESERVE U.S. ASYLUM?
abstract: The Reagan Administration's decision last week to grant refuge in the United States to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has drawn virtually unanimous approval and very little criticism in Washington. As the decision was formulated, it was apparently not the subject of any serious disagreement within the Administration, and it has received bipartisan support in Congress, where Democrats as well as Republicans have been praising the Administration's handling of the crisis.   The opposition has been generated mostly in the expatriate Filipino community, where some people have argued that Mr. Marcos should not be rewarded with sanctuary for abusing his position in Manila.   Mr. Marcos, his family and an entourage of associates were flown from the Presidential palace by helicopter to Clark Air Base, and from there to Guam and Hawaii, after crowds of Filipinos and military units rallied to demand his removal. The surge of protests followed an election Feb. 7 marked by fraud and violence, in which many Filipinos believed Corazon C. Aquino had been cheated out of victory by Marcos forces.

headline: NAVY USED NEW ELECTRONIC TACTICS AGAINST LIBYA THAT PROTECTED PILOTS
abstract: In its air attacks on Libyan missile sites and naval craft, the Navy has used new tactics that military analysts in and out of Government said today had enhanced the safety of its pilots without reducing the effectiveness of its firepower.   In the clashes around the Gulf of Sidra, the analysts said, the Navy used ''standoff'' tactics, with pilots staying away from their targets and firing guided missiles at military installations. They also depended more on electronics to pinpoint these targets than the Navy had in the past.   The tactics had been developed in the wake of criticism of the performance of Navy fighter planes in Lebanon in 1983 from people within and outside Navy aviation, including Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman, himself a reserve aviator.   In Lebanon, Navy aircraft flew to their targets and dove to drop bombs on enemy forces near civilian areas. The tactics were like those used more than a decade before in Vietnam.

headline: Thrift Institution In Mortgage Sale
abstract: Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan of Boston said that it had reached an agreement to sell up to $2 billion of new single-family home mortgages during the next year to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. In exchange, the thrift unit will receive from the federally chartered agency an equal amount of mortgage participation certificates, a kind of mortgage pass-through security.

headline: Guerrillas in Peru Wound 11 In Attack on Mining Center
abstract: Leftist guerrillas attacked Peru's main mining center on Monday night, wounding 11 people as they threw sticks of dynamite at a political party office, a police station and other buildings, the police said today.   They said one man, seven women and three children attending a meeting were wounded in the attack on the offices of the ruling American Popular Revolutionary Alliance in Cerro de Pasco, 110 miles east of Lima.

headline: Data Bank: March 30, 1986
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: PATENTS; Removing TV Noise And Interference
abstract: Quanticon Inc., a research company in West Long Branch, N.J., this week received one of a series of patents on the television technology it calls Quantimage.  Patent 4,568,966, granted to Bernard Lippel, president of the company, covers technology that permits removal of unwanted noise and interference from received signals, and can display a regenerated colored picture. Licenses are being offered to manufacturers of video recording devices and to the cable and television industries.

headline: Washington Watch; Briefcases
abstract: * The White House has nominated a member of the International Trade Commission, David B. Rohr, for a full nine-year term at the agency.    * Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will address the Bretton Woods Committee on Wednesday at its annual meeting. The committee lobbies for the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

headline: SWEDEN POLICE GET LETTER ON KILLING OF PALME
abstract: The police said today that they had received an anonymous letter describing events on the night Prime Minister Olof Palme was assassinated and appealed to the writer to get in touch with them.

headline: PATENTS; Improving TV Quality
abstract: AT&T; Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., received a patent this week promising television with higher definition and better luminance, chrominance and aspect ratio. Patent 4,564,857 was granted to Joseph L. LoCicero, a faculty member at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, and two associates. Ordinary television signals are to be transmitted over one channel and the brightness and color over another.

headline: Hussein-Arafat Talks Go On
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, continued their talks here today. But there was no sign of any breakthrough in resolving fundamental differences on the future of the Middle East peace process.

headline: New Zealand Police Stop Royal Convoy Protester
abstract: A Maori land-rights activist driving a van carrying a vulgar image on one side was arrested today after he tried to join Queen Elizabeth II's motorcade here today.   The activist, Dun Mihaka, was held on a charge of dangerous driving.

headline: Careers; Harm Seen In Gothic Romances
abstract: THERE are too few good novels about working women and too many bad, overromanticized ones, according to Dr. Gayle Greene, a California teacher and writer. For women starting careers Dr. Greene has a warning: Avoid paperback romances because most are ''quack medicine,'' dangerous to career planning.  In some commuting train stations in the New York area, such as Madison and Chatham, N.J., public libraries have set up racks of paperbacks ''free for the taking.'' Many are typical Gothic or modern romances, and they have a rapid turnover.

headline: IN DAMASCUS, SKYSCRAPERS NOT OF AGES
abstract: In the last half-century, this city, which claims to be the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in the world, grew 35-fold, from 70,000 to 2.5 million.   The transformation profoundly affected its landscape: urban planning was overtaken by the need for housing, and miles of identical concrete apartment blocks were hastily built.   Damascus swelled as peasants left the fields in hopes of finding riches in the capital and as Palestinians sought refuge after two Middle East wars.   The deep-rooted Syrian belief that one's home should be a replica of paradise - a wall-enclosed villa with flowing fountains and shade trees of bitter orange, jasmine and eucalyptus - was abandoned in a rush of land speculation.

headline: BATTLE FOR SOUTHERN YEMEN: HOW THE FURY BEGAN
abstract: A gangland-style massacre by President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani of his rivals in the ruling Marxist party's Politburo touched off more than a week of bitter house-to-house battles and a rebellion that drove him from office, according to authoritative Southern Yemeni sources.   Mr. Hassani called a meeting of the 15-member Politburo at 10 A.M. on Jan. 13. But he did not attend, Yemeni sources said, traveling instead by car to his tribal stronghold in the Abyan region with a small group of supporters.   As the other members of the Politburo entered their low, pastel green headquarters near the harbor, the President's personal guards reportedly opened fire on them with their Kalashnikov assault rifles, mowing down several of his most prominent critics.   But bodyguards of other Politburo members drew their weapons and a wild gun battle broke out, in which other opponents of the President escaped.

headline: Disney Net Improves 7.8%
abstract: Walt Disney Productions today reported earnings in the last three months of 1985 of $34.7 million, or $1.04 a share, up 7.8 percent from net income of $32.2 million, or 95 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. It was the highest profit ever for a fiscal first quarter at Disney. Revenues rose 18.2 percent, to $504.2 million, from $426.5 million.

headline: RUMANIANS ARE URGED TO LET 2 SCHOLARS GO
abstract: Senators Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, have urged Rumania to allow two mathematicians to go abroad.   The two scholars, Mihail-Radu Rosu and Silviu Teleman, have been offered visiting professorships for the 1986-87 academic year at American institutions.

headline: Advertising; Magazine Focuses On Drinkers Only
abstract: Michael Minick, publisher of Beauty Digest, is particularly interested in target marketing. That is why he was always concerned about the amount of waste involved in liquor advertisers buying space in general consumer magazines and wasting their romantic imagery on a multitude of non-drinkers, about half the population.

headline: Canada Bank's New Chairman
abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that Allan R. Taylor, its president and chief operating officer, will become chairman and chief executive on June 1.

headline: DAYS OF DECISION: AS OPTIONS NARROW, U.S. MOVES AGAINST AN 'OLD FRIEND'
abstract: Administration officials are wondering whether President Reagan's call for President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign has come too late to forestall a blood bath in the Philippines.   They also wonder whether the call was strong enough to overcome Philippine opposition leaders' suspicions about Mr. Reagan's close identification with the Marcos regime.   Whatever the answer, Administration officials say Mr. Reagan had no choice but to act as he did toward a man that the White House described today as ''an old friend and ally.''   ''He could not countenance troops loyal to Marcos using American arms against Filipino rebels as Washington stood by in silence,'' a key Administration official said.

headline: Morgan Raises Bid for Conrail
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company, leader of an investor group seeking to buy Conrail, today increased its bid for the railroad company by $200 million, to $1.4 billion.   Thomas A. Saunders, Morgan Stanley's managing director, said he hoped the sweetened bid would cause the Senate to defeat an Administration-backed bill to sell the Consolidated Railroad Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

headline: Advertising; Dewe Rogerson in U.S.
abstract: Dewe Rogerson International, a major British financial public relations firm, has opened an office at 250 Park Avenue with Carol A. Ruth, a former senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton, as president of the Dewe Rogerson Inc. subsidiary. In England, about 30 to 40 percent of the company's revenues are from advertising. The new office in the colonies is still devoid of clients.

headline: CLOSE CALL FOR PLANE CARRYING MARCOS
abstract: A small aircraft carrying President Ferdinand E. Marcos to a campaign appearance narrowly avoided a collision today with another small plane landing from the opposite direction on a small grass airstrip, according to officials traveling with Mr. Marcos.   Though some witnesses said President Marcos appeared shaken and dropped his glasses when he emerged from the aircraft at the town of Calapan in northeastern Mindoro Province, the officials said he had not been aware of the close call.   Moments before his approach, a single-engine Cessna that officials said was carrying security forces for Mr. Marcos's protection aborted a landing at the same airstrip and swung around for a second approach from the opposite direction.   According to witnesses, a colonel ran onto the airstrip waving his hat and flagged off the Cessna, which banked to the right above a stand of coconut trees, avoiding the President's twin-engine, 10-seat Beechcraft by what one witness said was 3,000 feet.

headline: CHIP ORDERS UP IN FEBRUARY
abstract: Orders for semiconductors increased in February, with the book-to-bill ratio rising to 1.10, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade organization based in San Jose, Calif.   A ratio of 1.10 means that for every $100 of products shipped, $110 worth was ordered, indicating an upturn in demand.   The association said average monthly orders for the three months ended in February were $667.5 million, up 9.3 percent from $610.6 million for the period ended in January.

headline: MITTERRAND TURNS TO A CONSERVATIVE AS PREMIER TODAY
abstract: After a day of uncertainty and closed-door meetings among political leaders, President Francois Mitterrand announced today that he would ask a conservative on Tuesday to become the new Prime Minister and form a Government.   He acted after his governing Socialists were set back in legislative elections Sunday, and the conservatives won a slim edge in the National Assembly. Under the 1958 Constitution that set up the Fifth Republic, the President must pick a Prime Minister from among the majority in Parliament.   Although the final election results showed that the two main conservative parties - Rally for the Republic and Union for French Democracy - had not won an absolute majority by themselves, they won control of Parliament with the help of independents.

headline: Chile Recovers Bodies Of 8 American Tourists
abstract: Chilean Air Force personnel today recovered the bodies of eight American tourists who died on New Year's Eve when the chartered plane in which they were traveling crashed on an Antarctic glacier, officials said.   The victims had planned to spend New Year's Eve among the penguins in Antarctica.

headline: Soviet Ties With Ivory Coast
abstract: Ivory Coast renewed diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union Thursday, 17 years after President Felix Houphouet-Boigny broke off ties. Mr. Houphouet-Boigny had contended that the Soviet Ambassador tried to organize an insurrection. A brief statement issued by the Government said the two nations would ''start anew in the shortest time possible the activities of the embassies of each country in the capital of the other.''

headline: A Leader of Solidarity Will Face Charges
abstract: The Government said today that an underground Solidarity leader would face charges of illegal union activities and trying to set off social unrest.

headline: Motorola Studied Toshiba Venture
abstract: Motorola Inc. acknowledged that it had studied the possibility of a joint venture between its semiconductor unit and that of Toshiba, the Japanese electronics manufacturer.

headline: LOAN FOR WHEELING
abstract: The financially troubled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation has gotten approval from a Federal bankruptcy judge for a $60.7 million loan needed to help it ride out a lull in revenues, a company spokesman said today.

headline: Chrysler Mini-Van
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation will start assembling mini-vans at its St. Louis plant in Fenton, Mo., early next year, company officials said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it had extended its consumer incentive programs to Feb. 28 from Jan. 31.    * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it intended to consolidate the Denver accounting and treasury operations serving its informations systems group with a similar facility in Orlando, Fla.    * Bank of Virginia, Richmond, said it had reached a definitive agreement to buy Security National Corp. for $68.50 a share.

headline: Business Ethics
abstract: To the Editor:   Substantial credit for the greater presence of ''traditional moral and religious values'' (''A Modest Revival in Business Ethics?'' Forum, Dec. 22) in industry and commerce is due to the widespread mass production and mass consumption of goods and services.

headline: MOSLEM NATIONS SUPPORTING QADDAFI IN THE U.S. DISPUTE
abstract: Moslem Governments, ranging from radical Iran to pro-Western Kuwait, have issued strong statements of support for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in his confrontation with the United States.   In Fez, Morocco, a meeting of foreign ministers of the Islamic Conference Organization adopted a declaration Tuesday, saying that it considered the ''imperialist-Zionist threat'' to Libya a threat to all Moslem countries.   The declaration of the 45-member organization, which includes such allies of the United States as Pakistan and Turkey, expressed solidarity with the Libyans and ''active support in defense of their sovereignty, territorial integrity and territorial waters.'' The Sixth Fleet is on station off Libya.

headline: Israelis Report Foiling Arab Kidnapping Plot
abstract: Israeli troops patrolling the Lebanese border early this morning thwarted an Arab terrorist attempt to seize Israeli hostages in Galilee, military sources said tonight.   Two Arab gunmen were killed and an Israeli soldier was wounded in the encounter, a military communique said.

headline: Jardine and Emett
abstract: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Emett & Chandler Companies, the nation's 12th-largest insurance broker, through a cash merger valued at about $62 million. Jardine, a diversified corporation based in Hong Kong, will pay $19 a share for Emett & Chandler's 3.26 million common shares outstanding.

headline: QADDAFI 'WELCOMES' A REPRISAL
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, warned today that Israeli or American retaliation for airport attacks by Arab terrorists would set off a ''tit for tat'' cycle of violence, with Libyans harassing ''American citizens in their own streets.''   The Libyan leader, speaking to a small group of Western reporters in his downtown barracks, said any attack on Libya would mean outright war in the Middle East and Mediterranean.

headline: Robot Statistics
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Rise of the Robots'' (Prospects, Jan. 5) quoted a University of Michigan study as stating that ''robots will displace 4.3 percent of the industrial work force.'' As co-author of that study, I must take issue with your use of this figure.

headline: 5 Reported Killed In Lebanese Clashes
abstract: President Amin Gemayel's Christian loyalists and Syrian-backed militia forces exchanged heavy artillery and tank cannon fire in Lebanon's central mountains today. The police said five combatants were killed and seven wounded.

headline: STOCK MARKET OPEN IN ISRAEL
abstract: The Tel Aviv stock exchange re-sumed trading today after a one-day shutdown because of reports that the Israeli Government might impose a tax on stock transactions, and share prices dropped as much as 10 percent, a spokesman said.   While Yitzhak Modai, the Finance Minister, has ruled out a tax on stock transactions or stock profits, Prime Minister Shimon Peres has said that a 2 percent tax would help alleviate Israel's budget problems by bringing in $30 million to $40 million a year.

headline: A NEW WAY TO BUILD CARS
abstract: WHEN the General Motors Corporation opens assembly plants in Kansas City, Kan., and Doraville, Ga., in the fall of 1987 they will be largely missing a key element of traditional mass production: an assembly line. Instead, the company plans to assemble cars using hundreds of motorized, unmanned carriers called automated guided vehicles, which will carry a car as it goes through the assembly process.   With the carriers, G.M. is breaking away from the auto industry's traditional method of operation, which is centered on a relentlessly moving assembly line that insures high productivity. But company officials describe the carriers as the heart of a new assembly system that they say will improve auto quality and greatly increase plant flexibility.

headline: Iran and Iraq Report Air Raid And Exchange Accusations
abstract: Iraq and Iran mounted bombing raids today and accused each other of attacking civilian targets in renewed aerial activity in their five-year-old war.

headline: LIBYA UNITS OF U.S. CONCERNS ARE SAID TO HALT OIL EXPORTS
abstract: In a move with potentially serious economic implications for Libya, most of the Libyan subsidiaries of American oil companies operating here have temporarily suspended exports of their entitled allotment of oil, business executives and diplomats said today.   These sources, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, said that only one of the five subsidiaries was still exporting oil.   The suspension resulted from concern about the ramifications of President Reagan's economic sanctions against Libya and the plunge in mid-January in the world price of oil from $25 a barrel on the spot market, where oil not under contract is traded, to $17 a barrel last week. Prices were a little over $20 a barrel today.

headline: Contractors
abstract: To the Editor:   Senator William Proxmire's demand that we ''take the criminals out of defense contracting'' may suffer from insufficient analysis (''Why Military Contracting Is Corrupt,'' Forum, Dec. 15). The system of defense contracting is not the only one in which competitive bidding virtually forces all the participants to become liars, crooks or both.

headline: A SURGE OF VOLUME FOR UNDERWRITERS
abstract: Wall Street raised more capital for corporate America in 1985 than in any previous year.   Corporate finance professionals bagged one elephant-size deal after another as a highly receptive market bought out such issues as Fireman's Fund, a record initial public stock offering at $824 million.   While a number of factors contributed to the outpouring of new issues, the principal one was the remarkable bull markets in both bonds and stocks. The stock market climbed far into record territory by year-end, as long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level in six years.

headline: DOES SATAN LURK IN TURIN, OR JUST SOME AMATEURS?
abstract: Is Satan haunting this most modern and rational of Italian cities?   In late February the Archbishop of Turin, Anastasio Cardinal Ballestrero, seemed to suggest that the Devil was lurking about when he announced the naming of six exorcists, priests who are formally charged with casting out demons.   But at the archdiocesan offices here, church officials seemed positively embarrassed at the idea that their city, the home of Fiat and other world industrial leaders, had developed a Satanic tinge.   ''Turin is not a magic city,'' insisted the Rev. Franco Peradotta, the vicar general of the diocese and a 58-year-old priest with an easy smile and a practical turn of mind. ''I have never seen a possession by the Devil.''

headline: SHIFT TO LONDON MARKS SALOMON'S GLOBAL REACH
abstract: In a personnel shift meant to take advantage of rapid expansion in its international business, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced yesterday that Peter M. Gottsegen, a managing director in charge of international corporate finance activities in New York, would move to London to oversee global finance activities.   For several years Salomon Brothers and Credit Suisse First Boston have run neck and neck as leaders of Euromarket financing activity.   Last year Salomon Brothers was the top marketer of bonds in that arena, acting as lead manager for $5.5 billion worth of Euromarket securities, up an impressive 62 percent from 1984's $3.41 billion.

headline: DOCUMENTS ON MARCOS CITE COLLABORATION REPORTS
abstract: Evidence that family members of the candidates in the Philippine presidential campaign collaborated with the Japanese during World War II has emerged as a hotly contested issue in the final days of the race.   Relatives of both the opposition presidential candidate, Corazon C. Aquino, and her running mate, Salvador H. Laurel, worked openly for the Japanese. Neither Mrs. Aquino nor Mr. Laurel has disputed the fact.   President Ferdinand E. Marcos has pointed up these connections, saying his own record is, in contrast, one of patriotism and opposition to the Japanese occupation force.   But United States Army documents that were disclosed last week indicate that Mr. Marcos's own record is ambiguous on this point.

headline: PATENTS; GENETIC MATERIAL USED IN BACTERIA PROCESS
abstract: A process of introducing genetic material into the cells of bacteria to induce the production of similar materials, such as interferon, hormones and insulin, was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: South Africa Criticizes 6 Touring Congressmen
abstract: Six United States members of Congress, on the last day of a tour of South Africa, ran into harsh criticism today when they were attacked by the state-run radio and snubbed by a black group.   The South African radio said the delegation led by Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, personified a ''form of foreign interference in the country's affairs that has grown dramatically in popularity among a certain kind of Western politician in the last year or two.''

headline: ISRAEL PARTY TRIES TO REPAIR CHAOS
abstract: Herut Party officials scrambled to patch together their fragmenting right-wing party today after the collapse Thursday of its national convention.   But the bitterness among the key leaders in the Herut Party - Yitzhak Shamir, David Levy and Ariel Sharon - appeared to be as intense as ever, and there was no indication that they were prepared to talk with one another, let alone resolve their differences.   With the Herut Party in a shambles, and Mr. Levy and Mr. Sharon having effectively undermined the authority of Mr. Shamir, the party leader and Foreign Minister, pressure seemed to be mounting today on Prime Minister Shimon Peres to exploit the situation for his Labor Party.

headline: RICO'S ASSAULT ON LEGITIMATE BUSINESS
abstract: RICO, the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, is a well-intentioned statute gone awry.   Congress enacted RICO in 1970 to fight organized crime and to protect legitimate businesses from invasions by organized crime. Today, however, legitimate businesses are more intimidated by RICO than by gangsters - they face claims totaling hundreds of millions of dollars stemming from RICO charges. The charge of ''racketeering'' (which encompasses a wide variety of criminal activities, including securities fraud) is now attached routinely to civil suits by unscrupulous plaintiffs solely to intimidate innocent companies.   Many of the problems stem from an aspect of the law that was virtually unnoticed in 1970: the private right of action, which allows individuals to bring suit under RICO for a variety of offenses, such as the provision of illegal goods and services or fraud.

headline: Soviet Kin Permitted to Join Emigre Film Director Abroad
abstract: The son and mother-in-law of Andrei Tarkovsky, the emigre film director, have been allowed to join him abroad, Western diplomats said today.

headline: Florida Freeze Threat Sends Orange Juice Up
abstract: A cold front swept across the United States and threatened Florida orange groves, prompting a sharp rise in prices for frozen orange juice futures today at the New York Cotton Exchange.   The sharp fall in temperatures also helped spur buying of energy futures contracts, with heating oil leading the way.

headline: EXXON NET RISES 26.6% IN QUARTER
abstract: The biggest company in the world, the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that its net income rose nearly 27 percent in the fourth quarter but fell almost 12 percent for the year.   Analysts pointed out, however, that most of the year's decline in net income came from special one-time provisions that the company took in the event it had to pay $2.1 billion in refunds and interest related to Government charges that Exxon had overcharged customers.   On Monday, the Supreme Court declined to hear Exxon's appeal of a lower-court ruling that the company had overcharged customers in the 1970's who bought crude oil from the Hawkins field in Texas. Profits of $1.81 Billion   Clifton C. Garvin Jr., Exxon's chairman, reported that profits for the final quarter rose 26.6 percent, to $1.81 billion, or $2.43 a share, from $1.43 billion, or $1.81 a share, in 1984. Revenues for the quarter were $24.68 billion, up five-tenths of 1 percent from $24.56 billion in the 1984 period.

headline: LITTLE-KNOWN APPLIANCE GIANT
abstract: Ward Smith took over as chief executive at White Consolidated Industries in January, and in recent interviews he has brimmed with ideas to improve the big appliance maker's manufacturing and marketing.   But his ambitious plans may now be somewhat in limbo.   In a move that surprised industry analysts, Electrolux A.B. of Sweden, one of the world's largest makers of home appliances, over the weekend offered $45 a share, or about $711 million, for White.   White, which is based in Cleveland and is the nation's third-largest manufacturer of appliances, has not yet responded to the unsolicited bid.

headline: REAGAN SAYS THE CHOICE IS BETWEEN BACKING HIM OR COMMUNISTS
abstract: President Reagan, discussing his proposal to send aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that members of Congress must choose between supporting his Administration or supporting Communists.   Continuing his weeklong campaign for his $100 million aid package in a meeting with House Republican leaders, Mr. Reagan said a great many people were deceived about Communist subversion and hinted that such was true of some in Congress.   The assertion came as some members of Congress complained that the Administration was losing votes for the aid because of the shrillness of its campaign and the suggestion by some that Congressional opponents were unpatriotic.   Mr. Reagan, asked at the start of the meeting if Democrats were facing a choice between supporting him or the Communists, replied:   ''It's what the choice comes down to, whether it is knowingly or not. And I've had enough experience with Communist subversion back in my former profession to know that a great many people are deceived, and not aware that what they're doing is inimical to the interests of the United States.''

headline: A Protest at Base in Spain
abstract: About 80 anti-NATO protesters demanding the dismantling of United States military sites in Spain marched to the Navy base in Rota today, the police said. Rota, in southern Spain, is one of four joint Spanish-United States bases.

headline: SOVIET SAYS U.S. SEEKS LIBYAN CONFRONTATION
abstract: A Soviet Government spokesman said today that the United States was making ''direct threats'' against Libya and was not interested in a peaceful resolution of their differences.   The spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko of the Foreign Ministry, declined to say at a news conference what action the Soviet Union would take if the United States blockaded Libyan ports.   His remarks were the first Soviet comment on the recent tensions.

headline: WORKERS ACCUSE DYNAMICS
abstract: Workers at the General Dynamics Corporation here have accused some managers at the company of falsifying time cards, and say the practice has led to overbilling on Government contracts.   Although the giant military contractor is currently under indictment for fraud, the charges against it have not included instances of incorrect billing for employee time.   But at least one other major military contractor, the General Electric Company, has faced such charges, and was temporarily barred from Pentagon work in early 1985. G.E. pleaded guilty to 108 counts of falsifying time cards, and was fined $1.04 million, the maximum allowable. G.E. was also ordered to pay back the $800,000 that was falsely billed.   In scores of interviews outside factory gates, inside their homes and over the telephone since last Friday, many General Dynamics workers said that supervisors at the General Dynamics plants here sometimes incorrectly billed employee hours to the Federal Government. The workers also said that, until recently, managers in some departments filled out time cards after the workers signed them. The employees in those departments signed the cards at the beginning of each week and never saw them again, they said.

headline: Texas Eastern
abstract: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it expects to report a unspecified loss in the fourth quarter because of about $100 million in nonrecurring charges. It said the charge resulted from lower crude oil prices and to losses from a pending divestiture.

headline: Washington Watch; Bank Bill on the Ropes
abstract: After the Supreme Court overruled the Fed last month and ruled that only Congress could outlaw limited-service banks, members of Congress finally thought they had a strong enough issue to get H.R. 20, a bill to bar such institutions, out of the Rules Committee, where it has been tied up for months. But their hopes seem to be fading fast.

headline: Advertising; Hasbro Agency Search Chooses Six Finalists
abstract: Hasbro Industries, one of the nation's largest toy and game companies, has reached the penultimate plateau in its search for a second agency.

headline: ARAB TERRORISTS CLAIM PARIS ARCADE BOMBING
abstract: An Arab group demanding the release of three terrorists from French prisons took responsibility today for a bombing that killed 2 people and wounded 28 at a shopping center on the Champs-Elysees.   Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who took office moments before the bomb exploded Thursday evening, said he had ordered increased security in public places.

headline: F.C.C. POLICY ON PHONES
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is set to propose abolishing its rule barring the regional Bell Telephone operating companies from selling equipment in conjunction with basic telephone service.   The F.C.C. action, listed on the agenda for Thursday's meeting, is being fought by consumer groups and independent telephone equipment makers and sellers.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 14, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on complaint by Lebanon at 11 A.M.

headline: AT PORT-AU-PRINCE MARKET, 'EMOTIONS ARE HIGH'
abstract: The market woman leaned over the counter of her dry-goods store and confided in a low voice, ''He's got to straighten up - or it's the army.''   Outside, on the sidewalk, a young bearded man chewed on a meat pie and thought about the same question the woman had answered: What does the future hold for Jean-Claude Duvalier, Haiti's self-proclaimed President for Life?   ''He's got to go - the people want him out,'' the man said before disappearing into a scene of brightly painted buses and women carrying trays of fruit on their heads.   Sprawling from a pink and lime-green painted structure, the Iron Market has long been the capital's forum for goods and gossip. Last Friday, in one of the most daring protests in almost the almost 30 years the Duvaliers have governed, protesters blocked streets around the Iron Market and taunted the police by chanting, ''Down with Duvalier!''

headline: PASSING MUSTER IN BRAZIL: PRESIDENT WOOS ARMY
abstract: It was a formal yet friendly occasion, with the 143 men in white dress uniforms and decorations enthusiastically applauding their guest of honor's stern warning that ''anarchy and civil disobedience'' would not be tolerated.   The guest, President Jose Sarney, seemed no less pleased to hear that he was popular among the armed forces - more popular, in the words of the Air Minister, Brig. Octavio Moreira Lima, than any other civilian leader in more than four decades.   The year-end gathering in the exclusive Army Club in Brasilia, however, was not unusual. Since becoming Brazil's first civilian President since 1964, Mr. Sarney has gone out of his way to woo top military commanders, not only paying frequent tribute to them, but also discouraging inquiries into human rights violations under the former dictatorship.

headline: STATE IS UNDER NEW DELHI RULE
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ousted the leader of the Moslem-dominated state of Kashmir today and in effect placed it under his control.   The move cleared the way for possible new elections in Kashmir, a northern state where there has been increasing violence between Moslems and Hindus. But at the same time, it appeared to create a host of new problems for the Prime Minister, whose political fortunes have recently started to ebb.   It was the second time in two years that a Kashmir Chief Minister was ousted by a Prime Minister. The dismissal was seen as a symbol of continuing instability in India's only Moslem-dominated state, where there is a special sensitivity because of its border with Pakistan.

headline: Advertising; ACCOUNTS
abstract: * Radio Station WMCA to Van Brunt Advertising.    * Ultrasonix Inc., to Lavey/Wolff/ Swift.

headline: Japan Trade Shift Urged
abstract: Senator John C. Danforth said today that Japan should set a goal of doubling its imports of foreign goods in the next three to five years to calm rising protectionist sentiment in other nations.   Mr. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, has been urging Japan to expand its imports of manufactured and agricultural processed goods on a visit to Tokyo as the head of a Congressional delegation.

headline: Kodak Alters Research Setup
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, continuing a broad reorganization and shift of its product lines, said that its research and development operations would be realigned in an effort to speed product development.   In addition, Kodak said it had agreed to sell its technology and patents used to make textile dyes to the Ciba-Geigy Group, a Swiss concern whose United States operations are based in Ardsley, N.Y. Both companies declined to disclose the price.

headline: Court Halts Kodak Refund
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, barred last month by a Federal judge from making and selling instant cameras, has received a court order to halt its planned camera refund program.   Judge David J. Shields of the Circuit Court of Cook County in Chicago ordered Kodak to stop the program until a lawsuit accusing it of insufficient compensation to camera owners can be heard.

headline: FOR A GRAIN GIANT, NO FARM CRISIS
abstract: IT is no wonder that a mystique surrounds Cargill Inc. It is easily the world's leading company in the highly secretive, fiercely competitive grain trading business. With $32 billion in revenues last year, it is also the nation's largest privately held company and is thus rarely forced to reveal details about itself.   What is more, the Cargills and the MacMillans, the two families that own most company shares, jealously guard their privacy. Even Cargill's headquarters, a 63-room replica of a French chateau, is hidden behind acres of trees on an estate near Lake Minnetonka, outside of Minneapolis.   Slowly, however, Cargill is lifting the veil of secrecy that shrouds it. In the past six months, it has had to file public documents as it turned, for the first time, to the public markets to borrow in order to take advantage of low interest rates. And with the nation's grain exports plunging, the company entered the foreground as part of the debate raging over farm and trade policies.

headline: HEAD OF SMITHKLINE FORCED TO SHIFT STRATEGY
abstract: Henry Wendt is the latest drug manufacturer to fall victim to tampering. The 52-year-old president and chief executive of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation has begun reformulating the company's strategy after a recall of capsule formulas of three of its over-the-counter drugs.   SmithKline last week ordered the recall of capsules of Contac cold medicine; Teldrin, the allergy remedy, and the appetite suppressant Dietac, after investigators in Houston and Orlando, Fla., found traces of rat poison in them.

headline: Leader of New Group Has 29 Years at Morgan
abstract: A day after he was given greatly expanded responsibilities at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Robert G. Engel was not sure how many people would be working for him.   ''I haven't figured that out yet,'' he said, ''but these changes will enable us to bring to bear the full resources of the institution.''   The changes that Mr. Engel referred to were formally announced yesterday by J.P. Morgan & Company, Morgan's parent. They include combining the bank's commercial lending operations and its capital market services into a new corporate finance group.

headline: 2 IN CONGRESS OFFER COMPROMISE PLANS ON AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS
abstract: In an effort to head off a defeat for President Reagan, two of his supporters on Capitol Hill suggested compromise proposals today that would combine United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels with a stronger push for a negotiated settlement in Central America.   Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the majority leader, conveyed the ''general direction'' of these and other potential compromises today to Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, according to a spokesman for the Senator. Mr. Dole reiterated his belief that without a compromise the President's push to aid the Nicaraguan insurgents would probably be rejected in Congress next week, the spokesman added.   Under both proposals, the Administration would receive the $100 million requested by Mr. Reagan for the rebels, known as contras. At the same time, the President would agree to pursue negotiations with the Nicaraguan Government. If the talks made progress, the aid to the insurgents would be delayed or withheld.

headline: Ex-Im Bank's Head Going to U.N. Post
abstract: William H. Draper 3d said yesterday that he was resigning as president of the Export-Import Bank, to become administrator of the United Nations Development Program in New York.   He said he expected to resign effective Feb. 28 and to take over the United Nations post around May 1, when the present administrator, Bradford Morse, retires.   Speculation on who might succeed Mr. Draper centered on his vice chairman, John A. Bohn Jr., and on J. William Middendorf 2d, the Ambassador to the European Economic Community in Brussels, who is understood to want the presidency of the World Bank.

headline: The U.N. Today: Feb. 19, 1986
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Iran-Iraq conflict at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: HOLLYWOOD SEEKS CONTROL OF OUTLETS
abstract: Hollywood is trying to expand its hold over the exhibition outlets for the movies and television shows that it produces by buying television stations and movie theaters.   In mid-February, for example, MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Pictures, bought television station WOR in New Jersey for $387 million. The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation last year purchased six television stations in major cities. And both Columbia Pictures Industries and MCA recently bought theaters.   Owning the final outlets for programs is not a new business for the movie makers. Their grip was so strong in the late 1940's that the Government separated the functions in a series of antitrust orders. Many of the big movie makers were forced to split their theater and production activies, and are still subject to those orders unless they win special permission from the courts.

headline: G.E. Cutting 1,500 At Turbine Plant
abstract: At least 1,500 jobs will be eliminated this year at the General Electric Company's turbine division in Schenectady, the top local G.E. executive, George Cox, said. ''The market environment for the products we make here is just simply awful,'' Mr. Cox told some 400 civic leaders at a Chamber of Commerce breakfast.

headline: U.S. EXTRADITES CROAT TO YUGOSLAVIA
abstract: An 86-year-old Croat described as the highest-ranking Nazi war criminal to enter the United States was flown today to Yugoslavia to face mass murder charges dating from World War II.   The man, Andrija Artukovic, was sent off less than an hour after Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court had denied a stay.   The Government said Mr. Artukovic had a role in the killing of 200,000 people while he was Minister of Interior and Minister of Justice in the Nazi puppet state of Croatia from 1941 to 1945.   A former Justice Department lawyer who worked on the case said the toll might have exceeded 700,000. The victims were said to have included Serbs, Jews, Gypsies and others.

headline: Venezuela in Debt Accord
abstract: Venezuela yesterday signed an agreement to stretch out repayments on $21.2 billion of its $26 billion of public-sector debt.   The terms, set with more than 400 banks worldwide, are about the same as Venezuela reached in a tentative agreement in September 1984.

headline: General Defies House Arrest, Seizes 2d Ecuadorean Base
abstract: A general who took over a coastal air base for four days and forced the resignation of two top Government officials seized a second military base today and demanded the arrest of the two officials and the dismissal of the President.

headline: CHURCH IN HAITI LAUNCHES LITERACY DRIVE
abstract: The Roman Catholic bishops of Haiti have begun a nationwide campaign to end the illiteracy of this poorest and least educated nation of the Western Hemisphere.   Bishop Francois Gayot, the head of the Haitian Bishops' Conference, said the aim of the campaign was to ''make three million people literate in the next five years.''   Before tens of thousands of people at an open-air rally, the Bishop appealed to other religious groups and all sectors of Haitian society to ''spread the word'' and cooperate in the literacy drive. Addressing the rich, he said, ''You, who have so much, you can give a little.''

headline: GUATEMALA INAUGURATES CIVILIAN LEADER
abstract: An elected civilian was sworn in today as President of Guatemala after more than 30 years of military-dominated rule.   The new President, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, told Guatemalans that the nation faced a ''terrible crisis.''   In his inaugural speech, Mr. Cerezo said Guatemala's treasury was empty, and he warned that the country faced a period of ''great austerity and great sacrifice.''   ''There are no funds to begin new projects,'' he said.

headline: OIL IMPACT ON POORER NATIONS
abstract: Most developing nations that import oil will gain more from the impact of falling oil prices on the industrialized world than from direct savings on their own fuel costs, bankers and economists say in assessing the effects of the price slump on the developing countries.   ''The real issue is the impact of the price cuts on the growth rates in the industrial world and on interest rates,'' said Christine Bindert, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. who has worked as an economic adviser for several Latin American governments.   To be sure, developing nations -just like the United States and other industrialized countries - cannot know just how much they will benefit from falling oil prices until they see how far the price decline goes and how long it lasts.   Nonetheless, economists estimate that the decline in prices should add between one-half of 1 percent and 1 percent to the growth rate of the economies of industrialized nations this year. That should in turn increase demand for Latin American, African and Asian manufactured goods and commodities.

headline: SANDINISTAS SAID TO ENCIRCLE U.S. INDIAN GROUP
abstract: A Miskito Indian spokesman said today that a group of Indian leaders from the United States and Canada, on a secret trip inside Nicaragua with a Miskito leader, Brooklyn Rivera, had been encircled by Nicaraguan Government troops.   The Mikito spokesman, Armstrong Wiggins, said the purpose of the trip was to familiarize the foreign Indian leaders with conditions in the Miskito area and the attitudes of the people.   A Nicaraguan official in Washington said he had no information from his Government about the presence of Mr. Rivera's group but added that if it had entered the country illegally and was traveling with armed men, it would ''have to suffer the consequences.''   Although the Miskito spokesman said the delegation had not gone into Nicaragua to engage in combat, the Nicaraguan official, Manuel Cordero, deputy chief of the Nicaraguan Embassy, pointed out that one of the American Indians on the trip, Russell Means, had declared in Costa Rica on Nov. 10 that he hoped to recruit 90 to 100 ''warriors from North America'' to fight the Sandinistas.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Martin L. Orlowsky was named executive vice president, sales and marketing; Richard A. Kampe was named senior vice president-marketing, and Gerald W. McKenna was named vice president-marketing planning, at R. J. Reynolds Tobacco.    * Peter D. Nichols was promoted to senior vice president/associate creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE SPECIAL EVENTS
abstract: CAN a country music concert sell cigarettes? Or skydiving get people to buy more beer? Or a runner's marathon pull them into a bank?   Apparently Philip Morris, Adolph Coors and Manufacturers Hanover think so. Each of them has sponsored such special events in recent years.

headline: BIOTECHNOLOGY: A NEW WONDERWORLD
abstract: THE first medical product manufactured by gene-splicing technology, human insulin for treatment of diabetes, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration less than four years ago. Since then several others have emerged, all as a result of advances in biological research that have made it possible to find, reproduce and study human genes, the blueprints for all living things, as well as modify them to produce substances different from any that have developed naturally.   Genetic engineering, as this process is known, is based mainly on advances that have taken place over the last 10 years. Already more than 200 biotechnology companies in the nation are seeking to exploit the new capabilities. And a recent report from the National Academy of Sciences estimated that this new industry had already created 5,000 to 10,000 new jobs. Additional employment is likely to develop in fermentation technology, the segment of the industry devoted to actual production of large quantities of novel or previously rare substances.

headline: IRAN OFFENSIVE WORRIES GULF NATIONS
abstract: Iran's recent offensive and its continued occupation of a strategic piece of Iraqi territory has stunned many Arab nations and revived fears about the vulnerability of both Iraq and its Persian Gulf neighbors, according to Arab officials meeting here.   The Iranian military drive in which troops seized the Fao Peninsula had been predicted for weeks by Iran's religious leadership. But Arab officials have expressed dismay that the well-equipped Iraqi military has been so far ineffective in expelling the Iranian invaders, and they say they fear the continued presence of Iranians on Arab soil could instigate incidents of sabotage by Islamic fundamentalists in their countries.   ''It's different this time,'' said Jordan's Foreign Minister, Taher Nashat al-Masri. ''The gulf countries are extremely worried, because although Iraq is doing well and will continue to do well, there is always the possibility of making a mistake.''

headline: Burroughs Cuts
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation said it would lay off 810 workers in a consolidation of production operations in California, Colorado, Florida and Scotland.

headline: HOLIDAY DELAYING U.S. BILL AUCTION
abstract: The Government securities market will be closed today in observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. The regular Monday sale of Treasury bills will be delayed until tomorrow.   While Treasury securities will be traded in London and Tokyo today, the domestic market will be closed because the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will not be open to handle electronic transfers of funds and securities. Tax-exempt and corporate bond departments at securities firms will be open and financial futures will be trading in Chicago. On days when the cash market for Government securities is closed, trading in tax-exempt and corporate issues and futures contracts is normally light.

headline: Chad Reports an Attack By Libyan Forces
abstract: Libyan forces attacked Chadian Army troops today in central Chad, the Chadian Government announced tonight in a communique received in Paris.   Foreign Minister Gouara Lassou said in the communique that Libyan troops had attacked Chadian positions at Kouba Olanga, 350 miles northeast of Ndjamena, the capital.

headline: O'NEILL ASSAILS AID REQUEST FOR CONTRAS
abstract: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, led a Democratic counterattack today against a new Administration request for $70 million in military aid and $30 million in economic aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.   In a statement read to reporters, Mr. O'Neill, who is a Massachusetts Democrat, said the Administration should practice the same ''smart diplomacy'' that worked in the Philippines instead of providing more aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents. The White House has asked action before Congress takes an Easter break on March 26.   The reference to the Philippines was an effort to counter the Administration's argument that those who were concerned about democracy in the Philippines should be even more concerned about democracy in Nicaragua, closer to the United States.

headline: THE OBSTACLES TO TRADE GAIN
abstract: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that the gap between what the United States buys and sells abroad - a record $148.5 billion last year - should narrow once a lower-valued dollar has had time to work into cheaper exports and costlier imports.   The decline, which began in February 1985, has already cut the dollar 40 to 50 percent against the pound, the German mark, the Swiss franc and the Japanese yen. Yet, Reagan Administration officials argue that even more time is needed for the market effects to take hold - especially since the bulk of the drop occurred only since last September's meeting of finance ministers in New York that set a coordinated intervention policy.   ''I think that the month-to-month trade deficit will be headed down by the end of 1986, partially as a result of the dollar's decline, and we definitely should see improvement in 1987,'' Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige told a Congressional hearing yesterday.

headline: New York State And City Bonds
abstract: New York State, its major authorities and New York City expect to sell about $1.63 billion of bonds in the first three months of the year. Interest on these bonds, as well as those issued by other local governments in New York State and Puerto Rico are exempt from state, city and Federal income tax for New York State residents.

headline: FROM A SYMBOL TO A LEADER: THE RISE OF CORAZON AQUINO
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino began to exercise presidential power even before Ferdinand E. Marcos left the country today, telling some of the country's most powerful men what they would be doing in her Cabinet, and making a key decision about the nation's top financial institution.   She did so in the same quiet-spoken manner in which, as a self-described housewife, she had hovered in the background during the political career of her husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Her manner today, however, obscured a personal transformation that has been noted both by political analysts and by members of her own family, who say they have watched her grow in strength and confidence.   In the four months since she decided to run for office, Mrs. Aquino, a genuinely reluctant candidate, has moved from being a symbol around which the nation could unite to being a leader.   ''It's astonishing,'' says a member of her husband's family. ''She was just a housewife. Her strength has astonished all of us. The transformation is amazing. It has even affected her children, who have grown as well.''

headline: QADDAFI TO HELP ARAB 'TERRORISTS'
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said tonight that Libya would train, arm and protect Arab guerrillas and other Arab volunteers for ''suicide and terrorist missions,'' and make his country a ''base for the liberation for Palestine.''   The Libyan leader made the declaration in a two-hour speech to 3,000 young people at the People's Congress Building in downtown Tripoli.   The speech was an abrupt about-face in tone and substance from the Libyan leader's remarks in recent days. They had been, for the most part, somewhat conciliatory toward the United States.

headline: El Salvador Promotes Officers Tied to Killings
abstract: Salvadoran military officials said today that two army officers, linked by Washington to right-wing death squads and later sent into exile under United States pressure, have received promotions.   The officials said that Maj. Ricardo Pozo had been promoted to Lieutenant Colonel and Lieut. Col. Mario Denis Moran had been made a full colonel.

headline: COSTA RICA GETS A PERSISTENT LEADER
abstract: The governing party candidate, Oscar Arias Sanchez, emerged today as the official winner of this country's presidential election.   Mr. Arias has said he considers himself the leader of a new, younger generation and calls John F. Kennedy a role model. The image seems to fit the 44-year-old President-elect, the youngest in his country's history.   Coming from behind to win the election Sunday does not seem to have come as much of a surprise to Mr. Arias. Close relatives said he had always been convinced that he would one day gain Costa Rica's highest office, and that he had gone after it with the stubborn persistence that is an essential part of his political character.

headline: JOHN PAUL FEEDS THE DYING IN CALCUTTA
abstract: Today, even Pope John Paul II was at a loss for words.   As tens of thousands of mainly Hindu, mainly destitute Calcuttans cheered outside, John Paul visited the home for the dying established by Mother Teresa in the heart of this city's slums.   Four people died at the hospice today, including a young boy, and the bodies were still in the home's morgue when the Pope arrived. Of the 86 still alive, many were near death.

headline: PRESIDENT TURNS TO THE SENATE IN FIGHT FOR BILL
abstract: White House officials said today that, with the House rejection of President Reagan's $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, they were placing their hopes on the Senate.   At the same time, they conceded that some serious tactical mistakes had been made in the battle in the House.   Meanwhile, some House Democrats said they had been able to defeat Mr. Reagan's aid proposal because the President had failed to articulate his policy clearly or show a firm enough commitment to seeking a diplomatic settlement. Resentment of Tactics    In addition, they said, the tactics of some Administration officials who had questioned the loyalty and patriotism of Mr. Reagan's opponents backfired, generating resentment and hardening opposition to the aid package.   Mr. Reagan, in a statement designed to project the Administration as looking ahead immediately after the House vote, vowed to continue efforts to obtain the money. The President said the Administration would now shift its efforts to the Senate, where an intense selling campaign is to begin Friday.

headline: TRIBECA BUILDING BEGUN WITH HELP FROM THE CITY
abstract: With the encouragement of liberalized zoning and tax benefits, a full block in Manhattan's TriBeCa section is being developed with a 14-story high-tech office building that will offer big space users floors of up to 46,000 square feet.   The project, on the block bounded by Greenwich and Murray Streets, West Broadway and Park Place, is a prime example of how city policy can guide development.   Three years ago, the city's Planning Department decided that the site in TriBeCa, which stands for triangle below Canal Street, was especially well suited for the development of a full-block office building. The site, just north of the World Trade Center, held a truck garage.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Apollo Computer Inc., Chelmsford, Mass., said it had signed a letter of intent with Texas Instruments Inc. to enter into a cooperative development program using Texas Instruments' artificial intelligence technology and Apollo's technical work stations.    * Boeing Co. said that Japan Air Lines would take delivery this year of nine planes, including two 747SR-300 jumbo jets that carry a record 591 passengers.

headline: PATENTS; Inspecting Nuclear Fuel Rods
abstract: AFULLY automated nuclear fuel rod inspection system was patented this week for the General Electric Company in San Jose, Calif. The scanning device measures the exact uranium and gadolinium content of every pellet in each fuel rod.

headline: Chad Seeks French Aid Against Libyan Attack
abstract: Chad said today that it had asked France and other friendly countries for military assistance to help it repel a four-day Libyan attack on a string of Government positions.   Foreign Minister Gouara Lassou told a rally in the capital that the Government had approached its traditional allies some time ago, in anticipation of the offensive.

headline: 30 TO 40 REPORTED KILLED IN TRAIN WRECK IN CANADA
abstract: A Canadian passenger train collided with a 114-car freight train today in western Alberta, and a railroad spokesman said 30 to 40 people died in the heap of twisted, burning rail cars.   An ambulance company reported 80 people injured; estimates of the total number of passengers ranged from 101 to 120. Of a total of 24 crew members on both trains, 7 were reported missing, A spokesman for Canadian National Railways, the country's principal freight rail carrier, said the accident occurred at 8:40 A.M. mountain standard time, 10 miles east of Hinton, a pulp-mill town on the main Canadian National line. The freight train was westbound, he said, and the nine-car passenger train was heading east.

headline: SMITH INTERNATIONAL IN CHAPTER 11 FILING
abstract: Smith International Inc., a leading maker of oil drilling tools, equipment and services, filed for protection from creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.   Jerry W. Neely, chairman and chief executive, blamed the filing on a $207 million award granted to the Hughes Tool Company in a patent infringement case against Smith. That award, ordered by Federal District Judge Harry Hupp on Feb. 14, is among the largest ever granted in a domestic patent infringement case.

headline: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 24.6 million shares, or 8.4 percent, in the month ended March 14, to a record 318.6 million shares. The previous high of 301.9 million shares was set Dec. 13, 1985.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was down 536,239 shares, to 24.8 million shares.   The following Big Board companies show large changes:

headline: Currency-Shift Reports Surge
abstract: The number of large currency transactions reported to the Government has quadrupled following the Bank of Boston's conviction in a money-laundering scheme, the Internal Revenue Service said today. For more than 10 years, the   Government has required banks and other financial institutions to report deposits, withdrawals or transfers of more than $10,000.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Abitibi-Price Inc. Toronto, the world's largest newsprint producer, said it would continue its inventory reduction measures by running its Canadian mills on short time in April.    * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said its American Telephone and Telegraph Information Systems unit had entered into an agreement to market Innovative Software Inc.'s Smart Software system.

headline: AQUINO SETS FORTH: AN AGENDA FOR ACTION IN THE FIRST 100 DAYS
abstract: When Corazon C. Aquino announced her candidacy for president three months ago, she made it clear she was campaigning on one issue: the ouster of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   In the course of the campaign, however, Mrs. Aquino evolved broad policies that she must now begin to put into effect.   The Cabinet she named Wednesday is drawn from the same managerial class as that of Mr. Marcos, and indeed includes some of his own former Cabinet ministers. But Mrs. Aquino has said there will be a major difference between her administration and that of Mr. Marcos. She says her Government will be free of the political patronage and corruption that bogged down the nation in recent years.

headline: WHITE, UP BY $10.25, HITS HIGH
abstract: The stock of White Consolidated Industries soared yesterday above the price that Electrolux A. B. of Sweden offered for the Cleveland-based appliance maker.   The shares jumped $10.25, to $48.75, its all-time high and well above Electrolux's $45-a-share offer, announced Sunday.

headline: PAPER IN MANILA PALACE LISTS $60,000 GIFT FOR MRS. REAGAN
abstract: A document found in the presidential palace lists a $60,000 emerald necklace that Imelda Marcos, wife of Ferdinand E. Marcos, supposedly gave to Nancy Reagan.  [ In Washington, Elaine Crispin, the press spokesman for Mrs. Reagan, said no such gift had been received. She said she had checked with Mrs. Reagan and with the White House gift unit, and had found no record of such a necklace. ]  The Philippine palace document, now in the possession of a commission seeking to recover the Marcoses' wealth, does not specify when the gift was made. An accompanying handwritten note to Mrs. Marcos's secretary is dated Aug. 2, 1985.

headline: A RECOVERY FOR EQUITY FUNDS
abstract: Amid booming sales and a roaring bull market, equity mutual funds last year scored their best performance since 1980 and one of their best years ever.   But even so, their average gain of 27.17 percent failed to match the 31.79 percent advance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, with dividends and interest reinvested.   For the year, equity funds specializing in foreign stocks, health care and the rebounding over-the-counter market did particularly well - replacing the more conservative, yield-oriented portfolios of 1984 as the biggest winners. Stunning Improvement   The overall performance marked a stunning improvement over 1984, when the average equity fund barely showed a positive return - 2.09 percent - against 6.29 percent for the 500-stock index. In 1980, when oil stocks were favorites of portfolio managers, equity funds scored an average advance of 33.48 percent, slightly better than the S.&P. index.

headline: TREASURY BOND YIELDS PLUNGE
abstract: Yields on Treasury bonds plunged to their lowest levels since August 1979 yesterday as investors rushed to lock up current long-term yields before they sink any further.   One result was that the yield on the bellwether long bond, the 9.25 percent issue of 2016, fell as low as 8.91 percent, its lowest level since Aug. 22, 1979, before closing at 8.93 percent on a late ripple of selling.   Meanwhile, discount rates on Treasury bills also fell. Dealers attributed this to yesterday's action by the Federal Reserve draining reserves from the banking system by effecting four-day matched sales. These reverse repurchase agreements served to bolster prices of bills and other short-term debt instruments, dealers noted.

headline: Economic Scene; Automation's Labor Impact
abstract: THE new automation technology, using computers, robots and artificial intelligence, has reawakened fears that machines will replace human beings and create mass unemployment. Do those fears make any more sense today than they did at the dawn of the Industrial Revolution when the Luddites, textile workers, smashed the machinery they thought would put them out of work?   Optimistic economists say no. They point to the past two centuries of rising employment and income, and the lack of mass unemployment, except for brief spells during recessions and depressions.

headline: Rumanian Missing in Greece
abstract: A Rumanian diplomat disappeared in Greece on Friday after his arrival as part of a four-member trade delegation, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman, Antonis Kourtis, declined to comment on whether the diplomat, identified in press reports as Jorge Yabasso, had sought political asylum in Greece or elsewhere.

headline: Dow Up 7 as Volume Shrinks
abstract: A rally in the final hour helped stock prices rise moderately yesterday, ending a three-day slide brought on by fears that interest rates have stopped falling.   Thom Brown, a market analyst with Butcher & Singer in Philadelphia, believes that without any new developments on rates the market will lack direction for the next few weeks. The Dow Jones industrial average, he predicts, will stay in the 1,490-to-1,540 range.

headline: THE RISKS OF A ONE-COMPANY SHOW
abstract: AT various times during the year, in 11 cities across the country, more than 60,000 corporate athletes huff and puff their way through a 3.5-mile road race sponsored by Manufacturers Hanover Trust. And in concert halls in 20 cities, audiences clap along to Barbara Mandrell, Alabama, and other performers in Philip Morris's Marlboro Country Music Festival.   To the participants and spectators, the race and the concert are of the same ilk as, say, the New York Marathon or the Newport Jazz Festival. But to the trained corporate eye, they are a very different breed of special event - one put on by one company, rather than an ongoing event that several companies pitch in to support.

headline: Advertising; Campaign On Health Set to Start
abstract: ''US HEALTHCARE. It's coming to Greater New York and it's going to have a big effect on your health,'' is the ending of four 10-second TV spots that will begin to air here today signaling the entry of United States Health Care Systems Inc. into the nation's wealthiest market.   It is the first of a $5 million bucket of advertising that the Blue Bell, Pa., company is going to spend here overwhelming the advertising of Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

headline: JEWISH GROUPS AND RIGHTS ACTIVISTS EXPRESS DELIGHT OVER RELEASE
