abstract: After eight years of lobbying, demonstrations, letter writing and hunger fasts, Jewish groups and rights activists yesterday hailed the release of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, but vowed to continue efforts on behalf of others who want to leave the Soviet Union.   ''It is a wonderful day, a momentous day - not an end, but a beginning,'' said Alan Pesky, chairman of the Coalition to Free Soviet Jews, an umbrella group. ''His release gives our movement a new sense of resolve, and we will continue to keep this issue at the forefront.''   Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, president of the New York Board of Rabbis, said:   ''I feel grateful that after all the times we prayed for his release, today we can give thanks for his release.''

headline: GAF STOCK SLUMPS ON CARBIDE DOUBTS
abstract: Shares of the GAF Corporation plunged $4, to $51.25, in heavy trading yesterday as Wall Street professionals grew increasingly uncertain that the roofing and chemicals producer would pursue its hostile $5 billion takeover battle for the Union Carbide Corporation.   Union Carbide stock, meanwhile, stood at $73.75, down only 25 cents, also in heavy trading, partly because of the company's special steps to support the market even if Samuel J. Heyman, chairman of GAF, drops out of the fight.   Several traders said that, if Mr. Heyman was planning to do something, he would have to do it by tomorrow morning, when advance trading will begin in bonds that Carbide is expected to issue in a few weeks.   The bonds are tailored to limit sales of company operations if anyone takes over the company. GAF has devised a plan to defuse the bond provisions, but its plan would be much harder to carry out once professionals began trading in the bonds because they would become widely disseminated. Even though GAF has offered to buy the bonds as a key part of its takeover offer, traders say that the price it is offering is not enough and that it will have to offer more.

headline: New Manville Plan
abstract: The Manville Corporation has told a Federal bankruptcy judge in New York it will submit a new, $2.5 billion reorganization plan and a financial statement by Feb. 14. The plan, which first was outlined by the company in December, must be voted on by each of the company's thousands of creditors. It would set aside about $2.5 billion for asbestos-disease victims and $125 million for property owners with asbestos on their premises.

headline: RUMSFELD WILL SUCCEED FORD AT EISENHOWER FELLOWSHIPS
abstract: Donald H. Rumsfeld will succeed former President Gerald R. Ford as chairman of the Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships, according to an announcement by Mr. Ford. The change will take place on May 28.

headline: Fortune Financial Action Considered
abstract: American Equities Group, a limited partnership that holds approximately 10 percent of Fortune Financial Group, said it might seek to remove the management of the savings and loan association in Jacksonville, Fla. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Equities is considering removing the board or taking other action because it is upset that it ''has not been fully informed of certain significant information concerning the management and operations.''   Kenneth M. Kirschner, a member of the partnership who has a seat on Fortune Financial's board of directors, charged that the board had never been told about an investigation by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board into a dramatic increase of the thrift institution's liabilities.

headline: Coleco Results
abstract: Coleco Industries expects its 1985 sales to be about level with 1984's $775 million, while earnings are expected to achieve ''record levels,'' the company's chairman, Arnold C. Greenberg, said in a letter to shareholders. He said the company -which lost $79.8 million in 1984, mostly because of its discontinued Adam computer - ended 1985 with no short-term bank debt and $110 million in cash and equivalents. Coleco, noted for its successful Cabbage Patch Doll line, also said it would begin shipping its Rambo doll this spring.

headline: SALVADOR PRELATE ACCUSES AIR FORCE
abstract: In one of his strongest statements to date, the Archbishop of El Salvador today condemned the indiscriminate bombing of civilians by the Government air force and the destruction of homes and crops in army sweeps of rebel-held areas.   The Archbishop's charges, made in a prepared statement read this morning in his name at the national cathedral, come after a highly unusual one-week trip by the Archbishop to rebel-held territory in northern Chalatenango department.   The Archbishop, Arturo Rivera y Damas, also charged that two bombs had been dropped within four miles of him on the first day of his visit. The charge by the nation's highest Roman Catholic prelate directly contradicts a statement by the Minister of Defense, Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova, that no bombs were dropped in the area.

headline: WARNER'S SCENARIOS FOR HITS
abstract: Warner Brothers did not release any of the top five films last year, but no one at the studio panicked. The studio had seven of the next 15 movies, including ''Goonies'' and ''Police Academy.''   Because of that showing, Warner Brothers took in more domestic revenue than any other studio. A year earlier it nailed down second place, although it had only one of the top five films, ''Gremlins.''   ''Warner may not make lots of home runs, but they do hit a lot of triples,'' said Art D. Murphy, the film expert at Variety, the entertainment industry trade publication. As a result, Warner, founded by the four Warner brothers 68 years ago, is generally considered by industry experts to be the most stable and best-run movie studio in Hollywood.

headline: SEARS AND RUNDLE
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that it ''has no interest in supporting'' the proposed sale of its controlling interest in the Universal-Rundle Corporation.

headline: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS ADDS
abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy two banks in Chicago's suburbs. Continental, the holding company for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, also said its board had declared dividends on its preferred stock.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aloha Inc., Honolulu, said its board had decided not to consider CNS Partners $27.50-a-share acquisition offer because majority shareholders oppose the bid.    * A.O. Electronics Inc., Tucker, Ga., said it had purchased Lockheed Corp.'s GTX-100 line of secure modems, which prevent unauthorized telephone access to computers.

headline: Exporting Drugs
abstract: To the Editor:   Our experience with DDT and various other pesticides should speak loudly for a ban on the export of un-tested drugs to Third World countries (''Exporting Unapproved Drugs,'' Forum, Mar. 9). When DDT and other pesticides are banned in our country but exported to third world countries, we get them back on the fruits and vegtables that we import. I do not even touch the ethical question of whether we should export drugs that we have positively found to be unsafe. URSULA ZADIK   Bronx, Mar. 11

headline: 2 KILLED IN BLAST IN A PARIS ARCADE
abstract: Two people were killed and 28 wounded, 10 seriously, when a bomb exploded in a crowded shopping arcade at rush hour on the Champs-Elysees.   The explosion at the Point Show arcade occurred just as Jacques Chirac began addressing the nation as Prime Minister. No one took responsibility for the explosion and there was no indication that it was linked to the announcement of a new, conservative Government, although some officials saw it as a warning to the Government.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1986
abstract: Markets    Wild trading on Wall Street sent the Dow sharply lower but left the broad market unscathed. The Dow Jones industrial average, after closing above 1,800 for the first time on Thursday, suffered its fourth-worst decline ever, falling 35.68 points, to 1,768.56. Trading was the fourth-heaviest in the New York Stock Exchange's history. The slump came late in the day during a ''triple witching hour'' when contracts for three types of trading instruments - stock index options, stock index futures and individual stock options - all expired simultaneously and complex trading maneuvers were undertaken.  [ Page 1. ]  The trading confused even seasoned pros and indicated a major shift in how stocks are traded.  [ 35. ]    The dollar continued to fall, with the British pound climbing to two-and-a-half-year highs, trading close to $1.52. Gold rose by $4.65 an ounce, to $356.25, in New York.  [ 43. ]

headline: L.L. Bean's Business Moved to Hill, Holliday
abstract: L.L. Bean of Freeport, Me., whose name is synonymous with outdoor gear and furnishings, has switched its account from Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, which has handled it for a decade, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston.   Wunderman, a Young & Rubicam subsidiary that specializes in direct marketing, is being replaced, said Christopher McCormick, manager/ advertising and direct marketing for Bean, because, ''we need the reinforcement that a full-service agency offers.''   Print will continue to be the primary medium but some of the $4 million to $6 million budget will go to other media to support the print message.

headline: Chilean Editor Is Jailed
abstract: A military court today jailed Fernando Paulsen, news editor of an opposition publication and a freelance correspondent for Time magazine and The Wall Street Journal, pending a trial on charges of slandering the national police.

headline: GATX ACCEPTS BID MADE BY LEUCADIA
abstract: The GATX Corporation has accepted a $40-a-share cash offer from the Leucadia National Corporation to buy the 91.1 percent stake it does not already own in GATX for a total of $495.8 million.   GATX, one of the nation's largest rail car and aircraft leasing companies, said today that the offer was conditioned upon final negotiation and execution of a definitive agreement, approval by GATX's shareholders and Leucadia's ability to provide adequate financing.   The decision made by GATX's board late Saturday afternoon ends a monthlong bidding war started last month by Leucadia, an insurance and consumer finance company.

headline: FORMER AD DIRECTOR WILL HEAD INTERMARCO
abstract: Frederick K. Rhines, who until earlier this month was ad director of New York magazine, is been named president of Intermarco, the United States subsidiary in New York of France's Publicis Group.

headline: Chairman Sets Goals For Uniroyal-Goodrich
abstract: During the 12 years that Patrick C. Ross directed the B. F. Goodrich Company's mainstay, its tire division, Uniroyal Inc. was a persistent competitor.   As of Tuesday, Mr. Ross, now president of Goodrich, had one less rival. Goodrich, the nation's third-largest tire maker, and Uniroyal, the nation's fifth largest, announced plans to combine their tire operations to form the second-largest company in the industry, behind the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. The tire operations of the combined companies generated annual sales last year of $2 billion, and controlled 18 percent of the overall market.

headline: West German Seized in East
abstract: The East German Government's press agency today reported the arrest of a West German man on suspicion of spying. The man was identified only as Rolf B.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO AID CONTRAS VIA SALVADOR
abstract: United States assistance to Nicaraguan guerrillas has recently been channeled through El Salvador, according to American and Nicaraguan exile officials, apparently in an effort to make up for a recent cutoff of supplies by Honduras.   At least some of the aid has been flown from the military airport at Ilopango air base, just outside this capital, one source said. It was not clear whether approval for the flights has come only from the Salvadoran Air Force or also from the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.   Officially, both Government and military officials continue to deny assisting the Nicaraguan anti-Government guerrillas, who are known locally as contras.

headline: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; Tax Bill Puts Senate On the Spot
abstract: UNDER the Constitution, tax legislation must originate in the House of Representatives, and few senators paid much attention last year while the House was writing a bill that would overhaul the Federal income tax system.   ''Most senators never expected this to pass the House,'' said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey. But pass the House it did, in the last week of the Congressional session, the result of an extraordinary alliance between President Reagan and the House Democratic leadership.   Now this highly controversial measure, one that would affect almost every taxpayer in America, individuals and companies alike, is in the lap of the Senate, and the senators have begun to squirm. Hardly any of them believes that the proposals advanced by President Reagan last spring and the bill approved by the House have much merit. But the prevailing view is that the politics of the day virtually assure that the Senate will approve a measure along those lines and that the bill will become law before the end of the year.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Del Monte Fresh Fruit Co., Miami, a division of Nabisco Brands Inc., has named John P. Polychron president and chief executive officer.

headline: BEATRICE DEBT IS DOWNGRADED
abstract: The debt rating on about $1.5 billion of outstanding long-term debt securities of the Beatrice Companies and its subsidiaries was downgraded yesterday by Moody's and S.&P.   The rating agencies cited the increased financial risk associated with the proposed $6 billion acquisition of Beatrice by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company through BCI Holdings, which was formed to acquire Beatrice and is issuing $3.7 billion of buyout debt.   Among the outstanding securities affected are Beatrice's senior debt rating, which was lowered to Ba-3 from A-3 by Moody's and to BB- from A by S.&.P. The subordinated debt was cut to B-2 from Baa-1 by Moody's and to B from A- by S.&P.   In addition, Moody's commercial paper rating for Beatrice and its Esmark, Norton Simon and Avis Leasing units was withdrawn at Beatrice's request, while the S.&P. rating was cut to Not Prime from Prime-2.

headline: GORBACHEV-REAGAN ADDRESS TO CONGRESS IS SOUGHT
abstract: The Senate Democratic leader, Robert F. Byrd, Jr., said today that President Reagan had tentatively agreed to appear jointly before Congress with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.But White House officials said no decision had been made.   Senator Byrd presented the idea in a telephone call and a letter to Mr. Reagan today. According to the Senator, the President said ''it would be fine.''

headline: GROWING PAINS FOR OSHKOSH
abstract: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc., the manufacturer famous for its children's overalls, has a problem that most companies wish they had: It has grown too big for its britches.   Oshkosh, a 91-year-old company long known for its drab overalls and other work clothes, experienced a phenomenal growth spurt in recent years after it discovered that parents adore putting their sons and daughters in pint-size overalls. As a result, Oshkosh's sales more than tripled to $162 million in 1985, from $47 million four years before.   ''We had a few years of unbelievable growth,'' said Charles F. Hyde Jr., the company's polished, white-haired president and chief executive officer. ''All of that growth was a result of children's clothes.''

headline: 12 QUIT CHASE LONDON UNIT
abstract: Chase Manhattan Ltd., the London investment banking unit of the Chase Manhattan Bank, confirmed yesterday that 12 Eurobond salesmen and traders had left and joined Kleinwort, Benson Ltd., a competitor in London.   The departures included Chase's head of international capital markets, Michael Bowen, and the head of Eurobond trading, John Salmon.

headline: A FRENCH PUBLISHER DEFIES SOCIALISTS' EFFORT TO RESTRICT HIM
abstract: A conservative publisher has challenged the country's Socialist Government by buying a newspaper in violation of a law curbing the size of his press holdings.   An announcement over the weekend that Robert Hersant had purchased the principal Lyons newspaper, Le Progres, has caused a sensation in French political circles, where it was seen as a calculated attempt to embarrass President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists during the campaign for the March 17 elections.   In what was seen as a deliberate display of contempt for the Socialists' efforts to limit his holdings, Mr. Hersant did not consult the Commission for the Openness and Pluralism of the Press, a body set up by the Government to review compliance with the 1984 law restricting press ownership.   Last year, when Mr. Hersant bought a Reims paper called L'Union, he sought to get around the new law by making the purchase through his son Philippe. But this time he took over Le Progres in his own name.

headline: OIL OFFICIALS ARE SAID TO LEAVE LIBYA
abstract: About a dozen top managers of American oil companies have quietly left Libya in the last few days, according to business executives and diplomats here.   The same sources, speaking on condition they not be identified, said Tuesday that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation had failed to make a $30 million tax payment that was due to the Libyan Government on Tuesday.   The reports suggested that Occidental and perhaps the other four major American oil producers here are planning to suspend operations when the President's executive order banning commerce with Libya takes effect Saturday, rather than pursue the apparently legal alternative of transferring operations to a foreign subsidiary.

headline: Eastern Pilots
abstract: Executives of the pilots association at Eastern Airlines have voted unanimously to set a Feb. 26 strike date and to send ballots on the measure to more than 4,000 members, a spokesman said. By law, Eastern's pilots may strike after midnight on Feb. 25, which is the expiration of a ''cooling off'' period set Jan. 27 when the National Mediation Board declared an impasse in talks between pilots and the heavily indebted Miami-based carrier. The decision to strike came Monday by the Air Line Pilots Association's 27-member master executive council, which had been meeting in Atlanta.

headline: JAPAN'S PUSH IN UPSCALE AUTOS
abstract: The new luxury, high-performance model that the American Honda Motor Company will introduce later this month is likely to raise the eyebrows of current Honda owners used to more Spartan cars. It comes with a high-tech 151-horsepower V-6 engine, a racing style suspension, plush interior and a sticker price close to $20,000. It is not even called a Honda.   The company's new Acura line -which centers on the top-of-the-line V-6 Legend but will also include the smaller four-cylinder Integra - is the strongest indication yet that the Japanese auto makers are determined to push into the highly profitable and growing American market for luxury performance cars. With the Acura, a new 200-horsepower Toyota Supra, Mazda's RX-7 Turbo and Nissan's 300 ZX, the Japanese are going after the market now dominated by such European manufacturers as Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Audi, Porsche and Saab. The few American entries in this category include the Chevrolet Corvette and Lincoln Mark 7 LSC, although others are under development.   ''The Legend is a legitimate competitor for BMW,'' said Ann C. Knight, an auto industry analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''The question is whether they can break through the cult-like loyalty to the German products. They probably can't do it on price. The more Mercedes-Benz charges, the more people seem to like it.''

headline: 8,000 SALVADORANS PROTEST AUSTERITY PLAN
abstract: About 8,000 people marched through San Salvador today to protest expected Government austerity measures.

headline: FIXED MORTGAGE RATES FALL TO AVERAGE 11.34%
abstract: Interest rates on fixed-rate mortgages dropped slightly between early January and early February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.   For fixed-rate mortgages with a 25 percent down payment, the average effective rate declined to 11.34 from 11.45 percent, a slower rate of decline than a month earlier.   Economists say the drop in mortgage rates is a result of rallies in bond markets, decreasing oil prices and a less inflationary environment. In some parts of the country, fixed-rate mortgages are now available at less than 10 percent. As recently as a year ago, interest levels on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages were as high as 13 percent.

headline: Tire Import Drop Cited
abstract: Tire imports dropped in January, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported today, and the company said a sluggish economy and not a stronger dollar brought about the decline.

headline: Honda Steel Pact
abstract: Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. said Armco Inc. and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation would join the Inland Steel Company of Chicago in supplying steel for Honda's auto assembly plant here. The three steel companies will supply about 78,000 tons annually of coiled steel for the major body parts of the four-door and three-door Accord models now being made at the plant as well as the being made at the plant as well as the four-door Civic that begins production in July. About

headline: China Cracks Down On Film Makers
abstract: Amid signs of an ideological crackdown on Chinese film makers, a Politburo member has warned that movies must benefit Communism or face a stern ''red light,'' the official press reported today.

headline: UGANDA REBELS BATTLE A RIVAL GROUP
abstract: Ugandan rebels who overthrew the Government two days ago were reported today to have clashed with another rebel faction.   Troops of the National Resistance Army, which seized control on Sunday, battled members of the Ugandan Freedom Movement on a road between Kampala and Jinja, according to Salim Saleh, a field commander of the Resistance Army.

headline: OIL PRICES CONTINUE TO SLIDE
abstract: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products slumped again on the world oil market yesterday, ending a distressing week as the game of brinkmanship between the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-OPEC producers continued.   The war of words, in which the Middle East oil-producing nations seek to force those outside OPEC, particularly Britain, to reduce their output, grew slightly hotter. The Kuwait News Agency reported that ''senior Persian Gulf sources'' said OPEC would force oil prices down to $13 a barrel if necessary to regain market share.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 28, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The trade deficit shrank by $4 billion in February, to $12.5 billion. Analysts, while cautioning against reading too much into one month's figures, said the improvement may mean that the gaping deficits that have dogged the economy have peaked. The decline in the dollar and the plunge in oil prices were helpful, but the drop also reflected weakness in the overall economy.  [ Page D1. ]    The F.D.I.C. gave details of its plan to permit banks that lend to farmers and to oil and gas producers to live with far less capital than now required. The agency said agriculture and energy lending had placed ''severe financial stress'' on banks.  [ D3. ]

headline: Technology; 'Intelligent' Auto Controls
abstract: TUNING a car radio, particularly today's button-bedecked models, can be an uncomfortable, even dangerous, undertaking on the highway. Drivers have to take their eyes off the road and look toward the middle of the dashboard to change stations or balance the sound.   Pontiac has come up with an innovative answer to the problem. All the buttons to control the radio on its sporty 6000 STE model are inside the hub of the steering wheel. A driver can adjust the radio without having to look away from the road - or even move a hand far from the wheel.

headline: Profits Jump At Hathaway
abstract: At a time when most investors in the stock market are doing very well for themselves, Warren E. Buffett has been making their gains seem paltry indeed.   Last Thursday, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment holding company headed by Mr. Buffett, the Omaha financier, reported that net earnings in the fourth quarter of last year leaped to $268.6 million, from $46.6 million, in the year-earlier quarter.

headline: EX-IM BANK OFFERS FIRST U.S. LOAN
abstract: The Export-Import Bank, a Government agency that provides credit for foreign buyers of American goods, today for the first time offered a loan to a buyer in the United States to meet what it said was heavily subsidized export financing from a foreign government.   The financing will help a big electrical manufacturing company, the Allis-Chalmers Corporation of Milwaukee, in its effort to sell four hydraulic-turbine electric generators for use in western Pennsylvania. A competing offer has been made by a Brazilian company.   The authority to offer credit to aid domestic purchasers was granted by Congress in 1978, but each use requires Treasury authorization.

headline: TREASURY RETURNS AS TOP BORROWER
abstract: The Treasury will reassert itself as the largest borrower in the credit markets this week with a regular monthly auction of two-year notes and an announcement of note and bond auctions next week totaling an estimated $19 billion.   In the short-term market, the Treasury will auction three- and six-month bills today totaling $13.6 billion. Late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at 6.55 percent, while the six-month issue was at 6.57 percent.   Assuming the Treasury adheres to its regular financing schedule, government securities dealers expect an announcement Wednesday for a three-part financing the following week. Auctions of an estimated $7 billion of four-year notes March 25, $6.5 billion in seven-year notes March 26 and $5.5 billion in 20-year bonds March 27 would raise about $15.25 billion of new cash to finance the Federal deficit.

headline: NICARAGUA BUSINESSMEN EXPRESS FEAR OF ATTACKS BY THE SANDINISTAS
abstract: A group of leading Nicaraguan businessmen issued a strong denunciation of the Government today, saying they feared for their lives and liberty.   In a statement, the businessmen said President Daniel Ortega Saavedra appeared to be threatening them when, during a nationally broadcast speech Feb. 21, he singled out the Superior Council of Private Enterprise as among those responsible for the country's problems.   The council is Nicaragua's principal private-sector federation, and has been a leading critic of the Sandinista Government.

headline: BL Bidders Announced
abstract: The British Government today announced a list of bidders, including General Motors, for a large chunk of BL P.L.C., the nation's biggest auto maker.   General Motors is the leading contender for a takeover of BL's commercial division, the truck and van manufacturing sector that also makes the Land-Rover jeep and Range Rover station wagon. G.M. was the only bidder offering to buy the money-losing truck division, as well as the profitable jeep and van sector.

headline: ASHLAND OIL MOVE
abstract: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had retained the First Boston Corporation in what Wall Street analysts view as the start of a defensive campaign to fend off a surprise $1.8 billion takeover bid from the Belzberg family of Canada. Earlier this week the Belzbergs disclosed that they controlled 9.2 percent of Ashland's stock and had offered to pay $60 for each of the remaining shares.

headline: Palau to Vote on U.S. Ties
abstract: The Trusteeship Council agreed today to send four observers to the Pacific island republic of Palau this month to monitor a plebiscite in which voters will consider a ''compact of free association'' with the United States. The accord would leave Palau independent, but give the United States responsibility for defense. The request for observers came from the United States Mission here.

headline: BANKERS TRUST PLANS A APPEAL
abstract: The Bankers Trust Company said yesterday that it would continue operating in the commercial-paper market while it tries to stay a court order forcing it to leave the business by March 1.   A Bankers Trust spokesman, Thomas Parisi, said the bank was working on the assumption that it would prevail in the courts, but was prepared to obey the court order and cease operations if the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denies its request for a stay.   Judge Joyce Hens Green of the Federal District Court in Washington ruled early this month that Bankers Trust's commercial paper activities violated the Glass-Steagall Act, which erects a wall between commercial banking and investment banking. On Tuesday, she ordered Bankers Trust to close its commercial paper operation March 1. Bankers Trust is seeking a stay of that order while it appeals Judge Green's ruling to the Court of Appeals.

headline: A MACHISMO THAT DRIVES WOMEN OUT
abstract: AMERICAN corporations are suffering a female ''brain drain'' that they can ill afford.   There are growing indications that the same women who entered management in large numbers in the 1970's are beginning a mass exodus in the 1980's. Increasingly, some of the best and the brightest women in the corporate world are resigning in favor of self-employment and spending more time at home.   Some analysts insist this ''corporate burnout'' is simply survival of the fittest. Yet the reason most often cited by the women themselves is an ''inhospitable corporate climate.''

headline: Privatization
abstract: To the Editor:   In two Jan. 19 articles, ''Why it Pays to Privatize Public Services,'' and ''A Bias Toward Bad Government?'' the Gospel according to the Heritage Foundation is fully revealed in the policies being floated by Budget Director James C. Miller 3d.   This view asserts that bureaucrats are far less able to make an asset work for them than private managers, and that resources are used more productively in the private sector.

headline: FREUHAUF'S INVESTOR IDENTIFIED
abstract: Asher Edelman, the New York investor, approached the Fruehauf Corporation earlier this month proposing a leveraged buyout but was turned down by the Detroit manufacturer of truck trailers and other automotive equipment.   The company, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, did not mention Mr. Edelman by name, but in a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Edelman confirmed that he was the one who had approached the company.   Mr. Edelman took over the Datapoint Corporation last year and Wall Street suspected that he was accumulating Fruehauf stock and was planning a move against the company.

headline: ANTITRUST LAWS
abstract: To the Editor:   Using I.B.M. as an example of the benefits of allowing greater merger activity is particularly interesting in that I.B.M.'s outstanding record of growth does not stem from mergers. I.B.M. has invested in the development, production, and marketing of a superior but narrowly defined range of products.   Other major industrial companies which have engaged in merger activity - U.S. Steel and General Motors, for example - have found their flagship products losing market share to foreign competitors.

headline: TED BATES ACQUIRING KOBS UNIT
abstract: LARGELY because of its clients' needs, Ted Bates Worldwide, the world's third-largest advertising agency, has joined the numerous other top agencies that have direct marketing subsidiaries. It is acquiring Kobs & Brady of Chicago and New York, effective April 1, and plans to take it international.   According to James F. Kobs, the 47-year-old founder who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the autonomous unit, his shop -with $70 million in billings - is the largest agency of its kind ever acquired. Hard to believe? Well, he supplied a list of nine other major acquisitions in direct marketing to prove his point, and the previous high was $42 million.

headline: Walesa Refuses To Repudiate Remarks
abstract: The Solidarity founder Lech Walesa said in an interview published today that he stood by every word of the remarks for which he will stand trial on charges of slandering the state.   Mr. Walesa, who supported a boycott of the Polish elections in 1985, is scheduled to face trial next month for suggesting that authorities inflated the turnout figures.

headline: FUROR ON CONVENT NEAR AUSCHWITZ
abstract: The establishment of a Roman Catholic convent near the site of the Auschwitz death camp has caused dismay among some Jewish groups in the United States and Western Europe who call it an affront to the memory of the Jews who were killed there by the Nazis.   A group of Carmelite nuns has been living in an unused theater just outside the Auschwitz site in southern Poland since late 1984. But the presence of the convent, which was set up as a place of prayer for all who died in the camp, was apparently not widely known until a fund-raising appeal was begun last year in Europe by a Catholic group in an effort to renovate the building in which 10 nuns now live.   The group, Aid to the Church in Distress, has also been criticized by some Jewish and Catholic leaders for a statement issued in conjunction with the fund-raising drive, in which it raised $150,000 in Luxembourg, Belgium and the Netherlands during Pope John Paul II's visit to these countries last May.

headline: PRETORIA FINDS MOZAMBIQUE NONAGGRESSION PACT 'ALIVE AND WELL'
abstract: South Africa said today that its nonaggression accord with Mozambique was ''alive and well'' after negotiations between senior figures from the two countries yesterday.   But reports from Maputo, Mozambique's capital, said a rebellion that was expected to wither as a result of the 1984 treaty seemed to have revived in recent months, with antipersonnel mines exploding on the city's beaches and attacks on suburbs. South Africa acknowledged supporting the rebels before the nonaggression pact was signed but insists it is no longer backing them.   In South Africa, meanwhile, the police, in what has become a daily litany, chronicled the deaths overnight of two more blacks in the township violence that has claimed more than 1,130 lives since September 1984.

headline: FRANCE SAYS 3 PLANNED TO BOMB SYNAGOGUE
abstract: Three men were charged tonight with preparing a bombing attack against a Paris synagogue.   The synagogue was the scene of a bombing five years ago in which four people were killed and nine wounded.

headline: SHCHARANSKY SKEPTICAL ON SOVIET RIGHTS POLICY
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky expressed doubt today that his release from a Soviet prison camp last week indicated Moscow was about to liberalize overall policies on Jewish emigration or human rights.   On the contrary, he said, past patterns showed a hardening of domestic oppression might be expected after a conciliatory gesture such as his release.   Last week, Mr. Shcharansky was part of an East-West prisoner exchange at the border of East Germany and West Berlin that ended nine years of imprisonment for him. In the mid-1970's, after being refused an exit visa to emigrate to Israel, he became an activist in the Jewish emigration movement and a member of a dissidents' committee monitoring Soviet human rights violations.

headline: Ford Credit Sells $200 Million Issue
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.69 to yield 9.33 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The notes, rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P., are offered with a yield about 70-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 14, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee on Non-Use of Force in International Relations -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - Scientific and Technical Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: South Korean Police Raid Opposition Offices
abstract: Policemen sealed off the headquarters of two opposition groups today, apparently in an effort to stop a petition drive for direct presidential elections.   About 50 policemen with warrants entered the offices of the New Korea Democratic Party and searched for documents, witnesses said.

headline: HUSSEIN QUESTIONS WHO SHOULD SPEAK FOR PALESTINIANS
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan, challenging the leadership of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, called on the Palestinian people today to decide who should lead them.   In an interview, he said he would ''respect'' a decision by Palestinians to preserve the P.L.O. as the ''sole legitimate representative'' of the Palestinian people. But he said another ''apparatus'' to express their wishes would also be welcomed in Jordan. 'What Do They Want Us to Do?'

headline: ITALY SEEKS TRIAL IN SHIP HIJACKING
abstract: Italian prosecutors have asked for indictments against 13 people for the hijacking last fall of the Achille Lauro cruise ship, and among them is the Palestinian guerrilla leader Mohammed Abbas, judicial sources said today.   In court papers filed in Genoa on Friday, the charges made against the 13 people ranged from criminal association to complicity in murder. A 69-year-old New Yorker, Leon Klinghoffer, was shot dead during the hijacking.   The prosecutors' action is the first step toward holding a trial in the Italian judicial system. An investigating magistrate will now review the accusations, and if he finds them substantiated, he can order a trial.

headline: MARCOS LIST OF PAYMENTS
abstract: Following is a list of payments and deposits found in ledgers and other documents among Ferdinand E. Marcos's belongings:

headline: BOEING IN BELFAST DEAL
abstract: A Belfast aerospace company, Short Brothers, signed a contract today with the Boeing Company for the joint production of a plane scheduled to begin service in 1992. Short will begin work on the 7J7 150-seat aircraft in the near future under the terms of the deal, which is worth more than $150 million.

headline: Luring I.R.A.'s To New Plans
abstract: INDIVIDUALS can open or add to Individual Retirement Accounts at any time of the year, but about two-thirds do so between Jan. 1 and April 15. Most of the new I.R.A. money, moreover, will arrive at banks, mutual funds, insurance companies and other institutions in the last four weeks of the period, as the various retirement account trustees step up their marketing efforts to attract more funds.   Commercial banks held 29 percent of all I.R.A.'s at the end of last year, according to The I.R.A. Reporter, a Cleveland-based newsletter. Other segments of the $204.5 billion I.R.A. kitty have been captured by savings and loan associations at 24 percent, brokerage firms at 15 percent, mutual funds at 14 percent, life insurance companies at 8 percent, credit unions at 6 percent and mutual savings banks at 4 percent.

headline: E.E.C. Seeks Comecon Tie
abstract: The European Economic Community agreed Friday to resume negotiations with Comecon on establishing official relations between the two trade groups.   ''One of the community's major objectives is to improve political and economic relations in Europe,'' said Willy de Clercq, the E.E.C.'s Commissioner for External Relations. In a meeting today with Rumania's ambassador to Belgium, Mr. de Clercq handed over a letter calling for the resumption of talks, which were halted in 1980 when Comecon, the Soviet-bloc trade organization, reportedly insisted on taking global responsibility for its member's trade with the 12-nation E.E.C.

headline: ADJUSTABLE-RATE PAPER IN FREDDIE MAC DEBUT
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, at a news conference yesterday, introduced a new type of security called a capped, adjustable-rate mortgage participation certificate.   The corporation, known as Freddie Mac, said it expects to issue about $1 billion of the new paper this year, beginning with an initial offering of about $335 million through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S SPEECH TO THE PARTY
abstract: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the Communist Party congress today, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:   Previous Leadership For a number of years the deeds and actions of party and government bodies trailed behind the needs of the times and of life. The problems in the country's development built up more rapidly than they were being solved.   The inertness and stiffness of the forms and methods of administration, the decline of dynamism in our work and an escalation of bureaucracy - all this was doing no small damage. Signs of stagnation had begun to surface in the life of the society.   The situation called for change, but a peculiar psychology - How to improve things without changing anything? - took the upper hand. But that cannot be done, comrades. Stop for an instant, as they say, and you fall behind a mile.

headline: SIMULATING VISION IN 4 STEPS
abstract: Most companies designing vision systems for machines describe vision as a four-part process:    * Capturing an image.    * Processing it so that it can be analyzed.    * Analyzing it to identify important features.    * Interpreting the results.

headline: BID MADE FOR CLEVETRUST
abstract: A group led by a Canadian investor, Robert N. Goodman, said Friday that it had made an offer for all of the outstanding shares of Clevetrust Realty Investors for $20 a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it was also considering soliciting proxies to elect three of its nominees to the board. The group, which holds 8.52 percent of Clevetrust's shares outstanding, told the S.E.C. thaT if its offer was not accepted, it might seek control of the Cleveland-based real estate and mortgage company through negotiated purchases or a tender offer.

headline: FILENE'S EXPECTED TO ADD FOOD LINE
abstract: Filene's, the Boston-based chain of fashion stores, is expected to announce this morning the opening of gourmet food departments in all 16 of its stores, according to retail trade sources.

headline: Xerox Products
abstract: The Xerox Corporation plans to announce several office automation products Wednesday, including a communications network for personal computers based on American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Starlan technology, industry consultants said. The announcements are the first in a series of office-product introductions Xerox is expected to make over the next few months.

headline: SALES RISE 1%
abstract: Business inventories slipped one-tenth of 1 percent in December, the first drop since August, while sales advanced 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.   Analysts said the combination of rising sales and declining business stockpiles was likely to increase factory production in the months ahead.   ''These low inventories are good news,'' said Priscilla Luce, an economist with Wharton Econometrics. ''It means that producers are going to have to step up their output in order to get inventory levels back to where they want them.''

headline: School Bonds For Alaska
abstract: Matanuska-Susitna Borough, Alaska, is offering $61.2 million of general obligation school construction bonds through underwriters led by the Foster & Marshall division of Shearson Lehman Brothers.   The bonds are tentatively offered with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due Aug. 1, 1986, to 7.10 percent in 1991 and 7.60 percent in 1996.

headline: ITALY SAYS IT FOUND CYANIDE IN SINDONA
abstract: Michele Sindona, the jailed Sicilian financier who fell into an irreversible coma on Thursday, is the victim of cyanide poisoning, the Justice Minister said today.   The official, Mino Martinazzoli, told Parliament that it was not clear whether someone tried to kill Mr. Sindona or if he had tried to commit suicide. He said tests on Mr. Sindona's blood had confirmed a lethal dose of cyanide.   Mr. Sindona, who was near the center of many of Italy's most important recent financial and political scandals, had been under constant guard at a specially constructed wing of the Voghera women's prison. The prison is considered one of the most secure in Italy.

headline: TAX PLAN PARALYZES MUNICIPALS
abstract: Trading activity in the tax-exempt bond market ground to a virtual standstill yesterday as dealers and issuers reacted with alarm to a proposal in the Senate Finance Committee that would subject interest payments on all municipal bonds to the alternative minimum income tax.   If the proposal - which would be phased in over a five-year period -becomes law, it could cost the nation's state and local governments billions in higher borrowing costs, industry officials said yesterday.   ''At best, this would increase the cost of financing very significantly,'' said Felix G. Rohaytn, senior partner at Lazard Freres and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York. ''And even if this thing is taken off the table, the fact that it has raised the question of prospective taxation has left a residue of unease.''

headline: TREATY IS SAID TO KEEP SOVIET FROM OUTDEPLOYING U.S. IN WEAPONS
abstract: Abandoning the second strategic arms treaty would enable the Soviet Union to add more weapons to its arsenal than the United States by 1990, according to an analysis by Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.   The analysis states that if the accord's limits are dropped, the Soviet Union will be able to produce nuclear weapon systems at a greater rate than the United States because the Soviet Union has more production lines for strategic weapons that are currently in operation.   The Reagan Administration is currently deliberating over whether the United States should continue to abide by the terms of the treaty, which was signed in 1979 but never approved by the Senate.

headline: DYNAMICS CORP. TO LIFT CTS STAKE
abstract: In a move that the CTS Corporation described as ''unfriendly,'' the Dynamics Corporation of America said it planned to buy one million CTS shares in a partial tender offer for $43 in cash per share, to raise its stake in CTS to 27.2 percent, from 9.7 percent.

headline: Editor of New York Now Publisher Also
abstract: The honor - and challenge - of being both editor and publisher of a magazine is not common in American publishing circles, although a few outstanding joint holders come to mind.   The newest is Edward Kosner, 48 years old, since 1980 editor of New York.

headline: Society for Savings
abstract: The Society for Savings said it had remerger proposal from the Shawmut Corporation. The society's board said the price was inadequate and that this was an inappropriate time to consider selling the company. Shawmut said it was disappointed by the board's decision and would now review its options.

headline: Business and the Law; Nonunion Labor's Rights
abstract: EVEN though the National Labor Relations Act is usually invoked to protect unionized workers or workers trying to form unions, the National Labor Relations Board is expected to decide soon a key case about how far the labor act goes to protect nonunion workers.   Under the labor act, employers are prohibited from dismissing or otherwise penalizing workers for engaging ''in concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection.'' The case before the N.L.R.B. focuses on whether employees who file a complaint with a government safety agency without consulting their co-workers have engaged in ''concerted'' activity and are thus protected by the labor act. The rationale would be that because their actions further the interests of their co-workers, they had the implied consent of those workers.

headline: Paris Aide Reported In Touch With Captors
abstract: A French mediator, Dr. Razah Raad, was reported today to have made contact with Moslem extremists holding French hostages.   A Christian radio station, Voice of Lebanon, said Dr. Raad, a Lebanese-born heart specialist, held meetings in Beirut's mostly Shiite southern suburbs.

headline: Kuwait Says Libyans Downed Plane
abstract: Kuwait's official press agency, KUNA, quoted a diplomat today as saying a Libyan anti-aircraft missile shot down an American jet fighter over the Mediterranean earlier in the week.   It did not identify the diplomat but reported he said the warplane was downed Wednesday by a Soviet-made SAM-7 missile as it flew over the Gulf of Sidra.

headline: GTE and Telecom Pick Leaders for New Sprint
abstract: Last Friday, the day after their companies, United Telecommunications Inc. and the GTE Corporation, announced that they had agreed to the largest merger yet in the long-distance telephone industry, Charles M. Skibo, Donald G. Prigmore and J. David Hann were all on the move.   The activity was entirely appropriate, and is likely to intensify in coming months if the result of the combination, the U.S. Sprint Communications Company, is to succeed.

headline: STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: Investors continued to swarm into the stock market yesterday after Thursday's record-breaking session, and prices closed mostly higher although a select group of blue-chip stocks that included I.B.M. came under heavy selling pressure.   Almost 192 million shares changed hands yesterday, the fourth-busiest session in Wall Street history, and more than 824 million shares were traded for the week. The weekly volume was the second highest on record, trailing only the week ended last Dec. 13, when 827 million shares were traded.   Unlike most other market indicators, the Dow Jones industrial average was unable to push forward one day after shattering the 1,700 barrier. It closed down 4.93 points, at 1,709.06.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CHEERS AND BARBS IN RUSSIA
abstract: There is something awesome about the volume of words generated at a Soviet Communist Party congress.   Over nine days, with a day off on Sunday, the 5,000 delegates to the 27th party congress sat stoically in their assigned rows in the cavernous Palace of Congresses through some 100 speeches, as well as 31 by foreign Communist leaders.   Each speech was printed in pages of solid type in the party newspaper Pravda and the Government newspaper Izvestia, with ''applause,'' ''prolonged applause'' and sometimes ''tumultuous, prolonged applause'' marked in at appropriate spots.   The only other interruptions at the congress, which ended Thursday, have been for ''votes,'' all unanimous, to adopt the party program, the economic guidelines, resolutions and other reports.

headline: ITALIAN CAR MAKERS SEEKING U.S. NICHE
abstract: Italy's reputation for fine design has stoked an enormous American appetite for all manner of Italian goods, from sweaters to lamps to appliances. But Italian car manufacturers have been unable to capitalize on that appetite.   Their cars represent less than one-half of one percent of American auto imports. And Italian car owners in the United States constitute something of a private club.

headline: ECUADOR REBELS ROUTED AND LEADER IS CAPTURED
abstract: About 2,000 soldiers, backed by tanks and artillery, today recaptured a Quito air base held by the former armed forces Chief of Staff, who had called for the overthrow of the President.   A Government spokesman said the rebel leader, Frank Vargas Pazos, had been captured.   The Quito radio said army and police forces battled the rebels for 90 minutes at midday and retook Mariscal Sucre air base, which Mr. Vargas seized Thursday night.   A Government spokesman, Patricio Quevedo, said in a statement broadcast over all radio stations, which were under Government control as part of a state of emergency, that four people were killed and nine were wounded.

headline: Advertising; Changes at the Top Of Kallir, Philips, Ross
abstract: Kallir, Philips, Ross, an ad agency in the health care field, announced major executive changes yesterday starting right at the top.

headline: Greece's Aid on Libya Urged
abstract: The United States Deputy Secretary of State, John C. Whitehead, met Foreign Minister Karolos Papoulias of Greece today to seek support for Washington's economic sanctions against Libya, an authoritative source said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: KAISER SUITORS
abstract: A group seeking control of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had raised its stake to 21.6 percent of the shares outstanding from 20.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it bought 664,077 common shares last Friday for $18 a share. The group is led by J. A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor, and Alan Clore, a British investor.

headline: INSIDER REPORTS
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE CROWN ZELLERBACH CORPORATION-Edgar H. Grubb, senior vice president, sold 10,047 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 11,203 shares.

headline: RAMOS, OUSTING MARCOS COMMANDERS, BEGINS CHANGES SOUGHT BY THE U.S.
abstract: In one of his first acts as the new chief of the armed forces, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos has taken a step toward the military changes long sought by Reagan Administration critics of the former Marcos Government.   The general, who was field commander of the small force that sparked the nation to oust Ferdinand E. Marcos, sent a message to the troops announcing that he was demoting some of the strongest Marcos supporters among command officers.   Among the first to ascend in the post-Marcos command are some of the field officers who defected with their troops to his side early, when the risk of a pro-Marcos attack seemed greatest.   Signaling the change was the choice of Brig. Gen. Ramon J. Farolan as chief of the air force. This reflected the fact that among the first to change sides were air force pilots who landed by helicopter gunships at the camp of General Ramos and Juan Ponce Enrile, the Marcos official who began the resistance Saturday and has become the new Government's Minister of Defense, his former post.

headline: Midland Plant Shift to Gas
abstract: The chairman of the Consumers Power Company has opened negotiations with natural gas suppliers for possible conversion of the defunct Midland nuclear power plant to natural gas, the utility said today.   ''All of this is very early,'' said Paul Knopick, a Consumers spokesman.

headline: Israelis Clear the Way For Talks With Egypt
abstract: The 10-member inner Cabinet cleared the way for the resumption of talks with Egypt today when it agreed on directives to the Israeli negotiators.   Prime Minister Shimon Peres said in a radio interview later that the Israeli negotiators would go to Cairo on Wednesday to seek an agreement on the definition of the central question to be adjudicated by international arbitrators in the dispute over the Taba beach on the Gulf of Aqaba.

headline: HAITIANS IN U.S. HOPEFUL FOR DEMOCRACY
abstract: Haitian leaders in the United States said today that the fall of the Duvalier Government presented the Caribbean nation with a long-forestalled opportunity for full democracy.   The leaders predicted that many Haitians in the United States would be eager to return to their native country. But they also suggested there might be a widespread ''wait and see'' attitude toward the new military-civilian governing council.   ''We welcome this change, and we see it as a first step toward democracy and liberation,'' said Fritz Longchamp, program director of the Washington Office on Haiti, which describes itself as a human rights and lobbying organization.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Too Much Too Soon?   Tumbling oil prices, joining falling interest rates, have the stock market soaring anew. Last week, the Dow Jones industrial average crashed through the 1,600 barrier. But investors face some short-term perils, says David B. Bostian Jr., who heads a New York economic consulting firm bearing his name. ''Investor enthusiasm may have caused an overbought situation in the markets,'' said Mr. Bostian, ''and there could be several sharp corrections before the markets resume their advance.''   Alan C. Leventen, president of Twenty-First Futures, a New York financial brokerage, agrees there are pitfalls, but he predicts investors will not stumble upon them until late this year or early in 1987. What is the trap? With inflation relatively low now, investor psychology may be ''overly positive,'' says Mr. Leventen. He expects the declining interest rates to stimulate both business and consumer borrowing and to set the stage for higher interest rates and inflation, which will arouse investor concern.

headline: VENICE COPES WITH CARNIVAL AND 2 KINDS OF TIDES
abstract: The bawdy pagan feast of Carnival began with a flood this year. Some people here think it was an omen.   Just as Venice prepared to frolic for 11 days, warning sirens blared last Saturday. Soon little green waves were rolling across St. Mark's Square.   The flood, caused by the third highest tide of the century, receded before the main events of the Carnival of Venice began Wednesday night, yet anxiety remained behind like some unsightly flotsam washed ashore.

headline: COURT REBUFFS PENNZOIL
abstract: A Federal appeals court denied a request yesterday from the Pennzoil Company for additional financial security in its legal fight with Texaco Inc.   The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York rejected a motion by Pennzoil, made last week, that sought to limit Texaco's ability to pledge its assets to lenders in order to secure financing.

headline: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES
abstract: The article ''When the Boss Becomes Your Doctor'' (Jan. 5) -which described the increasing participation of companies in health care decisions through tighter management of health insurance programs -elicited an unusual number of responses. What follows is a sampling.

headline: Fannie Mae Prices Two Debentures
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $900 million of 8.65 percent debentures due 1990 and $600 million of 9.35 percent debentures due 1996.

headline: REBEL GAINS ARE REPORTED, AND DISPUTED, IN SOUTHERN YEMEN
abstract: Rebellious Marxist forces appeared to have the upper hand in most of Southern Yemen tonight, according to refugees reaching here and diplomats' assessments. But with communications still cut, the political situation in the Soviet-allied nation remained confused.   Transmissions on the frequency of the official state radio - 1200 on the AM band - said that President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani had been ousted and that the ''collective leadership'' of the ruling Yemeni Socialist Party was in charge.

headline: REAGAN EXCHANGES GREETINGS ON TV WITH GORBACHEV
abstract: In an unusual television exchange, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev extended New Year's greetings today to the Soviet and American peoples. They expressed the hope that the two nations could narrow their differences in 1986.   The substance of the five-minute statements, with voice-over translations, was less significant than the exchange itself.   It was the first time that American and Soviet leaders had directly addressed each other's nation since President Richard M. Nixon visited the Soviet Union in 1972 and Leonid I. Brezhnev the United States in 1973.

headline: DEREGULATION
abstract: To the Editor:   Professor Thayer's contention that there is a connection between highway accidents and economic deregulation is disappointing. The evidence to the contrary can be easily researched and is far from anecdotal.

headline: LEVI STRAUSS REPORTS LOSS
abstract: Levi Strauss Associates reported a loss of $114 million for the fourth quarter, primarily because of interest and asset adjustments relating to the leveraged buyout of Levi Strauss & Company last August.

headline: E.E.C. SEEKING U.S. TALKS
abstract: The European Economic Community's executive commission invited the United States today to defuse a trade dispute over the accession of Spain and Portugal to the community through negotiations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade body.   A spokesman said a letter had been sent to the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, and the Agriculture Secretary-designate, Richard E. Lyng, proposing the cooling-off move.

headline: McCormick Unit
abstract: McCormick & Company said its board had approved a $92 million gas-fired co-generation project at its Gilroy Foods Inc. in California's Santa Clara Valley. It said the project would produce about 113 megawatts of electricity for sale to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and up to 190,000 pounds an hour of steam for Gilroy's food dehydration process.

headline: Advertising; Needham's Consultant
abstract: Stanley Marcus, 80 and chairman emeritus of Neiman-Marcus, has joined Needham Harper Worldwide as a consultant and will be available to all the agency's accounts offering his expertise, especially in the area of retailing and customer service.

headline: FRENCH ARREST EX-SERVICEMAN ON SPY CHARGE
abstract: A retired member of the French Air Force has been arrested and charged with spying for the Soviet Union, the Interior Ministry announced today.   French officials are said to believe that the man who was arrested was giving information to Soviet intelligence agents about the movement of French naval vessels around the Brest naval port, where France has based submarines carrying nuclear missiles since 1972.   The suspect, Bernard Sourisseau, 44 years old, described as a retired air force helicopter mechanic, was arrested about a week ago by agents of France's counterespionage police.

headline: SENATE FINANCE COMMITTEE: 20 MEMBERS WHO WILL CONSIDER TAX CHANGE
abstract: The following sketches of the 20 members of the Senate Finance Committee, 11 Republicans and 9 Democrats, are presented in order of the Senators' seniority: REPUBLICANS BOB PACKWOOD of Oregon . . . 53 . . . committee chairman for the last two years and the most important voice in the Senate on tax matters . . . capacity for leadership still untested . . . up for re-election this year to a fourth term, apparently without important opposition . . . traditional conservative on economic issues but liberal on social policy and has gained the enmity of the Reagan Administration by criticizing the President's policies on abortion and civil rights . . . favors using the tax code to achieve economic and social goals . . . advocates low capital gains rates, tax-free fringe benefits for workers, favorable tax treatment for Oregon's timber industry and tuition tax credits. BOB DOLE of Kansas . . . 62 . . . relinquished committee chairmanship last year to become majority leader . . . facing re-election in November without serious opposition . . . successfully changed public image from hatchetman to statesman . . . dominant Congressional figure on tax legislation in first Reagan term . . . orthodox conservative, willing to stand up to the President and advocates of supply-side economics . . . chief concern is the budget deficit but believes the tax revision bill ''should not be used as a vehicle to raise taxes or reduce the deficit'' . . . often has expressed distaste for special tax breaks and lobbyists. WILLIAM V. ROTH JR. of Delaware . . . 64 . . . Senate author of 1981 tax cuts . . . sponsor of a business transfer tax, similar to a value added tax, with the revenue used to reduce income tax rates . . . advocates low rates, tax-free savings accounts, generous business depreciation rules, deductible mortgages on vacation homes and tuition tax credits . . . chairman of Governmental Affairs Committee.

headline: Worthen Bank Deficit Widens
abstract: The Worthen Bank Corporation, the largest banking company in Arkansas, said yesterday that it lost $6.59 million in 1985's fourth quarter, much more than its loss of $452,474 a year earlier.

headline: G.M. EXPECTED TO REMODEL PLANT
abstract: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce formally on March 24 that it will remodel its Oshawa, Ontario, assembly plant to produce the W-body midsize cars scheduled for introduction in 1989.

headline: McDONNELL IS OUT OF REPUBLIC BID
abstract: The Republic Health Corporation said the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had withdrawn from an investment group that had agreed to a leveraged buyout of Republic at $305 million, or $18.50 a share in cash, because the buyout price was raised.   On Saturday, Republic Health's board approved a sweetened price of $18.50 a share and $1.50 face amount of debentures, which are valued at about 75 cents each. The investment group, Pesch & Company, said McDonnell Douglas's withdrawal would not hinder the transaction, which must be completed by Aug. 31.

headline: MARCOS REPORTED TO LOSE SUPPORT IN ADMINISTRATION
abstract: A consensus has developed in the Reagan Administration that the departure of President Ferdinand E. Marcos is critical to a non-Communist future for the Philippines and American interests in that country.   This widely held view was made clear explicitly or indirectly in interviews this week with key officials from the White House, State Department, Pentagon and intelligence agencies.   But the Administration has decided not to push Mr. Marcos from power by covert means, although that was considered by some officials, or by public attacks on him, although some officials have also come close to this. Distance and Waiting    Instead, the policy is to distance the United States from its old ally by publicly questioning Mr. Marcos's statements that he is seeking to effect the economic and military changes the United States has sought. Another element of the strategy is waiting, the officials said. Very soon, they said, they expect that Mr. Marcos's health will force him to withdraw from the scene.

headline: SALE OF NEW 2-YEAR NOTES EXPECTED
abstract: Treasury financings this week consist of today's auctions of new bills, followed tomorrow by a $9.5 billion sale of new two-year notes.   Before the regular weekly bill auctions, which were delayed because of Washington's Birthday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid Friday at 6.98 percent, while the six-month issue was 7.07 percent. The two-year notes to be auctioned tomorrow were offered late Friday on a when-issued basis to yield 7.89 percent.

headline: BEATRICE DIRECTORS ACCEPT BID
abstract: The board of the Beatrice Companies agreed today to accept an offer valued at more than $6 billion from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company that was slightly sweetened from the revised bid Kohlberg made in January.   In addition, Beatrice's board agreed in principle to settle some 20 shareholder suits by consenting, among other things, to reduce the golden parachutes paid to senior management and to eliminate the lockup agreement giving Kohlberg the right to buy key Beatrice assets, including its Tropicana juice unit.   Under the offer that Beatrice's board agreed to today after a five-and-a-half-hour meeting, Kohlberg will pay, for each Beatrice common share, $40 in cash and $10 in preferred shares that pay an annual dividend of 15.25 percent.

headline: COUNCIL NATIONALIZES DUVALIER'S HAITIAN PARTY
abstract: The new interim Government has nationalized all properties of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier in Haiti. The value of the properties was not disclosed.   Mr. Duvalier fled 12 days ago after a prolonged period of popular protests.   The Government also ordered foreign as well as Haitian nationals to disclose within two weeks any assets they may be holding in Mr. Duvalier's name. Failure to do, the decree said, would jeopardize their own belongings.

headline: SPORTSWEAR UNIT SHIFTS
abstract: Campus Sportswear of Paramus, N.J., has a new agency, Terry Conway of the advertising department confirmed yesterday.

headline: PACIFIC SOUTHWEST, NORTHWEST AIR TIE
abstract: Pacific Southwest Airlines said it would integrate its flight schedule with Northwest Airlines in an effort to pick up a substantial amount of additional travelers.

headline: TIN RESCUE EFFORT FAILS AND SHEARSON FILES SUIT
abstract: A last-gasp effort by the International Tin Council to revive its rescue plan failed today, leaving brokers on the London Metal Exchange facing huge losses and an uncertain future.   ''The only thing left to do now is try to count the losses and start preparing the lawsuits,'' one brokerage executive said.   The first suit was filed here later in the day by Shearson Lehman Brothers, the large American brokerage house.

headline: ANTI-MARCOS PRESSURE MOUNTING IN CONGRESS
abstract: Congressional pressure mounted today for an end to United States assistance to the Philippine Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, but the White House said it was ''far premature'' to cut off aid and close the two United States military bases there.   The growing emotion on Capitol Hill was demonstrated tonight when the Senate agreed to vote Wednesday on a resolution condemning the ''widespread fraud'' in the Philippine voting and requesting President Reagan to convey the Senate's findings to Mr. Marcos. Aid Suspension Is Urged   Another key Congressional figure added his voice to the criticism of the Manila Government when Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, wrote to President Reagan, urging him to suspend all aid to the Philippines. Mr. Fascell maintained that the United States would suffer ''inevitable damage'' if it failed to distance itself from Mr. Marcos.   Mr. Fascell was part of a chorus of voices on Capitol Hill today urging a cutoff of aid to the Marcos Government, a chorus that included Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, who insisted that the United States end its support for the ''corrupt, authoritarian regime'' of Mr. Marcos.

headline: Sallie Mae Uses Australian Dollars
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced a 200 million Australian dollar issue of zero coupon notes due in 1996 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.   After selling the Australian dollars in the forward foreign exchange market and then exchanging its zero coupon liability for a floating-rate liability, the agency ended up with a cost for its borrowing that is less than the six-month London interbank offered rate, according to an official at Shearson Lehman Brothers.   The notes are offered at market prices, but were quoted yesterday at 53.523 to yield 12.90 percent.

headline: VACANCY SIGN OUT IN MANHATTAN REALTY BOOM
abstract: After nearly a decade of explosive growth, Manhattan's real estate market has run out of steam, according to investors, brokers, developers and bankers who have lived through the industry's ups and downs.   Though prices in most categories of commercial and residential real estate have not fallen sharply, they have eroded from peaks reached in 1984. Many experts say bargains are beginning to emerge, especially in the office market in the financial district.   Among the signs that the Manhattan market has already softened are these:    * Office vacancy rates have moved up sharply since 1983, particularly in the financial district, where a boom in construction and slower growth in demand have left nearly 9 percent of the space empty, according to the Gordon Office Market Report, a publication put out by one of Manhattan's largest real estate brokers. Estimates from other brokers run as high as 13 percent. The same problem is now spreading to the midtown market,

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY; CLASSES IN KICKING AND GOUGING
abstract: ROBERT FISHER has lived in cities with high crime rates his entire life. And he's been lucky so far - never the victim of a crime. But when the Executive Self-Defense Center opened on New York's Madison Avenue last September, Mr. Fisher was one of the first in line to join.  ''I am forever reading about executives who find themselves in compromising positions with criminals,'' said the 36-year-old president of the Nationwide Corporation, a real estate company. ''I want to be prepared.''

headline: GORBACHEV WANTS RESULTS AT THE SUMMIT
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that his next meeting with President Reagan should produce practical results rather than broad statements about reducing the threat of nuclear war, the official Soviet press agency reported.   The agency, Tass, said that Mr. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, had made the statement in a meeting with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who is here for a three-day visit.   Tass said Mr. Gorbachev had emphasized that ''verbal tribute alone to the understanding of the danger of the present-day situation is no longer enough.''

headline: TAIWAN CURBS ITS COUNTERFEITERS
abstract: ON a drizzly night there are myriad bargains in Snake Alley, a covered market in one of this city's farther suburbs. You can eat a bowl of noodles while a chimpanzee chained to the restaurant counter tumbles for your amusement. For $70 you can buy a live cobra, watch the proprietor kill it and drink its blood as an elixir.   And for about $10 you can buy a counterfeit version of Rolex's gold Oyster Perpetual watch. The authentic version retails for $8,850 at Tiffany's in New York. The watch is one of dozens of lookalikes - fake Longines, Piagets, Cartiers, Girard Perregaux - that glisten in the neon light that intensifies the alley's garish air. The fakes are convincing enough to the layman's eye, but the merchants make no pretense. ''They're fake, you know,'' said a woman at a stall marked ''Cheap Watches.'' She added: ''But they keep the time just as well.''

headline: New-Product Showing For January Is Strong
abstract: January is typically a slow month for new-product introductions, since few manufacturers attempt sales presentations to retailers during December. However, as Dancer Fitzgerald Sample reports in its latest issue of New Product News, this January produced a strong kick-off to 1986, with 144 new products introduced - an increase of 14.5 percent over the same month last year.

headline: Patents; Anticancer Agent Purified
abstract: THE Cetus Corporation, the pioneer biotechnology company, has made progress in its production of recombinant interleuken-2, the anticancer agent. A clinically pure form is created by a process patented for the company this week.

headline: KOHL IN AN ACCORD ON SPACE DEFENSE
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger announced today that they had reached a basic accord covering West German participation in the Reagan Administration's missile-defense research program.   After two hours of talks with Mr. Weinberger in the northern Bavarian town of Grafenwohr, Mr. Kohl said that his Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, would travel to Washington next week and sign two accords -one on the space defense prorgam and another on technology transfer.   The breakthrough came at what had been meant to be a ceremonial troop and armor review at Grafenwohr, and it cleared the way for West Germany to become the second North Atlantic Treaty Alliance ally to commit itself formally to the so-called Strategtic Defense Initiative. Britain signed an accord on Dec. 6.

headline: Oil Prices Up Modestly; Trading Reported Light
abstract: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products rose slightly in light trading yesterday, as the market continued the cautious upturn begun Wednesday. But traders cast a nervous glance toward a meeting of Norwegian oil officials this weekend.   The meeting, in the remote village of Sanderstoelen, is held annually and includes bankers and politicians. But it assumed increased importance in the market's thinking this week when rumors circulated that officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and of Britain and Norway would meet secretly at the conference. OPEC wants the British and Norwegians to cut production.

headline: Iceland Official Resigns
abstract: Foreign Minister Geir Hallgrimsson stepped down today in a shuffle of Iceland's center-right coalition. Trade Minister Matthias Bjarnason said in a radio interview that the Foreign Minister was replaced by a fellow member of the right-wing Independence Party, Matthias Matthiesen. The former Foreign Minister will become a director of Iceland's central bank.

headline: HAITIAN DEMONSTRATORS CHALLENGE DUVALIER AGAIN
abstract: Anti-Government protests, a rare event in this Caribbean dictatorship, erupted here for two days this week, and today the authorities declared that security forces had been instructed to ''rigorously put down all illegal action.''   They also announced that all schools had been ordered closed in the aftermath of widespread student boycotts.   In one demonstration on Monday in a town 90 miles north of here, one person was killed by security forces and three were injured, according to local residents and foreign diplomats. Situation 'Very Tense'    Soldiers and militiamen were on alert in the capital and at the International Airport. Diplomats here characterized the situation around the country as ''very tense.''

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of 40-year debentures.    * Armstrong Rubber Co. has filed for $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 through First Boston Corp. as sole underwriter.

headline: KENNEDY REPORTS GAIN IN SOVIET EMIGRATION CASES
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy returned from a trip to the Soviet Union today and said 25 Jews for whom he had interceded were being permitted to emigrate.   The Jews, who had long been denied exit visas for a variety of reasons, were on a list the Massachusetts Democrat had presented to the Soviet authorities.   Senator Kennedy said the 25 had, ''in the words of the Soviets, 'been given favorable consideration consistent with Soviet laws.' '' He said six of them were already in the West.

headline: Northern Ireland Votes; No Violence Reported
abstract: Citizens of Northern Ireland lined up under heavy guard today to vote in parliamentary elections that are the first popular test of the British-Irish agreement signed in November.

headline: Soviet Official Visiting Iran
abstract: Georgi M. Korniyenko, the Soviet Union's First Deputy Foreign Minister, arrived in Teheran today for a three-day official visit. Iran's official press agency, in a radio report monitored here, said Mr. Korniyenko urged increased political contacts between Iran and the Soviet Union.

headline: A FORD CHANGE SET IN GERMANY
abstract: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been serving the Ford Motor Company, its biggest client, in 23 countries, is losing it in West Germany, an executive at the subsidiary's headquarters in Cologne confirmed Friday. Billings are between $30 million and $40 million.

headline: OCCIDENTAL SETS A DEAL FOR MIDCON
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday agreed to acquire the Midcon Corporation, the owner of one of the largest natural gas pipelines in the United States, for more than $3 billion.
