For Occidental, the nation's ninth biggest oil company, the Midcon deal would be its second major acquisition in the last three years. In late 1982, Occidental purchased a rival, the Cities Service Company, for $7 billion.   It was the acquisition of Cities Service, which has 2.5 trillion cubic feet of natural gas in the ground in addition to its oil reserves, that made the purchase of Midcon not only attractive but also necessary, according to Dr. Armand Hammer, the 87-year-old chairman of Occidental.

headline: BUSH IS IN PORTUGAL TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF ITS PRESIDENT
abstract: Vice President Bush arrived in Lisbon today to attend the inauguration of the Socialist leader Mario Soares as President.   Mr. Bush arrived at Lisbon's military airport after a six-hour visit to Tunisia, where he held brief talks with President Habib Bourguiba and other leaders.   United States relations with Tunisian have been strained since the Israeli air raid Oct. 1 on the headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization in a Tunis suburb in which more than 70 people were killed.

headline: TAKEOVER SPECIALIST JOINS DREXEL GROUP
abstract: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., broadening its merger and acquisition activities, announced yesterday that Martin A. Siegel, a takeover specialist at Kidder, Peabody & Company, has joined the firm as a managing director and co-head of the mergers and acquisitions group.   By hiring Mr. Siegel, who in the late 1970's developed a series of strategies to fend off hostile takeover bids, Drexel has acquired a big-name player for its department.   ''Drexel has very good people, but Marty Siegel is one of those name players that bring a dimension to the firm that wasn't previously there,'' said Kenneth J. Bialkin, a partner at Willkie Farr & Gallagher, a New York law firm that does a great deal of merger and acquisition work.

headline: REAGAN HAILS ECUADOR PRESIDENT AS MODEL LEADER
abstract: President Reagan met today with the President of Ecuador, Leon Febres Cordero, and hailed him as a model leader in the Western Hemisphere.   A soft snow fell and the temperature hovered at 23 degrees when Mr. Febres-Cordero arrived at the White House South Lawn for a welcoming ceremony with full military honors.   At the 30-minute ceremony, hundreds of shivering guests clapped their hands for warmth and stamped their feet as Mr. Reagan contrasted the Ecuadorean leader's ''brave struggle'' against international terrorism and narcotics trafficking with the ''oppressive'' Nicaraguan Government.

headline: CONGRESS LOOKS AT LIABILITY INSURERS
abstract: In the face of soaring costs and increasing scarcity of liability insurance, Congress is under pressure to impose Federal regulation on the insurance industry for the first time, a move that the industry strongly opposes.   For decades, Congress has let the states regulate insurance companies, and has exempted the industry from Federal antitrust laws. The result: a complex patchwork of local, often differing, regulations.   But members of Congress and their aides say that sentiment for Federal action, and perhaps reconsideration of the exemption, is growing, as the lawmakers are barraged with complaints about the cost and availability of insurance.   In a series of hearings held here last week, lawmakers recited a litany of troubles from their constituencies - accounts from municipal governments; school boards; gas station owners; day-care centers; operators of roller-skating rinks and ski slopes, and doctors who are either unable to buy insurance or confronted with huge increases in premiums.

headline: BRITAIN TO AID KUWAIT IF IRAN-IRAQ WAR SPREADS
abstract: A British official said today that Britain would extend military help to Kuwait if asked in the event that the Iraq-Iran war spills over into Kuwait.   The official, Timothy Renton, Foreign Office Minister of State, said at a news conference, ''Kuwait knows that were she to ask for specific military equipment or military assistance we would consider such a request quickly and sympathetically.''

headline: PHILIPPINE PANEL LINKS MARCOS KIN TO ILLEGAL DEALS
abstract: Government investigators have uncovered new evidence that Ferdinand E. Marcos's children and their spouses improperly acquired a lucrative group of businesses and were draining some of the companies of cash for themselves.   According to the special Government commission seeking to recover Mr. Marcos's secret wealth, the companies included three television stations, the nation's largest bus company and a supposedly Government-owned telecommunications concern.   All five companies have been officially taken over by the commission this week to prevent any further transfers of money to Marcos family.   A commission official said investigations at the companies had found a virtual absence of the normal business documents, such as incorporation papers and purchase and sales agreements, to indicate who the real owners were. Managers and employees of the concerns said Marcos family members had been running the companies.

headline: MANILA MAY TRY AN ABSENT MARCOS
abstract: The Philippine Government may put Ferdinand E. Marcos on trial in absentia on charges of illegally accumulating a vast fortune during his 20-year presidency, a senior official disclosed today.   The official, Jovito R. Salonga, head of a commission seeking the return of Mr. Marcos's secret wealth, said, ''We might sue the Marcoses in civil proceedings here.''   Then, he said, the new Philippine Government would use the verdict to ''try to get a judgment in the United States'' against the Marcos family's reported property holdings there.   Mr. Salonga did not spell out precisely what the charges would be, but said a trial might be held ''very soon.''

headline: VOTE IS TOMORROW
abstract: An intense 57-day presidential campaign concluded today with a mass rally here by President Ferdinand E. Marcos and a statement by the country's most influential churchman that was a virtual endorsement of the challenger, Corazon C. Aquino.   The candidates are required to stop campaigning on Thursday, the day before 26 million Filipinos are to vote in an election that both sides say may determine the future of the country's democratic institutions.   Scattered incidents of minor violence were reported along a pro-Marcos motorcade through the city and along an Aquino motorcade through the countryside, illustrating the rise in tensions as the election approached.   The battle lines have been so sharply drawn in the short campaign, between those who have held power for 20 years and those who want change, that there are strong indications that neither side is prepared to accept defeat.

headline: Northwest Air
abstract: Northwest Airlines and Republic Airlines are asking Federal officials to speed approval of Northwest's $884 million deal to buy Republic, saying an expedited purchase would benefit air travelers and employees. The airlines asked the Transportation Department to provide an exemption from the usual 6- to 12-month hearing process. The airlines asked for approval by mid-April, the start of the peak travel season.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Paltridge Inc., a Princeton, N.J., agency that thinks of itself as a marketing communications company, has just picked up the Lawn Doctor account, which could bill in the neighborhood of $1 million.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Beneficial Corp. is offering $100 million of A-3/A-rated 8 percent notes due in 1991 at 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Burlington Northern Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $400 million of debt securities.    * Caesars World Inc. has filed for $100 million of convertible subordinated debentures through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: Arrested in India In Protests Over Prices
abstract: At least 900 opposition party workers were arrested here today during a widely observed daylong work stoppage called to protest price increases.   The protest, which was marked by scattered violence, closed markets, schools, theaters and businesses throughout the capital.

headline: 14 FRENCH RIGHTISTS NOW IN DEMAND
abstract: On Sunday night, Marc Becam, the Mayor of Quimper in Brittany, was elected to the French Parliament as an independent. By Monday morning, he had become an enormously popular fellow.   ''The Rally for the Republic began calling me early Monday morning,'' Mr. Becam said of one of the victorious conservative parties. ''They begged me to come to Paris immediately and rally around the party.''

headline: MAJOR AMERICAN BANKS FREEZE LIBYAN DEPOSITS
abstract: America's biggest banks froze hundreds of millions of dollars in Libyan Government deposits yesterday, carrying out President Reagan's executive order. Although the President's directive left questions, bankers said they were able to put through the basic elements of a deposit freeze because of their experience in 1979 sequestering the assets of Iran.   The banks received formal notice of Mr. Reagan's order, issued Wednesday, in a letter sent yesterday by the Federal Reserve, which is the chief contact between the nation's banks and the Government. The Federal Reserve informs the banks about matters of national security.

headline: Nigerian Sets a Deadline For Relinquishing Power
abstract: The military leader, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, today set a target of Oct. 1, 1990, for his Government to hand over power and said he would leave it up to the Nigerian public to determine the form of the next government.   General Babangida, who assumed office after a coup four months ago, was in Abuja for the inauguration of a 17-member panel assigned to oversee a national debate on what form of government should be adopted and how to insure an orderly succession.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had agreed to sell Brookwood Recovery Centers to Parkside Medical Services Corp., an affiliate of the Lutheran General Health Care System. Terms were not disclosed.    * Carpenter Technology Corp., Reading, Pa., said to cut costs it was reducing salaried staff by 135, mainly at its headquarters, its Reading, Pa., plant and at its Bridgeport, Conn., plant.

headline: FORD INCREASES ITS NOTE OFFERING
abstract: The Ford Motor Company is offering $250 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due 2006 at a price of 99 to yield 8.984 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The notes, which are noncallable for the life of the issue, are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and they yield 89-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.   Underwriters said that because of strong investor demand, the size of the offering had been increased from $200 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Carol Cotton has been named senior vice president, management supervisor on new business and strategic planning at Dancer Fitzgerald, Sample, San Francisco.

headline: U.S. MEDICS GIVEN ANTI-TERROR ROLE
abstract: The senior United States military medical officer in Europe says 12 special medical teams have been formed and trained to handle casualties arising from terrorist attacks.   The officer, Maj. Gen. William H. Greendyke of the Air Force, said in an interview here that teams were alerted to render medical help in at least three terrorist episodes but had not been put in action. He said the teams had run through 50 training drills in 1985.   The general said the teams had been alerted during the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines plane to Beirut, the hijacking of an Egyptair plane to Malta and the capture of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.

headline: 2 Solidarity Activists Detained in Poland
abstract: The police detained two senior Solidarity activists today, preventing them from holding a news conference on behalf of political prisoners that was scheduled to coincide with the start of a conference of intellectuals.   The news conference, which was held in the apartment of Jacek Kuron, a leader of the Polish opposition, was to have been addressed by Mr. Kuron, who was one of those held. Solidarity sources said Janusz Onyszkiewicz, another activist, was also taken for questioning and both men were later released.

headline: U.S. JEWISH GROUP CAUTIONS ON ARMS
abstract: An group working on behalf of Soviet Jews said today that it planned an information campaign to show that Moscow could not be trusted on arms accords if it did not allow freer emigration.   Morris B. Abram, chairman of the group, known as the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, said that if emigration was not liberalized by the time Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, visits the United States, demonstrations ''as never before'' would be held ''to make the point that the Soviet Union cannot be trusted on arms.''   The date for the visit has not yet been set. President Reagan has proposed the second half of June, and the Soviet side a later date, perhaps in September.

headline: CRASH INVESTIGATORS, LACKING ANSWERS, HEAD BACK TO GANDER
abstract: Four weeks after a chartered DC-8 crashed at Gander, Newfoundland, killing 248 U.S. servicemen and eight crew members, investigators are still looking for a cause and are returning to the crash site to search for clues in the scattered wreckage.   The chief Canadian investigator, Peter Boag, said today that investigators from the Canadian Aviation Safety Board, joined by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and a United States Army team, would thaw the frozen ground on the snow-covered hillside crash site near Gander Lake and comb it sector by sector. A stream running through the site would be diverted, Mr. Boag said.   ''It's a very broad investigation at this point still,'' Mr. Boag told reporters visiting his laboratory near Ottawa's airport. ''We certainly have a number of areas we're looking at,'' he said, but he declined to be specific.

headline: NEW YORK FILIPINOS EAGERLY AWAIT OUTCOME
abstract: Filipinos opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos gathered at St. Agnes Church in midtown Manhattan yesterday to pray for ''a clean and honest election'' in the Philippines. Then they began an election watch in the Ninoy Aquino Movement's election center.   Partisans of Mr. Marcos have not set up an election center, but the Consulate will open one today in its Philippine Center.

headline: DOUBT CAST ON KEY LEDGER IN BONN PAYOFF SCANDAL
abstract: A key prosecution document in a number of corruption inquiries - a ledger bearing the names of prominent West German politicians - may contain several erroneous entries, the former bookkeeper of the Flick holding company testified today.   Appearing at the trial of two former Cabinet ministers, Rudolf Diehl, the 65-year-old retired bookkeeper, said that ''in some cases'' he had entered the names of politicians without being certain that they had received payoffs from a Flick fund nicknamed ''the black strongbox.''   Under questioning, Mr. Diehl said he had occasionally entered names himself because he had not been told precisely who the recipients were or had failed to ask his superiors. ''I didn't make entries every day in the ledger,'' he said. ''And when the gentlemen didn't have time, I in some cases just wrote names down myself.''

headline: A STAR IN COMPUTER PRINTING
abstract: At last May's annual shareholders meeting of the Eastman Kodak Company, one shareholder gave a three-minute speech blasting the company for throwing away money on its subsidiary, Atex Inc., which makes computerized publishing systems for newspapers and magazines.   But this was no ordinary shareholder. James P. Lennane, who holds about 100 Kodak shares, is president and founder of System Integrators Inc., Atex's major competitor.   Such unusual and aggressive tactics are characteristic of Mr. Lennane, who has built his company into a major player in the computerized publishing business. System Integrators' sales of systems that computerize writing, editing and makeup tasks have grown from $8.2 million in 1979 to $60.8 million in 1985, a period in which its profits leaped from $520,000 to $7.8 million.

headline: Article 578186 -- No Title
abstract: The Cigna Corporation, the nation's second-largest publicly held insurance company, announced yesterday that it would take a $1.2 billion charge against fourth-quarter earnings to strengthen its property and casualty reserves.   The charge, believed to be the largest in the history of the insurance industry, produced a preliminary operating loss of $1 billion in the fourth quarter, Cigna said. Excluding the adjustment, Cigna said it would have earned $192 million, or $2.47 a share.   In a telephone interview, James G. Stewart, an executive vice president and chief financial officer, said Cigna was strengthening its reserves to cover higher-than-expected general and professional liability claims as well as increases in asbestos-related worker compensation awards. ''In some regard, the change in reserves has been driven by a deterioration in the tort liability system in the United States,'' Mr. Stewart said. ''Judgments in the courts have been beyond our expectations.''

headline: U.N. REPORT LINKS TRAFFIC IN NARCOTICS TO LATIN TERRORISM
abstract: Drug abuse remains a serious problem around the world, and in Latin America the narcotics trade finances gun running, terrorism and other crimes, said a United Nations report issued today.   ''The abuse of a variety of drugs remains at a high level,'' said the International Narcotics Control Board's annual report.

headline: Advertising; Magazine's Appeal Is to Walkers
abstract: NORMAN RABEN, whose Raben Publishing Company in Boston acquired two magazines in two years, is now generating its own title for the first time. In the same genre as the company's Ultrasport and Bicycle Guide, the new magazine will be a quarterly special-interest publication called The Walking Magazine and is due in May.   Because he is convinced that walking as a pastime and as a form of exercise is about to boom, Mr. Raben is rushing to market his new entry, going to all-newsstand distribution at first (300,000 copies), with plans to begin acquiring subscribers later. Select Magazines, distributor of the other two publications, will also distribute The Walking Magazine.

headline: UNITING TO CREATE PRODUCTS
abstract: American companies, facing stiff competition from abroad and relaxed antitrust regulations at home, are banding together to cooperate in research and development at an unprecedented rate, according to corporate and Government officials.   For the first time, the officials add, the cooperation has gone beyond dealing with such industrywide issues as controlling pollution to projects that could result in new products with broad commercial potential.   The projects involve some of the country's biggest companies. Burroughs, I.B.M., Texas Instruments and other computer giants are members of the Semiconductor Research Corporation. Boeing, General Dynamics and Grumman are among 14 companies studying ways to develop computer software for military projects. And Hewlett-Packard and ITT are part of a fiber optics group.

headline: MEXICO DEBT EXTENSION
abstract: Mexico has won a second six-month extension on repayment of $950 million in principal on its $96 billion foreign debt, bankers in New York said yesterday.

headline: ZERO COUPON REAL ESTATE
abstract: SOME of the features that have made zero coupon bonds a popular investment can now be found in a few specialized real estate offerings. Like the bonds, these limited partnerships, with a ''multiplier'' effect, offer investors an opportunity to accrue interest and receive a lump sum payment at maturity.   The bonds, primarily Treasury issues, but also in corporate and municipal form, differ from the traditional variety in that they do not have periodic interest payments. Instead they are sold at a deep discount from face value, with a fixed interest rate established for the term of the bond. The interest accrues annually until maturity, when the bond is redeemed at face value.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Boole & Babbage Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., which sells computer software, has named Bruce T. Coleman president and chief executive officer.

headline: RUSH TO A FILIPINO FREE PRESS REPLACING REVOLUTION FERVOR
abstract: John Peter Zenger never mentioned a chicken farm as the alternative to the fourth estate, but that is how Luis D. Beltran, one of the premier newspaper columnists here, survived during the decade when he was banned from Filipino journalism.   Now, while the rest of the nation descends from the euphoria of a revolution, Mr. Beltran is where he wants to be, ahead of his readers, settling into an artfully cranky groove in the pages of The Philippine Daily Inquirer. Only this morning, he was criticizing President Corazon C. Aquino as easily as he had rooted for her in her challenge to Ferdinand E. Marcos.   The impishness of a free press is to be seen and believed in Manila these days. It is best visualized in the sidewalk hawkers, those ragamuffins and older entrepreneurs who scatter like roaches across the human flow, confronting pedestrians and walking against traffic as they wave and shout about their great handfuls of newspapers, inky with free flowing words, unfettered curiosity and bombast, at two pesos, or 10 cents, an issue.

headline: 2 MILD QUAKES HIT PAKISTAN
abstract: Two mild earthquakes were recorded today in northwestern Pakistan, and officials said there were no deaths or property damage. The tremors, centered 112 miles northwest of Islamabad, were recorded at 3.8 and 3.9 on the Richter scale, officials said.

headline: BIG JAPANESE TRADE SURPLUS
abstract: Japan recorded a trade surplus of $3.9 billion in February, a record for the month resulting from a sharp increase in exports to the United States and Europe and the Japanese yen's appreciation against the dollar, the Finance Ministry said today.   It was the largest surplus ever for February and the 10th largest for one month.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Motors Corp. said it had extended its low-interest financing and cash-rebate program on its Renault Alliance and Encore subcompact cars through the end of February.

headline: ILLICIT WEEKLY HAS SURVIVED POLISH RAIDS
abstract: An illicit Solidarity weekly, founded in 1982, has become an influential source of noncensored information in Poland.   The weekly, Tygodnik Mazowsze, is only one of hundreds of underground publications, from a children's magazine and scholarly quarterlies to worker bulletins. There is even a mimeographed daily in Silesia.   But it is Tygodnik Mazowsze, meaning weekly of Mazovia, a region of central Poland, that is usually first in publishing communiques from the underground, criticism of Government policies and reports on arrests and strikes. Over its lifespan of 156 issues, the weekly has often had to change its format as clandestine printers scrounged supplies, dodged the police and improvised editorial decisions on the run.

headline: Bond Market Receives Boost
abstract: The bond market, already the beneficiary of lower oil prices and low inflation forecasts, was lifted further recently by a spate of weak economic statistics and hopes for good demand from Japanese investors.   Although Friday's sharp 1 3/4-point rise in long-term Treasury issues was exaggerated by the expiration of March options to buy bond futures and a flood of buying in the futures market by securities firms, analysts said the upward direction of bond prices was also supported by good investor demand. Including last week's gains of about 2 5/8 points, the new 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond issue due in 2016 has gained more than 6 1/4 points since Feb. 7, and its yield has fallen to 8.70 percent from 9.30 percent.   For investors who avoided heavy commitments to long-term bonds in recent months, a portfolio shift from two-year notes to 30-year bonds now results in an yield increase of about three-fourths of a percentage point, down from a gain of about 1 1/4 percentage points a month ago.

headline: HERITAGE-GILL DEAL
abstract: Heritage Communications Inc. said it had bought 50 percent of Gill Industries, which operates the cable television system in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Brazil Seeks Plan Backing
abstract: AT 8 percent, Brazil's economic growth last year was the highest in the world. Its trade surplus of $12.45 billion was third only to Japan's and West Germany's. But its average inflation rate for last year was 230 percent and it owes more money to foreign creditors - $100 billion - than any other developing country.

headline: A 'REBORN' MANILA HAS A JOYOUS DAY
abstract: In a celebration that was equal parts of sweetness and joy, Filipinos embraced Easter today as a vibrant symbol of their political rebirth.   Resurrection was the theme of sermons across this devoutly Roman Catholic archipelago, with many equating Christianty's most glorious day with the Philippines' own redemption. Cardinal Addresses Thousands    Perhaps no sermon in the Philippines had a more unvarnished political past than one delivered before thousands of worshipers by Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Roman Catholic Primate and spiritual architect of events that culminated last month in the flight of Ferdinand E. Marcos and the ascension of Corazon E. Aquino.   ''This year,'' Cardinal Sin said, ''the verities of this great Christian feast have come to life in a way we never dreamed possible and in a manner which leaves us gasping and incredulous.''

headline: Bangladesh Removes Martial Law Leaders
abstract: The Government, in moves to accommodate opposition parties, removed all army commanders from their civilian jobs today and set a new date for a parliamentary election.   An official announcement said that the offices of the four zonal Martial Law Administrators, headed by major generals, had been shut down and that the generals had resumed military duties.

headline: Newspaper Editor in Soviet To Head Publishing Industry
abstract: A Soviet editor whose newspaper has been at the front of an officially inspired campaign for more openness in public life was promoted today to run the publishing industry.

headline: THE NEW FRENCH CABINET
abstract: Following is a list of Cabinet members in the new French Government, with party affiliation and some background: Prime Minister - Jacques Chirac, Rally for the Republic, Mayor of Paris. Foreign Affairs - Jean-Bernard Raimond, unaffiliated career diplomat, most recently Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; DIFFERING SIGNALS OVER THE DOLLAR
abstract: The dollar has fallen enough, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, told a Congressional panel, a comment that sent ripples through the markets and held broad implications for future monetary policy. It also indicated a split with Administration views, since a day earlier Treasury Secretary James A Baker 3d had said the dollar should fall still further. Although the two men sought to play down their disagreements, it was clear that they are at odds over how to control the economy. Mr. Baker believes the lower the dollar, the more help to the trade deficit and thus the budget deficit. Mr. Volcker believes a dollar that is too low will rekindle inflation. Lower interest rates, within the Fed's realm of control, would tend to force the dollar lower, and Mr. Volcker is not partial to that course.  Currency markets were tugged between Mr. Volcker and Mr. Baker. The dollar halted its three-week decline after Mr, Volcker's testimony, but drifted in confusion when Mr. Baker reiterated his position.

headline: Gannett Back In Audit Unit
abstract: Fourteen Gannett Company newspapers that pulled out of the Audit Bureau of Circulations in a dispute over how circulation figures are calculated will reinstate their memberships, the company said.   The decision followed a meeting between executives of Gannett and an audit bureau liaison committee that included executives from other newspapers and newspaper chains, Gannett said on Wednesday.

headline: SLAP FROM ENVOY'S WIFE
abstract: Sondra Gotlieb, the wife of the Canadian Ambassador, and one of the best known members of the diplomatic community here, was reported today to have slapped her social secretary in the face in public on Wednesday night.   Witnesses said the incident occurred on the front steps of the embassy residence as the two women awaited the arrival of Vice President Bush at a dinner for the Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney.

headline: O.E.C.D. Inflation Data
abstract: Inflation in the main non-Communist industrial nations slowed to 4.6 percent in 1985, from 5.3 percent in 1984, its lowest rise in 17 years, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

headline: LONDON FINANCIAL DISTRICT GOING TO THE ISLE OF DOGS
abstract: The Isle of Dogs, a thumb-shaped peninsula that jabs into the Thames River just east of the Tower of London, was once a landscape of ships' funnels, cranes and pubs, the home of the West India Docks and gateway to the British Empire. Then came the decline of the empire, the death of the docks and, since 1945, an exodus of 200,000 people.   Now, with a swiftness that has startled many, a new landscape is taking shape to serve an expanding financial empire hard-pressed for space in the mile-square City of London, only two miles away.   Ten million square feet of office, hotel and retail space, including three huge towers, are planned for the Isle of Dogs on a 71-acre site at Canary Wharf at a cost of $2 billion. At least 40,000 people would be employed there.

headline: TAKING MEASURE OF AMERICANS
abstract: In a suburb of Philadelphia, a group of sociologists and statisticians is collecting the measurements of thousands of Americans. Their goal: to establish new size standards for American clothing.   But even when they finish taking the measure of the modern American - and collapsing the information into a set of updated standards - consumers may see little of their handiwork.   For although the American Society for Testing and Materials is working at the behest of the Federal Government, it is meeting resistance from manufacturers who have all but ignored standards for years, preferring to establish clothes - and sizes - in their own images.

headline: 2 UNITS SOLD BY ALCOA
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America said it had sold two of its subsidiaries - the Rea Magnet Wire Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Algonquin Industries of Guilford, Conn. -to a management group for an amount under $50 million. The sale is part of a redeployment of assets.

headline: A DATA BASE FOR THE FORGETFUL
abstract: Of all the business software available for personal computers today, probably none are more intimidating to the average user than data base managers. Writers write, after all, so they at least comprehend what a word-processing program is supposed to do. Accountants and other number crunchers gladly allowed computerized spreadsheets to replace their pencils, not to mention erasers. But does anyone actually think of himself as a data base manager?   For the occasional user of data base software, the problem is compounded by spending a month conquering the rudiments of, say, dBase III and then not using it for a while. The intrepid computerist returns to the software only to discover that, because of the program's complexity, the homecoming is more like having to start the learning process all over again. That is precisely the situation Practibase ($99 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles from Practicorp International, Newton Upper Falls, Mass. 02164, (617) 965-9870) addresses - and on the whole succeeds in remedying.

headline: U.S. WEIGHS ASSIGNING WARSHIPS TO ESCORT DUTY IN THE PERSIAN GULF
abstract: The Administration is considering assigning Navy warships to escort American merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf to prevent another boarding by armed Iranians, State Department officials said today.   Administration officials acknowledged that Washington was caught off guard on Sunday when an Iranian Navy ship forced an American freighter, the President Taylor, to stop in the Gulf of Oman and submit to a search for war materiel for Iraq.   When no such goods were found, the freighter was allowed to proceed to Fujaira, its desination in the United Arab Emirates. Possible Future Course    A possible future course of action, officials said, would be for the United States to declare that the cargoes of American merchant ships were free of war materiel for Iraq and to authorize Navy warships to use force if necessary to keep the Iranians away. This could lead to a confrontation with the Iranians if they pressed their right to board a ship, but Administration officials said they did not believe the Iranians force the issue.

headline: SMALL BANK REVIVES URBAN AREA
abstract: In 1973, when many urban banks were eagerly lending money as far afield as South America, officials at Chicago's South Shore Bank had a vision closer to home - to revitalize 265 square blocks in a decaying community on the city's South Side.   At the time, South Shore looked to many like a bank interested more in charity than in profits. Yet by lending aggressively to the inner city while other banks shunned the idea, South Shore has not only turned the community around, but has made some money, too.   Though small, with $114 million in assets as of Sept. 30, the bank has been hailed by some urban experts as a prime example of a big-city bank that successfully engineered the turnaround of a community's decline. With South Shore's help, builders in the lakefront community about eight miles south of downtown Chicago have returned to their original grace more than 30 percent of South Shore's turn-of-the-century red brick apartment buildings and almost all of the area's homes.

headline: 3 KILLED AS SIKHS MARCH ON PUNJAB LEGISLATURE
abstract: At least three people were killed and 25 wounded today in the capital of Punjab State, where the police battled hundreds of militant Sikhs who tried to march on the state legislature.   Many arrests were reported.

headline: INQUIRIES ON MARCOS RAISING ISSUE OF PROSECUTION IN U.S.
abstract: The fall of Ferdinand E. Marcos has spawned or intensified several investigations of his personal and governmental dealings, raising the potential question of whether Mr. Marcos himself could face prosecution, Administration officials said today.   The officials said Mr. Marcos was given no immunity from either civil or criminal charges when he fled the Philippines and entered this country. But they said the issue posed difficult foreign policy issues, since legal action against him could hinder the ability of the United States to work for the departure of dictators from other countries in the future.   ''If we're faced with a situation like the Philippines, what kind of options are going to be open to us if we prosecute Marcos?'' one official asked.

headline: Co-founder Sells More Apple Stock
abstract: Steven P. Jobs, co-founder and former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., has sold another 885,000 shares in the company. The sales occurred between Feb. 3 and Feb. 24 for prices from $22.79 to $25.25, according to reports of filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Jobs could not be reached for comment on the sale, and it was unclear how many shares he still owns.   After losing a power struggle last summer with John Sculley, who he had originally hired away from Pepsico Inc. to be Apple's president, Mr. Jobs left the company and started a new venture called Next.

headline: SOUTH YEMEN LOYALISTS REPORTED HOLDING ON
abstract: Fierce fighting still raged today between factions of Southern Yemen's ruling Marxist party, according to refugees arriving in the African nation.   The refugees and other sources said President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani was apparently barricaded in an isolated section of Aden, the Southern Yemeni capital.   Southern Yemen, which has the only self-professed Marxist Government in the Arab world, is a close ally of the Soviet Union, which has naval bases and 1,000 personnel stationed there.   The fighting has pitted factions of the ruling Yemeni Socialist Party in a power struggle that experts say appears to be reverting to traditional tribal warfare.

headline: A PROLIFERATION OF SPACE CONFERENCES
abstract: USED to be, the Canaveral Council of Technical Societies' annual Space Congress in Orlando, Fla., was the only chance that space buffs had to gather together. Not any more. A rash of splashy space conferences and symposiums are now covering subjects ranging from how to raise capital for a space venture to how to go about marketing space-related products.

headline: MARCOS SAYS HE QUIT TO STOP CARNAGE
abstract: Speaking publicly for the first time since he was deposed as President of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he had decided to surrender power despite having ''overwhelming force'' in order to avoid ''the bloody carnage of our innocent civilians.''   ''I have been called, perhaps immodestly, brave in my time, but brave as I may have been against foreign invaders, I had no heart to shed Filipino blood,'' Mr. Marcos said in what he called ''a letter to the Filipino people'' read to about 150 journalists here this afternoon.   ''My life has been devoted to the upliftment of the Filipino by re-establishing his identity and dignity after centuries of repression. And so, knowing I could lose everything if I did not use military power, I chose my authority over such military powers to protect the Filipino people.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * American Airlines Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million of units through Morgan Stanley & Co. The units consist of a debenture and a warrant to buy the common stock of its parent, the AMR Corporation.    * Avco Financial Services Inc. is offering $100 million of Baa-2/A- rated, 8 7/8 percent noncallable senior subordinated notes due 1996 at 99.834 to yield 8.90 percent, through Kidder, Peabody.    * Barclays American Corp. is offering $100 million of A-1/AA rated 8 1/8 percent 10-year notes at 98 to yield 8.42 percent, through Goldman, Sachs.

headline: Chip Makers Report Gains
abstract: Electronic chip manufacturers in the United States, Europe and Japan have reported gains in orders and shipments for December.

headline: INVESTING; GIVING YOUR I.R.A. TO A MONEY MANAGER
abstract: IN the 1970's, when cash was surging into corporate pension funds, some investment managers would not touch any account of less than $10 million, and concentrated on the giant funds such as those of Xerox and International Business Machines. Even in recent years, many money managers have looked askance at small investors, reserving their advice - and their fees - for institutions or rich individuals. Mario Gabelli's firm, Gamco Investors, for instance, maintained a strict minimum account of $250,000.  But now, the explosion of individual retirement accounts, the contraction in the growth rate of corporate pension assets and the stunning expansion - and burgeoning popularity - of mutual funds, have made the individual investor the belle of the investing ball.

headline: New Sybron Offer
abstract: The Sybron Corporation, a maker of medical and scientific supplies, said it received a new leveraged buyout offer of $24 for each common share and $38.40 for each preferred share, or a total of about $265 million. The offer is on behalf of a new corporation to be formed by Montgomery Medical Ventures, an affiliate of Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage, and the Morgan Capital Corporation, an affiliate of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

headline: REBELS IN UGANDA TAKE CONTROL OF CAPITAL, BUT BATTLES CONTINUE
abstract: Western diplomats here said today that rebel troops were virtually in control of Kampala, Uganda's capital, and that fighting was continuing in and around the city.   But telephone and telex links between Nairobi and Kampala were cut this morning, and it was virtually impossible to obtain firsthand verification of the situation. Embassies in Uganda used radio to contact their diplomatic missions here.   ''Kampala is in N.R.A. hands,'' a radio transmission to the British High Commission in Nairobi said tonight, referring to the guerrilla force, the National Resistance Army. ''There are still pockets of resistance,'' the report said. ''Things have quieted down, but there is still shooting.''

headline: Salvador Guerrillas Tell Of Killing a Mayor
abstract: El Salvador's leftist guerrillas said today that they had killed a mayor and several municipal officials for crimes against the people and vowed to begin a campaign to put common criminals to death.   The rebel announcement, which was made on Radio Venceremos, said the killings were carried out in 1984 and December 1983.

headline: Bangladesh Bank Plan
abstract: Bangladesh hopes to increase its foreign-exchange earnings by allowing offshore banking in its free trade zone near Chittagong, the central bank said today. Offshore banking units would be allowed to accept deposits in 10 currencies.

headline: Politburo Member Is Elected To Be the Premier of Bulgaria
abstract: Georgi I. Atanasov, a member of the Communist Party Politburo, was elected Prime Minister of Bulgaria by Parliament on Friday, the official Bulgarian press agency reported.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 15, 1986
abstract: The Economy    New-car sales fell 8.3 percent in early January from year-earlier levels, despite renewed incentives, Detroit's car makers said. Light-truck sales dropped 19.2 percent. Analysts were disappointed, saying sales are still feeling the effects of the surge brought on by sales incentives in August and September.  [ Page D1. ]  Retail sales rose 1.9 percent in December, spurred by a rebound in auto demand then.  [ D4. ]  Americans took on $4.88 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in November, the smallest increase in more than two years.  [ D2. ]    Automatic spending cuts will force widespread curtailments in most non-military Federal programs. They will also cut the military budget for the first time in 13 years.  [ A1. ]

headline: U.S. BRIEF ON UNITARY TAX
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it had filed a court brief contending that California's unitary tax on foreign corporations violates the United States Constitution.   The brief, filed in Federal District Court in Chicago, says the unitary method interferes with the conduct of American foreign policy because it has become a source of conflict with foreign nations.

headline: TIMES MIRROR
abstract: The Times Mirror Company began offering $100 million of 8 1/4 percent, 10-year notes at a price of par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes, which are noncallable for the first seven years, are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P. They are offered to yield about 56-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Soviet Frees 3 Activists
abstract: Three members of a self-styled Soviet peace group have been released from detention, a member of the group, Aleksandr Rubchenko, said today. He identified the three freed members of the organization, the Group for Establishing Trust Between the U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R., as Viktor Smirnov, Nina Kovalenko and Irina Pankratova. Mr. Rubchenko said three others were still in jail - Aleksandr Shatravka, Vladimir Brodsky and Annetta Fadeyeva.

headline: Black Policeman Killed In Anti-Apartheid Unrest
abstract: A black policeman was killed and set afire and another black man was shot dead in anti-apartheid unrest reported today.

headline: CENTER STAGE FOR SYRIA
abstract: Developments in recent weeks, including the recent meeting between King Hussein of Jordan and Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, have again shown the ability of Mr. Assad to move his country to the forefront of Middle East politics. Diplomats here and in   Damascus say Syria has been brought to this position primarily by Mr. Assad's patient, single-minded and sometimes ruthless pursuit of his goal of establishing what he sees as Syria's historic role of dominance in the area.   In recent weeks, Mr. Assad has achieved three major coups:    * The installation of sophisticated Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles along his border and in the Bekaa region of Lebanon, to challenge Israeli reconnaissance flights.    * The signing of a Syrian-sponsored peace agreement between Lebanon's three main private armies, a move designed to end more than 10 years of civil war.

headline: GROWTH IN G.N.P. 0.7% IN 4th QUARTER
abstract: The economy slumped to a sluggish growth rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent from October through December, the Commerce Department reported today in its third downward revision of that quarter's performance.   The weakness pushed growth for the full year down to 2.2 percent, the slowest pace since a 2.5 percent decline in the recession year of 1982.   According to provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law, if G.N.P. growth falls below 1 percent for two consecutive quarters, Congress must vote on a resolution to suspend the law for the current and the next fiscal years.

headline: Advertising; Carl Byoir Appoints A Domestic President
abstract: In addition to being president of the New York office of Carl Byoir & Associates, a major international public realtions company, William W. Galvin 3d will also be president of the domestic company, a newly created job title. It will put him in charge of 10 regional offices and 18 affiliates.

headline: Peru Rejects I.M.F. Order
abstract: President Alan Garcia Perez has rejected a deadline he said the International Monetary Fund issued regarding repayment of Peru's debt arrears.

headline: 10-DAY AUTO SALES RISE 11%
abstract: New-car sales rose 11 percent in mid-February over the 1985 period, the nation's major auto makers reported today. The increase came as some companies closed out low-interest-rate financing programs.   The jump brought the daily selling rate to the second best ever for the Feb. 11-20 period.

headline: A FILM'S 'TYPICAL AMERICAN' ASKS WHY SOME SAY HE ISN'T
abstract: The United Nations film shows a young Russian pole-vaulter, his face bright against the background of a war memorial, running and finally hurling himself over a crossbar. Later, shown training children, he turns to the camera and says, ''There is no other sport that requires so much.''   The film then turns to a church in a low-income neighborhood in Queens, where a young black man is leading a children's choir. The young man is also shown studying in school, cooking for an elderly and disabled neighbor and working as a security guard. When asked why he is working so hard, he says he is trying to help ''myself as well as my family out financially.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Banctec Inc., Dallas, which makes document and information processing systems, has promoted Nort A. Stuart to executive vice president, operations, and William E. Bassett to senior vice president, customer services.    * Bell Savings and Loan Association, San Mateo, Calif., has appointed James V. Wheeless senior vice president.    * Better Book Inc., a publishing company based in San Francisco, has elected Walter D. Roach president, succeeding Donald G. Wolff, who becomes chairman and continues as chief executive officer.

headline: ISRAELIS ASKING WHY ONLY THEY MUST RETALIATE
abstract: Israeli officials expressed satisfaction today with America's apparent support for retaliation over the Rome and Vienna airport attacks, but raised questions about why Israel alone should bear the burden for responding to international terrorism.   Although they are very pleased to have the United States support, many Israeli officials are increasingly uncomfortable with the idea that they should be the exclusive ''world policemen'' for a rash of terrorism that has affected citizens of many countries, especially the United States. No Longer the Only Target   Senior Israeli officials quickly add that the questions they are raising should not be interpreted as precluding retaliation by Israel alone.   But they say that much of what the world is witnessing is state-sponsored terrorism that can be countered only by state-sponsored economic and diplomatic sanctions, and that Israel is no longer the only target of terrorists - who seem just as ready to kill Americans or West Europeans in the Palestinian cause. Their questions also probably reflect a degree of exhaustion in Israel with bearing the political and military costs of fighting terrorism for so many years. touched on these themes - particularly the failure of other countries to impose sanctions against nations that are known to support terrorist groups - in a strikingly low-key address he delivered today to the Israeli Parliament on the Rome and Vienna attacks.

headline: THE S.E.C. MAY PAY INFORMANTS
abstract: John S. R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency might begin to offer cash rewards for information about people who manipulate stock prices by spreading false rumors or who profit by insider trading.   ''We are looking into using some form of awards to informants,'' Mr. Shad said in an interview. But he added that the inquiry was ''very preliminary'' and that he did not know how much would be offered to informants.

headline: Reston Land Venture
abstract: The Reston Land Corporation, said that it was forming a partnership with the Boston-based Himmel/MKDG real estate development and investment firm to design and build an 85-acre urban center in the planned community of Reston, Va. Himmel/ MKDG has been involved in the development of similar projects such as Boston's Copley Place, Chicago's Water Tower Place and Denver's City Center.

headline: Nisshin Steel, Wheeling Pact
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said it signed agreements today with the Nisshin Steel Company of Japan to build a $65 million plant for coating sheet steel. The venture had been delayed since October 1983 by the American company's financial trouble.

headline: LIBYAN HIGH SCHOOL'S 3 R'S: READING, WRITING, ROCKETRY
abstract: Mohammed el-Aref, 15 years old, studies algebra, chemistry and literature at his neighborhood high school in Tripoli. He also has weekly lessons in rocket launching, hand grenade tossing, signals and communication, and machine gun assembly and maintenance.   ''Military courses are my favorite because they help me defend my country against its enemies - Americans, Zionists and imperialists everywhere,'' Mohammed said.   He is one of 2,000 boys, from 15 to 18 years old, at the Ali Awarith Secondary School in Tripoli. This, Libyan officials said, is a typical high school in the Libya of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO ORDER NEW NAVAL MOVES OFF LIBYA
abstract: The Reagan Administration has ordered two aircraft carrier battle groups to resume military maneuvers in the area of the Gulf of Sidra off the Libyan coast, a senior Government official said today.   The official said the aircraft carriers Coral Sea and the Saratoga and their support vessels, which are now on liberty in Italian ports, would arrive in the gulf region in about a week. The two carrier groups were sent to the region last month for a week of exercises that American officials said were designed to assert a right to operate in the area.

headline: Seeking Profits Via Bond Index
abstract: IT was time to take cover in the bond market last week as prices of tax-exempt, or municipal, bonds abruptly headed south and sentiment soured.   However, not all was gloomy. The municipal bond index futures contract, a complicated derivative instrument, offered a number of opportunities to profit even in the falling market. It was, in short, a good occasion for the contract to demonstrate its utility as well as its relative immaturity.

headline: THE PRICE OF OIL
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Refiners Breathe a Sigh of Relief'' (Feb. 23), Winston Williams makes two points with which I disagree.   First, he says that lower-cost crude oil as a result of lower prices will help refiners in their competition with low-priced refined imports. This assumes - incorrectly - that the price of refined products would not fall as much as other oil prices.

headline: HIGH COURT TO GET A CASE ON WHALING
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Government's appeal of a court order that it restrict Japanese fishing rights in American waters because of Japan's whaling activities.   The Government argued that the ruling, in a Federal appellate decision, interfered with ''the President's pre-eminent role in the conduct of foreign affairs'' and ''would have serious for-eign relations implications'' unless reversed.   The lower court, in a victory for a coalition of private wildlife organizations, said a 1979 law was intended to require the Government to impose tough, specified sanctions against any nation that failed to follow the International Whaling Commission policies designed to end the decimation of whales, especially scarce sperm whales.

headline: A FRENCH TV CREW IS SEIZED IN BEIRUT
abstract: Four French television crew members were abducted in West Beirut on Saturday, and an anonymous telephone caller said today that they had been seized by the Islamic Holy War organization.   The same shadowy fundamentalist group said last week that it had killed a Frenchman it had held for 10 months.   In a call to a Western news agency here today, an Arabic-speaking man said Islamic Holy War wanted to question the French television crew about what he termed its ''suspicious movements in the Islamic suburbs.''   The call came as a senior French diplomat arrived to investigate the abductions of French citizens in West Beirut, the predominantly Moslem part of the capital, in the last year.

headline: German Trade Surplus Rises to Record Level
abstract: West Germany recorded a trade surplus of $30.5 billion last year, its largest ever, according to preliminary statistics released today. The country's exports rose 10 percent in 1985, to $223.7 billion, while imports climbed 6.8 percent, to $193.2 billion.   The West German Government also issued a forecast for 1986 today that foresees moderately strong economic growth, low inflation and reduced unemployment.

headline: Leucadia Raises Stake in GATX
abstract: The Leucadia National Corporation said it had raised its stake in the GATX Corporation from 5.2 percent to the equivalent of 6.3 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Leucadia said it is considering acquiring some GATX assets and has entered into a standstill agreement with GATX in order to receive confidential information from the Chicago-based rail car leasing and shipping company.

headline: LIBYA: TEST OF WILLS
abstract: The military clash between Libya and the United States during the last two days represents a confluence of varied elements. On the surface, it is the American assertion of its right of passage through international waters in conflict with Libya's territorial claims.   But on a deeper level, it has been a strike against what Washington says is Libya's support of terrorism, and against the image of a United States helpless to deal with a provocative figure such as the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.  The Administration's action appears to have been carefully calibrated and timed to minimize political risk, both in Soviet-American relations and in the Middle East.

headline: XEROX SEEKS AGENCY FOR DOMESTIC ACCOUNT
abstract: The Xerox Corporation, in the person of Michael E. G. Kirby, its director of corporate advertising and promotion, confirmed yesterday that it was already involved in the selection process to find a replacement domestic agency for Needham Harper Worldwide, which has served it for 18 years. Mr. Kirby made it plain that the move in no way affects the relationship between Needham and the Xerox operating companies that retain Needham elsewhere in the world.   He said that the relationship had been ''long and fruitful'' but that a decision to change was made because ''we felt it was time to look for new ideas and approaches to meet our future advertising needs.''

headline: Fermenta Stock Halt
abstract: The director of the Stockholm Bourse, Bengt Ryden, said that the management of the biotechnology company Fermenta A.B. had requested that trading in its stock be suspended Friday after the stock exchange began an inquiry into the past month's trading.   He said the company would have to provide more information and make what he described as necessary clarifications as to why the share price had fluctuated so sharply since the group announced a linkup with A.B. Volvo on Jan. 8.

headline: Pacific Lumber Wins a Ruling
abstract: A last-ditch attempt by six dissident stockholders of the Pacific Lumber Company to block the $832 million takeover of the timber giant by Maxxam Group Inc. has been rejected by a Federal judge, who said the buyout was in the stockholders' interest.

headline: REBELLION COMES AFTER YEARS OF RESTIVENESS AND FRUSTRATION IN THE MILITARY
abstract: The troops that stepped from loyalist ranks tonight to resist President Ferdinand E. Marcos demonstrated to the nation and the world the intense pressures that have built up within the military during Mr. Marcos's 20 years in power.   The military, where Mr. Marcos began as a national hero, remains the key to his attempt to remain in power. As Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos made their stand in the Ministry of Defense headquarters, they were throwing down the gauntlet against Mr. Marcos and his most trusted military man, the formidable Gen. Fabian C. Ver.   Whatever the sudden move lacked in strategic wisdom, it instantly proved a popular success. Crowds of civilians anxiously gathered outside the ministry, offering cheers and food.

headline: PHILIPPINES PUTS MARCOS HOLDINGS IN THE BILLIONS
abstract: The Philippine Government said today that it had documents linking former President Ferdinand E. Marcos to overseas property holdings whose worth could be in the billions of dollars.   One set of documents being investigated appears to tie two New York real estate investors, Ralph and Joseph Bernstein, to holdings by the Marcos family.   The House of Representatives voted last Thursday to cite the Bernstein brothers for contempt for not answering questions about their relationships or business dealings with Mr. Marcos and his wife, Imelda. The vote on Ralph Bernstein was 352 to 34, and the vote on Joseph Bernstein was 343 to 50. Some Justices Said to Quit   In another matter, there were unconfirmed reports that some justices on the Philippine Supreme Court had resigned, as President Corazon C. Aquino has demanded. But Mrs. Aquino's close advisers said they had not had word that any resignations had been tendered, although they said such a move might come soon.

headline: HNG/INTERNORTH WITHDRAWS NOTES
abstract: A proposed $200 million offering of 9 3/4 percent notes due 1992 has been withdrawn by HNG/Internorth Inc., following the nationalization last Friday of its Belco Petroleum unit by the Peruvian Government.

headline: U.S. WILL SELL 40 FIGHTER JETS TO THE GREEKS
abstract: The United States and Greece have signed an agreement for protecting military technology that opens the way for the sale of 40 F-16 fighter planes to Greece, a State Department official said today.   The sale of two squadrons of the advanced planes had been pending for more than a year, the official said. The Administration's decision to go ahead with the sale followed Greece's agreement, worked out in the last several months, to sign what is called the General Security of Military Information Agreement, the official said. Worrying Over Greek Security   The State Department official said there had been concern in the Administration, particularly at the Defense Department, over Greece's ability to protect advanced military technology from Soviet agents.

headline: Uganda Rebels Advance To Kampala's Outskirts
abstract: Ugandan rebel forces advanced to the outskirts of Kampala today and an army barracks in the capital was reported shelled.   The developments came a day after Government soldiers went on a rampage in which six people, including four schoolchildren, were killed.

headline: MANILA DELAYS THE RELEASE OF FOUR JAILED COMMUNISTS
abstract: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino said today that it was delaying the release of four Communist guerrilla leaders arrested by the Marcos regime until their cases could be further examined. Among them is Jose Maria Sison, the founder and former head of the Philippine Communist Party.   But 441 other prisoners classified as political detainees began to be freed today from 12 detention centers around the country. Officials say that they are hoping to complete the release in a few days, but that heavy paperwork has made the process very slow.

headline: CLASSLESS SOVIET FAR OFF, PAPER SAYS
abstract: A leading Soviet economist has published an article asserting that economic opportunity in the Soviet Union is still determined to a large extent by a person's social status, connections and geographic location.   The article, published last Thursday in Sovetskaya Kultura, a cultural newspaper, offered a less favorable assessment than the Government's usual one about the Soviet Union's progress toward becoming the classless Communist society outlined in Marxist theory.   The Government usually acknowledges that economic disparities between urban centers and rural areas continue, but contends that here, unlike in capitalist societies, other sources of economic inequity have been largely eased.   The economist, Tatyana Zaslavskaya, wrote a report that was disclosed to Western reporters in 1983 that called for decentralization of the Soviet economy. The report, initially printed in 70 numbered copies, was never widely distributed in the Soviet Union.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, has elected to its board Paul H. O'Neill, president of the International Paper Co.    * American Brands Inc., a packaged goods and services company, has elected to its board Norman E. Auerbach, former chairman and chief executive officer of Coopers & Lybrand.

headline: GETTING BAD NEWS AT THE TOP
abstract: The discovery that vital information apparently never got to top officials during the ill-fated launching of the space shuttle Challenger is a failure of a sort not unknown in business circles.   Fears that cold weather could cause problems for the solid-fuel rocket boosters apparently never reached top officials who made the final ''go'' decision, although the Morton Thiokol engineers familiar with the boosters were not afraid to suggest the shuttle should be delayed.   Indeed, the engineers argued their point heatedly. But managers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who heard those concerns apparently did not relay them to NASA's top officials.   In fact, chief executives everywhere face a constant struggle to get bad news in front of them before it becomes a matter of crisis proportions.

headline: DOW CLIMBS 18.81, TO RECORD 1,570.99
abstract: Finishing up a week of impressive gains, the Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply yesterday to a record level in continued brisk trading.   Yesterday's volume of 143.5 million shares made January the busiest month in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 2.87 billion shares changing hands. December had held the record, with 2.8 billion shares.   But while volume remained impressive yesterday, traders and market analysts said blue-chip stocks rose mainly because of technical buying programs coming from the major financial institutions. Larry Wachtel of Prudential-Bache Securities said he counted a dozen such buying programs in the morning alone.

headline: The U.N. Today: Feb. 11, 1986
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the Situation in Southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Associated Madison Companies, holding company for the financial services subsidiaries of the American Can Company, based in Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Paul A. Finkel senior vice president and chief financial officer.    * British Columbia Resources Investment Corp., a producer of pulp, lumber, oil and gas based in Vancouver, has named Bruce Howe chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding Walter Riva.

headline: January 12, 1986
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: HOLIDAY STOCK SALE
abstract: The Holiday Corporation, the largest hotel company in the world, said the estate of William F. Harrah and a trust created under his will to benefit his sons would sell one million Holiday Corporation common shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Holiday said the estate obtained the shares in exchange for convertible debentures issued to it when Holiday Inns Inc., a subsidiary, acquired the Harrah's Casino Gaming Company in 1980. Holiday will receive no proceeds from the sale, a company spokesman said.

headline: OCCIDENTAL GETS PERU PACTS
abstract: Peru has signed two oil exploration and operation contracts with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation over the vocal objections of the country's sizable Marxist opposition.   The accord, signed Saturday, supersedes a contract that the Government scrapped last August with United States-based Occidental in a dispute over United States tax credits.

headline: Robins Judge Stays on Case
abstract: United States District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. refused to disqualify himself yesterday from the A. H. Robins Company bankruptcy case, in which thousands of women are claiming damages for injuries they say was caused by the Dalkon Shield birth control device.   Several of the lawyers representing the women had asked Judge Merhige to step down from the case because of his contacts and ties to the Robins family.

headline: A SHOPPERS' PARADISE ON THE PRAIRIE
abstract: ADECADE ago, Joan Didion, the author, wrote in a magazine article that if she owned a shopping center, ''I would have monkeys and Chinese restaurants and Mylar kites and bands of small girls playing tambourines.'' Let her come to Edmonton. Here on the northern fringe of Canada's flat, frigid prairie is a shopping center calculated to dazzle. There are monkeys, Siberian tiger cubs and 544 different kinds of trees taller than 12 feet. Four submarines prowl a 438-foot-long lake infested by real sharks.There's a roller coaster more than 13 stories high and a $5 million hockey rink where superstar Wayne Gretzky practices with the Edmonton Oilers.   Catch your breath. We're talking about West Edmonton Mall, the biggest shopping center in the world. Built by the Ghermezians, four mysterious Iranian brothers, the $640 million mall is not even finished yet. Soon to be completed is a ''water park'' as big as five football fields, where surfers will ride six-foot waves 360 feet across and visitors can tan themselves, all year round, under a giant artificial sun. Also rising is the $35 million, 360-room Fantasyland Hotel, complete with theme quarters. Guests in the Polynesian rooms will float on warrior catamarans-turned-into beds, for example, while homegrown cowboy types can sleep in a bed fashioned from a pickup truck.

headline: Textron to Sell Bostitch Unit
abstract: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Bostitch division to the Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., for about $193 million.   Bostitch, which makes industrial and consumer staplers and fasteners, reported sales of more than $200 million in 1985.

headline: The U.N. Today: March 5, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Expert Group on Accounting and Reporting Standards - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: SOVIET CONGRESS IS URGING ECONOMIC CHANGES
abstract: The Communist Party congress approved a resolution today calling for ''truly revolutionary changes'' in the economy.   The resolution, the main policy statement of the 27th congress, endorsed almost word for word the demand for changes made in speeches by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov.   Although all the decisions made beforehand by the Soviet leadership, the resolution will nevertheless serve as the touchstone for domestic and foreign policy for the next five years.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: SMALL TRADES FUELED RISE IN PENNZOIL
abstract: A trade-by-trade analysis of Tuesday's activity in the stock of the Pennzoil Company shows that a large number of modest-sized individual trades fueled the stock's explosive rise of more than 30 percent.   This surprised some market professionals, who said they had expected that large block trades of institutional investors or major arbitrage firms would have been responsible. The trading pattern suggested to some that smaller professional traders were leading the charge.

headline: MARCOS IN HAWAII
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino began her first full day as President of the Philippines Wednesday by naming 17 Cabinet members, conferring with defeated rival politicians and holding her first presidential news conference.   Early today, Mrs. Aquino's top military aide urged her to release 33 political prisoners. He also said the Government was studying another 400 cases.  [ Page A16. ]  Mrs. Aquino's first steps to put her presidency into motion began a day after Ferdinand E. Marcos left the Philippines aboard an American military plane. The deposed President, his wife, Imelda, and about two dozen close associates arrived Wednesday at Hickam Air Force Base, Hawaii, after a flight from Guam.  [ Page A15. ]  'Time to Heal Wounds'   At her election campaign headquarters, Mrs. Aquino worked throughout the day Wednesday to select her Cabinet, with more ministers expected to be named today. She met with a dozen Cabinet ministers from Mr. Marcos's disbanded Government and told them it was ''time to heal wounds and forget the past.''

headline: PATENTS; Inventions Rose in '85
abstract: ABOUT 3,000 more patents were granted in 1985 than in 1984, with a number of inventors filing from abroad. They included many Japanese and even a few Soviet citizens.

headline: INVESTORS FACE UNCERTAINTIES
abstract: The credit markets, fraught with uncertainty for much of the new year, will start getting answers to some of its questions this week.   Among other things, over the next five days investors and traders will find out if the market can absorb a huge supply of new Treasury notes and bonds.   Following the release of the Reagan Administration's budget for 1987 and the Democratic response to it, market participants should have a better sense of how bloody - or constructive - the fiscal policy making process is likely to be this year.   In a related event, at some point this week an indication may come from a court in the District of Columbia about the future status of a piece of legislation that spurred great enthusiasm in the markets during the fourth quarter, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings bill, which would impose automatic spending cuts if Federal budget deficits do not shrink toward zero by 1991.

headline: A BIAS TOWARD BAD GOVERNMENT?
abstract: THEY work mostly in an unimposing one-story brick bulding near the edge of campus and under a banner that seems almost deliberately unrevealing. This is an economic research operation in the shadow of Washington whose thinkers do not study policy options, rarely testify before Congressional committees and seem to mind not at all that their public recognition quotient is virtually zero.   Yet James M. Buchanan, Gordon Tullock and their small band of disciples at the Center for the Study of Public Choice are the fomenters of a quiet revolution in politico-economic thinking. They are not a policy organization, but one that focuses on the political process - ''on structure, on how the rules work and how they can be changed,'' according to Professor Buchanan.   In their writings and seminars, however, they have been the heralds of less: less government, less regulation, less debt through lower deficits. After years of ry scurity, the proponents of public choice have found their place in the sun during the conservative Reagan era. But they believe their growing support goes far beyond partisan politics; they call themselves proponents of powerful ideas whose time has come. They have had some supporters in previous Administrations and insist that their influence would continue even if the next President were a Democrat.

headline: INDUSTRY'S M.I.S. ROMANCE
abstract: WHEN Barry Miller began as a data programmer at Western Electric, the manufacturing division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, few opportunities existed for a computer specialist to make strategic decisions. But now as a management information systems director at Hapag Lloyd of America, a subsidiary of the German shipping company, he coordinates development and operations of all the company's information systems.   As computer-service divisions have moved from the back offices to a central role in the planning and managing of companies, employees with computer skills and an understanding of internal data management have become a valuable commodity.   The field is management information systems, popularly known as M.I.S., and it is one of the fastest-growing of all. The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that the number of systems analysts, a mid-level M.I.S. position, increased from 205,000 in 1980 to 359,000 in 1985 and is expected to grow to 520,000 in the next decade. Additionally, many businesses have made M.I.S. directors vice presidents, which in many cases has tripled the number of employees reporting to them. ''There is a big demand for individuals trained in M.I.S.,'' said Jack Ahlin, director of management department information systems and administration for the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: SOVIET REPORTED ACTING TO BEGIN NEW ATOM TESTS
abstract: The Soviet Union has started preparations for the possible resumption of nuclear weapons testing, Reagan Administration officials said today.   Satellite reconnaissance photographs show the Soviet Union has been digging holes and tunnels in which nuclear explosives can be placed and moving monitoring equipment into a test area, according to officials who have seen secret intelligence reports.   The Soviet Union announced last July 30, a few days after conducting a nuclear test, that it was halting its testing program and urged the United States to join in. The United States refused on the ground that it had to catch up with Soviet weapons development.

headline: ON AN ANGOLAN STREET, TRACES OF A RICHER PAST
abstract: A decade ago Portuguese colonialists would sit at sidewalk cafes on the Marginal, sipping coffee and reading yesterday's newspapers from Lisbon.   One recent day on the Marginal, a sandy-haired man could be seen dozing in a jeep, a copy of Pravda lying folded and unread at his side.   Curving along a crescent bay, the Marginal has long been the urban centerpiece and the human heartbeat of this tropical capital. If Luanda was once the Rio de Janeiro of West Africa, then the Marginal was its Copacabana.

headline: TWIN CALIFORNIA PORTS THRIVE
abstract: When Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo discovered San Pedro Bay in 1542, he was so unimpressed by the shallow, muddy inlet that he promptly left. It was centuries before the bay came into its own as one of the world's great ports.   Now the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, which are managed separately by the two cities but are side by side in San Pedro Bay, make up the fastest-growing cargo center in the world. And, according to J. Ronald Brinson, president of the American Association of Port Authorities, they are also among the most profitable.

headline: LUGAR TO LEAD PHILIPPINE OBSERVERS
abstract: The White House today asked Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, to lead an official delegation of American observers to be sent to the presidential election in the Philippines, Reagan Administration officials said.   Senate sources said Mr. Lugar was asked to lead the delegation by Secretary of State George P. Shultz after Mr. Shultz met with President Reagan in the Oval Office this afternoon to discuss the Philippine election and other issues.   Mr. Shultz told Mr. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, that Mr. Reagan had received a formal request today from President Ferdinand E. Marcos that an official American delegation visit the Philippines to monitor the election.   The White House, which had been scheduled to make public the names of the American delegation today, delayed the announcement. Officials said that the list was ''not yet composed'' and that the final details would be worked out early next week.

headline: New Chief Chosen At Martin Marietta
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the aerospace contractor, said yesterday that Norman R. Augustine, executive vice president, will become president and chief executive officer, effective April 1.   Mr. Augustine, who is 50 years old, succeeds Laurence J. Adams, who turns 65 in March. Mr. Adams, who joined Martin Marietta 38 years ago, is credited with helping to fend off a hostile takeover bid from the Bendix Corporation in 1982. Thomas G. Pownall, 64, remains chairman of the Bethesda, Md., company.

headline: MANDELA FORECASTS HUSBAND'S RELEASE
abstract: Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed black nationalist Nelson Mandela, forecast today that her husband would be freed but said she did not know when or where.   She spoke on her return here from Cape Town, where she visited Mr. Mandela today against a backdrop of intense newspaper speculation here that his release was imminent.   In other developments, the police said three black policemen were shot dead when they sought to intervene in a tribal dispute south of Durban that claimed six more lives. In Honeydew, north of Johannesburg, meanwhile, the police said they were looking for a group of whites who opened fire in unprovoked attacks on blacks Saturday.

headline: FRENCH ROTHSCHILDS AWAIT RIGHTIST WIN
abstract: Two bearers of the best-known name in French banking work away in a modern Paris office on the Avenue Matignon, waiting for the day when they can put that name back on their front door.   ''I'd like to see Rothschild Freres back on the door soon,'' said David de Rothschild. ''It will show the family has reestablished a small, sound investment bank here again.''   Four years after France's socialists nationalized the Rothschilds' Paris bank, David and his cousin Eric de Rothschild are reenacting a recurrent role in French history - awaiting the restoration of an older order. They are hoping to restore the French family's banking fortunes and counting on a victory for the conservative opposition in this month's French elections will help them do it.

headline: South Korea Detains Dissident a 3d Time
