abstract: The dissident leader Kim Young Sam was again placed under house arrest early today as President Chun Doo Hwan's Government continued efforts to thwart an opposition campaign to change the country's Constitution.   It was the third time in a week that Mr. Kim, 58 years old, was subjected to house arrest.

headline: CORPORATIONS INUNDATE BOND MARKET
abstract: With bond yields at their lowest level since 1978, large corporations are returning to the long-term debt market in droves. New bond issues totaled more than $5 billion last week, and securities dealers expected the heavy supply to continue in coming weeks.   Besides the low interest rates on new bond issues, corporate treasurers are attracted by the relative narrow difference between the interest cost on short-term borrowings and the cost of a new bond issue. By repaying variable rate bank loans and commercial paper with proceeds of fixed-rate, long-term bonds, corporate balance sheets are strengthened and financial officers will have less to worry about the next time short-term interest rates rise.

headline: PLANNING INVESTMENTS IN FACE OF TAX REVISION
abstract: With Congress at work on a plan to restructure the income tax system, Americans may have more decisions to make over the next few months than just those associated with filling out their returns.   The tax revision efforts on Capitol Hill will not affect 1985 returns in any way. But the proposals could well affect many of the financial transactions taxpayers enter into in 1986.   For many people, the proposals on the table could influence such basic financial decisions as whether to make an early deposit to an Individual Retirement Account, or invest in a tax shelter, municipal bond or a particular stock.   Although the Senate has yet to begin drafting its own tax plan, the House of Representatives started the clock running two months ago, when it approved a sweeping blueprint for revamping the tax code. Most of the provisions were assigned an effective date of Jan. 1, 1986.

headline: INVESTOR AIDS EUROPEAN WESTLAND OFFER
abstract: A bid by the United Technologies Corporation and Fiat S.p.A. to rescue Britain's financially troubled helicopter maker, Westland P.L.C., has been set back by large purchases of the company's stock by an investor advocating a rival European offer.   Analysts and investment bankers said today that it now appeared unlikely that the United Technologies-Fiat offer would receive enough votes from shareholders to succeed. To be approved, the bailout plan would have to be endorsed by 75 percent of Westland's shareholders at a special meeting scheduled for next Tuesday.

headline: PATENT CASE PLEA LOST BY KODAK
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company lost its battle yesterday to remain in the instant photography business.   Justice Lewis F. Powell of the Supreme Court denied Kodak's last-minute appeal for a stay of an injunction that orders Kodak out of the business by today.   Hours earlier, a Federal appeals court panel denied Kodak's request to lift the injunction.   The injunction was issued by Federal Judge Rya Zobel in Boston in October and was to go into effect today.

headline: SCHRARANSKY TELLS HOW HE CLUNG TO PSALMS CAPTORS TRIED TO SEIZE
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, describing his release from a Soviet labor camp, said today that he had flung himself into the snow and refused to continue on his way because his escorts tried to confiscate a book of Psalms that his wife had sent him from Israel.   ''They took all my possessions from me,'' he said on Israeli television, speaking in Hebrew. ''I said I would not leave the country without the Psalms, which helped me so much. I lay down in the snow and said, 'Not another step.' ''

headline: LITTLE MOVE IN 2 OIL STOCKS PREDICTED
abstract: Analysts expect a moderate rise in the value of the stock of Texaco Inc. and a slight fall in that of the Pennzoil Company today as a result of a Federal judge's ruling Friday. The judge said Texaco would not have to post a $12 billion bond to appeal a Texas jury's verdict against it.   ''What will happen today is very simple,'' said Andrew Gray 3d of the Pershing & Company division of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''Texaco stock is going to go up a little, and Pennzoil stock is going to go down a little. I don't expect substantial movement in either one.''

headline: ALTMAN IS SAID TO OFFER TOP POST TO DALLAS RETAILER
abstract: Jack Schultz, the general merchandise manager for women's apparel at the Sanger-Harris department stores in Dallas, has been offered the post of president of the B. Altman stores based in New York, according to retail trade sources.   Lewis C. Kaufman, who is now president of Altman, has held the post for several years. It was not clear whether he would retire or move to another job if a new president was named.

headline: Lecture by Farrakhan Is Prohibited in Nigeria
abstract: A scheduled public lecture by the American Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan was barred today by the authorities. No reason was given.

headline: Merrill Unit Is Realigned
abstract: Merrill Lynch Futures has decided to fold most of its operations into divisions of its parent company, Merrill Lynch & Company, a senior executive said yesterday.   John J. Conheeny, chairman of Merrill Lynch Futures, said his division would continue to exist after the reorganization, but its retail offices would be absorbed by the consumer markets division of the parent, and its commodities research staff would be folded into Merrill's research unit.

headline: DUVALIER ACCUSED OF GRAFT ON FOOD
abstract: Haiti's new Government has charged that the Duvalier family received millions of dollars annually by overcharging Haitians for staple foods, including products donated by the United States.   Most dramatically, in a country of wide starvation, officials said, the family established a system of profiteering in the sale of flour.   Finance Minister Marcel Leger said that for every sack of flour produced by the country's only flour mill, which is state-owned, $1 was sent to the palace without passing through the Treasury. He added that the mill produced 2.5 million sacks a year, and each 1,000-pound sack cost about $25.

headline: Bolivian Floods Kill 2
abstract: Heavy rains and rising waters from Lake Titicaca have killed at least two farmers, destroyed the crops of 140,000 Aymara Indians and caused $54 million damage, the Civil Defense Board said today. Waters from the lake, the highest navigable lake in the world at 12,506 feet above sea level, have risen nine feet the last two weeks from the heaviest rains of the region this century, the authorities said. Reports from Puno, on the Peruvian side of the lake, indicate that tens of thousands of Peruvians have lost crops, livestock and homes in the flooding.

headline: TEXT OF FILIPINO BISHOPS' STATEMENT ON VOTE
abstract: Following is the text of the statement today by the Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines:   The people have spoken. Or have tried to. Despite the obstacles thrown in the way of their speaking freely, we, the bishops, believe that on the basis of our assessment as pastors of the recently concluded polls, what they attempted to say is clear enough.

headline: Indiana Utility
abstract: The Public Service Company of Indiana said it had avoided default after winning a two-week extension on a $150 million credit agreement with a consortium of banks. A Public Service spokesman, Chris Combs, said company officials obtained the postponement late Sunday and would ask the consortium of 22 banks to extend the agreement through April.

headline: FRANCE BOMBS A REBEL AIRFIELD IN CHAD
abstract: French Air Force planes today bombarded an airfield that was a hub for supplying Libyan-supported rebels in northern Chad, Defense Minister Paul Quiles said.   Mr. Quiles said the French planes had hit the runway of the airfield at Wadi Doum, deep inside territory controlled by the rebel groups fighting the Government of Hissen Habre.   After the bombing raid, 200 French Air Force commandos arrived in Chad's capital, Ndjamena, to defend the airport there, officials said. There have been no French troops in Chad since France withdrew its forces from the country 15 months ago.

headline: Gas Access Deadline Delay
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission yesterday postponed the deadline by which natural gas pipelines have to decide whether to open their lines to all producers, including those offering cheap gas. The commission voted 3 to 1 to move the deadline from Saturday, to July 1.

headline: U.S. STEEL NET LIFTED BY OIL UNIT
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 96.6 percent, to $57 million, from $29 million a year earlier. Sales were virtually flat near $4.7 billion, and the company's basic steel operations showed a loss, so U.S. Steel got a big boost from its Marathon Oil Company subsidiary, analysts said.   They added that the company's results, while better than those at many other steel makers, were still considered modest.

headline: AN UNSETTLING QUESTION AT ROME TRIAL
abstract: A prosecutor's request for acquittal in the trial over the shooting of the Pope has raised the uncomfortable question of how Italy could hold a Bulgarian defendant for more than three years when the state's own prosecutor now admits there was insufficient evidence for conviction.   The proposal by the prosecutor, Antonio Marini - that the Bulgarian, Sergei I. Antonov, and two other Bulgarian defendants, who are being tried in absentia, be ''absolved for lack of proof'' - would not amount to full absolution. Their defense attorneys have protested the proposal, demanding a full declaration of innocence.   But the recommendation, made to the jury of two judges and six lay jurors who will get the case after nearly nine months of intense debate, constituted an admission that the evidence against the Bulgarians was ambiguous at best.

headline: Houston Bank in Loss
abstract: Texas Commerce Banchares today reported a $28.8 million loss for the fourth quarter, in contrast to earnings of $44.7 million for the 1984 quarter.

headline: Imperial Drops Takeover Bid
abstract: Imperial Group P.L.C., the large British tobacco, beer and food company, said Friday that it was abandoning a bid for United Biscuits P.L.C. afer the Government referred the proposed merger to the National Monopolies and Mergers Commission.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
abstract: International    OPEC ministers were deadlocked again on a plan to halt plunging oil prices but plan to meet again today for a ninth session. Ministers from several countries apparently rejected a complicated system of quotas under an overall production ceiling of 14 million barrels a day.  [ Page A11. ]  The drop in oil prices and OPEC's declining power are providing Israel an economic bonanza, as well as bringing diplomatic and political benefits.  [ A1. ]

headline: Sri Lanka Imposes Curfew
abstract: A 15-hour curfew was imposed on nine tea-growing areas of central Sri Lanka today after Tamil tea plantation workers went on strike and looting erupted. The Defense Ministry said security forces fired on looters in the town of Talawakele, killing one and wounding another.

headline: Economic Scene; Policy Issues' Tie to Business
abstract: THE business outlook for the next couple of years depends crucially on the outcome of a set of key policy issues. First comes the battle of the budget. The Gramm-Rudman law faces a constitutional test before the Supreme Court. But many economists believe that, whatever happens to the law, fiscal policy will soon be tighter. But how much tighter is difficult to say.   The Congressional Budget Office says President Reagan has underestimated military spending and that his budget for the fiscal year 1987 is $15.7 billion over the Gramm-Rudman deficit limit of $144 billion.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: SOLARZ APPLAUDED AND JEERED BY MANILA STUDENTS
abstract: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a longtime critic of Ferdinand E. Marcos, received some jeers amid applause today when he addressed students at the University of the Philippines.   The applause, which included embraces from the mother and sister of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the assassinated husband of President Corazon C. Aquino, acknowledged Mr. Solarz's campaign to uncover ownership by Mr. Marcos of properties in the United States.   The jeers came from students opposed to United States involvement in the Philippines who displayed signs reading ''Respect Philippine Sovereignty'' and ''American Junk - Get Out of Our System.''

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT AT THE WHITE HOUSE
abstract: Following is a transcript of an interview with President Reagan on Friday by R. W. Apple Jr., Gerald M. Boyd and Bernard Weinraub of The New York Times:   Policy on Philippines Q. Thanks very much for seeing us. We appreciate that. We're going to ask several foreign policy questions and domestic after. I thought maybe, if possible, we'd start with the Philippines and that whole area.   Sir, several Administration officials were quoted as saying that they were disgusted at what they found in Mr. Marcos's luggage when he came to Hawaii. Do you share their surprise about the scale of his overall corruption when he was leader of the Philippines?   A. Well, I'll tell you, I'm not going to comment on that. I think here, now, we're talking about something that is - there are legalities involved. And I think, rather than comment on that, our interest is in continuing our friendship, historic friendship with the Philippines, and I'm going to let the law and justice take its course. And we'll abide by the laws, but also, that will involve not just hearsay and gossip and so forth, but a determination of what's actually happened. I'll wait for that.

headline: FOREIGN MINISTRY COMING ALIVE WITH LAUREL
abstract: Accompanied by a bell-choir of telephones this morning, the press room clerks at the Philippine Foreign Ministry were putting up a map of the world - a sure sign, someone suggested, that this somnolent department was going to be a different place under Salvador H. Laurel.   Upstairs, in a forlorn office with a barren desk, Foreign Minister Laurel, who is also Vice President and Prime Minister of the new Government, met his first major foreign delegation.   The visitors had come from China to sign a cultural agreement, and Mr. Laurel took the opportunity to outline his priorities for revitalizing the country's foreign policy after years of its subjection to the personalities of the Marcoses. As squabbles within the coalition now in power in Manila concentrate on domestic political issues and the division of appointments, Mr. Laurel is free, commentators say, to create a highly visible role for himself in foreign affairs.

headline: U.S. MONTHLY DEFICIT FALLS
abstract: The monthly Federal budget deficit was $6.49 billion in January, down 56 percent from the December imbalance, the Government said today.   Even with the sharp decline, the deficit for the first four months of the fiscal year was 2.7 percent ahead of last year's pace, when the deficit surged to a record of $212.3 billion for the year.

headline: Retail Sales Up a Slim 0.1%
abstract: Retail sales rose a mere one-tenth of 1 percent in January as setbacks at department stores and clothing stores offset strong demand for new autos, the Commerce Department reported today.   The January performance was the poorest since sales plummeted 3.9 percent in October after auto makers ended a round of financing incentives.   Auto sales showed a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, reflecting a resumption of the financing deals. But sales at department stores dropped a sharp 2 percent, the second monthly decline. Total consumer sales climbed to $117.5 billion, adjusted for seasonal variation.

headline: CHURCH ACTIVISM RAISES QUESTION OF POPE'S STAND
abstract: Vatican officials said today that the vocal part played by the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines had raised difficult questions about the church's political role and about Pope John Paul II's campaign to distance priests from political activity.   But the Vatican generally welcomed the outcome of the struggle, in which President Ferdinand E. Marcos was deposed.   ''At the end, the thing was for the best,'' a high Vatican official said. ''Up to this moment, I think everyone in the world has a feeling of relief.''   The only official comment today came from the Pope himself, whose statements on the conflict had been remarkably cautious.

headline: Pepsico Had Slight Dip In 4th-Quarter Profits
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter dipped three-tenths of 1 percent as revenues rose 10 percent.   Pepsico, the second-largest soft-drink company after the Coca-Cola Company, said that net income in the latest three months declined to $89.3 million, or $1 a share, from $89.6 million, or 95 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales increased to $2.42 billion, from $2.20 billion.

headline: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL WARNS LIBYANS
abstract: A senior State Department official explicitly warned for the first time today that the Administration would consider military action against Libya if the nonmilitary sanctions already imposed by Washington fail to achieve results.   The official, John C. Whitehead, Deputy Secretary of State, said President Reagan ''reserved the right'' to use military force against Libya if Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi ''doesn't change the pattern of his actions.''   Mr. Whitehead made his remarks in a news conference reporting on his recent trip to rally support for actions against Libya among the allies. 'Cannot Tolerate' Qaddafi    He said that until Colonel Qaddafi ''changes his conduct'' in support of terrorists, ''it seems to me that Americans cannot tolerate a man living in this world, as part of the world community, and condoning these actions.''

headline: Meese Weighs Texaco Battle
abstract: The Justice Department is studying separate requests by Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company for it to enter the legal battle between the companies, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said at a news conference in Washington.   Sources close to Pennzoil have said the company believes the Reagan Administration might agree with its argument against a decision last week by United States District Judge Charles L. Brieant, who freed Texaco from having to post a $12 billion bond to appeal the case in Texas courts.

headline: OFFSHORE DRILLER IN CHAPTER 11
abstract: Citing the sudden plunge in oil prices last week, Global Marine Inc. filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.   The Houston-based offshore drilling contractor, which has 35 rigs worldwide, thus became the first major victim of the largely unexpected rapid slide in world oil prices. The company plans to keep operating.   Global Marine, in default on its $1.1 billion debt since last summer, had been holding discussions with its 37 secured creditors - mostly foreign banks and insurance companies -seeking to restructure payments.

headline: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ GETS A SQUIBB ACCOUNT
abstract: E. R. Squibb & Sons of Princeton, N.J., has hired Penchina, Selkowitz as the first consumer agency for the Dignity line of products from its Convatee division.

headline: G.E.'S INCOME UP 1.2% IN 4TH QUARTER
abstract: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter edged up 1.2 percent on a 9.4 increase in sales.   The electrical products and financial services company said net income increased to $660 million, or $1.45 a share, from $652 million, or $1.44 a share, in the 1984 quarter.

headline: U.S. Information Aide Is to Confer in Moscow
abstract: Charles Z. Wick, Director of the United States Information Agency, will leave Sunday for a two-week trip to the Soviet Union to discuss implementation of cultural accords, the U.S.I.A. announced today.   Mr. Wick will meet with Soviet officials to discuss the accords signed by President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, at their summit meeting in Geneva last November.

headline: BONN AIDE URGES MISSILE DEFENSES
abstract: The West German Defense Minister urged Western Europe today to develop its own antimissile system independently of the United States' space-based defense program.   The official, Manfred Worner, said at a meeting of national security experts that a separate Western European program was imperative because of potential Soviet advances in short-range missiles.   His remarks come at a time when Western Europeans seem to be expressing less skepticism about the United States' missile defense plans.   Senator William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican who is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said in the conference that Western European doubts ''have not disappeared, though they are less intense.''

headline: Reagan and U.N. Chief To Meet on Budget Ills
abstract: President Reagan will meet Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar at the White House on Friday to discuss the world organization's financial crisis, the United Nations announced today.   A United Nations spokesman said the visit was suggested in January by Vernon A. Walters, the American delegate, when United Nations officials told him that legislation recently passed by Congress would cause serious financial problems for the United Nations and cause the United States to violate its treaty obligations.

headline: PHILIPPINE BASES SEE A LONG STRIKE
abstract: A weeklong strike by Philippine workers has undercut normal operations at the United States naval and air bases in this country, and a military commander warned today that labor troubles could last ''quite a while.''   After a burst of violence in the first few hours last Friday, the strike has generally been peaceful. But lingering tensions sparked several clashes today between American servicemen and Philippine pickets blockading the gates to Subic Bay Naval Base in Olongapo and Clark Air Base in Angeles.

headline: PANAMA REBUFFS MARCOS, CITING NATIONAL SECURITY
abstract: Citing national security concerns, Panama formally rejected a request for asylum from former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos today.   Government officials would not explain the security issue, but they apparently felt that the presence of Mr. Marcos would further inflame the domestic political situation.   In a meeting with reporters in which the rejection was announced, the presidential press secretary, Guillermo Antonio Adames, denied that the United States had pressured Panama to accept Mr. Marcos.

headline: G.M.A.C. Offer
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $250 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due 1991 at a price of 99.70, to yield 8.95 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, which are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's, are priced to yield 44-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

headline: Kohl's Party Sustains Losses in Bonn Vote
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrat Party sustained heavy losses today in the first of a series of electoral tests prior to Mr. Kohl's bid for re-election next January.

headline: DIRECTORS CLEAR REPUBLIC BID
abstract: The directors of the Republic Health Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest publicly held health services company, have agreed in principle to a leveraged buyout led by three company executives for $19.25 a share in cash and notes, or a total of $335 million.   The acquisition will be completed through a merger between Republic Health and Pesch & Company, a New York investment firm.

headline: Italian Experts Report Bullet In the Head Killed Klinghoffer
abstract: Italian medical and ballistic experts confirmed today that Leon Klinghoffer, the American slain in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, was shot twice before his body was thrown into the Mediterranean.   An official report by an army ballistics expert and three medical professors who carried out a post-mortem on the body of Mr. Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old New Yorker, did not say who had fired the shots.

headline: Girl Killed in Beirut Fighting
abstract: A girl was killed and several people were reported wounded in battles between rival militias across the Green Line dividing the eastern and western sectors of the city today. About 250 militiamen from 10 pro-Syrian groups, meanwhile, took up five positions in West Beirut to help the army and the police keep order and prevent further fighting between the Communists and the Moslem radical Hezbollah faction.

headline: LEADERS TRAVEL TO STOCKHOLM FOR FUNERAL AND DIPLOMACY
abstract: Foreign leaders and delegations converged here today for the funeral of Olof Palme, the assassinated Prime Minister. The funeral promises to provide an occasion for high-level diplomatic contacts on subjects ranging from Soviet-American relations to southern Africa.

headline: THE STAKES ARE HIGH IN SPAIN'S NATO VOTE
abstract: A producer for Spanish television had insisted for weeks that she would vote to pull Spain out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the coming referendum.   But today, the eve of the vote, she has undergone a change of mind, if not of heart. She was opposed out of principle to military blocs, she said. But now she is afraid that Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, who backs NATO, might fall from power if he loses. Somewhat sheepishly, she added that she has also become half-convinced that NATO membership is better for Spain.

headline: Coca-Cola Deal For Shows Seen
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce soon, possibly today, that it has agreed to buy some of the assets of Merv Griffin Enterprises, including the popular television game show ''Wheel of Fortune,'' television industry sources said.

headline: A Comparison Of Indicators
abstract: How closely does the Dow Jones industrial average track the stock market as a whole?   A comparison of it and the New York Stock Exchange's index of common stocks and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shows that the Dow outperforms those broader measures in a disinflationary environment, such as the one now.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: LIBYA HOLDING MANEUVERS AS 6TH FLEET NEARS
abstract: Libya announced today that its navy, air force and air defense units had started a week of maneuvers with live ammunition within the Tripoli area.   The announcement, broadcast on radio and television, said the maneuvers began at noon and might continue until Feb. 16. No explanation was given. Diplomats said it was unusual for maneuvers to be conducted with live ammunition.

headline: EX-FINANCE MINISTER RETURNS TO A WARM WELCOME IN HAITI
abstract: Marc Bazin, a former Haitian Finance Minister, has come home to an enthusiastic welcome four years after he was dismissed by the Duvalier regime because of his attempts to curb Government corruption.

headline: B.P.-Iran Pact
abstract: Iran has paid the British Petroleum Company more than $120 million to settle claims arising from the 1979 Islamic revolution there, oil industry sources said.

headline: U.S. AIDES SEE CHANCE OF PACT ON AVOIDING WAR IN EUROPE
abstract: Eastern bloc and Western nations may be close to an agreement at the Stockholm conference on ways to reduce the risk of war in Europe, American officials say.   The conference, which reconvened Tuesday, is considering measures that would require each side to give notification of military maneuvers and information about its forces in Europe.   An agreement could be the first East-West arms control accord since the signing of the second strategic arms agreement in 1979. Progress at the talks could also encourage success at the next summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, later this year, according to Robert L. Barry, the American delegate to the conference.

headline: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; Shifting Personal Strategies
abstract: WITH Congress drawing up plans to overhaul the income-tax system, 1986 could be a watershed year in Federal tax policy. A restructuring would not only change individuals' tax bills, but would also alter the relative economic merits of a broad spectrum of investments and financial transactions, forcing major rethinking of traditional tax-planning strategies.   Tax shelters - be they real estate, oil and gas or equipment-leasing ventures - would lose much of their allure. Tax-exempt municipal bonds would also have less intrinsic appeal under a system of lower tax rates, but money-market funds, bank accounts and corporate and Government bonds would gain new sparkle. And parents would no longer be able to use custodial accounts as a tax-saving scheme to shift income to their younger children.

headline: Kaiser Aluminum In Credit Pact
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had signed a new credit agreement that consolidates into a single debt agreement its total bank debt of about $1 billion, which had been previously covered under a variety of agreements with approximately 40 domestic and foreign banks. The new agreement also provides for a $165 million, four-year revolving credit, the company said.

headline: ADDING BRAINS TO A SIMPLE MACHINE
abstract: THE technology gap between electronic typewriters and their electric predecessors seems to get wider all the time.   Electronic typewriters now have one-tenth the number of moving parts of motor-driven electrics. They are virtually silent, and as much as $20 per machine cheaper to make than the most sophisticated electrics, according to Dataquest Inc., a market research firm. And, perhaps most important, they can do things that conventional typewriters cannot do -a fact that undoubtedly helped sales of electronic typewriters surpass those of electrics for the first time last year.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 21, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. SECURITY COUNCIL    Meets at 11 A.M. on situation in the occupied Arab territories.

headline: TEXT OF THE REAGAN MESSAGE TO CONGRESS ON FOREIGN POLICY
abstract: Following is the text of President Reagan's message, titled ''Freedom, Regional Security and Global Peace,'' which was sent to Congress today:   I. America's Stake in Regional Security For more than two generations the United States has pursued a global foreign policy. Both the causes and consequences of World War II made clear to all Americans that our participation in world affairs, for the rest of the century and beyond, would have to go beyond just the protection of our national territory against direct invasion.   We had learned the painful lessons of the 1930's, that there could be no safety in isolation from the rest of the world. Our nation has responsibilities and security interests beyond our borders - in the rest of this hemisphere, in Europe, in the Pacific, in the Middle East and in other regions - that require strong, confident and consistent American leadership.   In the past several weeks, we have met these responsibilities - in difficult circumstances - in Haiti and in the Philippines. We have made important proposals for peace in Central America and southern Africa.

headline: Singer Acquisition
abstract: The Singer Company said that it had agreed to acquire the Dalmo Victor division from Textron Inc. for $174 million.

headline: REAGAN SAYS SUPPORT FOR THE CONTRAS MUST GO BEYOND 'BAND-AIDS'
abstract: President Reagan said today that the United States must do more to assist the Nicaraguan rebels, saying they could not fight the Government in Managua with ''Band-Aids and mosquito nets.''   Marking the start of a campaign to secure military financing for the rebels, Mr. Reagan said Congress must lift restrictions that prohibit such assistance and must increase nonlethal aid to the rebels.   Mr. Reagan's remarks, at the start of a meeting with Republican Congressional leaders, came as Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, asserted that Nicaragua had recently received a ''massive influx'' of sophisticated weapons from the Soviet Union and Cuba. He said the weapons had caused ''quite a toll in dead and wounded.''

headline: Citizenship in Belize May Soon Be for Sale
abstract: Belizean citizenship will be for sale under a plan proposed by Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel.   A person wanting citizenship in this former British colony in Central America could obtain it by buying a $25,000 Government bond, which would be worth only $12,500 to the buyer because the Government would keep half the money.

headline: PLAN TO AID F.S.L.I.C. IS OUTLINED
abstract: A senior Treasury official recommended today that the 12 regional banks of the Federal Home Loan Bank system shore up the depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation with hundreds of millions of dollars of loans or investments.   With some $10 billion in capital, the 12 banks, which provide long-term liquidity to savings and loan associations, are considered the strongest segment of the thrift industry.   In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, George D. Gould, the Treasury's Under Secretary for Finance, endorsed what many regulators and banking experts have been saying for months: that the the Home Loan Banks must play a central role in recapitalizing the insurance fund. The fund faces possible losses of $15 billion from the liquidation of 461 insolvent thrift institutions that have been allowed to remain open but might have to be dissolved.

headline: 3M Sues Ampad
abstract: The Ampad Corporation said that the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company had filed suit against it, charging patent infringement by Ampad's Clingers stick-on note product. The company, a leading manufacturer of paper products, said it believes that Clingers does not infringe any patents held by 3M for that company's Post-It product and that the suit was without merit.

headline: HIGH COURT TO DECIDE LIQUOR SUIT
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a New York State law that restricts discounting by liquor retailers violated Federal antitrust laws.   The Justices accepted an appeal from a ruling by the New York Court of Appeals at the urging of a Manhattan liquor retailing company convicted of violating the state law by selling at too low a price. The Justice Department, as a friend of the court, urged the Court to strike down the law, which regulates only the prices of distilled spirits, not those of wine and beer.   Both the retailing company, 324 Liquor Corp., which does business in Manhattan as Yorkshire Wine & Spirits at 324 East 86th Street, and the Justice Department said New York's regulatory setup amounted to illegal resale price-fixing because it allowed liquor wholesalers effectively to dictate artificially high retail prices.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Daimler
abstract: To the Editor:   I was intrigued by what was not said in ''Daimler Races Into High Tech'' (Dec. 15). Surely the company wants to stay abreast of technological developments in the automotive industry.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The World Bank yesterday offered $200 million of triple-A-rated 8 7/8 percent non-callable 40-year bonds at a price of 99.831 to yield 8.89 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The financing was the bank's first 40-year offering and its first in the American bond market since December 1984.

headline: HAITIAN JUNTA LETS FORMER POLICE CHIEF LEAVE
abstract: The new ruling junta of Haiti has permitted the former head of the secret police, one of the country's most feared men, to leave for political asylum in Brazil.   The move, bitterly resented by Haitians, is likely to affect the credibility of the Government, which has already been criticized because of the high number of officials of the deposed Duvalier regime in its ranks.   Escorted by soldiers and policemen, the police chief, Col. Albert Pierre, and his wife boarded a private Lear jet for Panama on Sunday night. A spokesman at the Brazilian Embassy said Colonel Pierre had been granted political asylum in Brazil.

headline: TOYOTA WILL RAISE U.S. PRICES BY 3%
abstract: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it would raise the suggested retail price of Toyota cars and trucks by an average of 3 percent because of the strength of the yen against the dollar.

headline: Botha Declines Meeting With Churchmen
abstract: President P. W. Botha, citing a tight schedule and lack of warning, declined to meet today with a delegation of leading anti-Government churchmen, including Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, to discuss South Africa's latest violence.

headline: Insider Parole Guidelines
abstract: The United States Parole Commission voted unanimously today to more than double the time in prison anyone convicted of insider trading must serve to be eligible for parole. The new guidelines are effective April 1.

headline: AQUINO HELPS TO MOURN AN OPTIMISTIC POLITICIAN
abstract: Relatives, friends and a throng of political believers stood at a mass of mourning here today for Evelio Javier, a politician and teacher considered by some of his friends as too much the optimist to survive in the lethal world of Filipino politics.   On Tuesday Mr. Javier was shot to death after six masked gunmen chased him through the streets of San Jose.   Corazon C. Aquino, hailed by the congregation as the ''President-elect,'' joined the packed church in singing ''The Impossible Dream,'' a song to which Mr. Javier often referred in his campaigns. The bullet-riddled body of Mr. Javier, one of her campaign leaders, rested in a white coffin open before the altar.

headline: DOW JONES SEEKS TO BAR TAKEOVERS
abstract: Dow Jones & Company said it would seek shareholder approval of several anti-takeover proposals at its annual meeting on April 16. The measures provide for a staggered board and what the company described as a ''fair price'' provision that would require a potential purchaser to make the same offer to all shareholders.

headline: P.L.O. SAID TO CONSIDER ENDING PACT WIOTH JORDAN
abstract: A senior Palestinian guerrilla official says the Palestine Liberation Organization is considering scrapping an agreement with Jordan in order to head off what the official called attempts by King Hussein to create a substitute Palestinian leadership. King Hussein has already scrapped the year-old accord.   The official, Yasir Abed Rabbo, deputy head of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, said scrapping the accord would also clear the way for talks designed to heal the rift in Palestinian ranks. Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, signed the accord with King Hussein on Feb. 11, 1985.

headline: MOTHERS SOBS WITH RELIEF AT THE NEWS
abstract: ''Tolya is free, God Almighty, Tolya is free!'' Anatoly B. Shcharansky's mother exclaimed today, her wrinkled face beaming, wet with tears.   For nine years, the woman, Ida P. Milgrom, had addressed appeals to the authorities at all levels of the Soviet state. A small, slight woman, now 77 years old, she had stood in the cold outside the prison of Chistopol, in the Tatar republic, demanding to see the warden, she had traveled thousands of miles for rare meetings with her son, she had suffered through months with no word from him.   She refused suggestions that she emigrate. She believed she had to remain as long as Anatoly was in prison. Assisted by her older son, Leonid, she struggled to find out what she could of her son's plight, to demand meetings and letters, to complain of his treatment and to appeal for his release. She and Leonid worked, at the same time, to keep the world informed of Anatoly's condition.

headline: Variety of Issues Set for U.S. Auction
abstract: The Treasury will auction a variety of short- and long-term issues this week, starting with today's offering of three- and six-month bills totaling $14.8 billion.   On Tuesday, the Treasury has scheduled a $6.5 billion auction of new seven-year notes due Jan. 15, 1993, followed on Wednesday by $4.75 billion of 20-year bonds due Feb. 15, 2006. The note and bond financing will raise $11.25 billion of new money to finance the Federal budget deficit.   Late Friday, the outstanding three-month bills were bid at a rate of 7.09 percent, while the outstanding six-month issue was bid at 7.14 percent. Securities dealers offered the seven-year notes on a when-issued basis with a 8.88 percent yield, while the 20-year issue was offered at 9.46 percent.

headline: American Medical
abstract: An investment group led by the Bass family of Fort Worth said it had raised its stake in American Medical International Inc. from 10.2 percent, to 11.4 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group did not amend its previously reported position that it held the shares for investment purposes only.

headline: ELECTROLUX'S OFFER REJECTED BY WHITE
abstract: White Consolidated Industries, hoping for a higher bid, said yesterday that it had rejected a buyout offer of $45 a share, or $711 million, from A.B. Electrolux of Sweden.  White, the nation's third-largest maker of major home appliances, said that in any sale of the company ''more than $45 a share should be obtainable for the stockholders.''

headline: AN ERA ENDS AT CONTROL DATA
abstract: William C. Norris, a giant figure in the history of the computer industry, retired today as chairman and chief executive of the Control Data Corporation, a company he founded and headed for 29 years but which is now in a fight for its life.   Robert M. Price, president and chief operating officer, was named to replace Mr. Norris. Mr. Price will also retain the title of president.   Mr. Price faces ''an extremely arduous, demanding task'' in leading the ailing company, said Michael Geran, an analyst with E. F. Hutton. ''No one's ever restructured a $5 billion company in the computer industry like this before.''

headline: PERU WARNS ON RETALIATION
abstract: President Alan Garcia Perez has warned that his hard-line foreign debt stance could drive the world banking community to retaliate with stiff, unprecedented sanctions against Peru.   He said last night that some private foreign banks could attach Peruvian exports abroad and the International Monetary Fund could try to block loans from all foreign creditors.

headline: Eagle to Cut 23 Employees
abstract: Eagle Computer Inc., which is struggling to raise capital to keep its operations afloat and bring its newest product, the Concorde, to market, said today that it would lay off 23 of its 83 employees as of Wednesday.   The personal-computer maker also said that it had not found an investor to provide a cash infusion to speed production of its Concorde project.

headline: AFTER 36 HOURS, 2 ARE RESCUED FROM THE RUINS IN SINGAPORE
abstract: More than 36 hours after being buried in the collapse of a six-story hotel here, two men were pulled alive from the wreckage late Sunday night. It took six hours to free them once they had been located.   The dramatic rescue came as hundreds of soldiers, firefighters and volunteer civil defense brigades sifted through a mountain of concrete, twisted iron, tiles and furniture, spurred on by faint voices. Rescuers hoped to free at least seven more people believed to be still alive in the demolished building. From the sound of his voice, one of them appeared to be a little boy.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Standard Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Mosler Safe Co. to a new company owned by an affiliate of Kelso & Co., Mosler's management and an employee stock plan.

headline: U.S. BACKS LATIN PEACE EFFORT BUT STILL SEEKS TO ARM REBELS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that they took a positive view of efforts in recent days to revive the peace process known as Contadora, but that they would continue to seek military aid for the rebels fighting Nicaragua's Government.   At the same time, they repeated that the United States would not resume direct talks with the Nicaraguan Government until the Sandinistas open a dialogue with the rebels. They also announced that the Administration's special envoy to the region, Harry W. Shlaudeman, would begin a visit next week.

headline: Pennzoil Files Court Memo
abstract: The Pennzoil Company asked a Federal court in White Plains yesterday not to allow a group of seven Texaco shareholders to intervene in its legal battle to collect $10.53 billion plus interest from Texaco Inc. A group of seven Texaco retirees filed a motion with Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant earlier this month.

headline: Bush Going to Honduras
abstract: Vice President Bush will lead the United States delegation to the inauguration of Jose Azcona del Hoyo as the new President of Honduras on Jan. 27, it was announced today. ''The United States is pleased to mark this event as evidence of the strengthening of the democratic process in Central America,'' the Presidential spokesman, Larry Speakes, said.

headline: TO THE MOUNTIE, FAR NORTH FEELS LIKE HILL STREET
abstract: One tense day last June, Cpl. Robert H. Peterson of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police faced down a drunken gunman.   Corporal Peterson, the sole law official in this desolate hamlet 60 miles north of the Arctic Circle, learned that two men had gotten drunk and stolen the local firetruck, and were speeding around shooting at windows. When Corporal Peterson found the truck, which was stuck in a ditch, one man stepped out with a shotgun, took aim and announced, ''I'm going to kill you.''

headline: NL Studying Coniston Bid
abstract: NL Industries, which has received a proposal from Coniston Partners to acquire the company, said it was studying the financial and legal issues raised by the offer. The oilfield services and chemical company, based in New York, said it would continue ''its evaluation of alternatives available to it.''

headline: ROME PROSECUTOR URGES ACQUITTAL OF 3 BULGARIANS
abstract: An Italian prosecutor called today for the acquittal of three former Bulgarian officials accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II.   But at the same time, the prosecutor maintained that the court had not allowed him to argue his case fully, and he seemed to urge the jury to ignore his recommendation and convict the Bulgarians anyway.   He also asked for life sentences for two Turkish defendants in the case and shorter sentences for two other Turks. Jury of 8 Includes 2 Judges    Next month, the case will go the jury, composed of two judges and six lay jurors. Five votes are required for a verdict.

headline: WINNER IN UGANDA
abstract: When Yoweri Museveni was sworn in Wednesday as President of Uganda, viewing the ceremony on the steps of Parliament were scores of children who had served as his soldiers.   As he plunged into the enthusiastic crowd and then drove away in the trappings of prestige and power - a black Mercedes-Benz - a 12-year-old was asked why he had become a child of war.   ''I fight for Uganda,'' the boy, Sylaz Kazzora, said. Dressed in a camouflage jacket, tattered corduroy pants and shoes that could best be described as bathroom slippers, he slung his rifle casually over one shoulder and held a cigarette on his lips.

headline: WOMEN HONOR AQUINO AND CALL FOR HER HELP
abstract: From the picket line and prison, from the comfortable middle class to the peasant feminist movement, women of the Philippines called on President Corazon C. Aquino today to put their cares on her agenda for reform.   Five thousand women gathered outside the presidential palace bearing garlands of flowers. Their concerns extended from the thousands of prostitutes who serve the American military bases to the banana plantation workers who earn even less than the substandard wages of their male colleagues.   ''We salute and honor you, Mrs. President, for giving us back our collective voices as women,'' Mrs. Aquino was told as she appeared outside the palace to greet the throng celebrating International Women's Day.

headline: SWISS BANKS CAUTIONED
abstract: The Swiss federal banking commission, in an unusual move, issued a statement today cautioning the nation's banks that they faced possible legal complications growing out of the handling of any transfers of money in accounts held by Mr. Marcos or his representatives.   A spokesman for the Swiss banking commission said the statement, which he called a ''reminder,'' noted that the banks might be required to release information on any such accounts or prevent the withdrawal of money ''under certain conditions and procedures of mutual assistance in criminal matters.''   The warning was issued by the commission after allegations published here and in the United States that Mr. Marcos and his family had large amounts of money in Swiss banks.

headline: PATENTS; Rotating Gun System For Armored Vehicle
abstract: A weapon system for an armored vehicle was patented this week for the General Motors Corporation.

headline: WEAK BOTTLER TIES HURT 7-UP IN FIGHT FOR SHARES
abstract: For decades, when it came to marketing, Philip Morris Inc., was considered one of the best.   The company's success in building its cigarette brands, particularly Marlboro, is legendary, and in the mid-1970's it also seemed to have found the marketing keys to the beer industry when it turned the Miller Brewing Company around.   So, when Philip Morris bought the faltering Seven-Up Company in 1978, the consumer giant's marketing prowess was expected to dazzle again, bringing new life to the St. Louis-based soft drink company that was founded in 1929 as the maker of a headache remedy.   But with 7-Up the Philip Morris marketing touch has apparently failed, and the subsidiary is now rumored to be for sale. The lemon-lime segment of the soft-drink business, a segment that 7-Up has always dominated, never appealed to American tastes the way colas do, leaving Philip Morris with what is essentially a niche product. And competition from Coca-Cola's Sprite and most recently from Pepsi-Cola's Slice, a lemon-lime soft drink with fruit juice, has eaten into 7-Up's leadership within that segment.

headline: Advertising; Donald Miller Going To a Media Buyer
abstract: Anyone who has observed Donald B. Miller, usually the tallest man at any American Association of Advertising Agencies annual meeting, in action would certainly make the educated guess that he could not wait for retirement so that he could get out to the links full time.   If you thought so, you would be wrong. The 60-year-old executive, once chief executive of Rumrill-Hoyt, which was acquired by Compton Advertising, retires Jan. 31 from Saatchi & Saatchi Compton and will immediately swing over to Media General Broadcasting Services, a media-buying company, as a senior vice president. Fore!

headline: BOTH SIDES CLAIM THEY ARE LEADING IN PHILIPPINE VOTE
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino claimed victory today in the Presidential election while President Ferdinand E. Marcos said only, ''I probably have won.''   The official Government vote count, after coming to a near halt on the afternoon and night of Election Day Friday, began moving slowly ahead and put Mrs. Aquino in a slight lead in sketchy early returns.   A respected poll-watching group that is relied on here to offer an independent assessment put Mrs. Aquino in the lead by a larger margin with more than a quarter of the vote recorded. Aquino Statement    In a statement issued by her office, Mrs. Aquino said: ''The trend is clear and irreversible. The people and I have won and we know it. Nothing can take our victory from us.''

headline: Economic Scene; Budget's Link To the Dollar
abstract: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S new budget has initiated intense public and Congressional debate over his proposals for reordering national priorities and shifting resources from the public to the private sector. Far less noticed, but of equal and possibly even greater importance, is the link between the budget and the Administration's strategy for dealing with national and international economic and monetary problems.   Those problems include the more than $900 billion in debts owed by developing countries, two-thirds of it to commercial banks; the danger that a slump in world trade would pose to all countries, industrial and developing alike; the record United States trade deficit, which hit $150 billion last year, and the growing American dependency on capital inflow; the threat of a renewed drive in Congress for protectionism, and the disordered and erratic relations between the dollar and other currencies.   If unsolved, those problems pose the greatest threat to American and world growth.

headline: IRAN REPORTS ITS FORCES CAPTURED STRATEGIC ISLAND
abstract: Iran said today that it had captured a strategic island in the Shatt al-Arab waterway, and Iraq acknowledged that Iranian forces had established a ''shaky foothold'' across the wide river in an overnight offensive.   Iran's official press agency said Iran had captured the island of Umm al-Rasas, in Iraqi territory west of the Shatt al-Arab, which is strategic because of ''its important oil installations.''   It later quoted a military communique as saying Iran's forces were ''fully stationed in the island and are prepared to suppress any enemy counteroffensive.''

headline: Market Place; Seers Bullish On Earnings
abstract: IT may be the onset of spring, or simply optimism over prospects for the companies they follow, but security analysts are projecting robust earnings growth of 29 percent this year for the companies represented in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.   This is the latest sounding taken by the Institutional Brokers Estimate System, a service of Lynch, Jones & Ryan that monitors the ''sell,'' or brokerage, side of the securities business. The service keeps track of estimates made by some 2,500 analysts who cover 3,300 stocks for 130 firms.   ''We also monitor 28 economists and market strategists employed by the brokerage firms, and this group looks for an earnings increase of 20 percent in 1986,'' said Stanley Levine, a vice president of Lynch, Jones & Ryan. ''During the last five years, security analysts consistently have been more optimistic over earnings potential than the economists and strategists.''

headline: Hitch Developing In Outlet Buyout
abstract: A complication may be developing in the proposed leveraged buyout of the Outlet Company subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group Inc. because of proposed changes in the tax laws, according to Wall Street sources. The sources said that the Rockefeller Group and advisers to the investors who want to buy the radio and television subsidiary were working last night to resolve the problem.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET HOLD TALKS ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS
abstract: American and Soviet officials have completed two days of talks on ways to stop the spread of chemical weapons, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The talks, which were held on Wednesday and Thursday in Bern, Switzerland, were positive in tone, the officials said.   The meeting represented the first attempt to follow through on a pledge made at the November summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to initiate discussion of ways to prevent the spread of chemical weapons.

headline: HILLMAN SALE STUDY
abstract: The Hillman Company, a privately held investment concern based in Pittsburgh, is considering whether to sell part or all of its interests in the Copeland Corporation and the Pameco Corporation, according to Morgan Stanley & Company, which has been hired to evaluate the situation.

headline: The Fine Print In Health Plans
abstract: THE increasing complexity of corporate health plans has put an added burden on employees who benefit from them. Not only are there likely to be major or minor variations among plans from company to company, but there could also be alternatives within each plan that affect treatment and reimbursement.   It is important therefore to read the plan in effect at your company carefully as the first step in taking advantage of the available benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 requires that all workers receive a copy of a summary plan description and of any changes made in the plan over the ensuing years.

headline: MARCOS'S WARTIME ROLE DISCREDITED IN U.S. FILES
abstract: The Army concluded after World War II that claims by Ferdinand E. Marcos that he had led a guerrilla resistance unit during the Japanese occupation of his country were ''fraudulent'' and ''absurd.''   Throughout his political career, Mr. Marcos, now President of the Philippines, has portrayed himself as a heroic guerrilla leader, and the image has been central to his political appeal.   In almost every speech throughout his current re-election campaign, including at least one this week, Mr. Marcos has referred to his war record and guerrilla experiences in part to show that he is better able than his opponent, Corazon C. Aquino, to handle the present Communist insurgency. Questions Go Unanswered    But documents that had rested out of public view in United States Government archives for 35 years show that repeated Army investigations found no foundation for Mr. Marcos's claims that he led a guerrilla force called Ang Mga Maharlika in military operations against Japanese forces from 1942 to 1944.   Mr. Marcos declined today to respond to six written questions about the United States Government records, which came to light only recently. The questions were submitted to Mr. Marcos's office this morning in Manila.

headline: COLAROSSI JOINS CATO JOHNSON
abstract: Benjamin Colarossi, who has been creative director and chief executive officer of Ross Roy/Colarossi Griswold, is leaving to become president of Cato Johnson, a New York-based international sales promotion and design subsidiary of Young & Rubicam. He will replace A.C. (Ace) Dalton, 58 years old, about whom, apparently, Y.&R. has a big announcement pending regarding an ''intriguing assignment.''

headline: IN APARTHEID'S WEB: THE BATTLE FOR THE TOWNSHIPS
abstract: Since the grenade exploded against the window of the room where the child was sleeping, Ethel Kose said, she has not spent a night at home, preferring, like her husband, Peter, to seek refuge elsewhere.   And, Thomas Buthelezi said, since the anonymous men grabbed him after a party and lacerated his back with whips, he, too, has feared for his life and wishes now to go and live elsewhere.   From afar, such stories of capricious violence might seem inappropriate in this segregated township, designed by the white authorities to be a model residential area for blacks, some of whom, like Mr. Buthelezi, used to live in tawdry shacks in the yards of others.   Here, on open land, 50 miles northeast of Pretoria, there are tidy homes with water in the faucets and power to run a hi-fi, and small, fenced yards, some ablaze with marigolds.   Yet, since this township was founded and people from South Africa's industrial heartland began to settle here in late 1983, the supposed idyll has been broken in a manner suggesting that despite promises of racial change, this country's white rulers still wish to exercise the kind of social engineering that has marked decades of apartheid.

headline: Blast Kills 7 Turkish Children
abstract: Children trying to chop up an unexploded mortar shell with an ax detonated it today, killing seven boys, the Hurriyet news agency reported.

headline: Mexican Loan Talks
abstract: A new date for talks in New York between Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, and representatives of the country's bank advisory committee will probably be set next week, a Finance Ministry spokesman said. Mr. Silva Herzog postponed the talks on new money for 1986, originally set for Thursday, because of the serious implications for Mexico of the latest drop in oil prices, he said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bell Atlantic Mobile Systems, the cellular subsidiary of Bell Atlantic Corp., said it had filed for approval from the F.C.C. to provide cellular mobile telephone service in Trenton and Atlantic City.    * Bobbie Brooks Inc., Cleveland, said it would discontinue making Junior and Missy sportswear and swim-wear apparel under the Present Co., New Expressions and Bobbie Brooks labels after it has completed shipping all summer and fall 1986 orders.

headline: Advertising; New TV Campaign For Harris
abstract: HOW would you feel if you spent $5.5 million to buy recognition only to find you are not being recognized?   That's what happened to the Harris Corporation of Melbourne, Fla., and its management was saddened, saddened enough to bring in a new vice president from International Business Machines. And he - Raymond J. Oglethorpe - might very well have switched to a new agency except he and his superiors decided to stay with Foote, Cone & Belding of Chicago, feeling they had invested too much in educating the agency on the complexities of their information-technology-communications-oriented company.   In any event it didn't take Mr. Oglethorpe long to diagnose Harris's advertising problems. He first asked for and got the help of some obliging, successful corporate advertisers such as Beatrice, Northwest Mutual Life and Rockwell International, Its plugged-in logo, all-print campaign, with the theme ''For your information our name is Harris,'' had too much copy that was too technical, Mr. Oglethorpe concluded. It was not all that distinctive and concentrated too much on Harris instead of customer benefits.
